Volume 40 of The Collected Letters of Thomas and Jane Welsh Carlyle includes 242 letters and covers the period from January to August 1864. There are 169 letters by Thomas Carlyle, 62 by Jane Welsh Carlyle, and 11 by Maggie Welsh on behalf of JWC. JWC wrote far fewer letters than usual to friends, and during the worst of her time in St. Leonards she did not even write to TC, although her cousin Maggie Welsh was writing letters for her. It was not until late March that there were any letters from JWC in her own hand, with only 18 before she went to Scotland in mid-July.

This volume is characterized by JWC’s continuing and extreme illness. The tone is set in the very first letter—TC wrote to Lady Ashburton: “My poor wife made me promise to write you a word,— ‘one word of acknowledgt,’ whispered she passionately, ‘for all these continual kindnesses’. … We (that is, she) are still in very great distress. … She has no sleep, can get none” (TC to Lady ALLA, 2 Jan. 1864). JWC had suffered during the second half of the previous year from a painful right arm, diagnosed by Dr. Quain as “neuralgia” (39:186JWC to MR, [16 Sept. 1863]); she then fell in the street, 22 September 1863, hurting her left side and leg. She initially appeared to recover, but then became ill with influenza, late November 1863; TC wrote to Lady Ashburton at the end of the year: “the Doctors call it mere ‘influenza whh has kindled into a general paroxysm all the neuralgias, hurts &c’;—they are agreed. … I never saw a being in such continuous agony!” (39:258TC to LLA, 21 Dec. 1863). Throughout December 1863 and into January 1864, JWC remained very ill and sleepless, and her cousin Maggie Welsh was sent for to act as sick-nurse, coming direct from Liverpool where she had been nursing a sick nephew.

There seems no clear consensus as to what was actually wrong with JWC. She herself called it various things, telling first her Welsh aunts: “The malady is in my womb. … It is the consequence of that unlucky fall—no disease there the Drs say, but some nervous derangement” (JWC to A, G, & EW, [5 March]), then Mary Russell: “the misery has been … an everlasting torture in my womb—it is not a cancer or any such thing—the Drs say, only a nervous affection—but all the same the suffering attending it is beyond all words to tell” (JWC to MR, [ca. 31 May]). Geraldine Jewsbury wrote to Walter Mantell, 14 February: “poor Mrs Carlyle is very ill. & nobody knows what is the matter with her—the doctors declare that it is all on the nerves—but I & her Cousin who is nursing her fear that she injured herself in her fall & that there is a
cause for all the pain & terrible restlessness. she suffers dreadfully & her restlessness is worse than the pain” (Mantell); and TC wrote to his sister Jean Aitken, early March: “I cannot for my life understand anything abt her disorder: since people keep asking, one is obliged to say something, ‘Better,’ ‘Worse,’ ‘much the same’; but really I do not know whether her sad calamity (and mine) is on the way of mending or on the other way” (TC to JCA, [6 March]). In April, in a reply to TC quoting Dr. Barnes’s and Dr. Blakiston’s use of the word “morbid,” JWC wrote: “It is no ‘morbid despondency’—it is positive physical torment day and night—a burning throbbing maddening sensation in the most nervous part of me ever and ever” (JWC to TC, [19 April]). She often wrote of “irritation” so bad that she had to take to bed in the afternoon (JWC to TC, [2 Aug.], and JWC to TC, [8 Aug.]); ten days later: “The Irritation has been less distressing, and that is the most important item of improvement; for I could bear all the rest patiently if I were but delivered from that!” (JWC to MCA, [18 Aug.]). It is sometimes unclear whether she was referring to a purely physical irritation, or irritation of the mind and spirits, a feeling of restlessness and unease, what we might now call anxiety attacks. But it was not only “irritation” as, after one of these attacks, she reported: “Something I said about my bowels … put [Dr. Russell] on ascertaining with his own eyes and the result was a discovery that I was excessively bilious” (JWC to TC, [8 Aug.]). At the same time she referred to having to get up during the night, for unspecified reasons: “Eight times I was awake and out of bed” (JWC to TC, [10 Aug.]); “I was out of bed fourteen times during the night” (JWC to TC, [31 Aug.]).

Her biggest fear was of going mad, either from pain or from sleeplessness; throughout this illness, for almost a year, she apparently had barely a single night’s proper sleep: “If sleep would come; I think I should recover!—the first time I have had this hope seriously—but—if it wont come—I must break down sooner or later … and I fear horribly for—not my life—but my reason” (JWC to TC, [5 Aug.]). The fear of madness, as well as of death, becomes a common refrain in her letters. TC later wrote:
div1.q: A hideous pain of which she used to say that ‘common honest pain, were it cutting of one’s flesh or sawing of one’s bones would be a luxury in comparison,’—seemed to have begirdled her, at all moments and on every side. Her intellect was clear as starlight, and continued so; the clearest intellect among us all; but she dreaded that this too must give way. ‘Dear,’ said she to me, on two occasions, with such a look and tone as I shall never forget, ‘promise me that you will not put me into a mad-house, however this go. Do you promise me, now?’ I solemnly did. ‘Not if I do quite lose my wits?’ ‘Never, my Darling; oh compose thy poor terrified heart!’ (Carlyle, Reminiscences 169).
div1.p: A feminist analysis might be that JWC’s many illnesses arose from a constant repression of her real self, in order to conform to Victorian social mores, and her own construct of herself as the “wife of a man of Genius“: “Sooner than speak out her thoughts, JWC bodied them forth in tumultuous illness” (Norma Clarke, Ambitious Heights [1990] 130). She was very angry and bitter when John A. Carlyle told her in July 1864 that if she had ever had any work, she would not be so ill, writing to TC: “He [John] has been very hard and cruel—and mean inconceivably! … Fancy his telling me in my agony yesterday that ‘if I had ever DONE anything in my life, this would not have been! that no poor woman with work to mind had ever had such an ailment as this of mine since the world began!!!’” (JWC to TC, 23 July). But this was not the first time that such a thing had been suggested to her, and she herself had frequently considered it. As early as 1833, John A. Carlyle had said something similar, as JWC reported to her friend Eliza Miles: “He told me yesterday, ‘Could I give you some agreeable occupation to fill your whole mind, it would do more for you than all the medicines in existence’” (6:410–11). TC wrote to JWC in 1842: “My prayer is and has always been that you would rouse up the fine faculties that are yours into some course of real true work, which you felt to be worthy of them and you! Your life would not then be happy; but it would cease to be miserable, it would become noble and clear, with a kind of sacredness shining thro’ it” (14:134TC to JWC, 9 April 1842). Her friend Geraldine Jewsbury encouraged her to write a novel. And JWC herself often lamented her own lack of a role. In a letter to Charles Gavan Duffy in 1845, she wrote: “I have sometimes thought that in a Civil War I should possibly find my ‘mission’—moi! But in these merely talking times, a poor woman knows not how to turn herself; especially if, like myself, she ‘have a Devil’—always calling to her ‘March! March,’ and bursting into infernal laughter when requested to be so good as specify; whither!” (19:197JWC to CGD, 14 [15] Sept. [1845]). Less than a year later, in a letter to Jeannie Welsh, she commented on her sense of the part she constructed for herself to play, while regretting her lack of “hard work,” and with a clear understanding of the damage such a lack could do:
div1.q: By and by Mrs Macready who is in the family-way began to talk of the dreadful “depression of spirits” she occasionally laboured under—“Ah said I, everyone I suppose has their own fits of depression to bear up against if the truth were told.” … “Oh no surely!—some people are never out of spirits—yourself for example I really believe you do not know what it is to be ever sad for a minute!!! one never sees you that you do not keep one in fits of laughter!” I made no answer—but congratulated myself on having played my part so well—I wish I could find some hard work I could do—and saw any sense in doing—If I do not soon it will be the worse for me. (20:194JWC to JW, [19 May 1846])
div1.p: In a letter to John Stodart in 1849 she wrote a heartfelt affirmation of the value of work:
div1.q: You tell me you have lost your fortune, and are obliged to work for your bread. Well! to speak truly, I feel no sorrow over this. If your heart ache; work, above all, obligatory work is the only remedy worth trying. Oh don’t I know what a privilege is that of sitting, with folded hands, thinking over a past that is past, because in the present and future all is too dark—ailment and sorrow overclouding the present and the future without hope or object! Oh depend on it, dear John, the loss of fortune or whatever it be that curtails one of that privilege is a thing to thank God for, is perhaps the one interposition that has saved one out of madness! (24:258–59JWC to JRS, [30 Sept. 1849]).
div1.p: Presumably JWC, like many a woman before and since, found housework both time consuming and physically tiring, without being in any way mentally stimulating or intellectually satisfying. Both John A. Carlyle and TC speak of her needing an occupation for her “whole mind” and “fine faculties,” and this is what she too is aware of lacking. JWC several times referred to herself as being too educated for her eventual position in life, writing in 1833 to Eliza Stodart: “for to say the truth my whole life has been a sort of puddling [muddle] as to health, Too much of schooling hadst thou poor Ophelia!” (7:32JWC to EA, [9 Nov. 1833]). Caroline Fox later remembered: “She talked of her own life and the mistake of over-educating people. She believes that her health has been injured for life by beginning Latin with a little tutor at five or six years old, then going to the Rector’s school to continue it, then having a tutor at home, and being very ambitious she learnt eagerly” (Caroline Fox, Memories of Old Friends [1882] 219–20).

JWC knew several women who used their education, mostly as writers, but they tended either to be single, like Geraldine Jewsbury or Harriet Martineau, or widowed, like Margaret Oliphant. Elizabeth Gaskell, with a husband and family, was unusual, and JWC did not entirely approve of her. George Eliot, with her irregular domestic life, might have written books that JWC loved, but JWC would not socialize with her. Much of the time JWC exhibited conventional Victorian views about appropriate roles for women, married and unmarried, and she did not exempt herself from these assumptions. While she excelled at satire at the expense of everyone, male and female, herself and TC, she was neither particularly feminist nor radical in her approach to social roles for women.

TC may have said that he wished JWC could find some work to do, but he expected her main role to be that of wife and helpmeet, running his house
and attending to his many needs. He too was often ill, usually with some form of digestive upset. He needed absolute peace and quiet in which to work—which involved JWC in protecting him from household difficulties, from environmental noises, and from too many visitors; and his absorption in his work and his absolute need of several hours exercise a day, either riding or walking, meant that she spent much time on her own. Running a house was an arduous task. Early in their marriage they were often very short of money, and JWC was required to do much of the actual housework as well as all the organizing. JWC undoubtedly believed that it was truly her duty and role in life to look after TC in every way possible to enable the writing of his great works for the benefit of mankind. She believed this in the same way that she believed that making a loaf of bread was as worthwhile as making Cellini’s Perseus, as she told Mary Smith in 1857: “it is not the greatness or littleness of ‘the duty nearest hand,’ but the spirit in which one does it, that makes one’s doing noble or mean!” (32:70–71JWC to MS, 11 Jan. 1857). The tragedy is that such a role could not be fulfilling to a mind as agile and inventive as hers.

Living as we do in the twenty-first century, in a world where every aspect of a person’s health, from birth to death, through disease, accident, mental illness, childbirth, and old age, is highly medicalized and professionalized, it is interesting to step back into the lives of people for whom most of these episodes were treated at home, with the assistance of relations and friends, and with little or no help from “professionals.” Illness in the nineteenth century was very common, very real and very dangerous; recovery often took a long time. Medical science, both in diagnosis and treatment, was still fairly haphazard, and it is arguable that doctors killed more than they cured. Remedies centered largely on varieties of sedatives and pain killers, or on digestive remedies; other than that the only cures were rest and time. Certainly none of the treatments the doctors offered JWC in 1864 seemed very effective; this was certainly TC’s view: “‘Neuralgia’. … ‘Disease of the Nerves’ (poisoning of the very channels of sensation): such was the name the Doctors gave it; and for the rest, could do nothing further with it; well had they only attempted nothing! I used to compute that they, poor souls, had at least reinforced the disease to twice its natural amount; such the pernicious effect of all their ‘remedies’ and appliances, opiates, etc. etc.; which every new one of them (and there came many) applied anew,—and always with the like inverse result” (Carlyle, Reminiscences 168). JWC was attended in her illness by four regular doctors (five if we include TC’s brother Dr. John A. Carlyle, who although he did not actually treat her, certainly made many suggestions as to her treatment). Between them they prescribed either sedatives and pain killers, in the forms of opium, laudanum, morphia, camphor, hops, henbane, cannabis, alcohol, and quinine, or digestive remedies, such as the terrifying
“blue pill” or the more modest rhubarb and magnesia. None of these appear to have had any effect for more than a few days, and often just led to a worsening of her condition.

What becomes strikingly clear in the story of these eight months is that JWC was cured by nursing rather than by doctoring, and nursing by family, friends, and servants, not by professionals. She was cared for first by her cousin Maggie Welsh, who lived in Fife, but who came to stay with JWC, initially in London and then in St. Leonards, and only left because she had to return to Liverpool to nurse the dying child of her brother Alex Welsh. Geraldine Jewsbury regularly offered her help, but JWC, still feeling very estranged from Geraldine, instead asked Mary Craik, the daughter of an old friend, to come from Ireland. These women, all single, obviously saw nothing strange in offering or being asked to leave home to come to nurse JWC. When she felt that staying in London was doing her no good, she accepted an offer from Dr. and Mrs. Blakiston in St. Leonards to stay with them. Mrs. Blakiston was JWC’s former servant Bessie Barnet, recently married to a doctor, with whom JWC had a pleasant visit in June 1863. They accommodated JWC, her maid Mary, and her cousin Maggie Welsh, presumably at some inconvenience and cost to themselves, but refusing all payment. They provided not only a kind home, but both doctoring and nursing. However, after a month or so JWC felt that she had outstayed her welcome with the Blakistons, and not wanting to return to London, she found a house to rent in St. Leonards, where TC eventually joined her. Maggie Welsh returned to Liverpool, and Mary Craik came to take her place.

In July, still very ill, JWC finally went to Dumfriesshire, first to her sister-in-law Mary Austin, and then to the home of Mary Russell, her mother’s old friend, and also her own friend for many years, who she knew would care for her and nurse her, and whose husband was also a doctor. She wrote to TC: “nowhere on Earth would I be better off externally than I am here. Mrs Russell is a nurse like my own mother—I have had no such nursing. … Then the Dr seems to me to have more sense. … He says, like you, that my illness is only to be acted on thro’ the stomach but does not make light of my nervousness—does not say slightingly that ‘nervous pain does not kill’” (JWC to TC, [25 July]). The peace and quiet, the familiarity of her surroundings, the feeling of being loved and cared for, and of her illness being taken seriously, all helped effect, if not an actual cure, at least a great improvement in her condition. Her appetite returned, she gained weight, and she even reported to TC a re-found capacity to laugh out loud, inspired by one of Dr. Russell’s dry remarks to his wife (JWC to TC, [19 Aug.]). She began to be able to think about returning home, enlisting the help of Eliza Forster in getting her bedroom redecorated, and sending TC detailed instructions about house cleaning. After her return to Cheyne Row at the end of September, JWC wrote to
Mary Russell to thank them for their care of her, ending her letter: “I shall always feel as if I owed my life chiefly to your Husband and you, who procured me such rest as I could have had nowhere else in the world” (JWC to MR, 3 Oct. 1864; MS: NLS 608.684; vol. 41).

As well as friends and relations, servants also played a large part in helping to nurse their employers. The greatest part of the care required by sick people was assistance with essential daily activities—eating, dressing, personal hygiene, help with moving about—and much of this could be done by servants. During a spell of illness the previous year JWC wrote to her former maid, Charlotte Southam, thanking her for a gift of violets: “their sweet smell reminded me somehow of your kind nursing in my long Influenza. No one has nursed me as kindly and as cleverly since!” (39:103JWC to CSO, 29 March 1863). At Thornhill JWC was particularly appreciative of the thoughtfulness of Mary Russell’s young servant Mary (JWC to TC, [3 Aug.]). But usually with a sick person in the house, especially if that person was used to doing some of the domestic chores herself, the servant would already have more than enough to do dealing with the daily household tasks, so extra help had to be brought in. The Carlyles had tried hiring a professional nurse, a Catholic “sister of mercy,” but this ended disastrously when she tried to pray over JWC (39:261TC to JAC, 29 Dec. 1863, and Carlyle, Reminiscences 170–71). Friends and family were more reliable and easier to have around.

JWC herself had often gone to a lot of trouble to care for others, and she seemed always to have an innate understanding of people’s troubled minds. She wrote in 1843 of her friend Joseph Henry Garnier: “Poor Garnier walked in at five and staid till after nine. … Poor fellow they may all abuse him as they like; but I think and have thought and will think well of him—he has a good heart and a good head, only a nervous system all bedevilled—and his external life fallen into a horribly burbled [confused] state about him—I gave him tea—and took him a walk—and lent him some music—and soothed the troubled soul of him” (17:73JWC to TC, [21 Aug. 1843]). When another friend, Richard Plattnauer, had a mental breakdown in 1844 and disappeared, JWC went searching for him, and found that he had been committed to Wandsworth Lunatic Asylum; she visited him there, and then brought him home to stay at Cheyne Row. She wrote about him to her cousin Jeannie Welsh: “I do not consider him by any means sane. … I know that I can keep him from any new crisis so long as he is beside me. … [N]o madman will ever hurt a hair of my head—I have too much affinity with them” (18:195–96JWC to JW, [ca. 29 Aug. 1844]), a sentiment she often repeated. She comforted the bereaved, apologizing in 1858 to Mary Russell for not having written to her: “The fact is, I have been belated in … everything this week—by having had to give from two to three hours EVERY DAY (!) to a man [John George Cooke] who has unexpectedly lost his Mother … he has fled away from everybody to me, who wasn’t aware before that I was his particular
friend the least in the world!—But I have always had the same sort of attraction for miserable people, and for mad people that amber has for straws!” (34:257–58JWC to MR, 30 Dec. 1858).

Another major event in the Carlyles’ lives in this volume was the death of Lord Ashburton, 23 March 1864. He had been a significant part of their lives for 25 years, and both Carlyles were deeply attached to him. So much attention has been paid to both TC and JWC’s relationship with the first Lady Ashburton, it is sometimes forgotten how important was their relationship with Lord Ashburton. His obituary in the Glasgow Citizen, 26 March, ended: “There will be many sorrowing friends now to whom the Grange was a home, but to none of them will the loss be so irreparable as to our great country man, the author of ‘Sartor Resartus.’ … No two men knew and loved each other better than they” (TC to JWC, 26 March). Lord Ashburton had been ill for some time and his death was expected the previous year, with the Carlyles’ anxiety about him mentioned frequently in their letters. In 1864, however, with JWC’s ongoing illness their primary concern, they were less voluble about their worries for Lord Ashburton. When they heard in February of the recurrence of his illness, JWC asked Maggie Welsh to write to Lady Ashburton, giving “her very dear love & to tell you what a grief it has been to her & Mr Carlyle to hear that Lord Ashburton has been so very ill of late” (MW to Lady ALLA, [6 Feb.]). And some days later Maggie Welsh wrote to Lady Ashburton again, reporting JWC’s feeling that she “‘would like to live a little longer to thank you for all your great kindness & thought for her.’ … [S]he said it was so thoughtful in the midst of all your own sad trouble” (MW to Lady ALLA, [18 Feb.?]). TC and JWC had both become very attached to Lord Ashburton’s second wife, Louisa, and felt deeply sympathetic to her loss. TC immediately wrote his condolences to Lady Ashburton: “Alas, dear Lady, here is the end then; come suddenly on us; and all is over … the shock to me, this morning, is great. To me also an Epoch is closed. … He was always always beautifully noble, concerned for others beyond himself” (TC to Lady ALLA, 24 March). It is characteristic of JWC that when she heard of his death, she roused herself to write a letter of sympathy to Lady Ashburton, the first letter of 1864 in her own hand: “Oh God Comfort you! if ever there was a man ready to pass from this sorrowful earth to be an angel in Heaven it was he! My spirit flies to your dear side, while my poor body is chained here with a cruel malady that I believe will prove fatal” (JWC to Lady ALLA, [25 March]). Lord Ashburton’s last act of friendship was to leave TC £2000, privately through Lady Ashburton rather than specified in his will, to save paying tax. TC wrote to thank Lady Ashburton: “Strange, yet simple, beautiful; so like the Doer of it:—the last finish to 20 years of friendly acts and offices on his part,—all done in the same gentle, quiet and fine way” (TC to Lady ALLA, 11 April). There were also
several other deaths in these months, mentioned in the Carlyles’ letters, if not of people close to them, then close to their friends—John Ruskin’s father, Henry Larkin’s baby daughter, JWC’s cousin’s child Jackie Welsh, Moncure Conway’s son, and Charlotte Southam’s adopted father.

Throughout this volume TC was still working on Frederick The Great, still struggling, still suffering, determined to finish it at last. Volume 4 was published at the end of February, and by the end of March volume 5 had gone to the printer. With our modern sensibilities, it is easy to see TC as being so busy with his book that he had no time for his wife’s illness. He did not stop work to help care for her, and although he did accompany her on her journey to St. Leonards, and then visited a couple of times, he chiefly remained in London working. And when he did decide to move down to stay with her, it was only on condition that he could continue working, writing to his brother John: “there was speculatn thereupon of my coming down too, and I suppose that also to be likely,—if I can possibly contrive to take my Work with me: tho’ I absolutely must not otherwise.” He wrote this in the same letter in which he described JWC as: “always on the edge of crying: full of hysterical pains and emotions, refuses to have any comfortable hope” (TC to JAC, 5 April). While in St. Leonards he spent time with her once a day on a short drive, the rest of the time he worked. It was his brother John, come to offer what support he could to both Carlyles, who took JWC out driving, sometimes several times a day, and it was John who finally accompanied her to Scotland and delivered her into the care of their sister Mary Austin at The Gill, where she stayed for a week before moving to the Russells at Holmhill. TC himself admitted he was no use in a sick room, nor was he expected to be. He inhabited his own sphere, and left the world of domesticity and sickness to the women. Even at her worst JWC knew she could not take him from his work: “Oh my Husband! I am suffering torments! … Oh I would like you beside me,—I am terribly alone—But I dont want to interrupt your work” (JWC to TC, [25 April]). When TC read JWC’s letters after her death, it was statements of care for his needs such as this that induced TC’s feelings of guilt about his treatment of her; but JWC knew that until Frederick was finished there could be no rest for TC, and little time for normal human relationships.

Nonetheless TC’s letters to JWC in this period were unfailingly kind and sympathetic, positive and encouraging; his apparent optimism and absolute belief in JWC’s inner strength contrasts markedly with his pessimism about himself and his work, particularly in his letters to other people. It is arguable that he saw this ongoing positive support as the most helpful thing he could do for her. These months from January to August 1864 were miserable for both Carlyles, and their letters reflect this; they are predominantly sad, painful, anxious, and frightened. However their deep affection for each other did
not waver, and was constantly expressed; it is this affection, together with the love and practical help and support of so many of their friends and relations, which makes what might at first seem rather a gloomy volume, both heartwarming and even uplifting.

div1.p: January–August 1864
January–August 1864

January. JWC has been ill since autumn 1863, and her health continues to give serious cause for concern. TC tells Lady Ashburton that JWC is taking “morphine, Camphor, Henbane … no sleep follows them, only increase of misery” (2). He writes to Elizabeth Downes offering her ailing husband £50 from a fund “set apart for the aid of some ‘meritorious Literary man in distress’” (9), and subsequently pays her this sum following its acceptance (13). Writing to Lady Stanley, TC states “I never saw her [JWC] (nor indeed anybody) in such suffering, and continual misery night and day” (13). By the end of the month, however, TC writes to the duchess of Argyll that “[o]f late weeks … there seems to be … some real progress towards improvet. … We are ordered to Hastings & the Sea-side” (31).

February. JWC’s cousin Maggie Welsh, who is helping to nurse her, writes on her behalf to Lady Ashburton “to tell you what a grief it has been to her & Mr Carlyle to hear that Lord Ashburton has been so very ill of late” ([6?]), and later thanks her for the “beautiful jelly … along with several other kind gifts” ([17?]). TC writes to his sister Jean Aitken of JWC’s continuing health problems, and of his growing despair at her lack of real improvement: “Darker disease, or with less help from medicine, I was never concerned with” (27).

March. Drs. Quain and Barnes, as well as other doctors occasionally, attend JWC, even making “a trial of ‘Animal Magnetism’” (1). TC struggles on with Frederick, writing to Neuburg for help with sources ([6]). JWC decides to take up the Blakistons’ invitation to stay with them at St. Leonards-on-Sea. TC writes to Emerson, introducing Edward Stanley and sending him volume 4 of Frederick (8). JWC travels to St. Leonards in a “sick carriage” resembling a hearse, her cousin Maggie in attendance; TC goes with her to see her settled, then returns to Chelsea (8). He writes every day to JWC reporting his progress, or lack of it, on Frederick; he thanks Lady Stanley for an invitation and reports that “[t]he Hastings news are favourable” (14). But JWC’s progress continues to fluctuate. TC tells JWC of a visit to Ruskin (15), whose father has just died, and a ride with Maud and Kate Stanley (17), that he has finished volume 5 “in a way,” and dined at Forster’s with Robert Browning and Alexander Dyce (20). Visitors continue to disturb TC at his work, asking for reports of JWC. News arrives (24) of Lord Ashburton’s death (23);
TC immediately writes to Lady Ashburton (24), as does JWC ([25]); she also writes despairingly about her health to William Dods in Haddington and to her aunts in Edinburgh, “my Dr has hopes of my recovery. but I myself am not hopeful, my sufferings are terrible” ([25]). TC attends Lord Ashburton’s funeral (31).

April. TC reports an emotional day at the funeral, also the “loss of my dear old black velvet cap” (1). JWC sends birthday wishes and a gift of a gold seal to Forster (2). TC reports a “hostile” review of volume 4 in the Saturday Review (4). He visits JWC and on his return reports to his sister Jean that JWC had put on a dress “the first time since November last! She walks tolerably with a stick”; she has suggested that TC might join her in St. Leonards, which TC is considering, as he is “in so low a way with the botheratns I have had” (4). He writes complaining to his brother John A. Carlyle about Robson’s delays, and that Larkin and Neuberg have both “fallen useless,” and encourages him to come and stay for a couple of weeks to cheer him up (5). TC’s work continues badly (8); JWC writes telling him that Lord Ashburton has left him £2000 in his will ([8]). TC is most indignant that Chapman is trying to pay him less than agreed ([9]), but later agrees to new terms (13); he declines to attend the celebrations for the tercentenary of Shakespeare’s birth (12). Visitors continue to call at Cheyne Row (15) and TC complains that he is “dull, beclouded, downpressed and altogether owlish” (16). JWC speaks of going home to die, but instead decides to take a small house in St. Leonards, fearing that she has outstayed her welcome at the Blakistons ([19]). TC makes plans to move to St. Leonards (22). Maggie Welsh reports that JWC “was very poorly all day yesterday” and that “morphia seems to have lost its effect” ([24]), and JWC herself writes to TC “I am suffering torments! … I would like you beside me” ([25]). “Middle of May” TC replies ([26]). JWC moves to her new house, 117 Marina (28).

May. JWC writes to TC about arrangements for him moving to St. Leonards and invites John A. Carlyle to visit her ([1]). TC tells JWC of his visitors, Rose Greenhow, Geraldine Jewsbury, and Robert Tait (2). John returns from his visit to report JWC’s “great distress and feeling of dispiritment” (3). TC writes to Jewsbury declining her offer to help nurse JWC (8), and to Neuberg to say he will be away, “with tools & goods” until the end of July (9). Maggie Welsh returns to Liverpool to help nurse her sick nephew, and Mary Craik comes from Belfast to help JWC. TC moves to St. Leonards (14), and reports to Neuberg that JWC is “improving and improved” and invites him to visit (18). TC writes to Larkin requesting books and his woolen shoes (26), and then requests that Larkin pay his tax bill (29). JWC replies to an invitation from Mary Russell, “Oh my Mary shall I live to see your dear face again?” ([ca. 31]).

June. TC sends Elizabeth Downes, recently widowed, a check for £50 from Lady Louisa Ashburton (3). He continues to request books and dictionaries from Larkin ([ca. 3]) and information from Neuberg (4). He writes to Lady Ashburton sympathizing over the Ashburton family dispute regarding Lord Ashburton’s will, and hoping that he and JWC might be able to visit her at the end of July (5). TC congratulates Woolner on his engagement (11). JWC tells Eliza Forster that “sometimes I think myself slowly recovering; at other times I despair utterly” ([12]). TC tells Froude he hopes to be finished with Frederick in six months and is saddened by Ruskin’s involvement in “Table-rapping … The most blasphemous, detestable, contemptible subter-doggery the Sons of Adam ever sank to” (23). He writes to Lady Ashburton to find out if Addiscombe is empty, as JWC wants to leave St. Leonards but has a horror of returning to Chelsea (25); as it has been let, John A. Carlyle suggests she go to Dumfriesshire (28).

July. TC continues to request material from Neuberg and Larkin (3) and ([6]). JWC leaves St. Leonards, accompanied by John A. Carlyle (12), stays one night in the Forsters’ house in Kensington, then travels overnight (13–14) to her sister-in-law Mary Austin at The Gill, Dumfriesshire. JWC reports to TC that on the journey to Scotland John was “dreadfully ill-tempered—We quarrelled incessantly” (15). She tells TC ([19]) of the carriage accident which occurred while out driving with James Carlyle and Mary Austin (17). TC returns to Chelsea (19). JWC arranges ([21]) to go to the Russells at Holmhill (23), then reports that “nowhere on Earth would I be better off externally than I am here” ([25]). Mary Craik, who has been helping TC in Cheyne Row, leaves to return to Belfast (26). Sleeplessness continues to torment JWC ([27]), and Dr. Russell advises her to drink wine during the night; JWC continues taking quinine ([28]).

August. TC pays John A. Carlyle for expenses incurred at St. Leonards and on the journey north with JWC; he is working on Frederick in the garden and expects to be into “Book 21st (last ‘Book’ of all!)” by the end of August (1). He is very low in spirits (2). JWC is still sleepless; tincture of hops having failed, henbane is tried ([2]), then “Indian Hemp” is suggested ([3]); however her appetite is much improved ([4]), and she reports that she has gained “five pounds since Dr Blakiston weighed me in April” ([5]). TC visits Ruskin (4) and “had mainly an unpleast evg, bad tea, bad talk” (6 [5]), then visits Forster and feels better for it (7). TC’s nephew, William, visits from Ontario (11). JWC complains to TC about John’s meanness, having reckoned her traveling expenses “to the minutest farthing … Oh mercy, that man is mean, mean!” ([12]). JWC asks Eliza Forster to send her samples of wallpaper for re-decorating her bedroom in Cheyne Row, as she “cannot go back to things
as they were!” ([17]). She tells TC that she had “laughed!!!” at a remark of Dr. Russell’s ([19]). TC thanks Lady Ashburton for sending him Thornton’s sermon about Lord Ashburton and tells her that both he and JWC have been dreaming about Lord Ashburton (21). He tells JWC that “[p]lenty of people come asking for you, day after day” (22). JWC considers taking Charlotte Southam back as housemaid and asks TC’s opinion ([23]). She tells of her successful shopping trip to Dumfries ([26]) and sends detailed instructions about the cleaning and decorating at Cheyne Row to both TC and Eliza Forster ([29]) and ([30]). TC’s spirits are low, “want of potatoes, I am ashamed to say, is the source of everything” (31).

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady A [LLA], 2 Jan. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p: My poor Wife made me promise to write you a word,—“one word of acknowledgt,” whispered she passionately, “for all these continual kindnesses: I am surrounded, wrapt up and supported on all hands by gifts and actings of hers!”Lady Louisa and Lord Ashburton were frequently generous with gifts of fruit, flowers, and farm produce from their estates.

I promised to write a word; but shall evidently find none in all my vocabulary to express the tenth part of what she meant. She herself (if it be Heaven’s will), let us hope, will probably write you many words on or about that subject; but neither will she, I believe, get quite to the bottom of what I are her feelings areThus in MS. upon it. I will therefore say no more; by silence, I believe, you will best understand it.

We (that is, she) are still in very great distress;JWC suffered a painful left arm for several months, summer 1863 (see 39:186JWC to MR, [16 Sept. 1863]); after a bad fall, 22 Sept. (see 39:204–6TC to LLA, 26 Sept. 1863), she became increasingly unwell (see 39:258–59TC to LLA, 21 Dec. 1863). I shd say as great as ever,—were it not for one small symptom, of whh perhaps I make too much. She has no sleep, can get none:—“one sound sleep in 7 weeks”; that has been her allowance. They are trying opiates again: last night, was the third of morphine Camphor, Henbane,—refuges of lies;—no sleep follows them, only increase of misery; such misery as you may imagine. Her mind, singular to say, is clear as starlight, practically cognisant of everything: “Stand by the helm,” I say to her, “you steadily, in this hideous tornado!”—alas, that is abt all I can do for her. It appears to me, if there had been no Doctor extant, she wd have been not worse off but better.— She does eat a little; actually can: and that is the sole “improvet” I can notice from the first; the one good symptom yet visible to me.

Thank Lord A. for his kind little Note; and guard him (and yrself) from this violent frost.The Times reported, 6 Jan., that there was still a severe frost.— If it were not like a mockery from such an element as this, I wd wish you & him “Newyear’s wishes” enough! For myself tho I have one, or even two, but I do not put them in words. God be with us all!

div3.sourceNote: TC-JCA, 4 Jan. MS: NLS 517.69. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.p: Dear Jean,—I have no very good news to send you, or else I shd be prompter abt it. Poor Jane is not to be called worse (so far as I judge), but neither can she be called better: and we are in great confusion and misery as heretofore. No right sleep even for a moment; most nights none of any kind: all the abominatn of drug stuff, after being tried in vain for 3 nights, have been flung into the ashpit agn. Night before last she had a severe and tedious attack of bowels (a dismal, tossing night); I was, and still am, in some hope this might have been Nature’s own effort to prepare for a little rest: but hitherto little or none has come. She can still eat a little (tho’ yesterday was languidward); the DoctorPresumably Dr. Alfred Barnes, JWC’s regular doctor; Dr. Richard Quain also attended her. comes twice a day (since this bilious attack), but still talks hopefully

My time, in additn to all, is quite stolen from me: I shd simply have no consoln left if I were cut off from a little “work done”! Wretched mortals “inquiring,” witht interest of theirs, cut me off now & then from any poor after-riding half hour of sleep: don’t I thank them, & their kindness! But really they mean it well.

Adieu, my day is running from me like water from a broken dish.— Tell MaryTheir sister Mary Austin. of the Gill, good soul, that her six dozen of eggs came, and only one cracked.The eggs sent early in 1859 had arrived mostly broken; see 35:9–10JWC to MCA, 6 Feb. 1859, and 21–22JWC to MCA, 7 Feb. 1859.

div3.sourceNote: TC-RC [RCO], 4 Jan. Addr: Midhurst / Kent. PM: London, 5 Jan. 1864. MS: Dunford House Trust, West Sussex Record Office. Hitherto unpbd. Richard Cobden (1804–65; ODNB), free-trade advocate; known to TC since 1846 (see TC to EF, 19 Jan. 1846, and TC to TB, 28 April 1846); M.P. for Rochdale 1859–65; living at Dunford House, Sussex.
div3.head: TC TO RICHARD COBDEN

docBody.p:
You are perfectly correct as to that of Sterling’s Life and the critic of it in The Times:For the critical review of TC’s The Life of John Sterling by Samuel Phillips (1814–54), Times, 1 Nov. 1851, see 26:236TC to JAC, 20 Nov. 1851. Cobden was involved in an “acrimonious dispute” with the Times (Miles Taylor, “Cobden, Richard,” ODNB). I have a clear recollection of Sterling’s Brother (the now Coll Sir
A Sterling)Sir Anthony Coningham Sterling. coming to me one forenoon with a Times in his pocket, and reading from it a rebuke of me to the effect in question;—with offer, on his part, to deal summarily with the same, if I wd permit; whh I wd not.

The time I cannot give: but I have written to Mr Chapman the Publisher to send you, at once, from his old records the day of publishing the first edition of Sterling’s Life;Edward Chapman, TC’s publisher; the book was pbd. 11 Oct. 1851; see 26:203TC to JCA, 11 Oct. 1851. and that will bring you within a week or so of the old Times No, whh contains the passage.

closer.salute: Believe me always / Yours very sincerely /

ps.p: Chapman, tho’ I believe it is no matter, is directed to be silent as to the message & questn.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JN, 9 Jan. MS: NLS 553.260. Pbd: Wilson 5:539.
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p: Dear Neuberg,—There is still no visible improvet here; and we are in great confusion and distress, the very sight of such misery a constant pain. My PrintersRobson & Levey. have begun agn; and will perhaps keep me closer at work; whh is the one consolatn left to me,—cd I get forward even with it. Vol VI threatens to be as tough a fight with Chaos as any. “To it; get done with it!” there is no other remedy.

I have got yr Mecklenburg-Strelitz Pamphlet;Princess Charlotte of Mecklenburg-Strelitz (1744–1818; ODNB) purportedly wrote a letter to Frederick the Great, winter 1760–61, complaining about his treatment of her country; pbd. as “Translation of a Letter, said to have been written by Princess Charlotte of Mecklenberg to the King of Prussia, on one of his Victories” (Gentleman’s Magazine 31 [Oct. 1761]: 447); see Carlyle, Works 18:357–60. She m., 1761, George III (1738–1820; ODNB), king of Great Britain and Ireland 1760–1820.—I have also got a pretty bit of excerpting &c for you to do for me: plenty of that now & coming! If you will stand true (as I know you will) to the end of this Vol VI,—I promise you immunity for the rest of my life.
Come on Sunday Evg at any rate.

div3.sourceNote: TC-ED [EDOW], 9 Jan. MS: NLS Acc. 9086. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO ELIZABETH DOWNES

docBody.p:
I was sorry to learn that Mr Downes had been ordered to Algeria by his Doctors,—tho’ it has been lately a consolatn to hear that he is doing well there. Let us all hope he will return, in strength, with the warm weather;For John Downes’s death in London, 15 May, see TC to Lady ALLA, 29 May. strong enough to resume his industries, whh now, I conclude, he is strictly charged to forbear! Meanwhile, allow me to state why I write at present.
John Downes, n.d.
Courtesy of the National Library of Scotland

There happens to be at my dispol, by kind Chance (as we may count it) a sum of £50, set apart for the aid of some “meritorious Literary man in distress“:TC was left a bequest of £50 per annum by Lady Harriet Ashburton to be “bestowed on distressed Literary Persons”; see 34:82–83TC to LOA, 29 July 1858. I know nobody in the world to whom it is more due, or is so likely to do its maximum of good, as to Mr D. or his Wife. I hope no foolish scruples will prevent yr accepting this sum. The money really is not mine, nor shall
anybody know whose it was, or will be: in a very true sense, it may be called a Gift out of Heaven; coming silently like Manna to comfort slightly the afflicted and the help-needing.

I wish you to mention it to Mr Downes;Elizabeth Downes forwarded TC’s letter, writing a note to John Downes on the reverse, concluding “I feel at writing on the back-paper of the Great Man’s Note but it is to save postage dearest and you will forgive / your loving Lizzie.”—or if you please (whh I shd like better) to accept it on yr own responsibility, be so kind as write merely “Yes,” with yr Address, on a bit of paper, and the money shall be sent by return of post.See TC to EDEDOW, 13 Jan. For an undated photograph of John Downes (NLS Acc. 9086 vol. 7.131), see opp.above.

ps.p: To Mrs Downes

div3.sourceNote: TC-JCA, 10 Jan. MS: NLS 517.70. Pbd: A. Carlyle, NL 2:219 inc.
div3.head: TC TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.p: Dear Jean,—You, and those dear to me, and to whom I am dear, ought at once to be made partakers of my little glance of good luck!—

The poor Soul had at last two hours of good sleep last night, and generally a “much quieter” night; she admits this morning (she for the first time, and dare not yet witht buts and doubts, poor creature) that she is a kenning better! The rest of [us]Omitted by TC. all hope now that we are fairly round,—tho’, taught by former experience, we will not anticipate uninterrupted progress, and will be content with the slowest rate of speed.

All is lucky (or seems so) today. A beautiful silent thaw; instead of horrible dust-element, of frozen smoke and rime. I got myself washed agn this morning (sponges not frozen to the plate)—and have got thro’ my affairs, you may fancy, with new spirit & velocity.

Of course you will let everybody know as heretofore:—I have counted that you can get this on Monday Evg; none of the rest have that chance.TC wrote on Sunday; there were no post collections in London on Sundays, but letters collected first thing Monday morning could be delivered that evening in postal towns such as Dumfries; letters would not reach the outlying farms of TC’s other siblings until the next day.
I will write agn in a day, or in two days.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 12 Jan. MS: NLS 526.1. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: After a very feeble days-work, I have still 3 minutes before going on the jog-jog (I ride that way to avoid falling, where the roads are hard; you have no idea with what swiftness, and with less disgust than I had at first: jog-g—jog—jg).TC’s horse, Noggs, was not very safe at high trotting, but was fine at jog trotting; see 39:204TC to JAC, 16 May 1863.

My poor Jane, of who you will perhaps [hear] today from Dumfries,See TC to JCA, 10 Jan. TC omitted “hear.” continues what we fairly call a little better. That was Quain’sDr. Richard Quain, one of the doctors attending JWC. deliberate phrase to me last night; to whh he added, “It will be a long time yet before she get quite rid“—alas, yes, I do not doubt it. You never saw a creature so brashed to pieces, and extentuated by pain and restless misery. She sleeps now fairly a little better, perhaps 2 hours altogether in the night, with perhaps additn of as much, in two or 3 pieces, thro’ the day. She lies also far quieter; broken down as in utter weariness & weakness; is ordered 2 glasses of sherry per day, & ½ glass of Hollands made into punch (whh too I think will do good for a certain reason). She is greatly discouraged, poor soul; but grasps at the idea of still continuing with us, if it can be done in not insupportable suffering. We must wait, and be thankful and patient.

I have got as you may fancy, very ill on with my work,—ah me!—but have constantly been crawling on: it wd be delirium to me otherwise. Robson pleaded to be off too, abt Xmas time: but he has now started agn; a thot more rapidly. I am writing (or trying to write) on Vol 6; a rough job: much lies there; but it is like sand to be spun into ropes.— — Poor Robson, not by his own blame at all, is going into the Bankruptcy Court!The Times reported, 26 Feb., the bankruptcy hearing of Robson & Levey (previously Robson, Levey & Franklyn, 23 Gt. New St., Fetter Lane): “The bankrupts were stationers of Fetter-Lane. … / It appeared that the bankrupts formerly carried on business in copartnership with one Franklyn, and in July 1863, this partnership was dissolved by the retirement of Franklyn, and a deed of dissolution executed by which Franklyn’s share in the partnership stock and effects was assigned to the continuing partners, who covenanted to pay and discharge all debts then due from the partnership. After the date of the deed Levey and Robson continued the business up to January of the present year, when the petition was filed under which they were adjudicated bankrupts. … Mr. Registrar Murray … was of the opinion that the creditors were entitled to prove against the estate of the bankrupts.”—

Mamsell Irma’s Letter you may burn; & say if you see herIrma Otthenin, da. of TC’s old friend Jean Otthenin, lived in Edinburgh. that I will ansr it. My loving regards to Erskine.Thomas Erskine of Linlathen spent winters in Edinburgh. Adieu

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady S [LST], 13 Jan. MS: Strouse. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO LADY STANLEY

docBody.p: I was much obliged by yr kind little word the other morning.Lady Stanley wrote to TC from Alderley, the Stanley estate, 3 Jan.: “I never knew till yesterday what a sad cloud you have had over your house I had heard Mrs Carlyle had hurt herself falling & was better—& refrained from troubling her & now I hear that for five weeks she has been in bed I am so very very sorry & I know how much you feel for her. … [S]hould the Doctor recommend perfect quiet do come here. We will take such care of you, you know you can ride here in the rain & not feel it but now we have clear frost & sunshine & could take long walks—all your young friends are here … & finally I now an old lady who are very fond of you.” TC’s “young friends” were “Johnny the soldier,” Edward Lyulph (who had recently visited Thomas Erskine, “who was very kind”), and the three unmarried das. (“who worship you”), Maude, Kate, and Rosalind. TC wrote about Lady Stanley’s invitation on her envelope: “Lady Stanley / Consd (nullity, alas!).” My poor Wife is very badly indeed: I never saw her (nor indeed anybody) in such suffering, and continual misery night and day. “Neuralgia,” all the Drs say; “and not immediately dangerous to life”;—tho’ 8 weeks of that sort of torment, and without any sleep but one night, must naturally be very wearing to a weak life!

I did not ansr you at once; hoping I might get better news to send. And since Sunday last there has been visible something like improvet: a little fraction of bad sleep daily, less of tossing,—utter weariness instead;—& on the whole such a degree of weakness as you seldom saw. This goes on since Sunday; even this not very steadily:—and we must accept it as the best that can be got.
No man in England, or I shd think on the Planet Earth, is so hurried abt as I lately. My cordial regards to yr Bonnie Lasses; & to yr Ladyship’s self and all that belong to you.

div3.sourceNote: TC-FC, 13 Jan. MS: Strouse. Hitherto unpbd. The letter was written on the back of the wrapping, addressed to TC, in which Henry Larkin presumably sent him the index.
div3.head: TC TO FREDERIC CHAPMAN

docBody.p: The inclosed the Index to Vol IV is done, be so good as wrap up Vol. & Index in a Parcel addressed “Mr Tauchnitz Leipzig”Christian Bernhard Tauchnitz (1816–95), Leipzig publisher, pbd. German translations of many of TC’s works. from &c,—and leave it ([paid?]) at Wms & Norgate’sWilliams & Norgate, 14 Henrietta St., Covent Garden, foreign booksellers. Henrietta strt
(speedy!)— / T. Carlyle (Chelsea 13 jany)

ps.p: To Frc Chapman Esqr

div3.sourceNote: TC-ED [EDOW], 13 Jan. Addr: 18 Glo’ster Road / Holloway / N. PM: London, 13 Jan. 1864. MS: NLS Acc. 9086. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO ELIZABETH DOWNES

docBody.p: I inclose the Draught for Fifty Pounds;TC noted in his checkbook: “13 jany 1864 / To Mrs E. Downes (from Fund) £50.0.0” (MS: NLS 20752). He also noted in his memoranda of amounts given from Lady Harriet Ashburton’s bequest: “13 jan 1864 - - - - £50 to Downes, a very meritors man, off to Algiers for health &c (money paid to his wife)— —” (MS: Bodleian Lib.). and can only wish and hope that Mr Downes may, before very long, come back to us, restored in health to a fair degree, and ready for his old fight with the world and its difficulties.
If you will be so good as write in the inclosed Cover, “recd”; and throw it into a Post Office, this little affair will be finished.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JCA, 18 Jan. 1864. MS: EUL. Hitherto unpbd. The letter follows TC to EDOW, 13 Jan. 1864 [This letter, pbd. at CL 44:234, is now placed at its proper chronological location.].
div3.head: TC TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.p: Dear Jean,—Yesterday and this morning I cd send you no good news: there was a relapse, sad to look upon; no sleep agn, no &c &c,—requiring all ones obstinacy to keep hopeful under: but since this forenoon, there has been a good deal of sleep (of its kind), and we seem to be fairly progressive agn. The DrsJWC had been very ill since autumn 1863, and was being attended by Dr. Alfred Barnes (ca. 180267) and Dr. Richard Quain (181698; ODNB); see 40:2TC to JCA, 4 Jan. 1864. never falter in their substantially hopeful prognosticatn; nor, except at bad moments do I: but the misery is enormous;—and I think they have abt admitted that their drugs can do no good at all.— You talk of quitting the BookFrederick the Great. for six months,—I cd as soon take and hang myself at once. Either the Book must finish or I! if you knew it.— But certainly to get on with it in any perceptible degree at all is not a simple operatn, as matters go. Enough, enough.
docBody.closer: Yours in the extremity of haste (11 p.m.) /T.C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-MC [MCON], 19 Jan. MS: Columbia. Hitherto unpbd. Moncure Daniel Conway was the pastor of South Place Chapel, Finsbury.
div3.head: TC TO MONCURE D. CONWAY

docBody.p: I am sorry to report that my poor Wife is still in the same whirlpool of sufferings,—Neuralgia all the Doctors call it, but are powerless to help it;—and that I fear it will be a long time before she can see any of her friends.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle
docBody.note: TC apparently wrote to Sir George Sinclair with news of JWC’s illness; Sinclair replied, 19 Jan., from The Mount, Upper Norwood, SE London: “My very dear & much honored friend / It must, I think, have been foreseen, that a letter from you would cause me too much pleasure, unless accompanied by the allay of some painful intelligence. Olivia [Sinclair’s youngest da.] & I were very much concerned, when we heard this afternoon of dear Mrs C’s painful, tho’, I am glad to learn, not dangerous illness.”

div3.sourceNote: TC-ACG, 21 Jan. MS: Fitzwilliam Museum, Cambridge Univ. Hitherto unpbd. Alexander Craig Gibson (1813–74; ODNB), folklorist and surgeon.
div3.head: TC TO ALEXANDER CRAIG GIBSON

docBody.p: Dear Sir,—I like the Cumberland RhymesGibson sent TC a copy of his lecture on Annandale rhymes Nov. 1863; see 39:243TC to JAC, 13 Nov. 1863; presumably he now sent him his lecture on “Popular Rhymes and Proverbs Connected with Localities in Cumberland,” which he delivered, 11 April 1861, to the Historic Society of Lancashire and Cheshire, pbd. in their Transactions … Session 1860–61 (Liverpool, 1861) 45–66. too, and the Lockerby Lick;Gibson described the Lockerbie lick in his lecture on Annandale rhymes: “Many were slain in the fight—those left wounded on the field being afterwards murdered at leisure. Such killed and wounded were for the most part fearfully slashed … by a back-handed sword-stroke … ever since, a back-handed blow has been known on the Border proverbially as ‘A Lockerbie lick’” (Transactions … Session 1862–63 [Liverpool, 1863] 165).—Cumberland also was a bit of my Heritage in this world; Skiddaw & the Fells,Skiddaw, one of the highest fells in the northern Lake District at 3,054 ft. (931 m.), is clearly visible from Annandale (see 35:201TC to TSS, 15 Sept. 1859). In the 1861 lecture Gibson noted: “The old rhyme claiming pre-eminence of altitude for certain hills on the confines of Lancashire and Yorkshire is well known and often quoted. One of equal antiquity … pays a similar compliment, and, as has been proved by the Ordnance Survey, with better reason, to three of the Cumbrian fells, and may be heard still in their vicinity. ‘Skiddaw, Helvellyn, and Catstycand / Are the highest hills in all England!’” (Transactions … Session 1860–61 54). Gibson’s footnote was that “Catsteecam … is the proper name of this height. The old rhymester has altered it to make it meet a rhyming emergency” (54). Helvellyn is 3,117 ft. (950 m.) and Catstycam 2,920 ft. (890 m.). to my young eyes, were the beautifullest thing I have ever seen, or shall now see.

I hope you don’t quite renounce the Book on Annandale and its History;Gibson contributed articles to various newspapers and journals throughout his life, but did not publish a book on Annandale history. tho’ your consideratns in regard to it are valid, and will have themselves obeyed. But a great deal can be done by careful husbanding of the bits of leisure that occur in the businest life: little by little something is got done at last. Much research wd be needed; consulting Archives, careful study of what authentic old Books there are: &c &c. If the few points that are indubitable cd be clearly marked, and a good separatn of them made from those that are dubious, and a still better from those that are false or grown inconceivable,—than wd rise a certain twilight over the whole matter, and curious outlines of the extinct Past Time (far beyond what one expects at first) might really be attainable. A Book on that untouched matter, in the Philemon-Camden style of worth,William Camden, Britain; or, a Chorographicall Description of the most flourishing Kingdomes, England, Scotland, and Ireland. … Written first in Latin … translated newly into English by Philemon Holland, 2 pts. (1610); a work TC often recommended; see 38:209TC to HP, 15 Sept. 1862. wd indeed be a beautiful achievement! I forget what I wrote to you
in the form of a Note.TC presumably replied to Gibson, Nov. 1863, thanking him for his article; letter untraced. But I suppose it was what I thot:—if it can forward yr object, do with it what you like.

closer.salute: In great haste at prest / Yours sincerely /

div3.sourceNote: TC-Duchess of A [DUA], 31 Jan. MS: NLS 7197. Hitherto unpbd. Elizabeth Georgiana, b. Leveson-Gower (1824–78), m., 1844, George Douglas Campbell (1823–1900; ODNB), 8th duke of Argyll. TC had met them at The Grange, Jan. 1862; see TC to JAC, 30 Jan. 1862.
div3.head: TC TO THE DUCHESS OF ARGYLL

docBody.p: You are very good to sympathise in our distresses.Elizabeth, duchess of Argyll, wrote, 30 Jan.: “I do not wish to trouble you, but must tell you that we were very sorry to hear of your anxiety about Mrs Carlyle’s health—and that it would give us great pleasure to hear that you are happy about her.” My poor Wife, for almost three months past, has been in great misery and suffering,—Neuralgia; the Doctors unanimously call it, but can do nothing for it (or even less than nothing);—and our outlook, at times, have been gloomy enough. Of late weeks, however, there seems to be perceptible, tho’ in a fluctuating uncertain way, some real progress towards improvet; at lowest, all opiates &c &c being now abandoned, there is now only the malady itself to struggle with. We are ordered to Hastings & the Sea-side;JWC went to stay with Dr. Peyton Blakiston and his wife, Bessy, at St. Leonards-on-Sea, nr. Hastings, in March.—in whh natural remedy the poor Patient herself, and I and everybody, have great hope.John Rutter Chorley wrote, 24 Jan., in reply to a query from TC about Matteo Maria Boiardo (d. 1494), Italian renaissance poet, and Francesco Berni (ca. 1497–1535) who recast, 1542, Boiardo’s Orlando Innamorato (1495). Chorley concluded: “What you say of Mrs Carlyle’s improved condition gave me a great Pleasure:—the idea of her bad nights and suffering days, of which I have heard at your door, has been present to me as a darkness for the last six weeks, God send that it may pass away.”
With many thanks and good wishes, I remain

closer.salute: Your Grace’s / much obliged & most obedt /

div3.sourceNote: MW-Lady A [LLA], [6 Feb.?]. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Hitherto unpbd. Dated tentatively early Feb., after TC’s hope that there was some “real progress” in JWC’s health; see TC to DUA, 31 Jan. JWC’s cousin Margaret Welsh came to help nurse JWC, 7 Dec. 1863; see TC to JC, 6 Dec. 1863, and TC to JAC, 11 Dec. 1863. The series of letters from Feb. to April from Margaret Welsh to friends about JWC’s health are included in this volume because they were presumably written at JWC’s request at a time when she was too ill to write for herself.
div3.head: MARGARET WELSH TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p: Miss Anstruther’sLady Ashburton’s niece Annie Nairn Anstruther; she and her mother, Mary, often helped Lady Ashburton when Lord Ashburton was ill; see 39:5JWC to MR, 10 Dec. 1862. kind note reached me this morning, & I feel very sorry that I have not written to you long ere this, but I thought that Mr Carlyle had been writing to let you know how Mrs Carlyle has been going on. I know he is very busy at present—& I see that he looks worried, besides having been most sad & anxious about poor Mrs Carlyle. She herself begs me to give her very dear love & to tell you what a grief it has been to her & Mr Carlyle to hear that Lord Ashburton has been so very ill of late.— Till Dr Quain told her & Mr Carlyle on Thursday they did not know that Lord Ashburton had been more ailing than usual & sadly distressed they have been to learn it. Most thankful they are to hear even of the slightest improvement, but what a time of anxiety you must have dear Lady. God grant that it may ere long be relieved. I many times think of your kindness the day you came up to see Mrs Carlyle & I am sure they both felt it much.

I wish I could give you a sincerely better report of her but today she is really very poorly, suffering very great pain, & she looks, I think, very poorly indeed. Still in some respects she is undoubtedly better than when you saw her,Possibly Lady Ashburton’s visit late Dec. 1863; see 39:263TC to RMM, 29 Dec. 1863. but in others she seems almost worse. She herself assures me that she never has felt at all really better & she is certainly often very very suffering. Still the doctors always say she is better & in nervous illness, such as hers seems to be, of course they can judge far better than others. Dr Quain who has been most kind in coming to see her repeatedly, saw her on Thursday & said that he considered her decidedly very much better. Her appetite is very good & for the last three nights she has slept a good deal, but truly the sleep, though one knows it must do good, does not seem to be felt so by poor Cousin. She is stronger too I think than when you saw her, in full—one feels that she ought to be better, but I cannot truly say that she ever seems to me to be really so. Perhaps I have grown a little disheartened seeing her so constantly suffering & that may make me less alive to the improvement. Still I do
not show her I hope that I do not quite think as the doctors do at least I try not for I feel & hope that I may be quite mistaken. They are very anxious for a Change for her,TC reported to the duchess of Argyll, 31 Jan., that they were “ordered to Hastings & the Sea-side.” & we often speak of it, but at times, as today, she looks very unfit for any place but home, though I do not indeed say so to her or look it either. I will write again if all be well very soon for I know that even with all your cares & anxieties you are anxious to hear about Mrs Carlyle.

She takes a great deal of food made with milk, & the cream, which comes in such abundance & so regularly, is much enjoyed by her, She many times says “how very kind they are.” I do trust to have better accounts to send you. The doctors are so hopeful that I feel it is scarcely natural or right in me to be less so. Perhaps it is from seeing herself so low, & always saying she will never get better. Sometimes however she does speak much more hopefully & says “if ever I get better I will do & … … .” For a time she never even would allow the possibility of ever being better, so this must surely be a better sign of her strength.
She again bids me give her kindest love

closer.salute: Believe me / Dear Lady / Yours respectfully & truly /

div3.sourceNote: TC-JR [JRU], [11 Feb.?]. MS: EUL. Pbd: Cate 105, where dated late 1863. Tentatively dated early 1864 when TC, JWC, and Ruskin were all in London, and in Feb. by Dr. Quain’s visits to JWC; see MW to LLA, [6 Feb.?].
div3.head: TC TO JOHN RUSKIN

docBody.p: Your benevolent CousinProbably Dr. William J. Richardson (b. 1811), Ruskin’s cousin, who lived in Tunbridge Wells; see 29:318TC to JRU, 23 May 1855. has been so very obliging as call; and—I & the ill Chances, lo, we have made such a mess of it as was never seen!

At dusk when I came home from my ride, there was a whirlpool of people in and about the house, one of whom I privately learned was Dr Quain. I retired to the kitchen, to smoke perdue and waylay Dr Quain. Having had a word from him, I stole up to my bedroom for the usual nap of sleep. I had not got to sleep there, when the maid came knocking with “a Letter, Sir” (your Letter, I did not learn by whom). I read the letter, with the bad candle and the bad eyes,—failing to make out the first line;—I conclude it was your man CrawleyFrederick Crawley (b. 1828), Ruskin’s valet until 1876. that had brot it; and I sent a verbal ansr as if by Crawley for you! Not till
half an hour ago, on reading the Note deliberately after dinner, did I ascertain for myself what an unutterable absurdity there had been committed;—to my own and especially my poor Wife’s very great disappointt:—with the question still in the rear, Is it forgivable and reparable, or is it?
I at once apprise you, at any rate and beg to make a thousand and a thousand apologies to the kind Dr. for what I unwittingly did.

div3.sourceNote: TC-CAW, 16 Feb. Addr: 1 Chapel Street / Mayfair. PM: London, 16 Feb. 1864. MS: NLS Acc. 9086. Pbd: Boston Evening Transcript, 11 May 1915 inc.
div3.head: TC TO CHARLES A. WARD

docBody.p: I got yr Noses;Charles Augustus Ward, “Noses: What They Mean, and How to Use Them,” Eclectic and Congregational Review 6 (Feb. 1864): 158–91. many thanks for so sappy a Piece!

Saturday gone a week, in a stupid Newspaper whh comes here (“Public-Opinn” so-called) I had fallen in with a morsel excerpted;Public Opinion, weekly review 1861–1951, pbd. an excerpt in “Classification of Noses,” 6 Feb.—and had said to myself, “Who in the world is this, then? A man that has actually some perennial human sense; while all else, from pole to pole, is gibble-gabble and quackle-quackle, in various pitches of noise!Ward concluded: “We have now tried to bring before the world the importance of properly using the nose, with what effect time only can show. … It now remains that those who may imagine that our remarks are irrelevant … should open their mouths vociferously in denunciation, and whilst they blacken us, blacken their own teeth also, for thus they will be truly civilized, and the savages will acknowledge them for genuine ‘black mouths.’ But from such as agree with us, we ask no praise, no waste of breath, for breath is Divine; we say to them … we say to all, ‘Shut your mouth’” (191). I must have this inquired into!”— And straightway the Essay itself came; you may judge how welcome. I read it that same night, really with great entertaint and satisfactn (everywhere with more or less of assent, generally with perfectly hearty do);—and have sent it to the worthy, so far as opportunity wd (Ruskin has it now, if I remember):—& on the whole, I believe you have done a stroke this time. And I will commission from you: All the Papers of that type whh prove accessible in yr repositories,—with as much despatch as you like.

div3.sourceNote: MW-Lady A [LLA], [17 Feb.?]. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Hitherto unpbd. Dated tentatively between MW to LLA, [6 Feb.?], and MW to LLA, [18 Feb.?].
div3.head: MARGARET WELSH TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p: As I think perhaps Mr Carlyle may not have written lately, for he seems both very busy & very sad at heart often, I now write feeling sure you will be anxious to hear of poor Mrs Carlyle. There seems to be very little change since the last time I wrote, but one cannot help fearing & feeling that as week after week goes on finding no real change for the better, the fear of her strength giving way becomes greater. Still from what the doctors say they have hopes she may yet overcome the illness.

For the last week she has not been suffering the weary, & sometimes intense, nervous pain nearly so much; this must be an improvement; for that constant suffering was most wearing out. How she has stood it so long has been a wonder to me. She is dreadfully thin & worn out looking, but she has still astonishing strength in moving herself. She has no apparent dislike to food, but for several days past she has not at all taken it with the same caring. Today I am thankful to see that she has more inclination for it. She bids me give you “her very dear love.” She “cannot thank you, she says, for your kind thought of them at all times.

Some beautiful jelly came this morning, along with several other kind gifts; also a Charming box of rusks, which Mr Carlyle likes so very much. She too often likes them steeped in milk. Mr Carlyle & she have been so very rejoiced to hear better news of Lord Ashburton. You must indeed, dear Lady, have had an anxious time for long, and what thankfulness to feel that all your care has been of avail. I have many times thought of you & your great anxiety. Believe me / Yours respectfully /
M. Welsh.

div3.sourceNote: MW-Lady A [LLA], [18 Feb.?]. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Hitherto unpbd. Dated tentatively after receipt of the jelly sent by Lady Ashburton; see MW to LLA, [17 Feb.?].
div3.head: MARGARET WELSH TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p:
Miss FarrerAnnie Louisa Farrer (1818–1910), friend of the Ashburtons; see 38:27938:biographical notes. called today to enquire for Mrs Carlyle & from what she told me we fear that Lord Ashburton is not so well even as when Miss Anstruther wrote last week. Mrs Carlyle bids me give her very dear love & tell you how
very deeply grieved she is for you all; but she hopes & prays that better news may come. I grieve to say that she herself is much the same as when I last wrote, but she says she feels weaker.

Mr Carlyle says that he thinks she is improving but very very slowly. She suffers such constant pain that she cannot but feel & look worn out with it. Last night she slept a good deal, & one is always most thankful when she does sleep, though it never seems to refresh her as one would expect.JWC had “three consecutive nights of sleep,” 16 to 18 Feb., followed by almost none on 19 and 20 Feb.; see TC to JCA, 21 Feb. Still one knows it would be worse were she getting no sleep as was the case for so long.
I do pray to be able another time to tell you of some real perceptible improvement, we can but hope & trust!
She is feeling much for you as you can well believe.

I am writing beside her just now, & she has just told me to say to you that she “would like to live a little longer to thank you for all your great kindness & thought for her.” She was quite touched when we brought her the jelly; she said it was so thoughtful in the midst of all your own sad trouble.

closer.salute: Believe me / Dear Lady / Yours very respectfully /

div3.sourceNote: TC-CAW, 19 Feb. Addr: 1. Chapel Street / Mayfair. PM: London, 19 Feb. 1864. MS: NLS Acc. 9086. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO CHARLES A. WARD

docBody.p: I cannot per- or dis-suade in regard to any one of those subjects you suggest. The subject that is and looks richest to yr own mind,—that is the subject to be chosen by you. The only other conditn is that of an Editor to publish it. I know two Editors,James Anthony Froude, ed. of Fraser’s Magazine 1860–74, and David Masson (1822–1907; ODNB), ed. of Macmillan’s Magazine 1859–68. and only two,—Froude (a highly superior man, Fraser his Magne) one of them. If you shd care to get two other Copies of the Eclectic,The magazine which pbd. Ward’s article on “Noses”; see TC to CAW, 16 Feb. & despatch them with the two inclosed snips of paperWritten on the MS in another hand was presumably Ward’s note of TC’s enclosures: “A J. Froude Esq / 6 Clifton Terrace / Hyde Park Gdns / Will Mr F look into that paper on noses and do me the favour to recollect C A Ward Esq 1 Chapel St in case he hear of him again / T Carlyle (19 Feb / 64”; and “D Masson Esq / Macmillan & Co / Henrietta St / Covent Garden.” stuck in at the proper page, and a little overlapping; that seems the easiest way of doing & saying for you all that I can in this matter. If indeed you wish anything done or said.— Yrs sincerely / T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JCA, 21 Feb. MS: NLS 517.71. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.p: You will be disappointed if you do not get yr word tomorrow night; &, alas, also disappointed when you do! The Dr’s letter, whh you wd get last night, brought favourable news of poor Jane’s having had 3 consecutive nights of sleep, better in kind and greater in quantity than had been known before;—but now we are at the old basis again: Friday night, a very poor allowance of sleep, and last night as good as none at all! Very great depression, weakness and misery the consequence. I strive to suppose it is chiefly the bad weather (frosty, bitter, snowy, bad for us all);—and it is possible there may be better sleep tonight: but we do not know. And on the whole you see how uncertain any “bulletin” is as an indication, in this dark and miserable passage of distress we are in. God only knows what is to become of us and it. We must wait, as patiently as is in our power what the Will of the Supreme is: help we can give none; comfort in the busss none can give us.Geraldine Jewsbury wrote to Walter Mantell, 15 Feb.: “I am writing in the drawing room of 5 Cheyne Row Poor Mrs Carlyle is very ill—& nobody knows what is the matter with her—the doctors declare that it is all on the nerves—but both I & her cousin who is nursing her fear that she injured herself in her fall & that there is a cause for all the pain & terrible restlessness. she suffers dreadfully & her restlessness is worse than pain it is only very seldom she will see me but I come on the chance of being useful sometimes— Mr Carlyle is still in the throes of Frederick & is very miserable about his wife no man cd shew more kindness or tenderness” (MS: Mantell).

I am myself still on foot, tho’ the frost is very troublesome to me: and my poor Task (the only one I can see for living at all) is obliged to encounter the dismallest impediments. I had a bit of a gallop today in the silent Country (after three miles of railway & suburb abominatn one does get into the Country): but I was soon obliged to turn, the roads getting more & more glassy and unsafe. I hope the Frost at least will take itself away. It is my little Horse that keeps me alive, as it were; roadway for him is a great indispensability to him. Condolences, talk from anybody I see, are distasteful to me: absolute silence, with a little work done, is my most tolerable posture of affairs. Mrs ChrystalJWC’s cousin and Margaret Welsh’s sister Jeannie Chrystal, presumably visiting from Glasgow. goes on Tuesday. Good night; I have still several things to do. Yr affecte T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lord S[LOST], 21 Feb. MS: Stanhope Manuscripts; Kent County Council Arts & Libraries, Maidstone, Kent. Hitherto unpbd. Philip Henry Stanhope (1805–75; ODNB), 5th Earl Stanhope, historian and politician, known to TC since 1839; see TC to JAC, 11 March 1839.
div3.head: TC TO LORD STANHOPE

docBody.p: Many thanks for remembering me in that or any other way! Surely I shall fall in with you, in some lucky ride or other wise, before long.Lord Stanhope wrote, 20 Feb.: “I regret to think it is a long while since I had the pleasure to fall in with you at the Athenæum or elsewhere.”

It is certain the Prince Fritz was a dissolute young lad of 17 gone, at the time specified,Lord Stanhope wrote: “My object … in now writing to you is to call your attention to a very extraordinary and to me quite novel statement respecting your Prussian hero which I have just found in a recent French publication. … Revue des deux Mondes of Feb: 15 for this year, page 846, and it states that the Empress Catharine II was believed to be the daughter of Frederick II. / In 1729, the year of Catharine’s birth, Frederick was a stripling of seventeen and it is stated that just at the requisite period for this theory he had gone upon a visit to Catharine’s mother the Princess of Anhalt Zerbst. It might be worth your while to trace from the documents in your possession how far the dates would really agree with the idea. Poor Princess of Anhalt! To have her character maligned after such a lapse of years!”—had met with his Orzelska, and initiatory Opera Nudity, at Dresden,For the entangled relationships of the young Frederick, Anna Karolina Orzelska (1707–69), illegitimate da. of August II (1670–1733), king of Poland 1697–1733, and Henriette Rénard (b. ca. 1685), and a young opera singer named Formera, see Carlyle, Works 13:116–18. the year before; and was going at a considerable rate (always in her latitudes, I have understood). It is certain also that Cathrine’s Mother was a foolish enough creature; some months younger than he (tho’ already Mother of a son, Husband’s age 39):The mother of Sophie Friederike Auguste von Anhalt-Zerbst (1729–96), later Catherine the Great, was Johanna Elisabeth of Holstein-Gottorp (1712–60), who m., 1727, Christian August von Anhalt-Zerbst (1690–1747). it is possible, too, Friedrich might make a visit to Zerbst in 1729;—but he wd not find her there (unless specially invited); husband & she had nothing to do with ZerbstZerbst, town 67 mi. (107 km.) SW of Berlin. for 13 years to come; but lived at StettinStettin, town 80 mi. (129 km.) NE of Berlin, now in Poland. in a limited and strictly military way, till 1742: So that the Story seems to me to hang by next to nothing. I have observed farther that, in certain Letters written to Frh, in Newyear’s time 1744, àpropos of the grand Russian outlooks,Frederick actively encouraged the marriage of Sophie Friederike Auguste von Anhalt-Zerbst to her second cousin and future tsar, Peter von Holstein-Gottorp (1728–62); see Carlyle, Works 15:480. by this foolish Woman, there is not (nor elsewhere, to my knowledge) the least trace of such an adventure lying in memory. In short, I take the story to be one of the very large covey hatched (on this King’s private
History) by idle malice, rumour & the God of Flies:Beelzebub, lord of the flies, originally a Philistine god; see 2 Kings 1:2. not worth investigating farther. After the recent “Matinées du Roi de Preuss”For the various theories about the authorship of Les Matinées du Roi de Prusse, écrits par lui même (Berlin, 1766), see 39:33TC to JN, 21 Jan. 1863, and Carlyle, Works 18:179–84.
