(killed ten times over, and still as lively as ever), one need not be surprised at anything of that kind.
In hopes of soon meeting yr Lordship somewhere, vivâ voce,—I remain always

div3.sourceNote: TC-JCA, 27 Feb. MS: NLS 517.72. Hitherto unpbd. TC’s letter is written on the back and in the bottom margins of a printed letter (undated) asking for support for the commissioning of a monument to William Makepeace Thackeray (d. 24 Dec. 1863), to be placed in Westminster Abbey. For a portrait of Thackeray, see TC to RMM, 29 Dec. 1863.
div3.head: TC TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.p:
Dear Sister,—I did not write to the Dr yesterday, partly in the hope that there might be slightly better news to send if I waited another day: but that has not been the case; and this morning, before any other employt, I must write you (for your & his behoof) a hurried word or two. Friday gone a week was the last night of real sleep there has yet been!In his previous letter to Jean Aitken, TC wrote that JWC had a “very poor allowance” on Friday 19 Feb., but on the previous three nights had slept well; see TC to JCA, 21 Feb. No night since that, can be said to have brot sleep; I think, only one night which brot partial sleep (of an hour or two); the rest, with nothing but scattered minutes,—most of them, as last night, without any sleep at all. The opium, by its “new method,” appears to be no whit better than by the old; and I myself shd rather wish it discontind & thrown to the dogs: but they alledge it keeps down the pain, not the less; and she herself is still clear for it as on the whole beneficial. She is also taking quinine. It is certain she is very much quieter than formerly (some weeks ago); but whether by exhaustion of strength, abatet of the disease, or use of opium, I cannot with my whole industry in the least convince myself. She is very low; speaks little, and only about one stern release as the alone possible for her. Morning after morng, I come down in hope; & hear only the news, “A wretched night; no sleep at all!”— Her appetite is fallen off at times: but whether that is by the Opium or by nature I cannot know. Darker disease, or with less help from medicine, I was never concerned with. We have to await Heaven’s appointment: nature herself informs us of that,—and that there is no other refuge left. She has quite given up the Hastings notion: and witht
her volunteering it, there cd be no possibility with safety. The frost & snow, thank Heaven, are gone; cold muddy thaw instead. I hoped some profit from that change; but none yet comes.— There are bad news from Ld Ashburton too:—on all hands, the waters getting out on us? To swallow our (my) poor Cadger’s Cart & worn-out Cuddy, with whh I am toiling thro’ the glarry wilderness, these ten years past, in a struggle as if for life, witht this new sad additn!— There is neither pleasure nor profit in writing abt such things,—far the reverse truly;—and I will end. Your affecte Brother T. Carlyle

ps.p: [Thomas Carlyle Esq]“Thomas Carlyle Esq” was written in another hand at the end of the printed letter, TC continuing with his postscript. The appeal letter was also signed by Charles Dickens, Lord Houghton, and Anthony Trollope. The bust was made by Baron Carlo (Charles) Marochetti (1805–67; ODNB), sculptor, and was duly placed in Westminster Abbey. will not concern himself, less or more; but thot you might like to read it;—came last night: no ansrJohn Ruskin wrote, [27 Feb.], that he meant to visit “today” but was “very far from well. … [W]ould you send me the merest line to say how Mrs Carlyle is? It would be very kind of you.”

div3.sourceNote: JWC [MW]-coal dealer [COD], 29 Feb. MS: Colbeck, Radford & Co., catalog 23 (May 1932); written “in the Third Person,” presumably the note was written by Margaret Welsh for JWC, rather than by TC or a servant.
div3.head: JWC [MW] TO COAL DEALER

docBody.p: [Ordering four tons of coal]

div3.sourceNote: TC-PB, 1 March. MS: Emmanuel College Lib., Cambridge. Pbd: K. J. Fielding and Peter Jackson, “Carlyle’s Reminiscences: Dr Peyton Blakiston and Bessy Barnet—A Note,” Carlyle Newsletter No. 9 (Spring 1988): 55 inc. The MS is damaged.
div3.head: TC TO PEYTON BLAKISTON

docBody.p:
You understand, without my speaking of it, how infinitely my poor Wife and myself are obliged by your great and constant kindness in this our extremity! We have had, [missing words]Line torn away; missing words possibly included “many doctors.” of skill and judgt, have been here, with their best endeavours; but all their appliances, opiates &c &c have worsened the matter (not in any case producing even temporary sleep or assuagement);—and except it be Nature herself struggling towards some recovery, of whh I flatter myself with seeing symptoms there is not the slightest improvet
traceable otherwise. In fact all the Doctors and I [missing words]Line torn away. and were unanimous in finding that neither there, nor in any other part, was the least derangt, of organ or of function, perceptible;—and she herself is convinced there is none: but that does not help the matter! The Drs (Quain, Farr,Presumably a colleague of Quain’s; possibly George Frederick Farr, M.D., 20 West Sq., Southwark. TC wrote later: “The doctors were many; Dr. Quain (who would take no fees) the most assiduous; Dr. Blakiston (ditto), from St. Leonard’s, express one time;—speaking hope, always, both of these, and most industrious to help;—with many more, whom I did not even see. When any new miraculous kind of Doctor was recommended as such, my poor struggling martyr, conscious too of grasping at mere straws, could not but wish to see him; and he came, did his mischief, and went away. We had even (by sanction of Barnes, and indeed of sound sense never so sceptical) a trial of ‘Animal Magnetism;’ two magnetisers, first a man, then a quack woman (evidently a conscious quack I perceived her to be),—who at least did no ill, except entirely disappoint (if that were much an exception)” (Carlyle, Reminiscences 172). [missing words].Line torn away; the list of doctors probably included Dr. Barnes.

This is all I had to say to you; dear Sir, —and, in spite of my confusion & my hurry, I believe you will be able to make out both what I mean & what I feel,—and to discern what you yourself are to do in it,—witht my writing another word. My best thanks to Mrs B. & you I need not add. Yours sincerely,
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JN, [6 March]. MS: NLS 553.261. Quot: Wilson, Carlyle 5:539.
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p: Dear Neuberg,—There will come to you Two Proof Slips (revises) upon the “Matinèes” Willms & Norgate Question.Les Matinées du Roi de Prusse, écrits par lui même (Berlin, 1766), a work purported to be by Frederick the Great, but which TC believed to be a satire, probably by Zacharie Pazzi de Bonneville (1710–80); see 31:89TC to JN, 9 May 1856, and Carlyle, Works 12:169–71. A new edn., by John Emerich Dalberg Acton (1834–1902; ODNB), historian, had been pbd. in 1863 by Williams & Norgate; see 39:33TC to JN, 21 Jan. 1863, and Carlyle, Works 18:180–84. Please examine accurately,—especially the references. “Thiébault” (for example) must be of another editn than what I have here (Paris 1805, 5 voll.);Dieudonné Thiébault, Mes souvenirs de vingt ans de séjour à Berlin; ou, Fréderic le Grand, sa famille, sa cour, etc. 2e édition, revue et corrigée, 5 vols. (Paris, 1805). TC’s copy: HCC. Neuberg replied, 10 March: “The reference to Thiébault I took from Preuss. … If I had your Thiébault I could … easily verify the passage.” TC does not refer to Thiébault in reference to Les Matinées.—if you can find the passage in that 1805 editn, pray do; if not, say in what editn it is.

BachaumontLouis Petit de Bachaumont, Mémoires secrets pour servir à l’histoire de la République des lettres en France, depuis mdcclxii jusqu’à nos jours, 36 vols. (1780–89); see Carlyle, Works 18:183. too (if I knew his date & place, exact page, and what he says &c &c). The NicolaiChristoph Friedrich Nicolai, Freymüthige Anmerkungen über des Ritters von Zimmermann Fragmente über Friedrich den Grossen, von einigen brandenburgischen Patrioten (Berlin, 1791–92); see Carlyle, Works 18:183. TC’s copy: HCC. I have verified.

I shd also like to know the Title (time &c) of the Wms & Norgate “mooncalf.”Les matinées royales, ou l’art de régner, ed. John Emerich Dalberg Acton (London and Edinburgh, 1863), which TC refers to as “this new London mooncalf”; see Carlyle, Works 18:184. Item of Samver; & what his “Grenzboten” is: if a Magazine, it must be of some month (in 1863).Karl Samwer pbd. an article on Les matinées royales in an 1863 issue of the monthly magazine Die Grenzboten, ein deutsche Revue, für Politik, Literatur und öffentliches Leben; Neuberg replied, 10 March: “The pages, which we have, seem to be cut out from two Numbers, but none of them has any trace of their Month”; see Carlyle, Works 18:184. You know well I never read a word of him.

I suppose the Kaiser JosephsKaiser Joseph II (1741–90), Holy Roman Emperor 1765–90. TC wrote to Mrs. Wilson, 17 Nov. 1863, asking for titles of books about Kaiser Joseph, so that he could order them from Germany; see 39:245TC to MRSW, 17 Nov. 1863; see also TC to JN, 9 May. Neuberg replied, 10 March, “Kaiser Joseph ought to be here this week, or next.” The only book on Joseph that TC cites in Frederick is Charles Joseph Mayer, Reisen Josephs II (Leipzig, 1778); see Carlyle, Works 19:186. are under way? I directed ChapmanProbably Frederic Chapman. (if he needed help abt a Berlin Book-post) to yr address.
We are in profound misery here;—I cannot for my life understand in what degree of danger:—but the suffering itself is heart-breaking. The Fates are not kind to me in these months. Ah me!—

p.name: T. Carlyle
p.note: Neuberg ended his letter of 10 March: “I have lost my good old Mother. … She was in her 89th year; she fell asleep, and did not awake again!” Frau Neuberg presumably d. in Heidingsfeldt; Neuberg visited her there, 1859; see 35:165TC to JN, 12 Aug. 1859.

ps.p: Chelsea, Sunday night late.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JCA, [6 March]. MS: NLS 517.67. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.p: You will probably apply tomorrow evg at the Post Office; and I wd gladly give you better news than I have—if I only could! I must write a baddish word rather than none.

My poor suffering partner is in great misery last week and still today. Next to no sleep for ten nights past; & in some six of them absolutely none! It is heartbreaking even to be near such a thing. She had appointed Tuesday (day after tomorrow) for Hastings; nor has she yet revoked: but I doubt if she will go. Her poor heart is worn quite out of her;—the thing you generally hear from her, on pressing that inquiry, is something of the “last release” that awaits us all: never before did she know what utter wretchedness, & being totally beaten, was!— I cannot for my life understand anything abt her disorder: since people keep asking, one is obliged to say something, “Better,” “Worse,” “much the same”;—but really I do not know whether her sad calamity (and mine) is on the way of mending or on the other way.— Last week has been rather hard for me too: I lost a day in writing &c abt this of Hastings; but that was a sacred and blessed kind of loss, in comparison. I have lost two nights by—causes not sacred! In short, I have very great difficulty to keep the plough by the shafts at all; but I strive, strive.

I aim to go on Tuesday, or whenever she goes:TC took JWC to stay with the Blakistons, nr. Hastings, Tues. 8 March; see TC to JWC, 9 March. it was her own request, and very natural, poor good soul; “I feel as if it were the first step into my grave,” she said.— For my own part, I have not the least hope of a “speedy recovery”; any recovery at all, so far as I can gather, mocks the attempt to date it, in such disorders. Appetite is not much failed, but I doubt latterly, a little. Good night dear Sister. Yrs T.C.

ps.p: I rejoice in Johnny’s good luck:Jean’s son John; his “good luck” is unexplained. let him be doubly steady to deserve it.

div3.sourceNote: MW-WD [WDO], [7 March]. MS: NLS 1797.102. Hitherto unpbd. Dated by JWC’s hope of traveling to St. Leonards, Tues. 8 March.
div3.head: MARGARET WELSH TO WILLIAM DODS

docBody.p:
Mr Carlyle has asked me to write in answer to your kind note which he received today, he begs me also to apologize for not writing himself, but he is just at present very much occupied. I grieve to say that my Cousin Mrs Carlyle is still very ill. The doctors are most anxious for her to go to the seaside, as they appear to think that a Change of air & of scene may do great good when many other things have unfortunately failed. I do hope & pray that she may derive benefit from it. It is decided that if she feel equal to moving we go to St Leonard’s-on-Sea tomorrow. I feel very anxious in thinking of the
journey for she is in a sadly weak state, but as the medical men seem to have little fear but that she will stand the journey pretty well, I try not to feel so uneasy about it, & would fain hope that once there she may ere long feel some good effect from the pure sea air.

She bids me give her kindest love. Perhaps you will be so very kind as to let Miss WelshJWC’s cousin John Amelia (Jackie) Welsh, who also lived in Haddington. know that you have heard from me, for I have of late been so much occupied that I am sorry I have been unable to write to her. I am sorry indeed to hear she is so ailing at present.

closer.salute: I am Dear Sir / Yours truly /

div3.sourceNote: TC-RWE, 8 March. MS: RWEMA. Pbd: Norton, CE 318–19; Slater 538.
div3.head: TC TO RALPH WALDO EMERSON

docBody.p: This will be delivered to you by The Hon. Lyulf Stanley,Edward Lyulph Stanley. an excellent, intelligent young gentn whom I have known ever since his infancy,—his Father and Mother being among my very oldest friends in London: “Lord and Lady Stanley of Alderley” (not of Knowesley,Knowsley Hall, Lancashire, seat of Edward Geoffrey Smith-Stanley (1799–1869; ODNB), 14th earl of Derby, prime minister 1852, 1858–59, and 1866–68. but a cadet branch of it), whom perhaps you did not meet while here.

My young Friend is coming to look with his own eyes at your huge and hugely-travailling Country;—and I think will agree with you, better than he does with me, in regard to that latter phenomenon. At all events, he regards “Emerson,” as intelligt Englishmen all do; and you will please me much by giving him your friendliest receptn & furtherance,—whh I can certify that he deserves for his own sake, not counting mine at all.

Probably he may deliver you the Vol 4 of Fredc;Vol. 4 of Frederick the Great was pbd. 25 Feb. he will tell you our news (part of whh, what regards my poor Wife, is very bad, tho’ God be thanked, not yet the worst);—and, in some six months, he may bring me back some human tidings from Concord, a place whh always inhabits my memory,—tho’ it is so dumb latterly!The most recent letter recorded from Emerson to TC was 8 Dec. 1862; see 39:21TC to JAC, 28 Dec. 1862.

div3.sourceNote: TC-ELS, 8 March. MS: Osborn Collection, Yale. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO EDWARD LYULPH STANLEY

docBody.p: Here is the Note for Emerson;See TC to RWE, 8 March. whh you can seal,—and may present with confidence to the best American I know.

One of the Two American CopiesCopies of vol. 4 of Frederick the Great. (Mr Butler’s)Charles Butler, who looked after TC’s American investments, lived in New York City. you will certainly get;—and I shd think Emerson’s also, unless the Bookseller (Chapman, 193. Piccadilly have already sent it off): I enclose you a Card for Butler, if you care to use it.

I will wish you a right good voyage; and that you may actually learn a great deal that is true, & that may be useful to you in after life. Occhij sciolti, bocca stretta [open eyes, closed mouth]:See 21:181TC to CGD, 15 March 1847. is not that it? The writer on NosesCharles A. Ward; see TC to CAW, 16 Feb. insists very pertinently (and with my entire assent) That everybody, almost at all times, ought to breathe thro’ his nose;—whh wd prevent, not only snoring, but infinitely worse things!—
Adieu & Bon Voyage.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 9 March. Addr: Dr Blakiston &c &c / St Leonards-on-Sea. PM: London, 9 March 1864. MS: NLS 616.577. Pbd: A. Carlyle, NL 2:219–20; Bliss, TC 360.
div3.head: TC to JWC

docBody.p: Oh my poor little Darling!—You behaved like a heroine yesterday, firm to your purpose; and surely it was a blessing you got the journey done, instead of waiting,—till today, for instance. How quiet you were, and clear and calm: my dear little suffering woman!TC wrote later: “About the beginning of January (1864) there were thought to be perceptible some faint symptoms of improvement or abatement; which she herself never durst believe in; and indeed to us eager on-lookers they were faint and uncertain—nothing of real hope, except in getting to St. Leonards so soon as the season would permit. / Early in March, weather mild though dim and wettish, this sad transit was accomplished by railway; I escorting, and visiting at every stage; Maggie Welsh and our poor patient in what they called a ‘sick carriage,’ which indeed took her up at this door, and after delays and haggles at St. Leonards, put her down at Dr. B——’s [Blakiston’s]; but was found otherwise inferior to the common arrangement for a sick person (two window-seats, with board and cushion put between), though about five or six times dearer, and was never employed again. She was carried downstairs here in the bed of this dreary vehicle (which I saw well would remind her, as it did, of a hearse, with its window for letting in the coffin); she herself, weak but clear, directed the men. So pathetic a face as then glided past me at this lower door I never saw nor shall see! And the journey—and the arrival. But of all this, which passed without accident, and which remains to myself unforgettable enough, and sad as the realms of Hades, I undertook to say nothing. / Her reception was of the very kindest; her adjustment, with Maggie and one of our maids [Mary] (in fine, airy, quiet rooms, in the big house, with the loving and skilful hosts), I saw in a few hours completed to my satisfaction, far beyond expectation. She herself said little; but sat, in her pure, simple dress, &c., looking, though sorrowful, calm and thankful” (TC’s note in Froude, LM 3:192–93). Henry Larkin also provided a detailed description of JWC’s departure from Cheyne Row: “She was decreasing in strength from day to day, and from week to week, and sinking into the saddest despondency and gloom of horror. I suppose no one who really watched her, ever thought to see her leave that bed alive. She herself had long given up all real hope. But one day she astonished me by telling me, she had made up her mind that if she must die, she might just as well die elsewhere as remain where she was, with nothing but the dreariest associations about her. She had consulted the doctors, and they had agreed that, with an invalid carriage, she might possibly still have strength to carry her as far as St. Leonards; and that, in short, she was resolved to try, even if she died upon the road. She then said, that ‘as usual’ she must depend on me to help her. She had arranged everything. An invalid carriage was to drive up to the door. She was to be lifted into it on a couch. The carriage would then drive to the station, where it would be placed on a kind of truck, and she would thus be taken from door to door, without any further exertion on her part. All she wanted me to undertake was, when all was ready, to carry her downstairs in my arms, and lay her upon the couch; the attendants would then lift her into the carriage. But, she added despairingly, ‘This time, I have insisted on Carlyle keeping out of the way till I am safe in the carriage. I don’t think you’ll find me very heavy.’ I was there at the time agreed, and carried her down as easily as if she had been a child of twelve years old. I was literally appalled at the shadow to which she had become reduced. After laying her gently upon the couch, I went to the front door to see that the carriage was ready to receive her; when I was still more shocked at the hideous receptacle to which she was, all unsuspectingly, about to be consigned; far more like a ‘hearse,’ as Carlyle calls it, than a carriage; in which the living corpse was to be slid feet first, through a small door behind! I saw at a glance the whole horror of the thing, as it would strike her; but it was too late to interfere, for she was already being carried from the home. I shall never forget the agony of the stifled shriek which she could not suppress, as they lifted and pushed her in; or the look on her face when she was in, as I stood at the side-door trying to cheer her. I do not know whether such cruelties are still practised on helpless invalids in the name of mercy, but I earnestly hope not. As soon as she had sufficiently recovered herself, Carlyle (who was not before present, as he afterwards imagined) was sent for; and I bade her good-bye, deeply feeling that it was the last poor service I should ever render her. But the end was not yet; for, after many months of suffering, she came back to us seemingly almost herself again” (Larkin, BQR 77–79). —

I saved my train, by probably the nearest miss even I ever made. Two seconds more wd have been fatal to it! I saw no carriage or omnibus; missed the road a little (quite at the end); and had to come in at a run, run,Word repeated at top of next page. shouting like
“stop thief!”— I got home in good time; found a good fire &c: but, alas, a house too silent, and gone all into the gaunt mood to one’s poor sunk heart. If I cd have burst into a passion of tears, it wd have been some relief.See also Carlyle, Reminiscences 172–73. I finished off my Proof; and went timefully to bed. For Maggy there was the enclosed Letter; and this morning for self the inclosed Mrs Kemble’s:Frances (“Fanny”) Kemble (1809–93; ODNB), actress, author, abolitionist, and feminist; see 25:124TC to JAC, 22 July 1850. After her divorce, 1848, from Pierce Butler (1806–67), Kemble lived between England, Philadelphia, and Lennox, MA; in 1863 she retired from giving solo public readings in Britain and the U.S. and also pbd. Journal of a Residence in a Georgian Plantation in 1838–1839, a record of her stay at Butler’s plantations where she formed her abolitionist views. I have not told her to call for you.The Carlyles were critical of Fanny Kemble; see 9:110–11TC to JCA, 29 Dec. 1836, and 134JWC to JOST, 1 Feb. 1837. Oh if I cd but hear some good news of my poor Jeannie’s sleep tomorrow morng! I try to live in hope. Surely, surely the shaking and the change will do something for you— I think perhaps you will have to get a house of yr own? But you need do nothing rashly.— God keep my Darling for me. Amen. T. C.

div3.sourceNote: MW-Lady A [LLA], [9 March]. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Hitherto unpbd. Dated by JWC’s and Margaret Welsh’s arrival at St. Leonards, Tues. 8 March.
div3.head: MARGARET WELSH TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.dateline: 5 Warrior Square St Leonard’s-on-Sea Wednesday [9 March 1864]
docBody.p: Mrs Carlyle bids me give you her dearest love & to thank you so very much for so very kindly granting her request, & so quickly!

Just as she was speaking of the Grange this afternoon, the little hamper arrived. She says I am to ask you if Mrs MackenzieMaria Louisa Mackenzie, Lady Ashburton’s widowed sister-in-law, often referred to as “Mrs. George.” will be so very kind as sometimes to write to let her know how Lord Ashburton is, as she has not the same opportunities of hearing here as at Chelsea, & as you well know how anxious she is to hear. I do think that you may be cheered by seeing continued improvement, for a most anxious time of watching you must have had indeed.

I know you will be rejoiced to hear that Mrs Carlyle really is here. We came yesterday, & most thankful we were to find that she bore the journey better than we had ventured to hope. She was very tired of course, that was truly to be expected. She scarcely slept however at all last night, & today she is very much the same as she has been for so long. Though they seemed to hope some immediate improvement (at least some did) it was really too much to expect
that, & one must hope & pray that in a little time we really may see some good effect come from the pure air & the change of scene. Mr Carlyle returned home last evening, & he means to come again very soon to see how she goes on; he has not been looking at all well himself poor man, for the last week, I dare say he will be the better of the complete quiet at home.

closer.salute: I am / Dear Lady / Respectfully yours /

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, [10 March]. Addr: Dr Blakiston’s / St Leonards on Sea. PM: London, 10 March 1864. MS: NLS 616.578. Pbd: Bliss, TC 360–61.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Alas, Darling, I expected better than “one hour”;—but I must be content! Yesterday was nothing but sleet & windy snow; sore upon the eyes, as one galloped thro’ it. Today is sunny; and if you dare try a bit of Bath chair on the beach—. But I almost fear too, so much frost is in the air.

I am silent here, as in Hades; silent, and was never sadder in my days. Am only getting fastened to work;—Consider if I can all at once. Except news from Hastings & that I have no other consolatn. — — Various persons calling for you (the Blunts, Miss Bromley &c);Rev. Gerald and Frances Blunt; Caroline Davenport Bromley. half a word from the Dr,TC’s brother John A. Carlyle. that (t. o.) thatWord repeated at turn of page. “Dr Russell’sDr. James Russell, husband of JWC’s friend Mary. Copy of Vol. 4 is arrived, & forwarded“:—vacancy, filled with the inane, is all all else to me.— A word tomorrow, Oh Maggie don’t neglect!Maggie Welsh was writing for JWC during this period of her illness.
There has come a Hare & Pot of Jelly from the Grange: What to do with the latter? Say, Maggie;—and send good news, if you but cd!

closer.salute: My blessings & prayers for the sole Treasure I have left.

docBody.name: T. C.

ps.p: Thursday 3 p.m. }
uttermost haste

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 11 March. Addr: Dr Blakiston &c &c / St Leonards-on-Sea. PM: London, 11 March 1864. MS: NLS 616.579. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p:
Dearest—Oh what a Note was Maggie’s to me yesternight before tea. She deserves a crown of gold. I have not been so glad for many months.— Alas,
I do dread some reversal too; we never have a smooth course. But don’t be discouraged for reversal, you poor soul; surely things are on the mending hand,—in spite of such weather.

I meant a strenuous night of work, after such a bulletin as that of yesternight: but tea was not done, when WoolnerThomas Woolner. came in,—loud as ever;—and my night went wentWord repeated at top of page. adrift, in the old way.

I have written for four dozen at Maldonado;TC noted: “21 March 1864 / (Hutchison & Co Leith, wine for Hastings,—ah me!) / £10..10..0” (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753). it will come by the First Steamer, & then to you in few hours more. I rejoice in yr 4 glasses,—that was always my own view. The KittensThe Carlyles always kept a cat to discourage mice. are safe (tell Maggy), and known to be “all bespoke, Sir.” I have recd nothing, or as good; I have not a moment left. God bless you, Dearest; thank Maggy for me.
docBody.name: T. C.

ps.p: Chelsea 11 March 1864

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 14 [12] March. MS: NLS 616.580. Hitherto unpbd. TC misdated; dated by his reference here to “Friday night” and his reference in TC to JWC, [15 March ], to having not visited Ruskin “that day,” i.e., Sat. 12 March.
div3.head:
TC
TO JWC

docBody.p: Dearest,— I am not much disappointed at the inferior news;—things must fluctuate; perhaps I shall hear something better as to Friday night, before tea agn. Oh that I might, that I might! But we must have patience, and expect humbly.

I am getting on with Work (totally solitary, nothing else to drive away the gloom); in the course of tomorrow (I hope, but know the hope to be fond) I shall perhaps have done with a certain ugly bundle of scraps;—and, more certainly, if I be diligt and lucky, the whole of Vol. V (with my blessing to it) may be in the Printer’s hands!Although Robson & Levey had gone bankrupt (see TC to JAC, 12 Jan.
), Robson continued as TC’s printer; his new firm was Robson & Son; they printed vols. 5 and 6 of Frederick, 1865. A thing to rejoice over almost with tears.— — I had no intentn of Hastings today; nor indeed till you yourself wished me. The jumble of that hideous railway railwayWord repeated at top of page.
 process is more hideous to me every time I try it. My own private notion, if things went well, was, to return when 
Vol V. was out of the Printer’s hands. But I will come any day & any hour my own poor Jeannie asks me. Understand that always.

Today while the Sun is so good, and the wind westerly (only too much of it), I figure to myself the possibility (little more) of a Bath chair & the Beach;—but I hope the DrDr. Peyton Blakiston. will forbid if there be risk. I myself had thot of riding to Denmark Hill;The Ruskins’ home, SE London. I have not seen poor Ruskin since loss of his Father,Ruskin’s father, John James Ruskin, d. 3 March. Ruskin wrote, [1 March]: “I should have been over to see you but my father is sharply ill and has needed me to be with him the past two or three days—it was all this dreadful frost— I’ll write again as soon as he is better.” He then wrote, 12 March, after his father’s death: “You will not think it was out of thoughtlessness or disrespect that I have not written to you. You had enough sorrow of your own, and could by no means help us in ours. … My mother and I are in all practical and necessary ways able for what has come upon us. She is very wonderful to me; I have little doubt but that I may yet, if I am spared, procure her some years of no false or slight, but peaceful and hopeful, happiness.”—whh is doubtless a very sombre event to him. Enclosed are all that came this morning: of whh Maggie will read to you what you can endure. No ansr to any of them. The jelly has landed in Roystondom;William Haylett Royston and his wife, Isabella, who lived at 1 Cheyne Row. the Hare had at once gone to Smith in expectn of mutton.Exchanging the hare (sent from The Grange) for mutton; presumably at the butcher’s, Benjamin Smith, 67 King’s Rd., Chelsea.
Adieu my Darling; God keep thee.
docBody.name: T. C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady S [LST], 14 March. MS: Strouse. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO LADY HENRIETTA STANLEY

docBody.p: You are very tempting:—and if I could get done with this hideous mass of Printer’s Proofs— But, alas, I dare not promise! Unless you see me in the afternoon,At 40 Dover St., the Stanleys’ London home. expect &c: let us have it so. The Hastings news are favourable!—

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, [14 March]. Addr: Dr Blakiston &c &c / St Leonards on Sea. PM: London, 14 March 1864. MS: NLS 1774.249. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Alas, my Darling! Maggie’s news of this morning have quite cast me down;—and I am very miserable, in spite of all I can say to rebuke myself for such “surrender to the power of imaginatn.” I did fear on Saturday evg when no Note came (after a kind of promise), that something not so good was going on, but I hoped for this morning,—and lo it is worse!

The truth is, I quite mismanaged myself yesterday; and am prone to take miserable views: I will therefore add nothing;—but agn draw upon Hope. God keep my one dear Treasure to me!— Thank Maggie for her punctuality on my behalf.

Nothing but the LeithPossibly a note from Hutchison & Co., Leith wine merchants, announcing the arrival of wine; see TC to JWC, 11 March. announcet is worth enclosing (“Miss Willis Sir,Probably Eleanor Willis, eldest da. of Dr. Robert Willis. and the ’Oss!”). Oh adieu

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, [15 March]. Addr: Dr Blakiston &c &c / St Leonards-on-Sea. PM: London, 15 March 1864. MS: NLS 616.580. Quot: Froude, Carlyle 4:275.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Well, Dearest, it is better than yesterday; better than nothing; we must be content, and agn hope. I am round agn today and getting some work done.— I was well left alone last night; and sat a[t]Letter omitted. least silent amid my glooms

I did not get to Ruskin that day; Neuberg rode up, one moment too soon; grown fairly deafish, and uglier than ever. Sunday, came TrollopAnthony Trollope. to “inquire for Mrs C” (his inquiry an offence to me); I instantly walked him out—but had to go talking with him mere fire-&-brimstone upon suet-dumpling (progress of the species &c &c),Trollope wrote to George Henry Lewes (1817–78; ODNB; see 39:27239:biographical notes), 21 March, “I went to see Carlyle last week. Oh, heavens;—what a mixture of wisdom & folly flows from him!” (Letters of Anthony Trollope, ed. N. John Hall [Stanford, 1983] 1:258). all the way to Hyde Park. What does the foolish ball of tallow want with me?— Afterwds Miss Bromley while I was stooping to tie my shoe came up;—bland-looking in the cold, but kind and good: talks of
perhaps coming down “for three days” (in the Holiday time) to a Hôtel on the chance of seeing you. &c &c
Oh my Darling, that you cd but write one scrape of a pen to me agn! Alas, I know not whether you can even bear to have those scrapings read to you?
Does Maggie recollect any Book here she wd wish to have? Thanks to her always. And may my news tomorrow be rather good,—alas, yes!— And God bless you, poor little Darling.
docBody.name: T. C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, [16 March]. Addr: Dr. Blakiston &c &c / St Leonards-on-Sea. PM: London, 16 March 1864. MS: NLS 616.581. Quot: Bliss, TC 361.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Oh my Darling, how thankful am I to hear of the small bit of good appearance, good or at least better, this morning! I had slept too long; and ran out with the Note; half-reading it, in my frozen conditn. Small, but to appearance real: we will be thankful for the day of small things.Cf. Zech. 4:10. Today is so bright, too; you will be out driving, I can hope. Medicine does lie in the blessed Spring weather if in nothing else. What kind of “carriage” have you (let Maggie say); or is it but a Bath Chair, & she walking by yr side?—— Yesterday I went to Ruskin’s, tho’ rain came on by the theWord repeated at top of page. way. Rn was calmer than usual; really good,—and perhaps will be profited by this stroke. His poor old mother seemed to be a new interest for him (very calm she, he said, and not complaining at all); he professed himself overwhelmed with busss,—and cd not guess where Lady VermillionLady Trevelyan; Ruskin wrote, 12 March, “To-day I have a note from Lady Trevelyan saying Mrs. Carlyle is much better.” had got her fine tidings. The rain & the delay cut off my Nap altogether; hence my lateness this morning. EllenThe Carlyles’ new maid, perhaps hired by Maggie Welsh. (tell Maggie) does very well; and wd be a clever hizzy, really a superior servt,—were my own poor Goody back to take comand:Line over “m” indicates double “m.” ah me, ah me! But that too is coming, please God.— Last night, from The Grange a “Hare & 2 rabbits with a big pot of jelly, Sir“:— Let Maggie write to The Grange, forbidding. Smith has got the Hare &c; not yet Royston the jelly; but shall, unless I hear from Mie otherwise. Adieu, Dearest
docBody.name: T. C.

div3.sourceNote: MW-[MLSM], [17 March]. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: MARGARET WELSH TO [MARIA LOUISA STEWART-MACKENZIE]

docBody.dateline: 5 Warrior Square St Leonard’s-on-Sea Thursday [17 March 1864]
docBody.p: Mrs Carlyle bids me thank you very much for your last letter & its better news. She says it will be very kind if you will again, when you have leisure, send just two lines to say how Lord Ashburton is. She sends her kindest love to yourself & to Lady Ashburton. Will you please say from her to Lady Ashburton that Mr Carlyle mentions having received another hamper from the Grange containing hares & & a large jar of jelly. As he himself never does take either hare or the jelly Mrs Carlyle thinks it is too bad that Lady Ashburton should so mindfully be ordering them to be sent. Mr Carlyle did not like to say this himself!

I do think I may give you a better report of Mrs Carlyle. She is certainly in every respect stronger than when we came, but she herself says that she has suffered for so long now that she feels as if she had but little courage or hope to aid her recovery. Those around her however do in many ways see improvements, more almost than could have been expected in so short a time & bye & bye I cannot help hoping she herself will begin really to feel amendment. She has had several short drives, & she is eating well. The sleeping too is on the whole better, but she still feels as if it did not refresh her as good sleep should. She bids me say that if kind nursing & good doctoring could do good she feels that she should be better. Dr & Mrs Blakiston are truly most kind in every way.

closer.salute: I am / Dear Madam / Respectfully yours /

ps.p: I have quite forgotten to say how very glad Mrs Carlyle is to hear a good account of the dear little girl.Mary Florence Baring.
Mrs Carlyle says will you give her dear love to Lord Ashburton.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, [17 March]. Addr: Dr Blakiston &c &c / St Leonards-on-Sea. PM: London, 17 March 1864. MS: NLS 616.582. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Maggie’s Note is more comfortable to me today than ever. Courage, my own little Heroine; you must take heart agn! It is evidt to me that I can hope a slow improvet; that I can hope all things. Let us thank God; and wait patiently— —

Hoity-toity: “The two Miss StanleysMaude and Kate Stanley. come to ride with you, Sir” (and I all in deshabille, my Proofs done a minute ago;—and need a clean shirt too)!— I wish the Miss Stanleys had chosen another day.— But, on the whole, what more had I? Nothing but repetitn of what you already know. Blessings on you all.
docBody.name: T. C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 18 March. Addr: Dr Blakiston &c &c / St Leonards on Sea. PM: London, 18 March 1864. MS: NLS 616.583. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p:
Let us be thankful, Dearest (tho’ you don’t believe it);—oh what a blessing are those tidings Maggie sends today. I feel as if I now durst fairly hope & believe that a visible tho’ slow improvet was actually begun. Take care of this cold March weather; it is bitterly cold, tho’ bright with Sun. When the west wind returns, that too will surely be an advantage to you. I am sorry you are cut out of yr poor little bit of fragrance! Don’t be cut out: yr DrDr. Peyton Blakiston. is a wise man in his art, and knows many things hidden from the like of me: but the innocent superlative virtues of tobacco in pacifying irritated nerves,—there is a point on whh he cannot (nobody witht experience of it can) be enlightened as I am! Tell him so, if you like;—and in fine, anyway, do you thus “think & smoke tobacco!”For the “Song on Tobacco,” see 39:183–84TC to JAC, 16 Sept. 1863.— The Stanley girls (Maud & Kate) gave me an immense gallop yesterday;—whh I suppose tended to good. In the evg while out walking for tea, intending finish of proofs next, I found an umbrella in the hall, and to enlighten the gloom of my solitude FarieRobert Farie. sitting upstairs! Poor Farie he seemed really interested abt you beyond many handsomer people that ask; —
had been in Rome all this while, seen Twisleton,Edward Twisleton. seen &c:—I gave him some tea, and marched him off in good time for my proofs.— Vol V will, I hope, be all off to Printer abt Monday morng: give the man two weeks to hustle thro’ it. This day fortnight, if all have gone well at St Leonards too, I may be thinking of a return ticket and a sight (Oh Heaven) of my poor Goody after that tragic Tuesday!Tues., 8 March, when TC took JWC to St. Leonards.— ForsterJohn Forster. (I suppose he has written, & forced Maggie to write) insists on a “family dinner (nobody but ourselves there, dear Carlyle)” on Sunday next. I cd have well wished it other; but no help. Adieu, Blessings on you T.C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-UC, 19 March. MS: Strouse. Hitherto unpbd. TC frequently used the “Piper had a Cow” rhyme for autographs; see TC to LS, 12 Aug. 1860.
div3.head: TC TO UNIDENTIFIED CORRESPONDENT

lg.l: ‘There was a Piper had a Cow, and he had nought to give her;
He took his pipes and play’d a spring, and bade the Cow consider:
The Cow consider’d wi’ hersel’ that mirth wad ne’er fill her,
“Gie me a pickle pease-strae, and sell your wind for siller!”—’

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, [19 March]. Addr: Dr Blakiston &c &c / St Leonards on Sea. PM: London, 19 March 1864. MS: NLS 616.584. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Oh dear, oh dear! But I privately dreaded it— Things never go long smooth; and besides this weather is really poisonous more or less. God grant I may get a touch of better news this night! Or perhaps Maggie may not have sent me anything; whh will be as bad (in my imaginn) as the truth itself cd well be in reality!—

The big floundering womanThe new maid, Helen, also often called Hellen or Ellen. instead of warning me ¼ to 3, warns me “5 minutes to 3, Sir!” Alas, Darling I am myself rather low,—bothered to half madness by Proofs that won’t do, by &c &c;—but I will not let myself get gloomy. No, no,—nor shall you, I swear! Except FuzJohn Forster. (ansd “Yes” to get done
with him, poor kind Fuz!) I have recd nothing. God be with thee Dearest. — T.C. (Saturday 3 p.m.).

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 21 March. Addr: Dr Blakiston &c &c / St Leonards on Sea. PM: London, 21 March 1864. MS: NLS 616.585. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Dearest I hoped to write a little more liberally to you today; but it is agn “Quarter to 3, Sir,” before I get fairly rallied. No matter;—alas, I know not whether you still care much abt reading even from me. Maggie says you do read me, however; whh is much.

You may judge what a relief to me Maggie’s little word at tea on Saty was, after the bad morning-bulletin! Today agn is rather bad; alas we always go wavering. The wind is now southeast, sky mainly grey; I think it will work to rain perhaps, & that will mean west-wind. Cower quiet, my poor little soul, and wait.

I got my vol V finished (in a way) yesterday—it will surely be out of my hands altogether before Saturday week! I did not get on well yesterday afternoon. Had to go to the Stanleys with news of you; found nothing there but chaos (in the talking way) as usual;—was hurried to catch Fuz’s time: got little profit by the Fuz dinner, tho’ it was pleast enough, & hospitable as the Sun! Nobody there but BrowningRobert Browning. and an old Mr DyceAlexander Dyce (1798–1869; ODNB), literary scholar, published a revised version of his 1857 edn. of Shakespeare between 1863 and 1867. William Shakespeare (1564–1616; ODNB), playwright and poet. Scotchman, Comentr on Shakespear, innoct old man); the talk was tolerably good, dinner unimpeachably so: I slept all night as if I had dined at home; nevertheless I had walked home in the profoundest sadness; and today still I am far enough from “happy.“— I found, howr I had escaped TaitRobert Scott Tait (1816–97), portrait painter and pioneer photographer; friend of the Carlyles since 1853; he lived at 14 Queen Anne St., Cavendish Sq., with his wife, Harriet, b. Wilson (b. 1832), m. 1859, and their da., Mildred (1860–1950). He painted TC’s portrait, 1854–55 (see 31:84TC to AGI, 6 May 1856), and A Chelsea Interior, 1857–58 (see 33:196–97JWC to MR, 29 Mar [1858]). & other undesirables.

Maggie may like to read Walter’s letter, whh John (to save writing of his own) has inclosed to me.John A. Carlyle wrote, 20 March: “Yesterday I had a letter from Walter Welsh, which is hardly worth enclosing. He is to be here this week & I may see him.”
docBody.name: T. C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 22 March. MS: NLS 526.14. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: Dear Brother,—Perhaps these items (whh explains themselves) may interest you for a moment;—you can then send Jean her part of them.TC and his siblings regularly sent family letters on to each other; John A. Carlyle wrote, 20 March: “I received your welcome package of letters yesterday morning, & immediately forwarded them to Dumfries where Jean would get them last night. … I read the whole of your fourth volume, & it seems to me quite as good as any of the others; but the quantity of laborious work that lies in it is very painfully great to my imagination. I am glad to hear that the fifth volume is nearly off your hands. Would that the remaining part were fairly done & ended! I trust it may cost you somewhat less labour than the rest, as you do not mean to go into details & have space enough for it.” Hastings news still fluctuates, and I can only keep obstinately hoping that there is a recovery tho’ a slow.— Poor Robertson’sJohn Robertson (1811–75), journalist, known to the Carlyles since 1837; see 9:337TC to JSM, 30 Oct. 1837, and 10:137TC to JAC, 27 July 1838. According to JWC, Geraldine Jewsbury and Robertson had a brief flirtation, 1845; see 19:41JWC to JW, [26 Feb. 1845], and 49JWC to JW, [5 April 1845]. Shadow authentically emerging, with a new Bride in hand; instead of being dead as we heard, will touch yr memory on various points pointsWord repeated at turn of page. of the near & distant Past!— The Bride, now Wife is, I think, a Surgeon’s Daughter in Brighton;—old Surgeon must I think be dead; for he came here two years ago, consulting as to charactr &c of Robson,Robertson.—was informed that the excellt Robertsn “had already a kind of Wife—was she dead?” upon whh the old Surgeon forbade.The last reference to Robertson was July 1860, when he was contemplating a new marriage, although his current wife was still alive; see 36:145–46TC to JAC, 7 July 1860. Both wives and the surgeon are unidentified. For an earlier reference to a Robertson wife, see 19:127JWC to TC, [3 Aug. 1845].
Weather is dirty frosty reeky; Vol VI ought to be getting on faster than it is! Adieu
T.C. (Chelsea, 22 March 1864)

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 22 March. Addr: Dr Blakiston &c &c / St Leonards on Sea. PM: London, 22 March 1864. MS: NLS 616.586. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p:
Dearest, Yr message to me is very wae this morning, and makes my heart sad;—but then the practical news is a little better: no wonder my poor we[e]Letter omitted. Lassie’s heart is altogether broken, for the prest, and her courage quite gone, as she often tells me it is! I privately, all along, ascribe a good deal to this
hostile weather, too: it is positively venomous upon the human skin, and thro’ that upon the human soul and body generally. Pluck up a heart, my darling; I know you will before long.

I have been totally alone and dumb since Sunday night; whh, tho’ sometimes the gloomiest way, is generally the best. Russell (of Harley Street)John Rutherfurd Russell (1816–66), physician to the London Homeopathic Hospital, living at 3 Harley St.; see 33:246–47TC to JRR, 21 June 1858. He was probably the Russell who visited TC in 1862, rather than A. J. E. Russell, M.P. for Tavistock, previously identified; see 38:140TC to JWC, [14 Aug. 1862]. wishes to know what evg I shd like to receive him, his BrotherRussell had three surviving brothers: William (b. 1805), Archibald (b. 1811), and Francis (b. 1814); the fourth brother was James (1801–62). and (if we are all lucky) on[e] Macdonald,Letter omitted. George MacDonald (1824–1905; ODNB; see 38:139–40TC to JWC, [14 Aug. 1862]), poet and novelist. He suffered throughout his life from lung disease and was a friend and patient of Rutherfurd Russell, whom he met at Leamington in 1853. Russell’s views on homeopathy influenced MacDonald, who dedicated his novel Adela Cathcart (1864) to him “affectionately”; see F. Hal Broome, “The Scientific Basis of George MacDonald’s Dream-Frame,” The Gold Thread. Essays on George Macdonald, ed. William Raeper (Edinburgh, 1990) 107.—whom I had difficulty to recollect for a tawty, dishevelled, noisy good natured blockhead once here before!MacDonald visited Cheyne Row in 1862, when TC described him as “blossomy,” “pock-marked, grizzled”; see 38:145TC to JWC, 17 [16] Aug. 1862. “Tawty” (tattie) used as an adjective, possibly meaning dirty. I light my pipe with the Project; and ansr nothing. Jean’s Letter came yesterday; but you may still read it. Her sympathy with you (not to speak of me) I perceive well to be genuine, & perhaps among the truest to my own in this world.

What an apparitn was that of the poor oorie Robertson coarse as life, and actually wedded to his new Dear! Is the old DrRobertson’s wife’s father was a surgeon; see TC to JAC, 22 March. dead then? Not a bad looking woman at all,—of the sappy and solid type; too good for where she is gone!—

Fuz on Sunday night had formed a magnificent project of St Leonards on Saturday come a week: Mrs F & he (being birthday of somebody),Forster’s birthday was Sat., 2 April. I to be their guest at the Hôtel &c &c in short a most sanguine hospitable Fuz! To whom I ansd, if all were right, how beautiful!—and so it hangs: you can check it, do with it (at least with me in it) whatever you like.— Maggie’s providt Letters (Oh you dear vigilt Goody) go the Post with this. Blessings on my poor little Wifie.
docBody.name: T.C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 23 March. Addr: Dr Blakiston &c &c / St Leonards on Sea. PM: London, 23 March 1864. MS: NLS 616.587. Quot: Bliss, TC 361–62.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Maggie’s Letter (whh I read with frozen hands agn, or half-read,—having slept too long) is agn comfortable to me: yes, poor Darling tho’ you are always in low spirits abt yourself; whh how can I wonder at, considering what you have come thro’ for six months past! If you can sleep, and eat, and go out daily driving in the blessed sunshine, in the breath of the sea, I have a firm outlook of my own that relief is gradually witht doubt coming to us. Dr Bln tells me himself you have ‘walked twice from the Drawingroom to yr little brougham’: downstairs;—did you actually walk then? Maggie did not mentn the fact. The Dr writes hopefully abt you in all ways;—but what I believe in, still better than in any Dr in this case, is the Spring Sunshine & the coming Summer—motherly to all living things. Courage, courage!—

Last night as I sat over my Proof (abt 8 p.m.), just finishing preparatory to tea, and a hopeful evg of work,—tip-tip-tap, a knock came to the door, and “Mr Ballantyne, Sir!”Thomas Ballantyne; see 39:118TC to MCON, 3 May 1863. TC generally wrote well of Ballantyne; see 30:66TC to WM, 15 Sept. 1855, and 33:183TC to LG, 14 Feb. 1858. For JWC’s response to him, see 30:204JWC’s Journal, 21 Oct. 1855. (figure with what ecstacy of welcome) walked in! Dirty coughy creature, why shd my poor life, in this press of time, be made shorter by thee? I did not, cd not fling the poor creeping body out of window;—and it was far past 10 before I got rid of him. Whh deranged all; kept me up too late &c &c Ah me!— Dr B speaks as if, at present he wd rather not have me come down, lest I excite &c: but do you consider it for yrself; & settle wholly as you wd like. A bright day, this; and probably you are driving. God be with you, Darling
docBody.name: T.C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady A [LLA], 24 March. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p:
Alas, dear Lady, here is the end then; come suddenly on us; and all is over!Lord Ashburton d. Wed., 23 March, 1:30 P.M., at The Grange. The Times, 24 March, reported that the “melancholy event … was comparatively unexpected. His Lordship had almost entirely recovered from the series of pulmonary attacks under which he had recently suffered, but expired suddenly from heart disease, to which he had been subject from youth.” Dr. David Christison sent TC the news; see TC to JWC, 24 March. David Christison (1830–1912), physician and archaeologist; Lord Ashburton’s physician for the last two years of Ashburton’s life (Surtees, Ludovisi 99). I had been nursing myself in fond hopes, as perhaps you had;—and the shock
to me, this morning, is great. To me also an Epoch is closed, much, how much, henceforth is forever hidden from my eyes! He could not say adieu to you; his Last word to you was “a smile,” —smile never to be forgotten, while remembrance lasts in this world. He was always always beautifully noble, concerned for others beyond himself. I believe you may feel that you have faithfully done your duty to him. I believe you have been the unspeakable blessing of his life during these years now done. This may be a kind of Consolation, when Time shall have softened the first poignancy of your feelings.
I need not bid you be firm; you have been used to be that;—and will act out, with composed clear mind, the businesses that yet remain.

To my poor Wife this will be a sore stroke tomorrow morning; but I cannot spare it her. As to me, if there be anything I can do, anywhither I can go,—on behoof of you, or of the memory of Him whom I have lost— But that I need not mention.
May God be with you, dear Friend, & with the dear little Child you still have.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 24 March. Addr: Dr Blakiston &c &c / St Leonards on Sea. PM: London, 24 March 1864. MS: NLS 616.588. Quot: Bliss, TC 362.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Alas, Darling, here is sad news, not from Hastings; but to be added to what is there! Poor Lord Ashburton is gone. Perhaps you have heard already? I send you Christison’s Letter: it gave a pungent shock to me, when I had done reading Maggie’s. That final “smile,” while making the sudden exit, is a thing one will never forget.— I have written a few words to the poor Lady.

Last night was agn stolen from me, in a scarcely tolerable manner: those two RussellsSee TC to JWC, 22 March. (tho’ I had not ansd at all) came on all the same; and found me with my back to the jamb, just abt going out for the Ante-tea bit of walk; it was near 11 before I got rid of the useless creatures. Tonight I have specifically ordered, “Nobody to be admitted”; and intend to have a fair tussel with my sheets.

Maggy does not tell me, the last two times, how much of sleep you have. Let her always mentn that, like a good bairn. I persist in ascribing much of yr lowness (how much I cannot say, but am sure of something in that item) to the dirty frost-air we have. It is quite wretched even to me who can walk. Oh
continue eating what yr poor faculty is up to; drink yr four glasses; drive out daily in the sunshine in the sea-air: Medicine I do know lies there, if it do not anywhere else!— Settle abt Saty come a week, just as you find it reasonable & desirable; there is still plenty of time. “’Oss, Sir!”— Adieu, Darling: I am very sad;—but shall get better in the open air, in company of my little Horse, instead of worse!

Helen is busy (at last) with the Two Rooms, Mrs SouthamElizabeth Southam, presumably helping the new maid with her work. with her: She does very well; punctually to bed & up: in fact she is a leish swift-handed hizzie, and needs only my poor Goody to have her in hand. God bless you, Dearest
T.C. (Chelsea March 24 1864)

div3.sourceNote: JWC-Lady A [LLA], [25 March]. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Pbd: Wilson, Carlyle 541; Hansons, NE 517–18. Written on black bordered paper, probably before JWC to WDO, [25 March], and JWC to AGEW, [25 March], news of Lord Ashburton’s death perhaps inspiring those letters’ gloomy tone.
div3.head: JWC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p: Oh my Darling! My Darling! I have only been told now— The DrDr. Blakiston. ordered it should be kept from me till this morning.

Oh God Comfort you! if ever there was a man ready to pass from this sorrowful earth to be an angel in Heaven it was he! My spirit flies to your dear side, while my poor body is chained here with a cruel malady that I believe will prove fatal; tho the Drs hold out hopes still— Oh God! it is among the few things for which I pray to be spared in life a little longer, this that I might prove to you my love and gratitude.
Oh do not forget me and may your kindness to me help to warm your own sad heart.Lady Ashburton replied 4 April; see JWC to TC, [8 April].

div3.sourceNote: JWC-WD [WDO], [25 March]. MS: NLS 1797.215. Hitherto unpbd. Dated by MW to WDO, [25 March], written on the reverse.
div3.head: JWC TO WILLIAM DODS

docBody.p: I was pleased that you wrote to ask for me— True kind friend to the last!— Yes! I fear the last is near— The Drs hold out hopes that I myself am not hopeful. I will bid my cousinMaggie Welsh. tell you all about me
God Bless you and yours—this is a solemn blessing; for it may be the last words you ever hear from you[r] affectionate
docBody.name: Jeanie Welsh

div3.sourceNote: MW-WD [WDO], [25 March]. MS: NLS 1797.215. Hitherto unpbd. Dated with reference to their arrival in St. Leonards “a fortnight ago,” 8 March.
div3.head: MARGARET WELSH TO WILLIAM DODS

docBody.dateline: 5, Warrior Square St. Leonard’s-on-sea Friday [25 March 1864]
docBody.p: My cousin has asked me to enclose her note for you, which I feel sure you will be pleased to see. I fear the account of herself which she may have given will not be very hopeful nor can one wonder after such a long & trying illness. We came here a fortnight ago, & I am most thankful to say that we do think there is some improvement; more the doctor says than she really feels, at least that, he says, is his impression, I would fain hope he may be correct, & that ere long we really may see my Cousin stronger. She is able to go almost every day for a short drive, her appetite is good & she is sleeping on the whole better than for a long time she has done. Still she is in, I fear, a very precarious state & it will be, at the best, long ere she regain her former measure of health which for so long has been but feeble. Mr Carlyle came with us here but he has returned home. He is to be back ere long for a day or two. Cousin is staying with her friends Dr & Mrs Blakiston, who are indeed most kind to us all. Mrs Carlyle bids me say to you that she will take it very kind if Mrs Dodds will sometimes look after Miss WelshJWC’s cousin Jackie Welsh. who she fears is very poorly. I wrote to her a short time ago, for she seems so anxious, poor thing, to hear about Mrs Carlyle.

closer.salute: I am / Dear Sir / Yours very truly /

div3.sourceNote: JWC-AW, GW, and EW [AGEW], [25 March]. MS: NLS 608.627. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:197; Fielding and Sorensen 297. Quot: Ireland, JWC 287. Dated by MW to GWE, [25 March], written on the second leaf of the paper, in which she wrote that Lord Ashburton had just died. Date confirmed by the letter’s similarity to JWC to WDO, [25 March]. Froude dated the letter “end of April,” with TC noting: “Probably still in Dr. B——’s house there. The next letter is expressly dated from the new hired house. Maggie still there, but just about to leave” (TC’s note in Froude, LM 3:197).
div3.head: JWC TO ANN, GRACE, AND ELIZABETH WELSH

docBody.p: I take you to my heart and kiss you fondly one after another. God knows if we shall ever meet again! and His will be done!— My Dr has hopes of my recovery. but I myself am not hopeful, my sufferings are terrible— The malady is in my womb— You may fancy!— It is the consequence of that unlucky fall—no disease there the Drs say, but some nervous derangement— Oh what I have suffered my Aunts! What I may still have to suffer!— Pray for me that I may be enabled to endure!
Dont write to myself reading letters excites me too much— And Maggie tells me all I should hear— I commend you to the Lords keeping—whether I live or die, Ah my Aunts I shall die, that is my belief.
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle
docBody.note: TC wrote later on the MS in blue pencil: “St Leonds (1863): oh, sad!” He also wrote at the top of the MS: “St. Leonard’s, end of April, 1864,” and at the foot: “end of April, 1864.”

div3.sourceNote: MW-GW [GWE], [25 March]. MS: 608.627. Hitherto unpbd. This note was written on the second leaf of the paper used for JWC to AGEW, [25 March].
div3.head: MARGARET WELSH TO GRACE WELSH

p.note: TC wrote later above salutation: “This leaf omit.”

docBody.p:
I do think you will all in some measure be pleased to see Cousin’s own short letter; I fear the account she may have given you will not be a very hopeful one, nor can I wonder. Dr Blakiston does consider her in many respects better & I do myself think she is. I confess I cannot feel so sanguine of any thing like the recovery he seems to hope for, still I have felt all through her illness that the doctors of course could judge far better than we could of an illness which is so decidedly very much on the nerves. I would like to see her more hopeful of her own recovery (as being really a better sign of her) but that feeling also may be a part of the illness. We can but trust & hope as you
say, for these things are in better hands than ours. This morning she has had very sorrowful news. Poor Lord Ashburton died on Wednesday.23 March; see TC to Lady ALLA, 24 March. He has been so ill for long that his death can scarcely be called sudden, still in the end it was sudden but most peaceful & gentle. It will be a sad distress to both Mr Carlyle & Cousin. I will hope to write soon again. With love Yours very sincerely / Margt Welsh

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 25 March. Addr: Dr Blakiston &c &c / St Leonards on Sea. PM: London, 25 March 1864. MS: NLS 616.589. Hitherto unpbd. The letter was apparently written in the afternoon, after TC’s ride.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Poor Darling, I am glad the news from thee are not worse;—let us be thankful, Oh be thankful and hope!— They call this “Good Friday”; but it is a very ugly Friday with dirty reeky fog and frost,—nothing good in it specially, but the absence of Italn organs,TC hated the noise made by organ-grinders; see 37:203TC to JWC, 7 Aug. 1861; presumably the organ-grinders, if Italian Catholics, observed Good Friday. and the deep silence whh I do consider a blessing. Yesternight nobody came; nobody cd get in (by order), if he had. My Proofs were a little refractory, however, and my hand rather feeble: I have done the best I cd,—till unpleasantly informed “10 minutes to 3 Sir!”— The ride is always medicinal. Alas, alas, one is very sad of heart; sad, and lonesome more and more, in this ever fluctuating world.—— I have spoken no word to anybody,—except three or so to Forster, who was waiting in the street, when I came home last night. Loyal to take yr decisn as to Hastings on Saturday week;—zealous meanwhile that I shall dine with him next Sunday night too. “No-body but ourselves 3,John and Eliza Forster, and TC. no wine at all, no“—(But I have privately determined that it will be better not).

Poor Mrs Larkin (on Tuesday night, what I did not hear till yesternight) was unexpectedly taken; and produced a daughter (of the 7th month), whh lived 12 hours! No servant at all was in the house (a servant coming shortly); only Larkin himself, and by lucky accidt some female visitor!— Poor Larkindom;—mother said to be doing well.— Our flour is come; place all cleaned as per order. Adieu my own Darling.
T.C. (Chelsea 25 March 1864)

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 26 March. Addr: Dr Blakiston &c &c / St Leonards on Sea. PM: London, 26 March 1864. MS: NLS 616.590. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: For the first time, no Letter from Hastings this morng: I hope it means only “much the same”;—but a word in the evg to confirm me wd be very welcome! The PostmanJohn Bullock. gave me a Letter from the DoctorJohn A. Carlyle. (as I came in to breakfast); I said, “Have you no other for me!” Not by this Post, Sir

Woolner stole away my third night (yesternight),—whh shall be the last theft this week! Not the very Pope shd get in, this night, if he called.— I am in the most disgusting bit of fash with Proofs; nothing better really than patching, piecing & above all placing—in spite of ignorance quite owlish all round me. Robson delays too; I have sent [to]Word omitted. spur him.— Oh with a good Notekin from Hastings what a go I shd make tonight,—and finish before bedtime!—

Perhaps you will read that notice on poor Lord Ashburton,—and if so, John’s letter for commentary.There was a brief announcement in the Times, 24 March (see TC to Lady ALLA, 24 March), and a notice in the Examiner, 26 March; John A. Carlyle possibly sent one of the notices in the Scottish papers. My heart is sad,—as whose of us is not!The Glasgow Citizen, 26 March, reprinted from the Scotsman, ended: “There will be many sorrowing friends now to whom the Grange was a home, but to none of them will the loss be so irreparable as to our great country man, the author of ‘Sartor Resartus’ and ‘The French Revolution: a History’—the noblest drama since Shakespeare. No two men knew and loved each other better than they.” Alas, we cannot help what befals us. We must be patient; be pious-minded hopeful!—

I have absolutely refused Fuz;—will go up to tea, if my Proofs be done. Tell Maggie, almost always to send me one word; were it itWord repeated. only, “Slept” so-&-so (if she can). She is very punctual indeed; & deserves thousand thanks.Maggie Welsh sent two notes which arrived by Sat. evening; see TC to JWC, 28 March. Good be with my poor Darling T. C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JF, [26 March]. MS: FC. Hitherto unpbd. Dated by there being “no letters from Hastings this morning,” “for the first time”; see TC to JWC, 26 March. Forster’s invitation was for Sun. 27 March, with Forster adding Browning to his original intention to include only TC, himself, and Eliza Forster; see TC to JWC, 25 March.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN FORSTER

docBody.p: Dear Forster,—You must not tempt me! I am truly in a poor peaking way, & have to walk, as on thin ice, thin & slippery!— If I get done with my Proofs I will come up to tea, abt half past 8,—and shan’t object to Browning by any means.
For the first time there is, this morning, no Note from Hastings; but I persuade myself it means nothing worse than usual;—& perhaps I shall hear at night. / yrs ever T.C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady A [LLA], 28 March. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p: Dear Lady,—It will be a welcome relief to my feelings to attend on Thursday.Lord Ashburton’s funeral, 31 March, at Northington Church, Hants. Lord Houghton wrote to his wife from Hyères about Lord Ashburton, late March: “So the ‘Grange’ is gone from me and mine. Taken with its personages, it fills a large place in my memories. I had much in common with him, mainly a failure in public life, which he bore with a dignity and manliness I have never assumed, but which he felt quite as acutely: indeed, in the comparison between himself and other men I think there was more of contempt and self-depreciation than goes with my nature” (Reid, RMM 2:122). There is a wild tone of woe in yr Note! I will not ask to see you on Thursday, unless you expressly permit. Our thoughts (to little use) are with you at all times. On Saturday I am to go to St Leonard’s, and see how the poor soul is. God bless you,—God help us all.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 28 March. Addr: Dr Blakiston &c &c / St Leonards on Sea. PM: London, 28 March 1864. MS: NLS 616.591. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p:
The Two Notes came (thank Maggie) the first in date an hour before the second; and were a great comfort in the solitary Saty Night. The Note of this morning is not so good; but we must be patient; we cannot always have a
favourable bulletin. This cold weather,—that nasty Dog. I hope it has not interrupted the fine quiet round you a second time. It cd apply to nobody in Britain who needs it less,—the villainous wretch.——— I spent all day yesterday in disgusting fashery (merely mechanical puddingFor “puddling.” most of it), and did not get the vile Proofs wrapt up till five p.m. I then walked to Grosvenor Street 32, and saw Miss Bromley (ill of cold, and beautifully flurried at first) for a quarter of an hour: she intends being at St Leonards on or abt Wednesday, but will lie perdue [concealed] in the Hôtel, and “take her chance” of catching a glimpse of you when driving. So don’t let it flurry you, Dearest:—refuse to see her altogether, if you feel it will do you the least ill.— After dinner (whh was hurried rather, or belated, & had no nap), I went to Forster’s for Tea: Browning there, plenty of tea, & something more like rational talk than oftenest falls to my lot. Abt the Saty at St Leonard’s great enthusiasm, & there was to be some “Correspondence with Miss Welsh” (abt yr permission of me, abt Hôtels, lest these be overcrowded unless bespoken, and I know not what); Maggies own Note tomorrow will be a most welcome phenn there.— How brave of thee to write to poor Lady Ashburton. I send a word today that I will come (no particlars introduced, for indeed I have no Bradshaw.Bradshaw’s Monthly General Railway and Steam Navigation Guide. I thot once it wd ansr well to stay there till Friday morng; & thence by Portsmouth to St Leonards;—but I felt it wrong to propose such a thing.— Adieu, Dearest; my haste is immense! T. C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 29 March. Addr: Dr Blakiston &c &c / St Leonards on Sea. PM: London, 29 March 1864. MS: NLS 616.592. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p:
Bad news agn this morning, my poor little Darling: alas, alas! And yesterday, meeting the strong wind from the West (tho’ it was still very cold), I fancied to myself “Here is better weather for her, coming!” Then did splashes of rain fall, and have made us all muddy again; but the wind is north still, and colder than ever.— I think these are what they call the “borrowing days,”For the old Scots weather proverb relating to end March / beginning April, see 36:97–99TC to LS, 19 April 1860.—a violent tussle, the last of the year, betn Summer & Winter (West & East), for abt a week, as march passes into April with its sunshine & warm showers. And yet I know not,—perhaps the wet, even with heat, will be disagreeable to yr poor weak state? The only thing I am sure of is that we are just coming towards
(straight towards) summer from this time;—and that summer is motherly & good to all living things.

I am quite au sécret [in seclusion] here; nobody admitted; my bother with sheets &c being great. And the beggarly Printers have all taken to eastering, & Robson says they will drink all this week,TC writes on Tues. following Easter weekend. For his earlier complaints about printers, drink, and Easter, see 16:131TC to JCA, 19 April 1843. & not work a stroke till their money is out! So that Vol V will still be hanging;—tho’ virtually I have done with it (to a nearness), and am working, and advancing in vol VI & last!—

Let me not forget to tell you to Countermand us (frankly if you wish it so, & these sleepless sorrows continue); to tell both the FostersThus in MS. & even me, “Not to come,” if you fear it will hurt you. I hope you won’t, & that the compulsion will not be so strong. But I think this perfect liberty is yr clear due; and may tend to relieve any anxiety on that score, shd things still go worse with sleep &c than one hopes. Oh Darling, sleep agn; my heart is sore to think of that misery for you.

Mrs Anstruther had called yesterday while I was riding; “had a message from Lady Ashburton,” I think she said;—at any rate, “wd call tomorrow a little before 3“: and has not done it! I know not whether to wait a little;—but must be ready at any rate. Good b’ye Darling;—and oh sleep, if you wd please me!
Thank Maggie; she is very punctual and good— Yours ever
docBody.name: T.C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, [30 March]. Addr: Dr Blakiston &c &c / St Leonards on Sea. PM: London, 30 March 1864. MS: NLS 616.593. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Dearest, I am quite belated; have had a line to write to John,—had to wait for Larkin & Proofwork: oh dear, & shall have to write to Fuz tonight;—see what a Note he sends me; what a prospect that of jollifying at the Hôtel; whh I can’t stand at all, at all!—

Maggie’s Note with the better bulletin of my poor little woman; that is the one good or pleasant thing that has befallen me hitherto this day. I woke too early (not by any blame); found it was one of the “borrowing days,“—streets two inches deep in inWord repeated on next page. snow-slushThe Times reported, 1 April, that on 30 March, 8:00 a.m., the ground was “covered with snow an inch deep, which soon dissolved.” when I stept out: I feel as if it were bitterly ungentle weather,—and fear tomorrow my news will be bad!

Tomorrow 10.15 I am to be at the Statn; Carriages at Winchester: 1 o’clock the hour;—oh that I were home agn, home and left silent!— Mrs Anstruther’s errand you see what it was.To tell TC the arrangements for Lord Ashburton’s funeral. A man of the DunlopsProbably William Dunlop (b. 1829), son of Archibald Dunlop (ca. 1782–1864), former Haddington distiller (who d. 21 Jan.), and his wife Anne, b. Vetch (b. 1795); see 37:150JWC to WDO, [15 April 1861]. sent up his card, to inquire for you; said you wd be sorry to hear of Mrs Trail’s deathThe Haddingtonshire Courier announced, 25 March: “At Cheltenham, on the 23d instant, Margaret Vetch, widow of the late Rev. James Traill, Episcopal Clergyman at Haddington.” Margaret Traill, b. Vetch (1793–1864) was the sister of William Dunlop’s mother, Anne. (“Trial” Helen called it, but I took it for Trail). Oh my own little Darling what a whirl one is kept in! No Goody here to protect me. Patience, however;—yes Dearest, time does bring Roses.German proverb; see 27:60TC to WM, 3 March 1852. God bless you
docBody.name: T.C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 1 April. Addr: Dr Blakiston &c &c / St Leonards on Sea. PM: London, 1 April 1864. MS: NLS 616.594. Pbd: Bliss, TC 362–63 inc.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.dateline: Chelsea, SatyTC wrote “Saty” in error for Friday. 3 p.m. (1 April!) [1864]
docBody.p:
Dearest Thank Heaven Maggie’s acct is on the good hand. Oh what a day I had yesterday;Lord Ashburton’s funeral. The Morning Post reported, 2 April: “The present Lord Ashburton and other relations of the deceased, with many noblemen and gentlemen, took part in the mournful ceremony. … The funeral cortège consisted of the tenants on horseback, two outriders, and an attendant bearing the esquire’s plume. Then came the hearse drawn by four horses, followed by the domestics of the household, and six mourning coaches. On arriving at the church the tenants and servants formed an avenue, the mourners passed through which into the building, when the service was read … and the coffin was lowered into the vault.” hurried, misdirected, tossed abt, with emotions whh nobody was sharing:—however, I did get home witht accidt abt 8 p.m. No accidt at all worth naming,—except the loss of my dear old black velvet cap; whh had fallen out of my pocket (pocket of the Tigerskin Pea-jacket) betn the railway & here.TC later recalled wrongly that he lost the velvet cap on his return from taking JWC to St. Leonards: “At length I left the house (or indeed they almost pushed me out, ‘not to miss the last train,’ which I saved only by half a moment by hot speed and good luck), and got home in a more hopeful mood than I had come away. Solely, in my last cab (from Waterloo station), I had stuck my cap (a fine black velvet thing of her making) too hurriedly into my pocket, and it had hustled out, and in the darkness been left. Loss irrecoverable, not noticed till next morning, and which I still regret. ‘Oh, nothing!’ said she, cheerily and yet mournfully, at our next meeting. ‘I will make you a new cap when I am able to sew again.’ But I think, in effect, she never sewed more” (TC’s note in Froude, LM 3:193). See also Carlyle, Reminiscences 173. Most probably was in the Cab,—and had the doorlamp been alight I
might probably have seen it there;—but, alas, the door happened to be dark; and my poor old cap was irrevocably gone! You made it for me almost 20 years; and I am quite regretful abt it all this day. I saw the poor Lady,Lady Ashburton.—who at parting kissed me: poor soul! But she will soon recover her grief. I saw Quain &c, who sent innumerable compts &c &c: but I will speak of everything tomorrow.TC went to St. Leonards on Sat.

By positive inability to get a Note written, I shall probably (if I can rise early enough) have to go with the Forsters! At latest (in the other case) I meant to start at 2 p.m. (the train my poor Goody came by), whh will bring me in amply in time for the Blakn dinner (whh I shd prefer; but if Fr have me on arriving I must go to dine with him). Sleep in yr House any way!TC decided to stay with the Blakistons, rather than at a hotel with the Forsters. God bless my Darling
docBody.name: T.C.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-JF, 2 April. MS: NLS 608.620. Hitherto unpbd. TC later wrote on MS: “(alas, alas!—Gone from Dr Blakns, I think?“
div3.head: JWC TO JOHN FORSTER

docBody.p: To my dear and ever kind frendThus in MS. Forster’s birthday was 2 April; he replied, 4 April: “I am so grateful to you—my dear—dear friend—for the pretty little gold seal you sent me yesterday. I never had a birthday remembrance I shall value so much. It shall hang at my watch as long as I have any interest in time—which I hope will be a long time, and that we shall have many many happy meetings meanwhile. Because I found you looking so much better than I dared to expect after all your suffering that it has made me very confident the worst is past.— God bless you and support you, my dear dearest Mrs Carlyle— You know (do you not?) how continually I think of you, and wish and pray for you to be well again more frequently than I wish for anything.” John Forster—from his grateful and sorely suffering
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 4 April. Addr: Dr Blakiston &c &c / St Leonards-on-Sea. PM: London, 4 April 1864. MS: NLS 616.595. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Dearest,—Here am I at home, and have taken a smoke (4 p.m.) with design to have another and some trial for a nap of sleep, and muttonbroth following it as dinner; but will first write my poor little Jeannie this word for tomorrow morning. All seems right here, and I consigned yr gift to Hellen, who seemed much gratified and has things in fair order here. No Letters for you, nor for Maggie. We had a nasty three of partners in our carriage; Jewish specimens all of one lot,—dirty Jew Father do mother, do nurse-maid and Baby, for whose sake they half-choked us all, till in the last 30 miles, it became too strong even for them,—the nasty creatures, and they had to admit a little through-draft.

Oh my little darling, what a 50 hours of chaotic emotions I have had. How glad, and yet how sorrowful,—the miseries of your poor little heart whh are too real to me; and the steadfast hope and perceptn I have that we are really making progress! Let us thank God; and patiently expect. Oh me, oh me!—

My time is up, and as I really have nothing to report, I will not risk being belated so foolishly.
