John has sent me a Saturday Review with an extremely contemptible review of Vol. IVThe review was mixed, acknowledging TC’s peculiar genius and historical effort, but deploring the fact that “Mr. Carlyle is voluminous in his contempt for the writers from whom he has to collect his materials. … Mr. Carlyle’s complaint is … to the effect that the minor French and German writers in the middle of the eighteenth century wrote on trivial matters in a trivial but natural way, and that they principally saw the less happy side of the King of Prussia” (“Carlyle’s Frederick the Great,” Saturday Review, 2 April). (hostile if the dirty puppy durst, but favourable to Chapmans’s purpose,Presumably Chapman would have been pleased by the reviewer’s general appraisal of vol. 4: “Those who admire Mr. Carlyle’s genius … will probably find that the fourth is equal in merit to its predecessors. There is the same accuracy in ascertaining and recording minute facts, the same skill in military narration, the same odd humour, the same felicity or audacity in indicating characters or institutions by a permanent and recurrent epithet” (Saturday Review, 2 April). TC might be referring to the fact that Chapman & Hall only printed 4,500 copies of vols. 3 and 4, rather than the 5,000 copies they had printed of vols. 1 and 2; or perhaps Chapman had already hinted he wanted to withhold part payment for vol. 4 until the whole work was finished; see TC to JWC, [9 April].—not worth a snuff of tobacco); this and a Note from Jean,Jean wrote, 1 April: “I hope you may find her looking more cheery The Forsters wd be a bad complication for both of you & her, but I hope got backed out of that.” is all I find here. God bless thee my own little Woman
docBody.name: T.C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JCA, 4 April. MS: NLS 517.17. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.p: I have just got home from Hastings; too late for this days post: but you will get my bit of message on Tuesday night (if you call);At the Dumfries Post Office. so I write it without delay.

Poor J as Maggie Welsh wd tell you, was in appearance beyond my expectatn not under it; the Doctor too, who is a rugged decisive kind of man, and not capable of perverting the truth, is quite sanguine abt the matter; and counts the progress made to be highly satisfactory. She looks quite otherwise, at some moments as if almost well agn; they assure me she eats better; almost every night gets some considerable allowance of broken sleep, and once or twice has had a real night of sleep; she drives out twice aday for most part;—in short, I do hope she is evidently mending. On the other hand, her own humour is almost quite despondent, and the pain and misery she still has is such as to cut one to the heart amid one’s joy over her essential improvemt. The Doctor makes but little of this symptom,—“natural to the disease,” he says:—and it does appear the pain she used to complain of is not at any time so intolerable as it was while here; and it is for an hour or so daily in abeyance, and twice for almost a day has been off altogether. Yesterday and today she had put on a dress (for the sake of company calling), whh is the first time since November last! She walks tolerably with a stick;—speculates on my coming down there to live too. Whh really might be the right plan to take, I myself being in inWord repeated by TC. so low a way with the botheratns I have had. I mean to send the Doctor a word tonight or tomorrow; but you may as well push this along too. Your affecte T.C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, [5 April]. Addr: Dr Blakiston &c &c / St Leonards-on-Sea. PM: London, 5 April 1864. MS: NLS 616.596. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p:
Dearest Suffering creature,—Here is a bad morning agn, as wild and rough as ever: it will be lucky if it do you as little mischief as you profess.— I got no Letter; did not want any since there cd be none from Maggie; I have
spoken to nobody; done nothing except sit sunk in sad thoughts (being far out of sorts in body too), and this bad forenoon, do a little bit of Proofing;—whh is really the one poor comfort I can lay hold of in my prest mood!— I had good mutton-broth (t.o.) but made a bad night of it nevertheless,—and am accordingly in the mood you have often known. It is strange what mischief I get even from kind neighbours,—the kind Fuz for instance, than whom no creature can be more heartily social & eager to help both of us. Well, well; one shd take care.

I gave Hellen the wages, £3 .. 7 .. 6; whh I suppose (tho’ she did not make much profession) must be an encouraget & “good joy”Coterie speech; see 10:167JWC to TC, [9 Sept. 1838]. to her. I was abt writing to John (who has got nothing for weeks); but stopt short,—my poor Dear being the alternative Oh that I had a blessing of any value to send to thee! Adieu T. C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 5 April. MS: NLS 526.15. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p:
My dear Brother,—I returned yesterday afternoon from Hastings; quite worn to the ground with what had gone on there (alas I must wait till night: here is warning of “the Horse” (a wet day too); and I have to write one word to poor Jane!) (Downstairs 11 p.m.TC’s parentheses were to indicate breaking off and restarting letter. After a furious gallop thro’ the nastiest plash of sleety rain; after sleep, dinner, and a dreary fit of working,—I resume, before going out for my final walk of the day. Jean has probably sent you from Dumfries my brief Hastings report. The Doctor, not at first sanguine (as his Letter, whh I always meant to send, wd have shewn) was grown quite emphatic about poor Jane’s improvet &c; and indeed it was undeniably evidt,—tho’, alas, her suffering is, no less evidently, still very great, and filled me with distress to witness it. She is always on the edge of crying: full of hysterical pains and emotions, refuses to have any comfortable hope. My guess is, she will have to stay yonder all summer; there was speculatn thereupon of my coming down (t.o.) too, and I suppose that also to be likely,—if I can possibly contrive to take my Work with me: tho’ I absolutely must not otherwise. Oh dear, oh dear! I am hard bested; and do much need all the poor remnant of energy that is left me in this juncture of things. The sea-shore, and absence from this unblessed element wd probably do me good: but my need of getting done with the intolerable Book is also intense! The prospect of fronting another winter like the last 3 or more, with it, makes me tremble. In fact, nothing but my Horse keeps
me alive at all, or in the least capacity for doing work. Robson’s Printers too plague me with their delaysCharles Robson had been involved in bankruptcy proceedings; see TC to JAC, 12 Jan. (Robson is coming perhaps tomorrow to fall on new plans with them); Larkin has fallen useless,Larkin was probably still suffering from the death at birth of his da., 22 March; see TC to JWC, 25 March. Neuberg do;Neuberg suffered recurring episodes of ill-health; see 39:181–82TC to JN, 10 March 1863; he had also recently suffered a bereavement; see TC to JN [6 March].—unfortunate mechanics deserting a doubly unfortunate poor old engineer in his extremity! We must and will manage nevertheless. Courage, Courage!—

You may judge, dear Brother, what kind of company I shd be, if you came to me! I get in genl nothing but mischief at prest out of all the people abt me. I cd not ask even you to come & front such a scene. But if you liked to come of will for a couple of weeks, and felt yrself in spirits for such a task, of course you might do me benefit, and the sight of cheerful affection affectionRepeated at top of next page. wd be a comfort to me. There is a reasonably good maid here; and the House, of course is mostly lying vacant;—the Drawingroom here a place for breakfasting in, and then for smoking in (with open windows), unless the garden be more inviting. There will be good weather soon; Erskine & yr Edinr friends will probably be in part leaving you; any work you are at can probably go on here as well as there: on the whole consider it;—and let me see you for a couple of weeks if you think it will answer.

Forster’s hospitality in the Hastings matter was really of the kindest: but it did me a great deal of ill; and I will not try such a thing agn. I was perfectly broken in heart & nerves when they set me down at the door yesterday afternoon. Left to my own gloom and my own resources, it is far better. Today, in spite of everything, I am more myself again.— Yr Saturday ReviewerReviewer unidentified; for the review, see TC to JWC, 4 April. (who waited me yesterday) is a dirty little messin, profoundly unconscious when his betters are riding by: in the absence of a dog-whip, I read him very slightly, tho’ the admissions even he had to make were rather encouraging to me, if not very entertaining . . aining.TC wrote “. . aining” at top of the other side of the page. Being so demoralized, I spent the greater part of the evg, reading the rest of that sad review stuff,—with a profound feeling of sadness at the “popularity” of such an article. All the writers, now and whenever I look, seem to be of the same type as mine. Shallow, barren wretches; uninstructed on all subjects, only crammed a little on some few, & insolently conceited on all; transcendency of commonplace the characteristic of everything they say and think (and I suppose, do) from year’s end to year’s end. Prithee shepherd, who keeps all these asses?Cf. Laurence Sterne, The Life and Opinions of Tristram Shandy, chap. 92.—

Good night dear Brother; I may, unless somehow hindered, add a word tomorrow. Do not forget my express regards to the good Erskine and the good Mrs Stirling.Thomas Erskine’s sister. Ay de mi. Yours ever affectle,—T. Carlyle (The maid has come in, since I began writing, and has overset my inkbottle,—wd I have paused for such an obstacle. I tore off the table-cloth; packed her away with it, and she has it clean agn, and is vanished to the shades of night. Adieu)TC wrote later: “Maggie’s daily bulletin was indistinct and ambiguous, but strove always to be favourable, or really was so. I sat busy here; generally wrote to my poor darling some daily line; got from her now and then some word or two, but always on mere practical or household matters; seldom or never any confirmation of Maggie’s reading of the omens. In the last week of March (as covenanted) I made my first visit (Friday till Monday, I think). Forster and Mrs. F. went with me, but did not see her. I stayed at Dr. B——’s, they at a hotel, where was dining, &c. Whether this was my first visit to her there I strive to recollect distinctly, but cannot. I seem to have even seen but little of her, and certainly learned nothing intimate; as if she rather avoided much communication with me, unwilling to rob me of the doctor’s confident prognostications, and much unable to confirm them. Her mood of fixed quiet sorrow, with no hope in it but of enduring well, was painfully visible. I had just got rid of my vol. v., deeply disappointed latterly on finding that there must be a sixth. Hades was not more lugubrious than that book too now was to me; and yet there was something in it of sacred, of Orpheus-like (though I did not think of ‘Orpheus’ at all, nor name my darling an ‘Eurydice’!) and the stern course was to continue—what else?” (TC’s note in Froude, LM 3:194).

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 6 April. Addr: Dr Blakiston &c &c / St Leonards on Sea. PM: London, 6 April 1864. MS: NLS 616.597. Hitherto unbpd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p:
Dearest, what a mercy to me, Maggies Note is agn favourable,—more so than I ventured to expect, after the flurries and the bad weather It is true there is something of fluctuatn reported: but we must be prepared for fluctuatn almost daily; and be thankful to see that the tide, were it only slowly, is making. That is the real fact, Dear; oh believe it, poor dispirited soul!— — I am still bird alone; “sparrow-like companionless on the housetop,”Cf. Ps. 102:7.—and truly it answers better than any company I cd get. Yesterday I had a long swift ride,—thro pouring rain, sometimes with a taste almost of sleet in it: the process was supremely unpleast, but it did me [good];Word omitted; “good” inserted in another hand. in another 24 hours I expect to be at par agn. Oh that I cd get on, howr; these beggarly mechanical delays are quite enraging to me. Robson was to call “some morning” for quickening measures; but disappoints me this morning; Larkin is grown not worth his lugs, —
hardly even as an errand man is he good: Wd to Heaven I were honestly out of this unblessed nearly intolerable thing, with the Life still left in me!—

You are now Housekeepers on yr own score. When yr money is threatening to run low, bid Maggy write, name the sum, and whether I must make to her to you or to Dr Blakiston.TC sent a check a few days later; see TC to JWC, [14 April].
Oh Darling; grant me another bulletin rather good! And God bless & keep thee.
docBody.name: T.C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 7 April. Addr: Dr Blakiston &c &c / St Leonards on Sea. PM: London, 7 April 1864. MS: NLS 616.598. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Alas, we said we wd be “prepared for fluctuatns”; and here, it seems, is one! Maggie says I might perhaps have had a word from a Hand the dearest in all the world to me, after so long abeyance in the grip of misery! Well; I will be patient,—as you must be,—under these interruptions and dreary ups and downs. Perhaps tomorrow the little Hand will be more under order to the kind will: soon, I know, the little Note will come to gladden me!—

I am still solus, whh is best for me. Yesterday, in riding, I did fall in with Lord Grey,Henry George Grey (1802–94; ODNB), 3d Earl Grey, politician; known to TC since 1844; see 18:115TC to JWC, 7 [8] July 1844. and there was a wagging of tongues, but nothing I cd call talk of a useful or agreeable kind; however, he gallopped diligently (in Rotten Row it was), and encouraged me to do the like, till we were both dirty; and I got thro’ my obligato ride with less tedium than usual. Today Robson has been here; in shifting (after his bankruptcy, poor soul); no speed possible for a week or two, but then there shall be plenty.— I got no Letter except one from a Museum Irishman,Possibly Samuel Langley (b. ca. 1823), from Cork, impoverished writer who previously assisted TC with museum research for Frederick; on several occasions TC gave Langley funds from Lady Harriet Ashburton’s bequest; see 35:54TC to SLA, 14 March 1859. full of blarney, and “wants £4 immediate”;—whom I shall be far from answering. Perhaps you will find in John’s Letter, just come, some point or so that may have interest.— You wd not be entertained, I fear, if Mrs Fanny Kemble called on you?Fanny Kemble wrote to TC, early March, apparently from St. Leonards; the letter was forwarded to JWC; see TC to JWC, 9 March. She is “30 (or 29?) Marina,” and wd gladly, I suppose, if you gave her signal.— Keep up thy little heart, Darling; and love
me as before! Maggie shall have her Autograph (I hope) tomorrow. God bless thee always.
docBody.name: T.C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 8 April. Addr: Dr Blakiston &c &c / St Leonard’s on Sea. PM: London, 8 April 1864. MS: NLS 616.599. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Alas, my poor suffering Darling, what is this agn, what is this! I was far from expecting the like of it. Yesterday here was not specially cold, and it was dry and sometimes bright; I kept priding myself, “She is getting a better drive than usual!” God grant I may get a better bulletin tomorrow. This morning I had awakened before six (never right since those Forster confusions), and then fallen asleep till after nine: I heard the Postman, while bathing; you may fancy what a treat Maggie’s poor Note was when my cold fingers broke it up on the street. Tomorrow, surely; tomorrow!— This day is agn of the type of yesterday; rather colder to my feeling; but I will still keep hoping.

My work goes on but ill; all the worse for these Robson delays & hagglings: but butWord repeated at turn of page. I am getting myself adjusted to that too;—and mean, tomorrow, to be fairly in upon the masses of vol 6, and to make a great figure in coercing them into something of Order before we start agn at our new rate of speed. “To have done in Septr!” I always say to myself;—and will not give it up till compelled. But all my calculations have been so false, and my hopes fond:—Courage, however, Courage! I have but two Wishes in the earth: That my poor Goody were restored to me; that I might have this unsufferable Book off me before a new winter come on her and me.
I am due for the Horse (need a shirt too);—must say no more.
God be with thee Dearest, and have pity and mercy on us both!—

ps.p: Nothing but Shakspre tercentenary Babble-babbles today!Celebrations planned for the forthcoming tercentenary of Shakespeare’s birth, 23 April 1564. The Times, 2 April, reported extensive plans for the festival, including a public subscription to erect a bronze statue in London, a scheme to create a Shakespeare school of the Royal Dramatic College, an exhibition at Stratford-on-Avon of portraits and pictures connected with Shakespeare and the stage, and a banquet in London at the Agricultural Hall.— Spills for the Toba[cco]Word incomplete. TC used twists of unwanted paper for lighting his pipe.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [8 April]. Addr: 5 Cheyne Row / Chelsea / London. PM: Hastings, 8 April 1864. MS: NLS 608.621. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:195–96; Bliss, JWC 311; Fielding and Sorensen 297–98. Quot: Ireland, JWC 287; Ashton 432. TC later wrote on the envelope: “St Lds ‘friday’ 8 April 1864: a tortured Letter from Her,—with inclosures: oh dear / (put these togr agn).” For the first page of MS, see above.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p: Oh my own Darling—God have pity on us!— Ever since the day after you left—whatever flattering accounts may have been sent you—the truth is, I have been wretched—perfectly wretched day and night—with that horrible malady—
Dr B knows nothing about it more than the other Drs— So God help me—for on earth is no help—

Lady A writes that Lord A left you two thousand pounds—not in his will—(to save the Duty) but to be given you as soon as possibleJWC enclosed Lady Ashburton’s letter of [4 April]: “My dearest friend—It was very kind & like you, in all your own suffering & misery to write to me in my desolation—for I am desolate indeed—as day after day I realize that I have lost for ever his beloved companionship & sweet society. It seems impossible that he who for the last 5 years, has been the one object of my existence, & on whose approval & love I set such value, that if I had that, I cared for nothing else—shd indeed have left me alone—oh! You can’t imagine the pain, & loneliness & heavy heart— I saw your dear husband—I cd see him—for I knew he loved him— My darlings care & thought for me surrounds me at every turn—& among all his other thoughtful arrangements for me, he has settled that I have the power of remaining on here for 8 months—if I like to do so. It is probable I shall for a few months—&, as I told Mr Carlyle, nothing could be more soothing, or precious to me, than a visit from you 2–at any time—so dearest please get well— My beloved one begged that £2000 might be sent to yr dear husband in memory of him as soon as it possibly cd be. He did not mention this, in his Will to avoid the Legacy Duty—ask Miss Welsh to let me know soon how you go on—with the assurance of my tenderest sympathy in your long trial of weakness & pain.”—“The wished for come too late!” Money can do nothing for us now!—

figure.p: Jane Welsh Carlyle to Thomas Carlyle, [8 April 1864] (detail)

p.hi: Courtesy of the National Library of Scotland

docBody.name: Jane W Carlyle

ps.p: Today I am a little less tortured—only a little,—but a letter having been promised I write

div3.sourceNote: MW-Lady A [LLA], [8 April]. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: MARGARET WELSH TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.dateline: 5 Warrior Square St Leonard’s-on-Sea Friday [8 April 1864]
docBody.p: Mrs Carlyle bids me write to thank you very much for your letter which she only received this morning. There happen to be two postmen who do duty in Warrior Square & the letter having unfortunately got into the hands of the wrong man, it has been wandering about till today we suppose.

Cousin says I am to give you her very dear love & to tell you how much she would like to be able to come to see you at the Grange but she fears that is indeed a far away prospect. Dr Blakiston considers her to be very much better; she is able to drive out once every day & often she goes twice, & is up all the day, at least moving about now & then & resting on the sofa. This surely shows that she must be gaining strength. If it were not for the terrible depression from which she suffers & the almost constant nervous pain which she has for so long complained of & which only leaves her for very short & rare intervals, I really should be quite hopeful of seeing her regain by & bye some of her usual health, which truly at the best is but very delicate.

She is very hopeless about herself, but that may be really part of her ailment. Mr Carlyle was here from Saturday until Monday2–4 April. & he said that he thought her looking better than he ventured to hope, so we will hope that milder & bright weather will help to cheer & strengthen her. She bids me say to you that “she feels as if a little time at this place would do you a great deal of good, for you have indeed had sore trouble & must be sadly worn out with watching & sorrow.”
She has been most thankful to hear that on the whole you are pretty well, & most thankful too to hear that the dear little girlLady Ashburton’s da., Mary Florence. is strong & well just now.
With most heartfelt sympathy dear Lady with all your sorrow

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, [9 April]. Addr: Dr Blakiston &c &c / St Leonards on Sea. PM: London, 9 April 1864. MS: NLS 616.600. Hitherto unbpd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Alas, Darling, I did not know yr poor little hand at all: what a time, since we last saw it,For JWC’s handwriting in 1864, see JWC to TC, [8 April], see 59. JWC’s previous surviving letters to TC, also sent from St. Leonards, were written in June 1863; see 39:148–49JWC to TC, 10 June, JWC to TC, 11 June, and 152–53JWC to TC, 12 June. For her handwriting in Sept.1863, see 39:195JWC to MCH, 23 Sept. there has been;—and the news still so very sad and dreary! It is painfully clear to me that my poor little Jeannie is loaded with misery; & has almost no hope left in her poor heart. It made me infinitely wae, all that, as I looked on it: nevertheless, Darling, the rest of us perhaps do “know better,” especially the Doctor who stands impartially looking,—and has seen many such cases. I do on my life believe and hope; I shd be altogether wretched otherwise! Write me a little Note agn however; even if a sad one: it will do me good, and you too.— — Poor Lord Ashburton; that is very affecting; and it shall be precious to me in more senses than one! Ought I to write abt it? I suppose, clearly yes (but am so loth to write).— Forster was here today; lets me off from dining tomorrow (thank Heaven); sends such regards &c &c: has been with the Chapmans; who want to pay only for “3,000 copies” (instead of 4,500) “till they see the Book’s end.” To whh I ansr, “No, by the Powers: pay me for this vol. exactly as you did for last,—and quick please! If you like better, walk out of it, leave it to me, and there is ready-money for the outlays you have made!”— Forster is off with that indignant message; and I suppose the actual money will come next. Base beings; one has weltered till one is nearly dead in the subterranean realms, and on emerging to daylight the first welcome is, “Some abatet in the pittance of payt will be fair, won’t it?” No, by all the gods! one answers, with one’s foot lifted into the air a little.— Courage, courage, my little heroine; we shall get thro’, both of us, into smooth water this year: I feel & say we shall.
Chelsea Saturday

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady A [LLA], 11 April. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Quot: Hansons, NE 518.
div3.head: TC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p:
On Saturday my Wife sent me the Note she had recd from you. To me it was abundantly affecting, that little trait whh you communicated, of Him whom
we shall see no more! Strange, yet simple, beautiful; so like the Doer of it:—the last finish to 20 years of friendly acts and offices on his part,—all done in the same gentle, quiet and fine way.For Lord Ashburton’s gift of £2000, see JWC to TC, [8 April]. Lord Houghton wrote about Lord Ashburton to a friend, 1 April: “I am thankful I went to see Lord Ashburton before he died. I came away without any hope. Altogether he was the noblest and purest-minded man I have ever known. If he had had powers and facilities of expression, he would have been a great one” (Reid, RMM 2:123). It makes me sad to the very heart; but shall be sacred, and a beautiful possession to me while I linger my few days or years behind him in this world.

I well conceive yr desolation; how you find with new astonisht at every turn that the substance of yr life, what was yr daily labour & yr care and yr joy, is suddenly fled away forever, and has left all vacant! This is sore, sore, while it lasts; but one gradually rallies, finds that areThus in MS. new duties, a life still full of such, and whh can be done (in a measure) as if still under the old dear banner, and in the name and as if for the sake of those that are away. Courage, Courage!—

Saturday gone a week I went down to St Leonards. Poor Jane, in her own sad mind is hardly at all better; and indeed her evidt miseries (only broken off at intervals) cut one to the quick: but it was clear to me that she had made considerable progress; and the Doctor, a rugged effective-looking man, was quite proud & confidt. Time will evidtly be needed: we must be patient with delays.

It was talked of, as certain, that I was myself to get down thither with Book, Horse, & try to write & live. I too have great need of “country”; an almost broken-down old veteran, in the 12th year of his final War!— Have you no chance to try Baby & Self with the sea-side sometime? It wd be very pretty.— Yours ever T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 11 April. Addr: Dr Blakiston &c &c / St Leonards on Sea. PM: London, 11 April 1864. MS: NLS 616.601. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Darling, my time (writing to The Grange just done) is run out;—I have in fact no news, that you cannot yrself almost predict. Maggie’s Note on Saty Night, rather a little better than the foregoing, she knows how welcome it wd be: then today too I counted the bulletin of average goodness, and was thankful: Being a silent man, “all this while my news are your news whh you send.— I will enclose these bits of Notes, some of whh came this morng.

The weather has grown quite warm: Larkin had to come this morning, and open my Study-window for air from above. Yesterday I sat all morning vanquishing Proofs: went then to Chorley,John Rutter Chorley. for sound of the human tongue; walked extensively with the unmusical, & landed at this door in time;—after dinner, I had still something of work chalked out, when lo—T. Ballantyne again the beautiful fellow-man! It is really very hard; but one can’t help it. I got in the end nothing done at all.

Fancy my Sinclair ProposalSir George Sinclair was staying with his son John George Tollemache Sinclair (1825–1912) and daughter-in-law Emma, b. Standish (1827–89), who lived at The Mount, Upper Norwood, nr. Croydon, SE London. too,—that I shd take a drunken man-servant off his hands!Unidentified; presumably not John Sinclair’s butler, William Duff (b. ca. 1823) of Perthshire. Ballantyne had come wanting mainly an “introductn to Sir George”; I considered it a properish revenge.——— Now Darling won’t you perhaps soon write me a Notekind yrself? Oh yes;—and be good, and get better.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 12 April. Dr Blakiston &c &c / St Leonards on Sea. PM: London, 12 April 1864. MS: NLS 616.602. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Dearest, It was but a so-so bulletin I had today,—alas, I can get no better: we must try to be content with it. I think I am myself getting low-spirited sad in my solitude. In abt a week’s time, if it don’t mend, I must have a try at MercuriesMercury was taken by the Carlyles in the form of a “blue pill,” small doses of which were thought to be a cure for nervous or mental ailments as well as for digestive upsets; see 32:111TC to LA, 26 March 1857. again!—

This morning besides Maggie’s Note there was one (that had cost “twopence, Sir”) from a man out of his wits,Unidentified. and full of rage agt something or other, whh I burnt: there was also a flaming & solemn set of Invitatns to the Shakespeare Tercentenary: 3 difft kinds of invitatns; “only come to Birmingham,” “in evg dress,” presided over by “George Dawson,”Birmingham’s Shakespeare Tercentenary celebrations were held at Nock’s Hotel, 23 April. The local Shakespeare Committee, led by George Dawson (1821–76; ODNB), preacher and lecturer, presented Birmingham with a new library “as a local memorial of the immortal bard” (Birmingham Daily Post, 25 April). This became the Shakespeare Memorial Library Room which housed Birmingham Central Library’s Shakespeare collection. Dawson, long an admirer of TC (see 19:144JWC to TC, [13–14 Aug. 1845], and 20:145TC to JHA, 15 March 1846), accompanied him to Germany in 1852; see 27:277TC to JAC, 9 Sept. 1852.—Ach Gott in Himmel [Oh God in Heaven]!

Yesterday there was from the Literary Fund an invitatn to be Dinner Steward & see the Prince of Wales;The Examiner announced, 23 April: “The seventy-fifth anniversary dinner of the Corporation [of the Royal Literary Fund] will take place in St. James’s Hall, on Wednesday, the 18 May. His Royal Highness the Prince of Wales, in the Chair. The List of Stewards will be closed on the 30th April, and published.” Albert Edward (1841–1910; ODNB), prince of Wales. only costs you £5. .5, & the price of yr dinner (and the digesting of it);—burnt on the spot. Stratford-on-Avon “Tercentenaries” were also rife (burnt likewise):—Fredk Chapman did however send me a Bill for my yearly “Collective-Works pittance”;—nothing yet for the Frk Vol IV, my refusal by Forster having been positive.
Oh my Darling, I do much miss thee here! But where is the help? I need not continue this,—especially as 3 is struck.The time for TC’s afternoon ride.

I am not sure I shall not try for Sinclair & Norwood this afternoon: it will be one vile thing got done; whh is always a consolatn when one’s conscience repugns & remonstrates, and ones spirits are low.

closer.salute: God bless thee,—and return thee to me soon!

docBody.name: T.C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 13 April. Addr: Dr Blakiston &c &c / St Leonards on Sea. PM: London, 13 April 1864. MS: NLS 616.603. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: My heart is sore and wae exceedingly to hear of yr misery, poor Darling. Too evidt that you are loaded with suffering & dispiritment; and that is a sore element in the Doctor’s confident prognosis,—whh I do believe in too (tho’ poor you cannot): but oh this is a sad drawback to it; and makes one very miserable. And, alas, what can one do in it! Nothing for us but hope, still hope with confidence in spite of present clouds. Perhaps Maggie will send me something better tomorrow: who knows? Perhaps you yrself will manage me a little Note agn before long. Oh do, the soonest you can!—

I did not get so far as Sinclair’s yesterday: at Streatham I had promised to myself to investigate a certain bye-road whh seemed to lead in Norwood directn:—alas on arriving there, I found it shut by a gate (importt circumstance not noticed formerly!)— Upon whh, being very sombre of mood,
I turned for home agn. Today, however, I do mean to go (unless quite too nasty), and have a vile bother finished.

Today Chapmn the elderEdward Chapman. came (see Forster’s Note inclosed); I was very surly with him; but took pity on hearing him out. He is to pay me 3d part at once, 3pt by bill of 6 months, 3d by bill of 9. As I don’t put the least value on those sinister rumours,Possibly in relation to Robson & Levey’s bankruptcy proceedings (see TC to JAC, 12 Jan.) and perhaps referred to in Forster’s (untraced) note. this will cost little inconvenience;—and I cd not afford to haggle on those outworks. Nay there really was some reason in what he urged.— Enough of him—

Will you let Maggie read to you that Dream in the Glasgow Citizen?The Glasgow Citizen published a letter entitled “A Strange Dream” from an anonymous “M.D.,” 9 April 1864: “The perusal lately of an interesting article on ‘Sleep and Dreams,’ in the April number of Macmillan’s Magazine, recalls to my mind a curious dream with which I was visited on Monday morning the 26th of March. In the dream, I was transported to the study of Thomas Carlyle, where I saw the form and features of the grey-haired and many-wrinkled philosopher, as distinctly as next morning I saw the straight form and blooming face of my own wife. The author of ‘Sartor Resartus’ was standing, I at his side; but there was no conversation—silence being apparently the golden rule in this literary-divine vision. While I cannot describe the character of the room in which we were, the one feature of it which attracted my attention was the old lion’s writing-desk, on which lay a neatly-piled heap of finished manuscript, which was probably a portion of his ‘Frederick the Great,’ although I did not seem to know. Now comes the wonder of the dream. While I stood beside the silent T. C., I looking on this heap of M.S., there glided into the chamber a figure as real as, though rather less palpable than, our own. We both knew, and felt assured that we both knew, that this shadowy form was the Deity. Without looking at us, or looking either to the one side or the other, the form moved right up to the desk, and extracted a handful of the M.S. from about the middle of the heap, and at once retired with it. Although this is the wonder of the dream, it did not, in the least, seem to excite either the wonder of T. C. or myself. We did not move from our standing position; and, after what appeared to be an almost imperceptible absence, the same figure quietly returned, and having replaced the M.S. in the exact place from which it had been extracted, retired from our presence as silently and shadowily as it entered. During the continuance of this vision not one word was uttered, and not one touch of wonder felt. I have never seen Thomas Carlyle in the body, and probably never will—his great old face being familiar to me only from the recent photograph; but in the dream I was in his house apparently not for the first time, and as if he and I were on the most intimate terms of friendship. To neither of us did the entrance of the Deity seem at all unexpected; and we felt that the visit was as natural as any everyday occurrence. With the disappearance of the shape, which was of course that of a man, with face muffled—the whole vision melted into thinnest air. I have always possessed a great capacity for dreaming; and while dreams come to me in multitudes, they are neither the children of wine nor indigestion, I being a person of temperate habits and enjoying good health. For the most part, however, my dreams come like shadows, so depart, leaving little more than the merest wrack behind; but this one, in which such august personages figured, will not easily or soon vanish from my memory. Whatever the dream may mean—if anything—I hope that it can only portend good to our distinguished countryman—both to him and his; and that he may be spared to finish, not only the great work which was thus divinely fingered, but others of ripe wisdom and power.” Possibly this was the same “M.D.” as the correspondent of Illustrated London News, 30 Oct. 1858, who claimed knowledge of JWC’s father; identified tentatively as John Burton; see 34:235JWC to JC, [Nov. 1858]. It is
not long; and it excels in loyal Platitude all I have ever witnessed before. Bid her clip it out & date it. And oh a better Note tomorrow, Dear!— Your own ever T.C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, [14 April]. Addr: Dr Blakiston &c &c / St Leonards on Sea. PM: London, 14 April 1864. MS: NLS 616.604. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Again, and ever agn, surely this is very miserable! Can it be the bitter north wind with the glaring sun that is hurting my poor Darling? It is hostile, as everybody feels, to the human skin:—I cannot tell what it is; I can only grieve, and inwardly brood (very unhappily in my bad moments);—and try agn to rally into confidt hope, whh I always do.— Don’t bother yr poor heart abt writing till you feel abler: you know what a pleasure it will be; but let it not cost you pain. I have sent £25;TC recorded, 14 April: “Miss Welsh (for Hastings household) £25 .. 0 .. 0.” (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753). whh Maggy & the Dr (till they know Maggy by herself) will get turned into cash. I thot of putting it in yr name (and will if you like better); but feared it might mean your getting out of a carriage into a Bank &c &c. The sum also is arbitrary & here accidental: I think £25 (twice over or so?) was the sum I handed to Maggie: if you like better to have it in 50’s, say one word.— Robson is horribly delaying me with his Proofs (“bankrupt” &c poor man):See TC to JWC, 14 [12] March. but I am taking the matter in flank;—and andWords repeated at turn of page, with TC’s line over the first “and.” expect to be able to tell you (in not many days) Abt when I shall be able to set off with a certain manageable & really considerable bit of work, and set to doing the same (supposing you shd want me) at yr hand! I mean a big mass of stuff, whh definitely needs only a few Books for managing it! Won’t that be fine,—were the weather better, and my poor Goody with it?—

Never was such a boring jumble of an afternoon & evg as I had at Norwood yesterday.Upper Norwood, where Sir George Sinclair was staying with his son; see TC to JWC, 11 April. Most innocent, & wearisome of men. And Miss OliviaOlivia Sinclair, Sir George’s youngest da. (who was just on the wing for Dundreary & the Theatre)Lord Dundreary was a character in Tom Taylor’s play Our American Cousin (1858), made famous by the actor Edward Askew Sothern (1826–81; ODNB). Sothern was appearing in the play at the Theatre Royal, Haymarket; the Times announced, 11 April: “Theatre Royal, Haymarket. Monday, April 11, and during the week, positively the last nights but five of Mr. Sothern in his famous representation of Lord Dundreary, the performances of which will cease on Friday, April 22.” pressing my hand with a joy
as over a world saved (or what wd save a world, and bidding me “Give her &c (“my regards,” she said with emphasis). I came home after coffee, at the gallop, and had tea not sooner than ½ past 9. Woolner tip-tapped & there was nothing more but talk. Can you appoint the 3 kittens?See TC to JWC, 11 March. All fully ready, says Hellen.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 15 April. Addr: Dr Blakiston &c &c / St Leonards on Sea. PM: London, 15 April 1864. MS: NLS 616.605. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: No sleep agn, my poor little Woman; nothing but bad news on the back of bad! To say truth, I expected nothing better for this day: yesterday when I went out the wind was so cutting and bitter, with clouds of dust whirling in all the ill-watered place, it made my own ride quite comfortless, wretched in the thots I had. “Morphia” in any form is a right unwelcome article;—may it be long before you try it a second time! But I hope, agn hope more than ever. For last night, abt midnight, I cd notice that the wind had quite fallen (probably rain & west-wind not far off), and today is far more temperate and soft:—indeed it is almost too warm up here.TC’s attic study. Larkin was called in a few days before to open the window; see TC to JWC, 11 April.— — That is a miserable ugly little thing that of poor Mary’s. What a pity she had not run to the Post-Office with her sovereigns, poor soul!Mary, the maid who was with JWC at St. Leonards, had presumably just received her wages, which were paid quarterly. TC gave Helen her wages, £3 7s. 6d., early April; see TC to JWC, [5 April]. I shd think there can be no doubt but somebody within the House must have done it: no thief from the streets wd think of scaling such a House, with the street-door standing permanently on latch-key. Totally unimaginable. But that will not bring the money back; I fear there is no hope of that.

Last night I was preparing for tea (8 o’clock just gone), and intending my best for an attempt on something of work after,—when tit-tit-tat, and (to my relief) only VenablesGeorge Stovin Venables. entered. Rather dullish; but has some real understanding,—seraphic in comparison with my Ballantyes &c. “Lowe,” he tells me, is
out of Office; & he seemed to think deservedly so.Robert Lowe (1811–92; ODNB), MP for Calne 1859–68, vice president of the Committee of Council on Education 1859–64, from which he resigned after a vote of censure accused the committee of over-editing school inspectors’ reports before publishing them; it was later exonerated. Likely to be stinted too in carronading (in the old way) from The Times,—his Parliamenty Seat being Calne whh depends on Marquis of Lansdown.Lowe was also a leader writer for the Times, 1851–68. His constituency (composed of 174 electors), Calne, Wiltshire, about 90 mi. (145 km.) W of London, was under the patronage of Henry Thomas Petty Fitzmaurice (1816–66; ODNB), 4th marquess of Lansdowne, whig politician. No matter, no great matter, “my Robert!”— — God send me better news of thee, poor little Dear. Amen / T.C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 16 April. Addr: Dr Blakiston &c &c / St Leonards on Sea. PM: London, 16 April, 1864. MS: NLS 616.606A. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Oh my poor Darling, is there to be no end of the bad news, then? Morphia and no sleep; alas, I thot we had had enough of that. I hear of nothing so welcome as that the Dr does not intend anything farther of that kind! I like to hear also of his sitting to chat with you, in the endeavour (whh itself is something) to pull up yr thot from their too natural despondency. God grant that Maggy may send me some Note yet this night, of better tenor, to carry me over the Sunday!— I shall be very thankful; but ought to prepare also for disappointt.

I have had a baffling totally unsuccessful day; set of Proofs coolly defying all that I can do upon them,—dull, beclouded, downpressed and altogether owlish as I am! Perhaps I shall do better after my ride. Yellow artists and their Organ-grinding are the only encouraget at prest offered.— We had rain last night, and the West victorious. Now it is dim-grey, and the East is blowing agn. The West is sure of victory however, and that soon.
I am glad to hear of Mary’s recovering her 4 sovns: if I were in her place I wd invest them in a Post-Office Savings Bank, where they cannot be stolen.

My Sister Jean is gone to Edinr, “to look at it after 36 years”;—stays with John (some room or other vacant)John A. Carlyle had rooms at 67 Hanover St., Edinburgh. till Wedny next. A Letter from said John, anounces that she is come,—and otherwise is vacancy’s self as usual.
I wish anybody wd refuse Forster for me! But I myself have hardly strength of mind to do it.
Well, well; shd not I say to myself what you often hear from me, “Courage, courage!”— It is the vile baffle of work I have suffered all day.
docBody.name: T.C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 18 April. MS: NLS 616.606B. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: The Note of Saty night was a grateful relief to me; and I hoped this bad fit was over, and better times of progress come in. Alas, the Reports this morning (Maggie’s especially) throw me all aback agn! I have been so busy too, ever since they came, that I have got no right meditating on the facts, or what probably the real aspect of the matter may be;—I shall not, till I get on horseback (that is, 10 minutes hence), or till I have got athwart the railway screamingsThere was much railway building in London during the 1860s, some of which TC would pass on his ride, which was probably SW to Wimbledon; see TC to JWC, 25 April. (half an hour hence), fairly get the matter meditated;—“Oh dear” is all I can yet say; Oh dear for my poor Goody and myself!—

So much I can see; Dr Bln persists in his opinn; tho’ the force of yr depression of spirits seems to disappoint him.Blakiston wrote, 17 April: “Whilst I am able to pronounce Mrs Carlyle’s general health much improved, & to tell you that she has gained both strength and flesh, I regret to inform you that her mind still morbidly dwells on certain local sensations, which she says are in no wise relieved / As I have exhausted all the remedial measures that are known to me, I can only hope that time may yet do that which medicine has failed to accomplish.” On the street the other day, BarnesDr. Alfred Barnes. stopped me to ask: when I told of yr dispiritment he too ansd, “Oh yes, mawbid, mawbid” (meaning morbid imaginatn, and confidt that it wd go off by degrees). God help thee, my Darling; it is very evidt thou art in sore & almost constant misery (whh it is miserable even to witness) whatevr the origin of it may be!— Maggie says (or you by her), “You almost wish you were at home agn.” Dr Bln says “you talk sometimes of hiring a small House,” and asks “Is he to help you in that?”Blakiston wrote: “She seems anxious to get into a small house here, & if you also think this would be desirable, we will immediately look out for one.” By all means, if you deliberately wish it! Tell him so;—or ought I to tell him? (Perhaps I may send you his Letter itself;—tho’ you might by possibility be piqued at his “morbid” notions?)— Yr little head, poor Dear, was one of the clearest in he[r] MtysFor “Majesty’s”; letter omitted in “her.” dominions, up to my last sight of it Whatever it decides abt this affair, shall be a decree to me,
unless matters have wonderfully changed in the interim.— A mass of rubbishy Letters came along with Maggie’s: too numerous & worthless for me to send as yet. I enclose Jean’s from Edinr, if it can answer you for a moment. God bless thee, Dearest One.— T.C.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [19 April]. Addr: 5 Cheyne Row / Chelsea / London. S.W. PM: Hastings, 19 April 1864. MS: NLS 608.623. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:196 inc; Wilson, Carlyle 5:542 inc. Quot: Ireland, JWC 287. The envelope is written in another hand, presumably Maggie Welsh’s.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p: It is no “morbid despondency”TC referred to JWC’s “dispiritment” and interpreted Barnes’s word “mawbid” (following Blakiston’s “morbidly”) for JWC’s state of mind as “morbid imaginatn”; see TC to JWC, 18 April.—it is positive physical torment day and night—a burning throbbing maddening sensation in the most nervous part of me ever and ever— How be in good spirits or have any hope but to die!
When I spoke of going home it was to die there, here were the place for living—if one could!

It was not my wish to leave here. It was the Blakistons own suggestion and wish that we should get a little house of our own. I have rather wondered at the short time their benevolence has held out but it is natural as not even the honour of a cure is to be gained for all their pains!
Oh have pity on me— I am worse than ever I was in that terrible malady
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 19 April. Addr: Dr Blakiston &c &c / St Leonards on Sea. PM: London, 19 April 1864. MS: NLS 616.607. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: My Darling, I will not rejoice over-much, nor be confidt beyond what my usual wont is; but surely I am very glad,—and do thank the Morphia for once! Probably the late bad weather had the main share in yr miseries, after all? We are now fast getting into Summer; too fast, for my temperate feeling (as an individl, not as a Good to Goody)—but there will be plenty of fluctuatn yet; and puffs of cold, whh I wd have you beware of.

On consideratn, I see not why I shd not send you that short Note of the Dr’s: it will shew you the back of his cards,—if you ever suspected they were
difft, on the side he shewed me.For Blakiston’s letter of 17 April, see TC to JWC, 18 April. Make my peace with him, if I am doing medically wrong,—shd you ever speak to him on the subject, as I reckon it probable you won’t; but leave you freedom. Certainly no people have helped us like these Two in our sore time. An obligatn I will never forget.

As to the “small House,” you know you are Missus in that question; and that, if it seemed to ansr otherwise, and a House quiet, and containing a writing room not with western exposure (beware of the west for heat!)—I shd like it better than anything other. Look abt you therefore; and let me know how you prosper in House-seeking, if you do try it.

I am arranging with all my might to be ready soon with a mass of work that will be portable (Proof-Slips whh from Book 1 of Vol VI, these can be done with a map & few Books); Robson’s shift of place,Charles Robson, in partnership with one or both of his sons John and Christopher, was now at St. Pancras Road. & the delay occasioned, fits in too.

I made a mess of my day yesterday, and of my night;—want of punctuality! Nothing stirring or arriving; but goosy-goosy Notes from Norwood (good old GooseSir George Sinclair. reading me in bed yonder);—& work has gone not so ill. Adieu, Dearest. / T.C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, [20 April]. Addr: Dr Blakiston &c &c / St Leonards on Sea. PM: London, 20 April 1864. MS: NLS 616.608. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p:
Dearest,—What a gleam as lightning, clear & sad, these two or three lines from yr own poor hand are! Alas, there is no doubt abt my poor woman’s own real pain and wretchedness, whatever the Doctors may entitle it. But on the whole I am not disappointed: common sense teaches me, first that yr recovery of nerves never cd be sudden; 2d that visibly (to myself, were there no testimony of Medicine as an Art at all) yr genl or outward and essential state of health had improved, and is improving (yes, Darling, there is no doubt of that, & the summer is before us, and the summer is as if come,—tho’ we shall have bad weather yet); 3dly thirdly,Word repeated at top of next page. that Medical Art never has done, nor does now, nor ever can do anything for you (tho’ the Summer sea-air, and food & exercise, and the vis medicatrix [healing power] that is in Nature everywhere, certainly will);—and fourthly (what practically might have been firstly of all), that you must with all decent diligence get into a House of
our own!— I meant this day to announce that practically to Dr Blakn (seeing how it lies), but have no time left: do you take all steps you can in it, and push the others into diligence; no delay abt “fourthly”!— On the whole, do not say their beneficence has ended soon: I really am infinitely obliged to them (and will try to shew them so, at least to make their money-considns good);—and I privately think it has lasted very long. Think if Mrs Bn & 2 had come to No 5 here?JWC, Maggie Welsh, and the maid Mary were all staying at the Blakistons. Oh be “pious,” Darling sufferer! Write a word tomorrow too, wilt thou? T.C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JN, 20 April. MS: McGill Univ. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p: Dear Neuberg,—I shd like something of detail abt Raynal’s relations to Frh, especially Frhs receptn of him in 1781.Guillaume Thomas François Raynal (1713–96), French writer, whose L’Histoire philosophique et politique des établissements et du commerce des Européens dans les deux Indes, 4 vols. (Amsterdam, 1770), was banned in France, 1779, and burned by the public executioner. Raynal fled to Berlin, where he was coolly received by Frederick the Great in 1782; TC gave him the briefest of mentions; see Carlyle, Works 19:270. Here is a Note, especially a reference to Preuss iii.270TC’s reference is to Rödenbeck, not Preuss; see Carlyle, Works 19:270. whh will initiate you.— By the blessing of Heaven Vol 5 is now (after the miserablest delays) gone from me, forever & a day. Vol 6 I am determined to see ended (on some terms) before Autumn quite go!

The Engraver has got the “Frh at his last Review” (Frh self & horse is all he will attempt).J. Browne engraved the detail “Friedrich II König von Preussen” (Carlyle, Works 19:frontispiece.) from Friedrich’s ‘Last Review,’ painted by Edward (sometimes Edmund) Francis Cunningham (ca. 1742–95; ODNB), Scottish portrait painter. The frontispiece of the 1st edn. of Frederick noted that the picture also contained 39 other portraits of his generals, and that its full title was Frédéric le Grand retournant à Sans-Souci après Les Manoeuvres, accompagné de ses Généraux. J. Browne was possibly Joseph Brown, engraver (listed in E. Benezet, Dictionnaire des Peintres Sculpteurs Dessinateurs et Graveurs [Gründ, 1999]); otherwise not further identified. Photograph of the Mask of F’s faceThe deathmask of Frederick the Great, cast by the Prussian court sculptor Johann Eckstein (1736–1817); see 28:26–27TC to CKJB, 3 Feb. 1853. (in Kunst-kammer [Art Gallery]: MagnusEduard Magnus (1799–1872), German portrait and genre painter, professor at the Berlin Academy, gave TC considerable help in finding portraits of Frederick; see 27:324–26TC to LOA, 7 Oct. 1852, and 33:211TC to WWV, 22 April 1858. will have to be written to abt that
Yrs always T.C.

My very kind regards to all those friends you mention: the Erskines,Possibly Thomas Erskine and his sister Christian Stirling, in Edinburgh. the Richardsons,Possibly John Richardson (1780–1864; ODNB), and one of his two unmarried das., Isabella Helen (1821–79) or Joanna Baillie (1831–1900); see 36:78TC to VL, 26 Feb. 1860. Richardson was in poor health and lived at Kirklands, nr. Jedburgh, Scotland. the Speddings,Possibly Thomas Story Spedding (1800–1870) and his wife, Frances Emily, b. Headlam (ca. 1811–86), who lived at Mirehouse, nr. Keswick, Cumberland; or his brother James Spedding (1808–81; ODNB), who lived at 60 Lincoln’s Inn Fields until sometime in 1864, when he moved to Westbourne Grove, where he lived with his widowed sister-in-law, Jane, b. Headlam (ca. 1807–84), and her two das., Sarah Frances (b. 1836) and Isobel (b. 1839).—lady and gentn in each case, nominatim [by name].It is unclear whether Neuberg intended visiting or writing to them. Yours ever faithful T. Carlyle

ps.p: News from Hastings baddish lately—but I hope they are improving.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 21 April. Addr: Dr Blakiston &c &c / St Leonards on Sea. PM: London, 21 April 1864. MS: NLS 616.609. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Darling, I am under Mercury; I have many things to say,—but not now, in such haste & such spirits.

One thing I wish you wd particularly convince yourself of (and perhaps Maggies conviction as that of an impartial bystander wd be a useful confirmatn): namely That the people’s wish really & truly is that you shd leave them. I begin to think it possible yr jealously proud spirit may have misled you. The Blakistons are not to lose anything of their vulgar money-substance by their kindness to you past, prest, or to come (I hope they are aware of this; I wish, if not, that they shd clearly be). It seems to me possible the £3 weekly may not be so despicable,—instead of a big house, gaping vacant;—and that they really do not want you to go away, if you wd consent to sit witht suspicn of their grud[g]ingLetter omitted. you? This ought to be ascertained, Yes or No, beyond possibility of doubting it farther,—before anything is concluded in Marina.A house had been found to rent at 117 Marina, St. Leonards; they moved there 28 April. (Can’t you employ Maggy,—as an impartl third party: to use her best politeness, discretn &c, and above all, candid eyesight?)

My Darling knows, I wd somewhat rather be in a “House of our own” (somewhat, but I cd do bravely too in that upper room): but yr shudder at shifting is very intelligible to me; & then it seems at the end of june (2 months hence) we shd have to shift agn! That seems to me a sad drawback.— —
Well, this is all today. For you & for Self, Darling, my heart is wae, wae; & I will say no more. Card enclosed came this morng. God be with you T.C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-FC, 22 April 1864. MS facsimile reproduced with text: Michael Silverman Catalogue 1998.
div3.head: TC TO FREDERIC CHAPMAN

docBody.p: Recd from Mr Chapman, in Three Drafts payable at different times, One thousand one hundred & sixteen Pounds, &c (£1, 116 .. 13 .. 4); being payment for Four thousand Copies of Vol. Fourth of Frederic the Great,—500 other Copies remaining, whh are not payable at present.TC noted: “26 April 1864 … £1,116 &c part paid, part payable (price of vol IV)” (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753).
docBody.name: Thos Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 22 April. Addr: Dr Blakiston &c &c / St Leonards on Sea. PM: London, 22 April 1864. MS: NLS 616.610. Pbd: Bliss, TC 364–65 inc.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p:
My Dearest,—I am very glad for all our sakes! It appears, my theories of yesterday were already completely settled, and the per contra ascertained as fact; whh being the case, news of a House actually got, on such suitable terms, is the very best news I cd expect on that head. Me the House will suit far better than any kind of “lodging” wd;—my one reason for wishing yr continuance was that I thought the change wd flurry & fret you; and that the House in questn wd have to be changed from agn. As it is, may I not hope that the adjustt of yourself once more under your own little roof, may perhaps be a distractn from yr sore inward miseries, and so do you, as well as all the rest of us, good! O how I long to see my dear little Ship’s Captn take command agn, and lay her deft little hand upon the rudder once more! You will, I am sure, if not now altogether, get soon altogether, & then there will be lucky voyage again. I trust in God that does await me: it will be the brightest thing that has befallen me since that evg, when I lay on the sofa expecting my little Dove “home from the city”JWC’s accident, 22 Sept. 1863, occurred on her way home from visiting her cousin Mary Godby (1826–86), who lived in St. Martin’s le Grand, City of London; see 39:204–206TC to JCA, 27 Sept. 1863. See also 39:27339:biographical notes, and Carlyle, Reminiscences 163. (ah me!) with Olive in her bill!Cf. Gen. 8:11. There has been a sad nightmare instead. But we will look back on that too with tender feelings,
not with pain, if it please God!— Maggie had by yr order something abt “expence.” Dismiss that thot, I bid you. My little Jeannie was the thriftiest and most gracefully poor of all Eve’s Daughters when we had nothing (whh makes me richer than PotosiBolivian town at the foot of a mountain containing one of the richest silver mines in the world, thus a byword for untold wealth; cf. 1:282TC to WG, 19 Oct. 1820. to think of now):—and ought not she, of all women, to have plenty now that there is enough and to spare?—

I have, all this while, beingThus in MS. scheming out work possible at Hastings; and in spite of poor Robson’s own hurries and confusions, whh to me are such intolerable delays and sources of uncertainty & incalculability,—I think I have managed it; and that, practically, you will hardly have the new House heated (and tried on all sides, whh was an excellt thing to bargn for) till it will rise to be discussed “What day is the fellow to be expected then?” Today I have written to JohnJohn A. Carlyle arrived 24 April; see TC to JWC, [25 April]. that if he proposes to visit me “for a fortnight,” he must set abt it straightway! & so, within some 4 or perhaps even 3 weeks— But it is too soon yet till you have got moored in yr new berths. I calculate it will do me a great deal of good: and Heaven knows whether I don’t need it. London & my gloomy sick existence in it has been growing more and [more]“More” inserted in another hand. oppressive, since you had to leave it and me. Ah me, ah me!—

Today I am in the post-mercurial state, whh, you know, means castor:Castor oil. I lost 1½ hours of my morning sleep; my oleaginous friend forbids free riding, and threatens otherwise to go bankrupt,—disgusting friend. Chapman too was here, and paid me all my moneys;—these I had to distribute (with instructns) among Bankers (Dumfries & a modicum here);TC kept most of his money in the British Linen Co., Dumfries, and money for daily living expenses in the London Joint-Stock Bank, 69 Pall Mall. so that my “work” has been a zero today,—alas, zero itself, it must be owned. But I am going to walk; then to see if riding be good. God bless thee, Dearest.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 23 April. Addr: Dr Blakiston &c &c / St Leonards on Sea. PM: London, 23 April 1864. MS: NLS 616.611. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p:
Dearest, do not fret yr little heart, one moment: I believe every word you make Maggie write represents a bit of fact,—whh you see and saw, and whh
I cd only guess at from the distance. The getting of the House,—deducting merely the flurrying & fussing you get by it (whh, I hope, Maggy will well screen you from, in many points) was the one thing I regretted; to myself & to all of us otherwise I regard it as a clear improvet & gain. So be steady, poor Dear, and witht fussing yr poor heart, get out of this First Scene into Scene Second & the new locality. By the way, I think if you cd take any charge of her, this Maid Ellen wd prove an excellt servant,—she really seems to me a cleanly, orderly, correct, swift and handy creature, and might be made by you— Well and I believe she will too! But you will have to partitn the duties as accurately & str[ictly]Word unclear; MS torn. as you can; for this big Body won’t be subject to Mary; and indeed she is a cleverer creature much, and already nearly (not yet quite) as punctual.

Robson the Printer came in person; can do nothing for me at prest (just flitting);To new premises; see TC to JWC, 19 April. does hope to give me “all the remaing Seven-Years War”See Carlyle, Works 18:481–93. (whh I thot of correcting at Hastings) “by the end of May,“—alas! But I have already devised other work (of few books) for doing in Marina, if end of May be too long to linger here.

Some time ago, Jack spoke of visiting me if I wished it. “Two weeks,” I ansd, “if you wish it” (for I don’t thingThus in MS, for “think.” I can be helped much by visiting, tho’ the sight of poor Jack and the hearing of Scotch news might well be cheering now & then in such solitude). Jack [I]Word obscured in MS. believe does intend; but since that day (as his custom is) avoids the least hint abt the matter! Yesterday I had to write, “If you are for coming, come at once!” Today there is the inclosed bit of Brevity from him,—whh will carry you to Edinr & Jean there, not disagreeably. The Forster Dinner I have verbally refused.— — Yesterday I had no riding, almost no walking even,—silence, and castor fallen bankrupt. However, I got my sleep back (I wish poor thou, half as well!) and to day have not the usual abhorrence to riding. Garibaldi is gone too;Giuseppe Garibaldi (1807–82), Italian patriot, left London, 23 April, on his way back to Italy. He came to England, 3 April, to thank the British nation for its support of the unification of Italy, and to be treated for a leg wound sustained at Aspromonte Aug. 1862 (see 38:185JWC to TC, 2 Sept. 1862). He made a triumphal entry into London, 11 April, greeted by half a million people, mostly working-class, welcoming him as a champion of the dispossessed and a courageous foe of despotism. The Russian radical exile Alexander Herzen (1812–70) remarked, “The idol of the masses, the one grand popular figure of our age that has been perfected since 1848, enters in all the brilliance of its glory. Everything bows down before it, everything celebrates its triumph; this is Carlyle’s hero-worship in real life” (My Past Thoughts, trans. Constance Garnett [1926] 5:33). He was also taken up by the aristocracy, possibly deliberately to prevent him mingling with radicals. Pressure was brought to bear on the British government by the rulers of France, Italy, Austria, and others, and Garibaldi’s planned tour of the provinces was suddenly canceled on the grounds that he was too ill to continue. Courage!—

ps.p: 23 April 1864 (Shakespeare-Fool Day)For TC’s views on the celebrations around Shakespeare’s birthday, see TC to JWC, 8 April.

div3.sourceNote: MW-TC, [24 April]. MS: NLS 1768.70 and 72. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: MARGARET WELSH TO TC

docBody.p: I can only give you a very poor account of Cousin today I am sorry to say. She was very poorly all day yesterday & went to bed as soon as she came in from her drive. This morning she went out for an hour but she felt so ill when she came home that she said she could not sit up & has been in bed all the afternoon. I have just asked her if she has any message & she says “tell him that I feel very ill, & that often I want him to come, but that I do not want if I can help it to disturb his work; but that some day perhaps I really will ask him to come to see me.” If one could but give her one moment’s ease & make her feel more comfortable it would be a comfort to oneself as well as to her, but one feels utterly powerless to do even that, she seems so completely miserable from pain & discomfort. It is very miserable truly for her, & to us to see her so suffering it goes to one’s heart. She may be stronger in actual strength, but indeed the amount of suffering to all appearances is as great as ever it has been in all her illness. How she keeps any strength at all I cannot tell, for whatever they may say it is difficult to believe, when one sees her constantly, that the suffering is not so great to herself as it appears to others. It would be a comfort to think it if I could. Like other things the morphia seems to have lost its effect. She did not have it last night; the Dr thinks it ought not to be given without stopping it for some days.

I am truly sorry to have to send you such a miserable report today but it is no use saying she is better than she is, in hopes of her feeling really a little better tomorrow as I would fain hope she may be.

ps.p: I am glad to hear your brother is coming to you for a little, you will be glad to have him.

Cousin has just asked me to open my note to say will you please to send a
cheque for 12 guineas for the Dr, as she thinks the Cheque will be better than the moneyThis second postscript was written on a separate slip of paper.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, [25 April]. Addr: Dr Blakiston &c &c / St Leonards on Sea. PM: London, 25 April 1864. MS: NLS 616.612. Pbd: Bliss, TC 365–66.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Oh my poor little Jeannie, what is this agn! Maggie’s Note has cut me to the heart; and indeed I am, with this not alone, but with this beyond all other things, extremely miserable. But there is no use mentioning that. I have studied to stick closer to work all day, as the only resource there is (but a very poor and inadequate resource too);—and in my last ¼ hour here, must continue to do so.— Send for you,Presumably TC meant “me.” Dearest, any day you like I will come: indeed I begin to feel dimly that if yr House suit, I shall be better there; and in spite of the Printer, I perceive I can bring work. “Abt the middle of May perhaps?” (i.e. in a fortnight or not much more), that begins to be a speculatn with me. Oh get better, Dear!—

I have sent you Twenty Guineas; you asked for “Twelve”; but I think, if you meant that as payment of Bln, you must have quite stinted yr own generous feelings (out of love to me); certainly my own is that it ought to be Twenty. If you don’t mean it as payt in genl, but merely as payt for something you have counted to be really £12 .. 12, send me back this, and I will burn it, and write you a 12 .. 12 instead.TC noted: “29 April 1864 / Dr. Pn Blakiston / St Leonards / £21. .0. .0 / (This was cancelled flung into the fire as wrong for the prest)” (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753); TC misdated the counterfoil. See also TC to JWC, 25 April.

Yesterday morning while I sat breakfasting, “Dr Carlyle, Sir!” as large as life walked in. Poor fellow, he tries to be as gentle regular and accomodating as possible; is evidently very sorry for me and mine: & had I somebody to keep house, wd be a comfort to me in idle hours;TC later wrote: “In the end of April, brother John came to me. Before this it had been decided (since the B[lakiston]s, who at first pretended that they would, now evidently would not, accept remuneration from us) that a small furnished house should be rented, and a shift made thither; which was done and over about the time John came. I was to remove thither with my work (so soon as liftable). He by himself made a preliminary visit thither; then perhaps another with me; and at his return I could notice (though he said nothing) that he meant to try staying with us there; which he did, and surely was of use to me there” (TC’s note in Froude, LM 3:194–95).—but that is not much the case yet. Oh Maggie write me better news,—tho’ indeed you must write me
the true before & in spite of all. May God help my poor little woman & me to better!— T.C (Monday 3¼ p.m.).

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 25 April. Addr: Dr Blakiston &c &c / St Leonards on Sea. PM: London, 26 April 1864. MS: NLS 616.613. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Monday Night (Second Note).—It was not till I had got out to ride, and was across the Tartarean ringTartarus, in Greek and Roman mythology the lowest part of hell. of railways & screaming confusions,See TC to JWC, 18 April. that I got to see what you had meant with the Twelve-guinea Draught: it was to pay yr Lodging for 4 weeks on the day you should go. Twelve, therefore, must be the sum; and here (to arrive tomorrow Evg, and not fret you farther) is the Draught for it.TC noted: “25 April 1864 / To Dr Pn Blakiston / St Leonards / £12 .. 12 .. 0 / This too is struck out” (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753). The Twenty-one you can, for the present, return (unless you instruct me better,—for I have very little time to think of it): I guess it ought to be Twenty-five (or some such sum,—that you approve of); and paid at a difft time, after all that?— You shall instruct me when (whh I hope will be soon I am your guest. Oh get better, Dearest; and all will yet be well!—

I had a tearing ride, round by Wimbledon &c &c: the doing of it, especially the entrance on it is not pleasant; but it brings always a sensible benefit. Oh that you were but waiting my return with yr pleasant bits of news and talk as heretofore while I sat safe smoking my pipe!— — Heaven grant Maggie may send me better news tomorrow. Good night, Darling. Yours
docBody.name: T.C.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [25 April]. Addr: 5 Cheyne Row / Chelsea / London. PM: St. Leonards, 25 April 1864. MS: NLS 608.624. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:196–97; Ireland, JWC 287 inc; Wilson, Carlyle 5:542; Fielding and Sorensen 298. Quot: Ashton 432. TC later wrote on the envelope (dating incorrectly): “St Leonard’s 1864, April 5 / Excruciating! Alas, alas!—“
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p: Oh my Husband! I am suffering torments! each day I suffer more horriblyTC wrote later of this letter and JWC’s letters of 8 and 19 April: “In those seven or eight months of martyrdom (October 1863–May 1864) there is naturally no record of the poor dear martyr’s own discoverable; nothing but these small, most mournful notes written with the left hand, as if from the core of a broken heart, and worthy to survive as a voice de profundis” (TC’s note in Froude, LM 3:195).

Oh I would like you beside me,—I am terribly alone— But I dont want to
interrupt your work— I will wait till we are in our own hired house and—then if I am no better you must come for a day

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, [26 April]. Addr: Dr Blakiston &c &c / St Leonards on Sea. PM: London, 26 April 1864. MS: NLS 616.614. Pbd: Bliss, TC 366.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Patience, Darling; Oh try to bear yr sore load, my little woman, whh makes us all miserable (me at least, right certainly) in yr sad unrelievable misery. Wd I cd but do the least thing that wd help it. To come to you? Oh yes, Dearest; that I will surely do! Indeed it begins to be plain or almost plain that I shall do little good even in my work till I get settled beside you. “Middle of May or so“:—and send for me sooner, send for me any time when you want me. Robson is likely to be silent till May end; I am prosecuting my writing here; and endeavouring to make for better progress than I turn out to be able for.— My mercury too (as is usual, and ITC wrote “(t.o.)” at the foot of the page. could not dispense with it) has rendered me utterly sad, for one thing. But I am better too, au fond [at bottom].

Yesternight I sent you the proper Draught (so soon as I had leisure to consider): I long now to hear of yr removal (day after tomorrow), & how poor you have stood it. If all be right there, it will not be long till I come with my luggages: if anything be wrong, it is the more reason why I shd come at once “for a day” or longer, whenever you demand me.— Here is a Letter from Lady An; for whom I ought to call, I suppose, tomorrow or next day. She seems to know little of yr situation; thinking of a visit to The Grange!— Jean seems to have been greatly entertained by her Edinr week;See TC to JWC, 16 April. a phrase of hers (to John, abt the sight of me) almost makes me cry, in poor down humour. God bless my Dear.—T.C

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 26 April. Addr: Dr Blakiston &c &c / St Leonards on Sea. PM: London, 26 April 1864. MS: NLS 616.615. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p:
Maggie’s Report is still bad then: alas, what can I do! Blakiston may be exaggerative; indeed, I cd see he took far too little pity on yr evidt miseries; and
perhaps he might also medically underrate them—and bluster them away: but I do not consider yet that his medical verdict was mistaken,—the less as it agrees with that of everybody who has experience of such things. John has been telling me of a recent Edinr case: a Dr Henderson,Probably William Henderson (1810–72; ODNB), homeopathic physician, 50 Moray Pl., Edinburgh. big strong man, betn 50 & 60, and diligt Physicn there, he took a neuralgia in the arm, obstinate tic in it whh defied all remedies, and “for two years kept him from ever once fairly sleeping!”— Being very miserable, he at length tried by himself some (t.o.) solutn of arsenic (famous well-established solutn name I forgetPossibly a homeopathic solution of Arsenicum album.), took 3 drops of it daily; had evidt benefit, but was always obliged to pause, as it acted on his teeth too: but always began agn after pause; and in few weeks, “one night” the pain went utterly away, and sleep & health are restored ever since. “Her pain may, probably will, go away, like a flash of lightning,” says poor Jack, to comfort me. “I wonder if she wd try tincture of arsenic?” says he sometimes. Oh Darling, do try & pluck up spirit agn!—

Hellen has gathered all yr comanded Bundle; all except one of the good Table cloths (whh is at the Wash till saty, Wash’s address not known): I think she means taking all the other things to Oakley streetIsabella Simmonds lived in Oakley St.; perhaps she was to forward the “commanded Bundle.” The “Wash,” presumably for “Washerwoman,” unidentified. this night; but will adjoin the Tablecloth in time, if you wish it & give the address.— Adieu, loved & suffering one. My time is done. Here are plenty of Letters of last night. Heaven help thee tomorrow at Flitting time! I hope Maggy has sent the “No” of Marina. Adieu. T.C. (Wedny 26th)

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 28 April. Addr: 6(?) Marina (or ask at Warrior Square No 5) / St Leonards on Sea. PM: London, 28 April 1864. MS: NLS 616.616. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p:
What a dim cold dirty day, my poor little woman is getting for her flitting to the new House! Maggie has not happened to send me (indeed I did not ask in time, & I dare say she had told me once already) the No in Marina: but I calculate you will get this, too,—were it good for anything, except to say “Alas, I am here, and watching you with a heart wae enough, if that cd help!”— I am terribly plagued (or fancy myself so, being thin skinned just now) with interruptns here: Night before last, it was Tom Wilson & Dr Willis:Thomas Wilson and Dr. Robert Willis.—ah me; but Tom is off, almost at Hamburg by this time. Last night, it was J. Aitken (Dr &
heTC’s nephew James Aitken and Dr. John A. Carlyle. sitting here, on my return from riding; unable to say distinctly whether they were dined or not, agreed it shd be “half-dined“: one portion for us two &c &c!) It is with the greatest difficulty, that I can save 3 hours out of my 24 for real work,—that is to say for a swim as if for life. Stead[y],Letter omitted. howevr;—oh that I cd be steady!—

Yesterday John AllenProbably John Hensleigh Allen (1818–68; see 33:51TC to JWC, 25 Aug. 1857), cousin of Hensleigh Wedgwood (1803–91; ODNB) and his wife, Frances (Fanny), b. Mackintosh (1800–1889), old friends of the Carlyles; see 9:106–7TC to HWE, 11 Dec. 1836.John Hensleigh Wedgwood was unidentified at 33:51. stopped me on the street (as did others after) to say that Robt Mackintosh had been suffering all winter (disease of the heart), and this morning was dead!Robert James Mackintosh (1806–64; see 30:224JWC’s Journal, 21 Oct. 1855), British colonial governor, Frances Wedgwood’s brother; he d. Mon. 25 April. I cannot tell you what a knock it gave me. Poor Mackh; an honourable gallant kind of man; and we are (suddenly, to me altogether) to behold him no more. The eldest Wedgd son, it also appears, is dying;James Mackintosh Wedgwood (1834–64), Hensleigh and Frances Wedgwood’s eldest son, d. 24 June. mother & Father hastening home from Rome,—uncertn whether they will find him alive.— — Lady Ashbn when I called yesterday, was “not coming till tomorrow, Sir”; today probably I shall be across River.—— John has taken a crying to go down & see you: I suppose he wd do nothing but annoy you?— In that case, I will keep him away. Jean’s Letter mentns Mrs RussellMary Russell. &c. God bless you, dear. T.C.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [28 April]. Addr: 5 Cheyne Row / Chelsea / London. PM: St. Leonards, 28 April 1864. MS: NLS 608.625. Pbd: Fielding and Sorensen 298 inc. TC later wrote on the envelope: “1864 / 27 April”; 28 April confirmed by the date of their move to 117 Marina.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p: Maggie and Mary are gone with the luggage in a fly—leaving me to follow, after their fires are lighted. Oh me! me! What dismal work this is!

But thank God for two days of ease! I dare not hope the stilling of my torture will last. It has been obtained by rubbing in opium—and opium has never continued to help me—Dr B has no idea what that agony is! He has called it half a dozen different things—followed half a dozen different treatments—and when at his wits end he ignores the misery of the thing altogether.

I cannot think there can be any analogy between that Edinr caseDr. Henderson’s case, information sent by John A.
