Carlyle; see TC to JWC, 26 April. and mine—for mine is specially female Nevertheless I spoke to Dr B about the arsenic— And he said “he never used Arsenic it was a medecine he disapproved entirely“— That “he would meet Dr Carlyle in consultation if he pleased—but random suggestions founded on no knowledge of the case were not worth listening to“—
He himself has made a good many “random suggestions,” it seems to me—

And I am to take “patience“—and “keep up my spirits.” Oh if you felt for one five minutes, the torture I have been feeling for months, without hope of relief except in the grave—you would not dare to tell me about patience.

See what a long letter I have written!— Tomorrow it will probably be the old story— I shall get no sleep in the new bed—and the rubbing in will no longer avail! It is strange that I can take no joy in my present ease—but I do not—I dare not— I have been so often mocked with momentary improvements produced by new remedies and giving place to worse torment than before!
Oh you may understand my state; when wishing ardently to live, for your sake and other sakes, I nevertheless pass no day without wishing myself dead—out of my misery

ps.p: Dr B would have nothing to do with the check “never meant to take rent from us” Maggie will send it backSee TC to JWC, [25 April], and TC to JWC, 25 April.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 29 April. Addr: 6(?) Marina (used to be 5. Warrior Square) / St Leonards on Sea. PM: London, 29 April 1864. MS: NLS 616.617. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Oh how I wish I cd hear that you slept well last night! Whh I will still try to think possible (tho alas not very likely) in spite of yr anticipations. Temporary I will believe this bit of improvet to be; but how thankful even for a two days of it, for one day. In spite of all my misgivings I have seen nothing Dearest, since you went away that has given me so much real pleasure as this first real Letter of yours, in your old hand, and with yr old sharpness of wits & insight into facts abt you. Heaven send me more of them; day after day, I shd ask for nothing better!

I hope No 6 wd find you this morning. Maggie will now write me an acct of the House (need not be minute, what rooms are in it, what &c): and give
me the No to start with!— John is in strong anxiety and curiosity to know, whether he will be accepted tomorrow (he wd go himself &c &c): but I do not think (tho’ I have not told him) there is the least chance for tomorrow; nor cd it probably do anything but bother you all. Next Saty perhaps;—by whh time (or almost by whh) perhaps I might be almost ready to come myself for good—if I were to undertake . . akeRepeated at turn of page. at once! Do as you like, Dear. Jack’s skill in such disorders cannot well be considerable; but I shd judge it cd not well be less than that of all the Medicos you have had from this hand & that; and his sympathy in the matter is evidently true after its kind.— — With all his good will he is doing me little good here; but yet fully more than I expected. Were the House in command, we shd be much better; but his fussy anxiety to give me no trouble, does give some: add to whh Hellen has not been above par; and I (with my Castor-Mercury set of nerves caught up on the sudden) have been all this while below it. However I am now better; also getting thro’ some nasty work. Things will all go better now! Yesterday morning, it is true, Hellen announced herself ill, of a dreadfully sore little finger; this morning, after poulticing &c and being sent to bed, it proves to be whitloe: “will soon be over,” prophecies Jack, who has lanced it, under good omens: and Hellen herself has called in a nice clean little girlUnidentified further. (of her acquaintce to run abt for her in the interim. So that we shan’t suffer at all.— Yesterday I did not call at Bath HouseLondon home of Lady Ashburton. today I intend it. Did you get Dickens’s No 1,Dickens’s Our Mutual Friend (1865), with illustrations by Marcus Stone (1840–1927), was pbd. in 20 monthly installments from 30 April.—alas, cd you read it, or bear to have it read?

closer.salute: Adieu, Dearest; I pray for good news. Yours ever

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [29 April]. Addr: 5 Cheyne Row / Chelsea / London. PM: St. Leonards, 29 April 1864. MS: NLS 608.626. Pbd: A. Carlyle, NLM 2:293–94 inc. Quot: Fielding and Sorensen 299. TC wrote later on the envelope: “(1864 / 28 April).“
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p: Again a day of comparative comfort! The “Linament” and rubbing still having the desired effect.
God forgive me that I cannot be glad and thankful! That I can only expect shudderingly the return of the horrid thing!

I got thro’ the night in my strange bed—better than I had hoped—fell
asleep about three— It is a most tidy little house—and so clean!—and I think quiet—

Maggie is out, with two of the Liverpool LieshmansPresumably relatives of James Leishman (1782–1839; see 11:15TC to JAC, [4] Feb. 1839), business partner of Maggie’s father, John Welsh; probably Hannah Leishman, b. Francis (b. 1821), wife (m. 1861) of his son, James Leishman (b. 1812), coppersmith, and his widowed da., Janet Penn (b. 1822), m. William Penn, horse trainer, 1844. who are come over from Brighton on her invitation, I knowing nothing till an hour before they came!

I fear, as John has had no practice at what they call “a Lady’s Dr” he can suggest nothing either “at random,” or on reflection, to save me from this worse than death torture; but if he likes to come for a day and take care of you I shall give him some dinner and be glad to see you both— Could you come on Monday? Oh if I might be even as well as this when you come! but that is too much to hope!
What quantities of things I have to tell you—if I had my poor soul freed from the pressure of physical torment.

Oh my Dear my Dear, shall I ever make fun for you again?— Or is our life together indeed past and gone? I want so much to live—to be to you more than I have ever been—but I fear I fear!— As yet your / own affectionate
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 30 April. Addr: 117. Marina / St Leonards on Sea. PM: London, 30 April 1864. MS: NLS 616.618. Hitherto unpbd. TC’s letter written on reverse of Lady William Russell’s note.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: My Darling, Oh how glad I am that your remedial measure still, in spite of yr Anticipatns, holds out! “One has power over an external thing of that kind; can increase the intensity of it” &c opines my Medical Oracle here:—poor soul, he has been balancing my Lawbooks, buying me nail-brushes &c & really as kind and patt with me as possible. He is very ardent for a Journey to you on Monday;—but I find it will be far better to wait till abt next Monday, and make one journey, a journey for good (with my Books all on my back, & my Horse in a box behind me!) Don’t you think so, too? Jack will possibly come with me; or, if you permit, come some day by himself, if actually going to Edinr (as he talks) before that date.— If you do in any way want me, Dear, on Monday, write, and I will come that day or next.

Hellen’s whitloe is almost gone agn (began last Saty, it appears; was not
heard of till thursday last): the little LassieHelen’s friend, brought in to help. will probably finish today. Woolner came last night, and swallowed the bits of hours. Lady Willm (t.o.) has this moment, for the first time since you went, made express message.Lady William Russell wrote, 30 April: “How is she?— —how are you going on?—I will not ‘Entsagen’ [renunciate]— — —it is all very well for Goethe———.” Johann Wolfgang von Goethe (1749–1832). For Goethe “entsagen” meant renunciation of selfhood, “by which alone the first real entrance into life is conceivable” (Goethe, Wilhelm Meister, trans. Carlyle, Works 24:334). See also 5:177TC to G, 23 Oct. 1830. I will call, during my ride. Lady An not come yesterday when I called; had “sent no word.” “My Compts, & say I called twice,” enjoined I.— — The weather is good; I am nearly thro’ a brutal mass of Neuberg Stuff,—ach Gott as ugly as himself! I shall wait with tremulous hope for some possible word of Maggies this night. God keep thee, Darling
docBody.name: T.C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-HL, [late April/early May 1864]. MS: Duke. Hitherto unpbd. [This letter, originally pbd. at CL 45:219, has been assigned a document date of 1 May 1864 and moved to its proper chronological location.]
div3.head: TC TO HENRY LARKIN

docBody.p: The “Secretary”For a description of TC’s “Secretary” made from the large crate (containing books and papers) that TC took with him to St. Leonards, May 1864, see 40:101TC to JN, 18 May 1864. is come, at length; and seems to be very well,—all but a couple of small stripes of cloth, whh will need to be glued in, at the front joint atop, in order to keep out the dust: that or something equivalent will be indispensable there. Pray call,—and let us consider it; and get it fixed, and put in action. Yours always

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [1 May]. Addr: 5 Gt Cheyne Row / Chelsea / London. PM: St. Leonards, 1 May 1864. MS: NLS 608.628. Hitherto unpbd. TC wrote later on the envelope: “(St Lds / 4 May ? 1864).“
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p: It will be best Dear; that JhonThus in MS. should come—by himself some day this week—say Tuesday— We will give him a bed if he likes.
Your own coming—with the Books—“for good” next week will be quite agitative enough, without any complication; for such a poor wretchedly nervous creature as me!

Maggie will have to go up to Chelsea the day before you leave—to collect and bring hither many odds & ends needed— Linen—silver spoons knives, clothes &c— At present our sheets &c are on hire and our spoons and knives on loan (from Mrs Blakiston)—hired houses dont supply such things

Besides what is to be brought here there are many valuables lying about, that must be locked away—before the house is given in charge to Mr Larkin, and Mr AllenUnidentified further; probably not John Hensleigh Allen. put to sleep in it—that is how it is to be is it not?—
Maggie can stay till you are packed up and off, and then follow with Helen, who is much wanted here—Mary being far more willing than competent

You will see from the fact of my writing, that I am not fallen back into that terrible torment I was in! No—but falling back I am since yesterday afternoon, it has been creeping over and I had a miserable night, and tomorrow I shall be as I was—or I am greatly mistaken!—
You will be patient with me when you come, will you not?— No mortal could bear that torture and be calm and rational—
Send the Drumlanrig stickPresumably a walking stick cut from the woods of Drumlanrig Castle, 17 mi. (27 km.) NW of Dumfries, main seat of the dukes of Buccleuch. by John—the one I have has no head

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 2 May. Addr: 117. Marina / St Leonards on Sea. PM: London, 2 May 1864. MS: NLS 616.619. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p:
Dearest, You have unexpectedly got ample news today by word of mouth,—so that I need not say anything in such haste! Jack had, for some reason or other, set his heart on it; went off before yr Letter came, whh wd surely have held him back till tomorrow. Left me at breakfast; had tried and again tried to entice me with him,—but I shrunk from the empty jumble of to & fro, and have tried to be busy here instead. To get qùam primùm [as soon as possible] down to you for good; that surely is the really wise industry.————— The sight of yr handwriting is like manna to me these mornings;—in spite of yr ill prophecies, there you still are, you see. And surely it is a great fact that yr unbearable misery does become intermittent,—to this greater extent; for hitherto, I think, there has been no such interval. Courage, oh and Hope, my poor little Dear!——— Jack wd tell you what a deluge of Greenhow,Rose Greenhow, in Britain as a Confederate emissary. She noted in her diary, 2 May: “With Carlyle, made tea for him. He drank four cups. Talked delightedly, a la Carlyle. Deeply sympathetic with the situation. It warms my heart to hear his enthusiastic praise of my gallant countrymen.” She first visited Cheyne Row 15 Feb., recording 24 Feb.: “Miss [Jewsbury] called upon me. The same evening wrote me sending an invitation from Mr. Carlyle [for] the next day (Sunday). I could not go. … The invitation was repeated for Monday. Found him entirely different from what I had expected. He is erect, tall 5 foot 8 or 10 inches, little sinewy figure, full brown beard and slightly grizeled hair. Has a strong Scotch accent in speaking which he uses less when he is animated. Talks a great deal. Is deeply interested in American affairs and a most noble advocate of the South. He asked me a great many questions amongst others, what sort of a looking animal was Lincoln. I endeavored to do justice to his appearance and where upon Mr. C arose from his seat and shook himself like a great dog, and [said] Soulouque the flat nosed negro of Haty and Abraham Lincoln the rail splitter of United States are a worthy pair to stand side by side in history. He asked about our President Mr. Davis and I described him. He placed his fingers over his eyes and said, ‘I see him. God has made the situation for the man.’ He spoke in strong language of the crimes and imbecility of the North and when I arose to go at a late hour, 11½ o’clock. He said, ‘I will do anything for your country.’ I said, ‘An article or few words from you, sir, will carry weight and would be deeply gratifying to our President and our people.’ Mrs. Carlyle is sick of a nervous disease, which makes him very unhappy as he is deeply attached to her.” She noted, 23 April: “Spent an hour with Carlyle who is very kind to me. Strong sympathy with the South. My words not lost in a barren soil.” She wrote, 18 June, that she had received a letter from TC: “Very kind and sympathetic. Says he wishes to write some thing up on the American war. Letter entirely Carlylism” (Greenhow’s diary [with regularized spelling]: www.onealwebsite.com/RebelRose/RoseDiary; MS: North Carolina State Archives; see also Brent E. Kinser, The American Civil War in the Shaping of British Democracy [Farnham, Surrey, 2011] 40–41). Emperor Faustin Élie Soulouque (1782–1867), freed slave, dictator of Haiti 1849–59; Jefferson Davis (1808–89), president of Confederate States of America 1861–65.
Geraldine, TaitGeraldine Jewsbury and Robert Tait. & Co came swiming in, last night. Today there is a Letter from the Otthennins in Edinr alarmed at John’s “precipitate departure,” and begging “one word” abt you, to whom they impute it! Jean’s letter will interest you in Annandale for a moment. God bless you, Dearest T.C.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MR, [2 May]. Addr: Holme Hill / Thornhill / Dumfries. PM: London, 3 May 1864. MS: NLS 608.629A. Pbd: Fielding and Sorensen 299–300 inc. TC later wrote on the envelope: “(3 May 1864).” As the envelope has a London postmark, it is probable that John A. Carlyle brought the letter back to London to post; he visited JWC 2 May.
div3.head: JWC TO MARY RUSSELL

docBody.dateline: 117 Marina / St Leonards on Sea [2 May 1864]
docBody.p: You will be glad, I know, to see the poor old handwriting again; and will infer from it, that I am given back to the living world— — But you must not be too sanguine about my recovery— I am still hanging between Life and death, only, for the last few days I have been freed from the torture that has distracted me these many months back— It may return—most likely will return and be all the more intolerable by contrast with this breath of ease—

So I make haste, while I can still do my own will, to write you these few lines, just to say I have thought of you and loved you always thro these dismal months of silence— Have often looked at the picture of Holme HillMary Russell’s home in Thornhill. on my bedroom wall, and mourned to think I should never be there again—never never—
Maggie shall write you the particulars of our life here— I have no strength for more

closer.salute: Love to the Dr / and believe me / living or dying ever / your affectionate

docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 3 May. Addr: 117. Marina / St Leonards on Sea. PM: London, 3 May 1864. MS: NLS 616.620. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Dearest, Tho’ there was nothing to be said this morning, and no letter cd be expected, I felt as if I had been disappointed, not to see yr hand agn!

John got home abt 10 p.m.— I am sorry to say, I had been late with tea, & had barely done (everybody here is willing to be late, & I have to take the resisting in my own hand; whh I really do, but with ill success, poor Goody being away)! John told me all he could; but was not very lucid. He had been surprised and touched by yr great distress and feeling of dispiritment (no wonder!)—and kept saying, “She will need to be very gently dealt with” (yes indeed, Sir)! He said there were “5 bedrooms”; how many stories of the House, he cd hardly say, nor whether there was a likely one for writing, or for smoking. However, you had been very good to him (whh was really good of you, Dearie);—and I have thots of coming down with him next Friday or Saty to look with my own eyes. Won’t that do? Tell me however.

I am getting on a little with work; but there is no right progress possible while the Printer stands chained. It is like that of “keeping time” (above spoken of): there is nobody but my own poor self to push forward in any departt of the business; everybody & everything is willing to sleep if only I wd.

Lady Ashbn I did not ask for yesterday; having other errands, to hat-shopSee TC to JWC, 11 May. &c. Very probably she is not yet come.— “Miss Willis, Sir,”Probably Eleanor Willis; see TC to JWC, [14 March]. & the time up: that is the fact here. Oh Darling, Oh my own poor little Jeannie, tell me tomorrow that yr remedy still holds out;—and that you begin to believe, and look up! Such intermittency I surely augur well of; but I know well too what abysses of woe my poor suffering one has been long plagued in. Adieu; my blessings on you, if I had any!—

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 4 May. Addr: 117. Marina / St Leonards on Sea. PM: London, 4 May 1864. MS: NLS 616.621. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Bad news today my poor little Lassie; alas, it is what I have been anticipating for some time. How glad shall I be if Dr Bln is right,—if my poor suffering Jeannie sends me agn a bit of writing in her own hand tomorrow!

Shall not I come, then, on Friday or Saturday? “Yes,” your poor heart says; “if only it do not agitate me too much!” Send me yr sanctioning word, Yes or No, as you really judge best. John will come at any rate, and bring whatevr you order.— I have been very busy today; but find daily such a heap of more extranea to shove off me as is very strange! My ride is very useful; I am genlly quite done up and fairly in the dumps by the time of his arrival at 3¼ p.m. I am convinced my late dinner is a bad thing for me. We will have it changed to the old summer-hour, when I get to you; perhaps I shall then get to have, if not that meal (whh wd be so delightful), then some meal, in company with Her I like best! Esperons [Let us hope], for a future day, at least.

I am going agn to Bath House; not at all certn; but indeed it is no matter— Yesternight American Conway (Moncure)Moncure Conway much admired TC, despite their political differences; see 39:114TC to JAC, 29 April 1863. came irresistibly in; consumed the evg in loose chatter, useless, but not quite painful. The War, he admits, is very like ending; will die away after this “Campn” so-called.Abraham Lincoln made Ulysses S. Grant (1822–85) commander of all the Union armies early 1864; his strategy was to use the Army of the Potomac to engage the Army of Northern Virginia under Robert E. Lee (1807–70), Confederate general, while Union forces elsewhere undermined the South’s ability to counter-attack. Grant realized that only the total defeat of the Confederate forces and their economic base would bring an end to the war. “The note of preparation for the resumption of active operations in Virginia has been sounded. … A threefold advance on Richmond … has been determined upon. … General Grant has left Washington for the army of the Potomac” (Examiner, 30 April). Enough, Dearest; my time is up,—my very pen contradictory— The Helen seems to me a clever hizzy, very honest &c withal; and, I expect, will turn out beautifully under yr command. As much else will;—Bless thee, my Dear / T.C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JM, 4 May. Addr: Leisure-Hour Office / 56. Paternoster Row / City. PM: 4 May 1864. MS: NLS Acc. 9086. Hitherto unpbd. James Macaulay (1817–1902; ODNB), author, and ed. of various periodicals, including Leisure Hour, Sunday at Home, and the Religious Tract Society’s periodicals. TC addressed the envelope to Dr. Macaulay; Macaulay graduated as a doctor from Edinburgh Univ. but never practiced.
div3.head: TC TO JAMES MACAULAY

docBody.p:
It wd give me pleasure to express publicly by some opportunity the great love and respect I have, ever since my young years, retained for the Poet Cowper;William Cowper (1731–1800; ODNB), poet and letter-writer; see 5:48TC to G, 22 Dec. 1829. It is not known what Macaulay wanted TC to write; he later edited Cowper’s Letters: A Selection from the Correspondence of the Poet William Cowper, with biographical memoir and notices of his correspondents (1886).—and I still hope for some good chance of that kind. But at present,
I regret to answer you, it is entirely forbidden by the multiplex loads of other business whh occupy, and wd more than occupy, every moment of my time. I remain, with kind regards,

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 5 May. Addr: 117. Marina / St Leonards on Sea. PM: London, 5 May 1864. MS: NLS 616.622. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: No Letterkin from yr poor little self; alas, and a very poor bulletin of you from Maggie: “Some sleep,” “a restless night,” ‘very wearied’: however, it is something (to me something considble) that your pain still continues partly in abeyance. Good weather is ahead too!—

Tomorrow John is for off; morning train, I suppose, he will bring yr things (whh perhaps you care little for): I myself mean to try my best to catch Bullock the Postman before Jack go (sometimes Bullock is naturally come at that hour, sometimes not); I will then eagerly ascertain if you wish or permit, and either accompy John or follow him if (as I hope) you be affirmative. I shall then see my poor Jeannie with my own eyes agn, and see if any eyesight of mine can what her case is in this interval. Yesterday, so hurried abt, I thot it was only Tuesday! I shd have mentioned my coming coming,Word, with line over it, repeated at turn of page. the day before. By dint of effort I got a dirty confusion ended 3 or 4 minutes ago; and cd stand a day of holiday (so sad a “holiday” is all we have, Dear; sad, but blessed!)—while the Printer still continues asleep.—— —— I got myself quite ruined yesterday,—seeing Lady An: she had come on Monday; “wd like to see you, Sir, I think”; upon whh I tried for admissn to the stable; at 2 doors, nobody there; engaged a man of my own from the street: got up, found the poor Lady just abt to treat with some statuary (Funeral Monument, alas), and agreed to go away till “5 o’clock”; careered round the Regts Park, got back rather after time, found Venables, found tea: hardly got home till ¼ to 7: no nap; no right sleep either till perhaps 5 a.m.!—that is the cost of a call there! Howevr I am now well enough agn. Lady has come up for Baby, who has bronchitis; will wait here & at Addiscbe till QuainDr. Richard Quain. has cured Baby. Jack is almost miracsly amenable. Good be with thee Darling T.C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-GEJ, 8 May. MS: Yale. Hitherto unpbd. For an undated photograph of Jewsbury, possibly taken around this time, see above.
div3.head: TC TO GERALDINE E. JEWSBURY

docBody.dateline: St Leonard’s, 8 May 1864TC visited JWC in St. Leonards over the weekend of 6–8 May. —
docBody.p: Jane and I are both very much obliged by yr prompt kindness, and readiness to help: but she thinks a fortnight, whh wd consist nearly all of novelty and adjustment, to be succeeded by something else of the same, wd too much flurry & distress in her present poor weak state: and so she has ordered me to write off to a second-best elsewhere, in hopes of having her for a month certain.Mary Craik; the Carlyles had been friendly with the Craiks, who lived in Belfast, since 1835; their last recorded meeting was in 1860; see 36:139JWC to GCMC, 18 June 1860; see also 32:60–61JWC to GLC, 20 Dec. [1856]. TC wrote later: “Early in May this (Chelsea) house was left to Larkin’s care (who at last came into it, letting his own); and all of us had reassembled in the poor new hospice (‘117 Marina, St. Leonards’), studious to try our best and utmost there. Maggie Welsh had to return to Liverpool (to nurse a poor little child-nephew who was dying). I did not find Maggie at St. Leonards; but the good Mary Craik (Professor’s Mary, from Belfast), by my Jeannie’s own suggestion, was written to, came directly, and did as well; perhaps more quietly, and thus better” (TC’s note in Froude, LM 3:195). Whh I have done; thus ending the first act of the affair,—all but our memory of yr goodness in it, whh must not end so soon.

p.hi: Courtesy of Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Columbia University

docBody.p: The Shirts came perfectly; thanks also for yr speed there. John &TC omitted “I.” return to morrow; Maggie cd not quite go at once, but will follow so soon as ready, in a day or two: if you call any evg I can report progress;—and, abt the end of the week, I have engaged to be quite back, Books, Horse and Man.—— In haste (as usual)

div3.sourceNote: TC-JN, 9 May. Addr: Roslyn Park / Hampstead. PM: London, 11 May 1864. MS: NLS 553.262. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p:
Dear Neuberg,—I am sorry to have missed you; and hard[ly]Letters omitted by TC. hope another opportunity: on Saturday I am myself to set off, bag & baggage,—till july end, according to calculatn. I found my poor Patient visibly improved; tho’ still in very great misery, whh however is intermittent in some considble degree, not constant as here. I am packing up my tools (a thing I never tried before, & find to be like a Friedh Campaign, in a sort), my tools & goods; settling with
laggard Printers, laggard etceteras of all kinds; and very miserable in my weak flurry and morbid want of skin. God help me to get thro’ this Book in oppositn to the whole world & the Devil to back, as it often seems to me.— —(t.o.) I read SchneidawindFranz Joseph Adolph Schneidawind, Leben Kaiser Josephs II (Hamburg, 1816). nearly out last night: he has some sense, but writes as if for idle young people accustomed to the Liberal Newspapers; dates almost nothing (and now & then wrong too), jumbles everything (cart before horse &c), in short will do me hardly any good at all.

I wish much you wd make a serious effort, and actually get me (witht delay, or as fast as the Post can bring it) an authentic reasonable Book on JosephKaiser Joseph II; see TC to JN, [6 March]. In Frederick TC noted that he eventually found most of his information on Kaiser Joseph in Joseph Hormayr’s Oesterreichischer Plutarch (Vienna, 1807–14) 4:125–223 and “five or six recent Lives of Joseph, none of which, that I have seen, was worth reading, in comparison” (Carlyle, Works 19:282). (references given &c &c) After the endless favrs you have done my Task & me, this is one still possible! Write to some intelligent man in Germany (explaining as you can):—if you know none better, T. WilsonTC had already consulted Mrs. Thomas Wilson on this matter; see 39:245TC to MRSW, 17 Nov. 1863. is back to Weimar agn; let him consult the scientific-historisch oracles at Weimar (in my name and Allah’s) and despatch by Post (if possible in a sewed conditn, Schneidawd I have had to sew) this charitable bit of help: the money for whh shall be a small matter to me! Yours always
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-AP, 9 May. The letter was enclosed in an envelope, addr: Mr. Donald Ross, Cabinet-maker / 13. Denmark Street / Soho. PM: London, 11 May 1864. MS: NLS Acc. 9086. Hitherto unpbd. TC wrote on reverse of letter: “To A. Panizzi Esq / Librarian &c &c / British Museum.” Anthony Panizzi (1797–1879; ODNB), principal librarian, British Museum.
div3.head: TC TO ANTHONY PANIZZI

docBody.p: The Bearer, Mr Donald RossDonald Ross (1826–1916), cabinet maker, specializing in fine inlaid furniture. Connection to TC untraced. (13. Denmark Street, Soho) wishes admittance to read in the British Museum: and I hereby certify that he is a fit person for enjoying such a privilege.Those wishing to use the reading rooms of the British Museum were required to send in a written application with a letter of recommendation from one of the group of “recommenders of readers,” of whom TC was presumably one (P. R. Harris, A History of the British Museum Library [1998] 88, 284).

closer.salute: I have the honr to be / Yr Obedt Servt

docBody.name: T. Carlyle

ps.p:
A. Panizzi Esq
&c &c

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 9 May. Addr: 117. Marina, St Leonards on Sea. PM: London, 11 May 1864. MS: NLS 616.623. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Dearest,—John’s report of you for yesterday, after I left you in the rain, is satisfactory: but I long much to hear of yr sleep last night. This day agn is cold enough but there is no wet, only cold grey wind.— I returned safe from my journey: safe, but sad and wearied;—I lay down & slept an hour as the first thing. Nothing but vacuity & solitude (rather gaunt for the moment) waited me here: I set diligtly to some work, and held myself quiet till midnight.

This morning since 8 I have been afoot; in the thick of business since. I have written abt 10 Notes on various paltry trifles (of busss); my floor is getting covered with at least a longer & longer row of Books, as I bethink me of these: I have looked into various Mss (save the mark)Proverbial, formula to avert an evil omen. & made them printable;—Robson is appointed to meet me here on Friday morng, and take delivery of his “Copy” & final instructns. I hitherto don’t see why all shouldn’t be ready on Saty morning.

Gne Jewsbury you see is perfectly ready; a little repentant,JWC and Geraldine Jewsbury had quarreled early in 1862; (see 38:48JWC to CCU, [31] Jan. [1862],) and only began meeting again in summer 1863; see 39:167JWC to MR, 9 July 1863. Jewsbury presumably replied to TC to GEJ, 8 May, offering again to care for JWC at St. Leonards. I have no doubt. At present I have ansd nothing, nor need you; our ready ansr being “Miss Craik is asked”; only in failure of her, here as yr pis-aller [last resource] is always Geraldine, poor soul!— Ld Houghton (cidevant [heretofore] Milnes)Richard Monckton Milnes was elevated to the peerage as Lord Houghton, Aug. 1863; see 39:262TC to RMM, 29 Dec. 1863. was here as fat as ever, and asking with real interest & kindness. I will give yr message to Lady A:—I wish I were home agn, & thro’ this middle-Passage. God bless you little Woman.— T.C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 11 May. Addr: 117. Marina / St Leonards on Sea. PM: London, 11 May 1864. MS: NLS 616.624. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: My poor little Woman is now left alone, under John’s nursing,—he will strive to be very tender, and do his very best, I have no doubt; forgive him if at any time his hand be less soft than he intends it! It is near 3 here; but Maggie is not come,—so in the interval (tho’ I am grown cold, fire being out) I will write my poor Jeannie. I woke early (too early, tho’ my ride last night did me real good, as I compute); I have had such a Day of Jumbling Among Papers as never before:—but, thank Heaven, I am now as it were quite thro’; ready to meet Robson, & deliver him plenty of stuff (I think really more than plenty) to make Proof Slips of. I hope we shall get on double & treble quick now, were it but established in my little Closet of a “Study” under dear Goody’s wing! Courage, my poor Darling; we shall certainly rally, after all; it is a thing I have never doubted, except in few bad moments, bad & few!— But there will be a considerable spell of fettling I doubt:—cd the Engineer of TrailtrowJohn A. Carlyle; origin of nickname unknown; see 22:69TC to JWC, 13 [14] Sept. 1847; Trailtrow is a watchtower and hamlet 2½ mi. (4 km.) SW of Ecclefechan. (ask him) perhaps contrive in my bedroom to make the bell ringable from the bed,—e.g.? If he can, he will. You may thank him for his clear Letter; definitely intelligible to me tho’ brief.

I found no Lady Ashburton last evg; found nothing but Venables just behind me, preparing to call. I will try agn tonight, I think, or tomorrow. I had gone first to the Hatter in Vigo Street,Scott & Wright, Man’s Mercers, 6A Vigo St., nr. Regent St.; see TC to JWC, 3 May. who had sent my Hat (sorrow on him, after all my pains abt it) totally too strait,—wdn’t look on me at all. A little bit of business, forcing me to speak to mankind, often does me good.— Will the Doctor go to these Livery people,Probably Thomas Skinner (b. ca. 1802), livery stables, Sussex Rd., St. Leonards; see TC to JAC, 17 July. and prepare them for my Horse? Any day, before he arrive. The price here is 25/ by the week,—horse on the best of food; beans such a portn as he can. An excellt eater; healthy as a trout &c &c.— Oh my darling, I wish we were thro’ all this; and got together agn! It is past 3 some minutes; but there is nothing of Maggie. I must have my dinner soon. Adieu, or can I still add a word?— Your forever T.C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-HL, [11 May]. MS: Huntington Lib. Hitherto unpbd. Dated by TC’s check to Larkin, 12 May.
div3.head: TC TO HENRY LARKIN

docBody.p: Dear Larkin,—Wd you call on Hana,Hana, newsagent, not further identified. and pay him this (and 6d more for a new No that will come tonight), and give notice that I do not want any more Newspapers till further order. If yr funds are out (as I suspect), pay all the same, & I will repay.TC recorded, 12 May: “to Hy Larkin (for myself) / £35. .0. .0” (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753).
Small Bit of Copying waits here,—anxious to be done soonish

ps.p: Chelsea Wedy [11 May 1864]

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 12 May. Addr: 117. Marina / St Leonards on Sea. PM: London, 12 May 1864. MS: NLS 616.625. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Darling, you “are miserable enough,” John reports to me; but nothing positively worse: I will be thankful,—and hope to see you soon. Maggie as you wd learn arrived just on the stroke of 4;—I was shocked to learn that you had been disappointed of my Letter! I gave it to yg Silvester,Presumably William, grandson of John Silvester, livery stable owner. who ran, fearing we were already close on the time (¼ to 5), and he had been a minute, or half one, too late. I took better precautn yesterday, and will today.
We are all up to the throat in litter; working whatr we can to be ready for Saturday, I still count on it, and am doing my very utmost.

Yesterday just when Maggie came, & I had hardly done with my dinner, Lady An and Miss BaringPresumably Louisa Baring, Lord Ashburton’s elder sister. got in. I had to go down, tho’ they only asked for Maggie. Very kind: Lady strong for yr coming in july or sooner;—speaks of running down to you for a few hours to see for herself. This evg I am to call; and that I hope will end it.— I am dreadfully ill off for punctuality here: no Goody now to keep me to the Sun-dial; everybody wanting to be unpunctual here if I wd let them. Alas, alas!—

The Craik busss is all right, it seems; beautifully set agoing witht fuss: very good. Maggie, I perceive, was almost or altogether desirous to go on if the Craiks had failed: she is now prompt and ardent to return and be with you
till the Craik; I urged that it was quite needless & superfluous, but doubtless she has written and you yourself can decide. I, for my own share, feel greatly obliged to Maggie—and, alas, I know well, it is not I that was in bitter misery beside her, or have to pardon her any shortcomings! Be as tolerant of her as you can.
Past 3 a fair way agn! I am tumbled out in a hurry to ride, & get myself jumbled for the whole night after; no nap, no &c.— Thank John for his Letter: take care of yr poor self,—God be with you T.C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 13 May. Addr: 117. Marina / St Leonards on Sea. PM: London, 13 May 1864. MS: NLS 616.626. Pbd: A. Carlyle, NL 2:220 inc; Bliss, TC 366–67.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: My poor little Jeannie, I hope, has slept better last night; and if so, this good May day may be farther of benefit,—at least, pleasanter to drive in. I got John’s Letter last night, but not till 11 o’clock, our oblivious maidHelen. having left it on the box till then. Of course I am very glad that you have got a Craik settltMary Craik arrived during the following week; see TC to HL, [21 May]. on the favourablest terms. Maggie waits yr permission to attend me tomorrow,Maggie did not return to St. Leonards; “Maggie had taken leave of me at Chelsea … went off for Liverpool, looking sorry to go” (Carlyle, Reminiscences 175). and stay till Wednesday:—I hope you will let her come? She is abundantly diligent here; and keeps the gloom of the House from settling on me.

For the rest, we are up to the chin in wreck and pother; the Books are all packed,—Larkin to ascertain if they cannot be sent this night, and got to arrive on SaturdayTC wrote on Friday. as soon as we! Tomorrow at 12 we actually vanish hence (unless something occur), and shall be with you at the hour John & I arrived. Oh poor Darling, I wish I cd do you any good by my coming! But at least you will have the comfort, as I shall, of our being all together agn—that is always something— (Enter Neuberg; steals 10 minutes: it is already long past 3; no “punctuality” here but my own; and you know what that is!)

Lady An was at home last night; gave tea (at 5½ p.m.) what I wd have; and detained me far too long. She is coming down to you on Monday; that seems to be her resolution:—I think I will bring Maggie at any rate? For the rest, we will keep the Lady mostly altogether off you, if you are afraid or averse.
But I must down stairs, & see whether no dinner is coming on any terms. Thank John for his two Notes; let him have the groomUnidentified. waiting tomorrow!

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady A [LLA], 13 May. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p: Your Note and its Enclosure have come safe; a missive that goes into my very heart, and has a kind of religious value, not to speak of the pecuniary.Lord Ashburton’s bequest; see TC to Lady A, 11 April. God grant I may live, whatever of life remains to me, in a way worthy of such a fact, and the facts it symbolizes to me! I shd then be made rich indeed;—richer than California,TC often used California as a metaphor for great wealth; see 38:32TC to JCA, 31 Dec. 1861. I sometimes think. But let me be silent.
I have written to the Wife that you are likely to come on Monday; whh will be bright news to her. I have packed half a ton of Books, Maps, Paper-scrawls; I seldom in my time had a more chaotic day.
Good Night, and may Monday’s Sun shew you to us.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-IS [IEB], [15 May]. MS: NLS 1797.232. Hitherto unpbd. Dated May to June 1864 by JWC’s stay at the Marina address; tentatively placed at 15 May in relation to JWC to LLA, [18 May], where JWC wrote of being “so weak and nervous” that writing threw her “into a flurry.“
div3.head: JWC TO ISABELLA SIMMONDS

docBody.p: I can write no letter I have quite gone off my sleep which aggravates my torture—
The photograph is beautifulPresumably the photograph of Isabella Simmonds and her da., Ethel; see 100above.—

figure.p: Isabella Simmonds and her daughter, Ethel, [1864]

p.hi: Courtesy of Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Columbia University

p.name: Jane Carlyle
p.note: Gerald Blunt wrote a note on a blank sheet of JWC’s note: “Written to Miss Barnes of Chelsea afterwards the Wife of my friend John Simmonds of Lincolns Inn who gave it to me in 1899 (She is dead) A B.” Gerald Blunt’s first name was Abel.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JN, 18 May. Addr: Roslyn Park / Hampstead / London. PM: St. Leonards, [18] May 1864; London, 19 May 1864. MS: NLS 553.263. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p:
Dear Neuberg,—I have not yet recd the Book; but there is no doubt it will come, after a day’s delay, whh they have right to in the Parcel Post. With this
Book whatever it be we will rest satisfied on the Joseph head: it & yr HormayrKaiser Joseph II and Joseph Hormayr; see TC to JN, 9 May. (if I had it here) and two others of old date, then shall suffice. Thanks for yr care in this matter.

My Wife goes out twice daily, &c &c; and is said by the Doctors, and even believed by myself, to be improving and improved: but she is still utterly weak and very miserable; unable to seize any firm hold of hope, and easily struck down by the least agitatn or exertion. I, for my own poor share have at last got my writing closet refurnished;TC wrote later: “With a violent effort of packing and scheming (e.g., a box of books with cross-bars in it, and shelves which were to be put in, and make the box a press, &c. &c.), in all which Larkin and Maggie Welsh assisted diligently, I got down to Marina on one of the first days of May [Sat., 14 May]. Dreary and tragic was our actual situation there, but we strove to be of hope, and were all fixedly intent to do our best. The house was new, clean, light enough, and well aired; otherwise paltry in the extreme—small, misbuilt every inch of it; a despicable, cockney, scamped edifice; a rickety bandbox rather than a house. But that did not much concern us, tenants only for a month or two—nay, withal there were traces that the usual inhabitants (two old ladies, probably very poor) had been cleanly, neat persons, sensible, as we, of the sins and miseries of their scamped, despicable dwelling-place, poor, good souls! / In a small back closet, window opposite to door, and both always open, I had soon got a table wedged to fixity, had set on end my book-box, changing it to a book-press, and adjusted myself to work, quite tolerably all along, though feeling as if tied up in a rack. One good bedroom there was in the top story, looking out over the sea—this was naturally hers; mine below and to rearward was the next best, and, by cunning adjustments curtains improvised out of rugs and ropes were made to exclude the light in some degree and admit freely the air currents. We made with our knives about a dozen little wedges as the first thing to keep the doors open or ajar at our will, their own being various in that respect! To put up with the house was a right easy matter, almost a solacement, in sight of the deep misery of its poor mistress, spite of all her striving. / The first day she was dressed waiting my arrival, and came painfully resolute down to dinner with us, but could hardly sit it out; and never could attempt again. With intellect clear and even inventive, her whole being was evidently plunged in continual woe, pain as if unbearable, and no hope left; in spite of our encouragements no steady hope at all. On the earth I have never seen so touching a sight!” (TC’s note in Froude, LM 3:198–99). and today (what is the one effectual comfort I can have) have got a bit of writing done: “Potatoe-War,”The War of the Bavarian Succession, 1778–79; see Carlyle, Works 19:189–222. whh has been a bother to me for a week past. Before the end of the week, I hope to be on Seven-Years War and fairly under way!—

The place, weather &c are charming: Brother & I have a daily swash in the Sea, as first thing; my last is a long ride,—to Battle, last night, where the Old AbbeyBattle, market town in Sussex, 7 mi. (11 km.) from St. Leonards; site of the battle of Hastings, 1066. Battle Abbey was dedicated in 1095 and founded to commemorate the victory of William, duke of Normandy (ca. 1028–87; ODNB), over Harold II (ca. 1022–66; ODNB), king of England, and the Anglo-Saxons. looked wondrous to me in the setting sun, and the whole village and
Country supremely beautiful: vile roads mostly dusty & public this was my worst grievance.

How welcome wd you be here, with Pony to accompany, especially with carriage, whh I think wd come in very great requisitn! With or witht pony and carriage, I cannot doubt it wd do you good. I myself feel improved,—in spite of the sleep part whh always proves a difficulty.— — The Book is come, this instt: “Too late for evg delivery,” it says.

I wish you cd do me (in yr usual masterly way) a Chronology &c of the American War (revolt of 1775, I mean):The outbreak of hostilities, 1775, leading to the American Revolutionary War. 1766 Stamp ActThe Stamp Act of 1765, imposed on the American colonies by Britain to pay the costs of maintaining an army in America. It aroused violent opposition and was repealed in 1776.—1783 Peace & Republic:The negotiated end of the American Revolutionary War at the Treaty of Paris, 1783. TC scarcely mentions the American Revolutionary War in Frederick; see Carlyle, Works 19:155–56.—I shd find it useful by and by.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-Lady A [LLA], [18 May]. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Pbd: Fielding and Sorensen 300 inc. Dated with reference to TC to LLA, 13 May, when TC expected Lady Ashburton’s visit to be on “Monday”; JWC either wrote “yesterday” in error, or misdated “Wednesday.“
div3.head: JWC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p: I do so want to write you a long letter dearest Lady Ashburton, and to thank you rightly for your two dear kind letters to me. But alas I cannot. I am so weak and nervous that the very attempt at writing throws me into a flurry— Oh it is weary work! this life of mine.
I waited for you so anxiously yesterday Mr C went to meet you at the railway.See TC to Lady ALLA, 29 May. your letter did not some till four o’clock—
Shall I see you? I should give much to kiss your dear face again. They say I shall get well in time but I don’t believe it— Ever yours anyhow living or dying Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-HL, [21 May]. Addr: 6. Cheyne Row, Chelsea / London. PM: St. Leonards, 21 May 1864. MS: Huntington Lib.
div3.head: TC TO HENRY LARKIN

docBody.p: Dear Larkin,—I forgot to tell you abt Hana the News Vendor;TC asked Larkin to pay Hana, 11 May; see TC to HL, [11 May]. and “Public Opinn”See TC to CAW, 16 Feb. must be wandering abt London, these two Saturdays last! Please to clip off the adjoined Address,TC’s address is still on the MS, written at right angles at the right hand side. and leave it with Hana on Monday early enough:—and contrive, in some good way (perhaps you object to put a Notice in the window, and warn everybody that the House is empty!), to let it be known that Letters &c can be left at No 6,Larkin lived at 6 Cheyne Row. in future.

We are getting on tolerably well here (after a good deal of botherg with adjustts); our Patient evidently on the improving hand (new CompannMary Craik. come & suitable), place extremely pleast, sea-bathing &c &c: and for my own poor share, I hope (what is the sumary of all) to send you a new bit of Copying soon.— With kind regards to Mrs Ln. Yrs always T. Carlyle

ps.p:
T. Carlyle Esq
117. Marina
St Leonards on Sea
(for “Public Opinn” Copy, till farther notice)

div3.sourceNote: JWC-HL, 23 May. MS: Huntington Lib. Hitherto unpbd. Written in another hand, presumably Mary Craik’s, and signed by JWC.
div3.head: JWC TO HENRY LARKIN

docBody.dateline: St. Leonard’s on Sea 23rd Monday May [1864]
docBody.p: I will tell you what to do with the bottle of Champagne, which I now know all about, and which was sent to me as a specimen of something very remarkable.JWC was given champagne by Caroline Davenport Bromley after her accident, early Oct. 1863 (see 39:211TC to JCA, 2 Oct. 1863), but this is another bottle; the giver is not known. Put it aside till the 14 of July, which is my birthday, and then drink it, your wife and you, to my memory. Be kind to my cat, and with kind regards to your wife and self, Your Ever
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-HL, 26 May. Addr: 6. Cheyne Row, Chelsea / London. PM: St. Leonards, 26 May 1864. MS: Huntington Lib. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO HENRY LARKIN

docBody.p: Dear Larkin,—You get a Parcel today, & this is a supplementary Message;—it is a sad difficulty, that of shifting one’s tools, I find!—

Please look out for these Books,Presumably TC enclosed a list of books for Larkin to send; untraced. especially the vol. of FredcUnidentified. (not forgetting the ReimanDaniel Gottlob Reymann, General-Karte von einem Theile des Russischen Reiches in Gouvernements und Kreise eingetheilt (Berlin, 1802); see 35:234TC to HL, [19 Oct. 1859], and Carlyle, Works 18:259. whh you have): make all into a parcel (brown paper & string will carry them safe enough); and despatch by rail. There will be others, I fear, but at prest I can think of no more.
Mark down accurately agt me what these Parcels cost you!—
I wrote to Robson, yesternight, abt the Two Sheets &c. This is my first operation of today, this to you.— Bad times for me;—my poor Patient, too, not doing so well for the last few days!—

p.name: T. Carlyle
p.note: TC apparently wrote to Jean Aitken, 23 or 24 May; the envelope alone survives: Addr: The Hill / Dumfries / N. B. PM: St. Leonards, 24 May 1864; Dumfries, 25 May 1864 (MS: NLS 517.73).

div3.sourceNote: TC-HL, 26 May. MS: Huntington Lib. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO HENRY LARKIN

docBody.p: Dear Larkin,—send me Kausler too (the quarto Book, I mean):Franz Georg Friedrich von Kausler, Atlas des plus mémorables Batailles, Combats et Sièges des temps anciens, du moyen âge et de l’ âge moderne (Carlsruhe and Freiburg, 1831). The work was in two vols., an atlas and a text, written in French and German; see Carlyle, Works 12:296–97. Larkin apparently sent the atlas vol.; see TC to HL, [27 May]. I can’t do at all witht Reimann & him. But it shan’t be for long.

Item; If you cd discover anywhere (in my bedroom, press or wardrobe, to right of fire-place) a certain pair of woollen Shoes (or Ancle-boots), whh I refused to take,—how welcome wd they now be in the cold weather! Be patt with me, & do yr best.

ps.p: 26th towards 3 p.m.

div3.sourceNote: TC-HL, [28 May]. MS: Huntington Lib. Hitherto unpbd. Dated after TC to HL, 26 May, where TC asked for “Kausler.“
div3.head: TC TO HENRY LARKIN

docBody.p: Dear Larkin,—Wd you send me the Book “Kausler”; I have got (partly by accidt) the big Battle-Atlas “Kausler,” and will take advantage of it a little.— Yrs truly / T. C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady A [LLA], 29 May. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Quot: Hansons, NE 519.
div3.head: TC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.dateline: 117. Marina St Leonards on Sea 29 May 1864—
docBody.p: I attended, that Monday, at the Railway Statn here;See TC to JWC, 13 May, and TC to Lady ALLA, 13 May. but you know there came nothing of it! We begin now to long considerably for a word abt bonny little Baby’s state of health;Lady Ashburton’s da. Mary Florence had bronchitis; see TC to JWC, 5 May. and whether Addiscombe or Bath House is yr billet & hers, and what is going on in that interesting circle,—under our horizon for the prest.

I flatter myself poor Jane is really improving; really tho’ in a slow and fluctuating manner. We have the finest May weather, and outer influences: weather & these are, I believe, the only essential help there is. She goes out twice daily in one of their vehicles here; has tried a few yards of walking, more than once; but could not make much of that: she is utterly weak (as if broken on the wheel for six months long!)—and naturally has sunk into great depression; tho’ I hope that also is abating. I myself make desperate attempts, day after day doing my very utmost, to get some little work effected;—& shall, I expect, succeed at last; tho’ the deluge of incoherencies that rushes daily in on me from all points of the compass (all abutting on unhappy me, and my poor Enterprise) is hitherto very great.

The enclosed Crumply Bit of Paper has been here since near the date of it; a tragic piece;—& was on the edge of the kitchen-fire this morning; when I bethot me again, & recalled it, for Ladyship’s perusal first!— The poor Downes who is here dead (dragged himself home from Algeria to die) is the tragically well-deserving man who got a certain £50, of whh I was speaking lately.John Downes d. at his home, Upper Holloway, London, 15 May; TC sent money from Lady Harriet Ashburton’s bequest in Jan.; see TC to EDEDOW, 13 Jan. His
Widow has one childThere were two das., Annabelle and Margaret. & no money. Yr friend Dr BrownDr. John Brown (1810–82; ODNB), physician and author; his letters to Downes were included in Letters of Dr John Brown with Letters from Ruskin, Thackeray and Others, ed. J. Brown and D. W. Forrest (Edinburgh, 1907); for his friendship with Lady Louisa Ashburton, see Surtees, Ludovisi. of Edinr knows much more abt them than I practically do. But it struck me, as yr loyal heart thinks of continuing that £50 annually,For Lady Harriet Ashburton’s bequest, see TC to EDEDOW, 9 Jan. here perhaps might still be the place for the next instalt? The Widow’s Address (or late Address) is on the crumped Paper,—whh now please do burn away!—

You never told me what yr feeling was at sight of that frightful oil-likeness of the gloomy half-frozen old man?There was no recent oil painting of TC, unless someone had made a copy in oils of a recent Jeffrey photograph; in Sept. an engraving of a Jeffrey photograph of TC was pbd. in Illustrated London News, 10 September, 261. Presumably not the portrait of Frederick the Great on horseback, used as the frintis. forfrontispiece to vol. 6 of Frederick; see TC to JN, 20 April, and Carlyle, Works 19: frontis.19:frontispiece. I myself am far from loving him;—tho’ my Wife and PersonsUnidentified. rather do. With many regards,

div3.sourceNote: TC-HL, 29 May. Addr: 6. Cheyne Row, Chelsea / London. PM: St. Leonards, 29 May 1864. MS: letter Duke; envelope Huntington Lib. Pbd: Larkin, BQR 42 inc.
div3.head: TC TO HENRY LARKIN

docBody.p: Yr Parcel came, perfect, yesterday at 3 p.m.;—carriage 1 shg + 2d for porterage (1. .2d in all; a most cheap accommodatn,—thanks to you withal).
Please tell Hana to fling his Public Opinn into any Post-Office on Friday nights, or whenr he gets it: we shall in that way receive it on Saty 3 p.m.,—instead of sunday, as this morning.

Oughton’s Tax BillThomas Oughton (b. 1826), income tax collector, Jubilee Pl., Chelsea; see 38:204TC to JWC, 9 Sept. 1862. is considered here to be correct;—and you will oblige me by paying him; and sending (or keeping!) his receipt for the £3 .. 0 .. 1. June 22 I will repay you;—but till then, it appears, my Acct in the Bank is quite fractional!TC noted on the reverse of a counterfoil dated 24 May: “Simply 2s left in Bank, it wd seem! Till june 22 when there will be £50 more;—and, Augt 4, £192 addl” (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753). Mark down everything.

Robson has sent me a heap of Proof-matter; but no part of those unblessed
Two sheets,—witht whh I cannot stir from the spot. Sad to say!— I am writing to him agn, To be instant abt it. So you need not call.

We are doing tolerably well here,—our Patient, I do think, slowly recovering; I too trying to work, tho’ under the above entangling circs. The weather is cool, clear, summer-like; highways whirly with insupportable dust; but in the country lanes there is beautiful riding,—so silent, clean, amid seas of verdure; and the prettiest little Hamlets of Old-English type I have seen for many a year. Nothing to object to, except the excessive steepness, and the perpetual changing of level; but that also has its advantages. With kind regards.

div3.sourceNote: TC-TW [TWO], 31 May. Pbd: Woolner 247–48.
div3.head: TC TO THOMAS WOOLNER

docBody.p: I at once sign,A petition against street musicians. The “Street Music (Metropolis) Bill” was introduced in the House of Commons, 4 May, by Michael Thomas Bass (1799–1884; ODNB), M.P. for Derby 1848–83 and brewer. The Times reported, 11 May: “Mr. Bass’s Bill is very short. … [I]t proposes to enact that any householder, personally or by his servant or by a police-constable, may require any street musician or singer to depart from the neighbourhood of the house; and a penalty of 40s. is imposed on every one who, after being so required to depart, sounds or plays upon any musical instrument or sings in any thoroughfare near any such house.” Bass spoke in the Commons, 29 June: “Mr. Charles Dickens was in favour of the Bill, and he had letters from the Poet Laureate, Mr. Carlyle, all the leading artists, and between 300 and 400 of the first musicians of the day, who declared that the interruption caused by street bands rendered it quite impossible to carry on their profession. … Mr. Tennyson wrote that he was driven from London by street bands, and the late Mr. Thackeray used to say that he had often been glad to take refuge in the fields” (Hansard 176:472). The bill became law in Oct. TC had long complained about street musicians; see 28:38TC to JCA, 8 Feb. 1853, and 37:203TC to JWC, 7 Aug. 1861. and return;—I would even walk in suppliant procession to the Hon. HouseHouse of Commons. (if necessary), bareheaded and in sackcloth and ashes, entreating said Hon. Long-eared AssemblyI.e., asses; for TC’s earlier use, see 13:288TC to JGM, 27 Oct. 1841, 22:180TC to JCA, 25 Dec. 1847, and 33:60TC to JWC, 31 Aug. 1857. to deliver us from that most absurd of all Farce-Tragedies daily played under their supervision.

We are all doing rather well here; well, considering. My poor Mrs., I cannot but flatter myself, continues slowly to improve, tho’ her sufferings are still very great. I myself complain most of my intolerable bankrupt Printer, and
the delays he occasions. Without work done, there is no real triumph to be had over one’s multifarious confusions here and elsewhere.

The air, the sea, the green land, and fine old-fashioned Country Hamlets, the rides by shore and silent lanes white with hawthorn: all is beautiful here;—on one’s first egress, such a sky as is miraculous to London eyes, every morning.
To work, to work! For the night cometh withal.Cf. John 9:4.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JN, 31 May. Addr: Roslyn Park, / Hampstead / London. PM: St. Leonards, 31 May 1864. MS: NLS 553.264. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p: Dear Neuberg,—I am on the Capture of Berlin by the Russns (Octr 3–12, 1760See Carlyle, Works 18:286–96.); whh appears to be all carefully written: but on what authorities, Good Heavens! Except Archtz, Tempf, Preuss, Heldene,Johann Wilhelm von Archenholz, Geschichte des siebenjährigen Krieges in Deutschland vom Jahr 1756 bis 1763 (Frankfurt, 1788); TC’s copy: HCC. George Friedrich von Tempelhoff, Geschichte des siebenjährigen Krieges in Deutschland, 6 vols. (Berlin, 1794); see Carlyle, Works 17:72. Johann D. E. Preuss, Friedrich der Grosse, eine Lebensgeschichte, 5 vols. (Berlin, 1832–34); Helden-, Staats-, und Lebens-Geschichte des allerdurchlauchtigsten und grosmächtigsten Fürsten und Herrns, Friedrichs des Andern, 11 vols. (Frankfurt, 1758–64); TC’s copy: HCC. no mark of any left here.— I suspect a certn Anonymous of Hamburg (as I call him)“Anonymous of Hamburg” was TC’s name for Johann Friedrich Seyfart’s Geschichte des (seit 1756) in Deutschland und dessen angränzenden landern geführten Krieges, 4 vols. (Frankfurt, 1759–62); see Carlyle, Works 15:18; TC’s copy: HCC. 3 little quartos, bound, red edges (stands behind my back, and at the edge of a shelf: easy to find by those marks): Oh try it;—get me something for TottlebenGottlob Curt Heinrich Graf von Tottleben (1715–73), Russian commander at the siege of Berlin, 3–12 Oct. 1760; for TC’s description of him, see Carlyle, Works 18:289. at least!— Or answer that you can get nothing; and I will give it up.

Item, what you can do better than another: Consult Walpole’s George IIHorace Walpole (1717–97; ODNB), Memoirs of the Reign of King George the Second, Edited from the Original Mss. with a Preface and Notes, by the Late Lord Holland, 3 vols. (1846); TC wrote “2d” above “II,” probably because the “II” was blotched, and could be mistaken for “III.” (behind my back, close to the north wall), and find (by his Table of Contents for 1760) what he says of Mauduit’s Pamphlet (agt Pitt & the War):Israel Mauduit (1708–87; ODNB), colonial official and political writer, author of Considerations on the Present German War (1760), a fierce attack on the policy of continental intervention by William Pitt (1708–78; ODNB); see Carlyle, Works 18:331–35. TC’s copy: HCC. Walpole mentioned Mauduit in his book on George III; see TC to JN, 4 June. excerpt
me (I mean sumar- summarizeThus in MS; TC repeated the first two syllables at turn of page. for me, brief as can be, but meaning given, and salient phrases if there are any) what Walpole (& his EditorHenry Richard Fox, 3d Baron Holland (1773–1840; ODNB), politician and man of letters; after Walpole’s death his Memoirs were kept in a sealed chest until 1810, and were then entrusted to Lord Holland to edit. imediately) say of this Pamphlt & Mauduit: I am then all ready for him.— These things (not even the Tottleben) cannot well be needed for a week); but of course, the sooner the better.
We are all doing tolerably well here (I hope):—work, however, is tragically impeded by Printer delays, by &c &c! Heaven grant us patience,—all of us
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

ps.p: 117. Marina, 31 May 1864

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MR, [ca. 31 May]. MS: NLS 608.630. Hitherto unpbd. Dated shortly after the arrival of Mary Craik at St. Leonards, ca. mid-May.
div3.head: JWC TO MARY RUSSELL

docBody.dateline: 117 Marina / St Leonards on Sea [ca. 31 May 1864]
docBody.p: Oh my dearest Mary—your kind invitations to Holmhill draw tears from my heart. Alas my Darling you have no idea I perceive of the critical, miserable state I am in— Mrs Aitken knows nothing of it—and Dr Carlyle about as little— The Drs, who have attended me, themselves have been at a nonplus— You speak of my ‘arm’—my arm is nothing in it now—for months my arm has been all right—the misery has been a more terrible thing, an everlasting torture in my womb—it is not a cancer or any such thing—the Drs say, only a nervous affection—but all the same the suffering attending it is beyond all words to tell.
It is a degree less since I came to this house but still sufficient to keep me in wretchedness day and night
I am very weak—can hardly walk across the floor—but that is partly because of pain and stiffness in my legs which Dr Blackiston imputes to supposed gout! God help me whatever it is—
I have hardly a hope of recovery—but they tell me I am too dispondent.

It was cruel in Maggie Welsh to leave me in such a stateMaggie Welsh returned to Liverpool to nurse her dying nephew; see TC to GEJ, 8 May.—but the Mary
Craik I have got in her stead is much more to my taste—a kind useful modest girl—
Oh my Mary shall I live to see your dear face again?— God only knows— I am very miserable

closer.salute: love to the DrDr. James Russell, Mary’s husband. / Your own friend

div3.sourceNote: TC-ED [EDOW], 1 June. MS: NLS: Acc. 9086. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO ELIZABETH DOWNES

docBody.p: Permit me to inquire whether you still live in the old House, or if not, what yr Address now is?

I was deeply grieved to hear what had befallen you and yours: a tragic end indeed to that sad “journey home”Downes returned home from Algeria shortly before his death, 15 May; see TC to Lady ALLA, 29 May. on the part of a brave and honest man!— Please to answer the above question, so soon as possible; there being something of an object in it, more or less.See TC to EDEDOW, 3 June.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-ED [EDOW], 3 June. Addr: 18. Gloucester road / Upper Holloway / London. PM: London, 4 June 1864. MS: NLS: Acc. 9086. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO ELIZABETH DOWNES

docBody.dateline: 117. Marina, St Leonards on Sea, 3 june, 1864—
docBody.p: Thanks for yr prompt ansr. The Dowr Lady Ashburton, whose Husband was lately taken from her, leaving one little child, claims to be “a Sister in affliction with you, and to do a sisterly act” (these are her own words);—and thro’ me, begs yr acceptance of the inclosed Doct for £50.The check apparently came directly from Lady Ashburton, rather than through TC’s account.
It wd be a most false delicacy if you had any scruples,—whh, I persuade myself, will be far from you. Please send me notice to the contrary.

closer.salute: I remain / Yours with many regards /

div3.sourceNote: TC-HL, [ca. 3 June]. MS: Huntington Lib. Hitherto unpbd. Dated by Larkin’s reply, 7 June.
div3.head: TC TO HENRY LARKIN

docBody.p: Dear Larkin,—Wd you send me a French DictionaryProbably M. P. Lorain’s Abrégé du Dictionnaire de l’Academie Française; 2 vols in 1 (1836) (Carlyle’s House 83). (all French, it is in a Paper cover, stands in shelf 1st, right hand as you look into the Drawingroom fire):
2°. a German do (1 vol. German do (1 vol. German & Englh;Unidentified. it is for Germn spelling mainly);—stands near the French.

3°. From the study room (behind me, & to my rt hand), a small dim book in 3 voll, called “Bourcet”Pierre Joseph Bourcet, Mémoires historiques, sur la guerre que les Française ont soutenue en Allemagne depuis 1757 jusqu’en 1762, 3 vols. (Paris, 1792); TC’s copy (HCC), autographed “T. Carlyle, Chelsea, 1858”; see Carlyle, Works 18:379. abt seven-years War.
4° (but not least!) The Mackintosh Leggings (surely discoverable somewhere) whh I ride with in wet weather.

We do tolerably here:—is there yet any outlook of a tenant for you? Neuberg’s acct of the Cat is quite pathetic:Larkin replied, 7 June: “I sent off the Books and leggings this morning by Rail: also posted ‘Fraser.’ You may rest quite sure that I do not, and will not, neglect the poor unhappy Cat. She evidently considers hers a very hard lot,—quite exceptional in the order of Creation,—and it has hitherto been more than I could do to convince her to the contrary! I have not yet obtained a tenant. I have two or three applications, but am very doubtful whether they will come to anything. The next Parcel you send to me had perhaps better be addressed to me at the ‘Battersea-Park Railway Pier’ [where Larkin worked]. I should get it just as soon, and at a much less expence.” oh don’t neglect her; I am sure you you don’t!—
Please take the Fraser;Fraser’s Magazine. put these 4 Stamps on it (I think it needs 4), & change the Address to:
Revd Walter Welsh

Auchtertool
Kirkcaldy
N. B.
I have been all day over Proofs; and still in haste, tho’ well tired.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JN, 4 June. Addr: Roslyn Park, / Hampstead / London. PM: St. Leonards, 4 June 1864. MS: NLS 553.265. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p: I have found my Tottleben; thank Heaven! Do not mind that any farther.

The Mauduit Pampht is, for certain, discussed in Walpole;For Tottleben, Mauduit, and Walpole’s Memoirs of George II, see TC to JN, 31 May. end of 1760 (I suppose,—& I have twice or oftener read it there): but I guess it must may be in George III, MemoiresHorace Walpole, Memoirs of the reign of King George the Third, ed., with notes, by Sir Denis Le Marchant, 4 vols. (1845) 1:33–34. (whh also are at Chelsea) not in Gge II. Pray look & send it me.

We stay here till end of july. I am not in very high figure of health; nor is my poor Jane much improving of late:—but I do now hope to get a few sheets hurled off my hands,—whh is the one poor consolatn left me in the world at prest

ps.p: There is even a Copy of Mauduit in my shelves (one in a little dumpy vol. of Pamphts, whh you will hardly care to read,—tho’ I had marked it as the best, witht knowing whose it was

div3.sourceNote: TC: Testimonial for Thomas Ballantyne [TB], 5 June. MS facsimile: Grey of Howick Collection, Prior’s Kitchen, The College, Durham, Co. Durham; another facsimile is in Houghton. Pbd: T. Ballantyne, Essays in Mosaic (1870) viii inc. Ballantyne enclosed this testimonial in his letter, 15 Oct. 1866, to Lord Grey. For TC’s more detailed testimonial for Ballantyne, also sent to Lord Grey, see TC to LG, 14 Feb. 1858.

docBody.p: I believe Mr Thomas Ballantyne to be perfectly sincere in his Political Opinions (whh I farther consider to be true, and of importance at present); & I have long recognised in Mr Ballantyne a real talent for excerpting significant passages from Books, Magazines, Newspapers (that contain any such), and for presenting them in lucid arranget, and in their most interesting and readable form.Ballantyne pbd. Passages Selected from the Writings of Thomas Carlyle in 1855; see 11:32TC to TB, 23 Feb. 1839. Witness my hand,

p.name: T. Carlyle
p.note: The preface (by J. Hain Friswell) to Ballantyne’s 1870 compilation quoted TC’s letter from “I have long” to the end, Friswell introducing the extract: “How far the compiler of these Essays is fitted for the very important task he has taken upon himself, may be judged by the following sentence from one who never flatters, who weighs every word he utters, and who, in depth and earnestness, is second to none in this age” (Essays vii). Ballantyne included 12 quotations from TC; only Emerson was quoted more, with 18.

ps.p:
117. Marina, St. Leonard’s-on-Sea
(for 5. Cheyne Row, Chelsea)
5 june 1864

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady A [LLA], 5 June. Addr: The Grange / Alresford / Hants. PM: St. Leonards, 5 June 1864. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Quot: Hansons, NE 519; Surtees, Ludovisi 111.
div3.head: TC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p: I have done yr Samaritan errand:A check for Elizabeth Downes; see TC to EDEDOW, 3 June.—I did not receive Mrs Downes’s 2d Letter (the first was to make sure of her Address) till this morning, otherwise I ought to have been quicker. It will be a very great benefit to the poor bereaved fellow-sufferer (widow of an honest and deserving man); and will be a solace to your own kind heart, and thus not want “its reward.”Cf. John Gay, “Epistle to Methuen,” line 42.

I also forwarded the Two Letters according to yr order. They point to a painful Chapter of affairs; painful to me to read, how much more to you to be active part of! Distressing, and even disgusting,—as I can well perceive. But there is one remedy, and I think only one, whh I think you might adopt: To be off with all these people, and their afflicting ideas; to retire into cold politeness, and silence in regard to that and the like subjects. My Wife says, “You do not really care for any of them except Louisa“:Louisa Baring, one of Lord Ashburton’s sisters. The dispute between Lady Louisa Ashburton and members of the Baring family was escalating as a result of accusations made by Lord Ashburton’s brother the Rev. Frederick Baring (1806–68), rector of Itchen Stoke, Hampshire, and repeated by his sister Lydia Emily Baring (1814–68), that Lady Louisa wrote a codicil to her husband’s original will without his knowledge, allowing her to remove family busts, paintings, and other items from both Bath House and The Grange. In May, Lady Louisa’s solicitor sent her the instructions for the codicil given him by Lord Ashburton and written in his own hand. In the original will, written 16 July1863 , Lord Ashburton left Bath House and its pictures and busts to her for two years, after which ownership was to revert to the holder of the title. On 9 Dec. 1863 he added a codicil to the will in which he left the leasehold of Bath House, its pictures, busts, and his chattels to his wife absolutely, as well as all the pictures at The Grange, without exception. Lord Ashburton had also wished that Melchet Court, bought from Frederick Baring for her (see 38:8JWC to LLA, [11 Nov. 1861]), be furnished from the Grange. Upset by the accusations that she was acting unethically, Lady Louisa decided to follow the wishes of her husband in his original will and to return Bath House and its pictures and busts after two years. For details of the dispute, see Surtees, Ludovisi 106–10. The Leeds Mercury reported, 13 June, “The will of William Bingham Lord Ashburton, dated July 16, 1863, with a codicil, dated Dec. 9, 1863, was proved at Doctors’ Commons on the 1st instant, and the personalty was sworn under £180,000. He bequeathed to his widow, Lady Ashburton, £10,000, and his furniture and personal effects, except his collection of pictures and statues at Bath House, which is left to the title upon certain conditions. His London residence is left to Lady Ashburton, with the enjoyment for two years of the pictures, which are afterwards to go with the title. His Devonshire and Cornwall estates are settled upon his only child, a daughter, and her issue. His American personalty is settled in like manner. Melchet Park, in Hampshire, and his residuary real and personal estate are given to Lady Ashburton. The principal landed estates were settled by the first Lord Ashburton on the title, and go to Francis, now Lord Ashburton, and his male issue. Certain furniture and effects in some of the residences on the settled estates are bequeathed to the title.” never mind any of them,
therefore, except her. I really advise this course, as the peaceable and safe one. Lawyers &c are there for the purpose of doing all the rest.

We are fluctuating forward here; have our ups and downs from day to day; but I really hope, are making progress. Jane was very low three days ago (no sleep at all, night before); but, for the last 2 days has seemed conspicuously better,—tho’ we are not permitted to say it, so despondt is she always, poor little soul. At the end of july, if able at all, she will be right willing to come to you,—and I with her, with a heap of Books &c hanging to me!— The Addiscombe Hamper is a daily blessing here; such butter, such cream, unprocurable by money:—I ought to be ashamed of myself; but am actually going to ask the Lady Bountiful for bread in additn! Bread here is bad; unwholesome too, I sometimes doubt; the Sick Dame and I eat of home-baked (when we can get it, whh here is not possible) “less than 1lb daily“:—that is Two Halfquartern loaves in the week (with a aTC repeats “a” with a line above it, at turn of page. margin over):—these are the exact facts: I cover my face, and disappear in haste!

div3.sourceNote: JWC-KS [KST], [10 June]. MS: NLS 1797.87. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO KATE STANLEY

docBody.p: Thanks, Darling for your kind and pleasant letter. I wish I could answer as you deserve but I am not yet up to letter-writing—indeed it were hard to say what I am up to! And my cousin has gone away to nurse another relation, and the young LadyMary Craik. I have got in her stead is too modest to write letters to unknown peopleMaggie Welsh wrote several letters giving news of JWC’s progress to Lady Ashburton, TC, and others; see, for example, MW to Lady ALLA, [136 Feb.?], MW to WDWDO, [7 March], and MW to GW, [25 March]. without an effort which I grudge to inflict on her
So I must just thank you—that’s all—and tell you how I am.

My handwriting will show that I have no great increase of strength—indeed the improvement which both my Dr and Mr Carlyle celebrate is a very little thing— I am certainly better than when I was carried away from Chelsea but I still suffer terribly, and have no particular hope that I shall ever recover! I wish to live—wish to have a future granted me for showing my gratitude to all those who have been so kind to me during my long illness— But it is difficult at my age, worn down with eight months of torture, to see the bright side of things—and indeed life is not to be desired on the present terms.
Now I must stop.—
God bless you! Dear and all of yours—
write to me again—tho I cannot write letters I am glad to read them

div3.sourceNote: TC-TW [TWO], 11 June. Pbd: Woolner 249–50; Wilson, Carlyle 5:545–46.
div3.head: TC TO THOMAS WOOLNER

docBody.p: Your Letter from The Grange, last Sunday, was naturally very interesting to us! My poor Wife is still too weak for writing, almost ever: but both she and I, and she bids me say so, are delighted to hear of your getting an eligible young Wife,Alice Gertrude Waugh. Henrietta Elizabeth Froude, J. A. Froude’s second wife, wrote to Woolner, 7 June: “The children returned from their walk yesterday reporting that they had seen ‘Mr. Woolner walking with a tall young lady—oh! so pretty & we think he must ‘be beloved to her’ (their expression for such matters)—for we passed him quite close & he never saw us!’ / Your note explains this sad neglect of your former friends & I am delighted to think that the surmises of the youthful minds were so correct” (Woolner 249). Georgina Margaret, age 14, Rose Mary, age 12, and Pascall Grenfell, age 10, were the children of Froude’s first marriage.—which we are aware is the crown and keystone of all comfortable Housekeeping, and expect will be a very great improvement to you, in that and all other respects. Solomon said long ago, “He that getteth a good wife, getteth a good thing”;Cf. Prov. 18:22. and I never heard anybody contradict him,—nor will I myself, by a long way!

In early times I used to hear a great deal of your fair Bride’s Grandfather; “Dr. Waugh,”Rev. Alexander Waugh (1754–1827; ODNB), United Secession minister from the Scottish borders, minister of Secession Church, Wells St., Oxford Rd., London, 1782–1827. oracle of all Scotchmen in that strange London, and much talked of at home among the Dissenting Religious Circles;—an excellent reasonable solid kind of man, I do still understand. Whom if a certain Young Person resemble, it will be well with her and Another! Very seriously we wish, to her and to you, all manner of prosperity, and a fortunate and useful life together.

We still imagine there is improvement visible here from week to week,—at least I do, rather more and not less confidently as we go on; and am for my own share at length got thoroughly busy again; which is an immense point in my favour. Everything is lovely exceedingly in these green environs, in this bright sea and sky;—and, till July unkennel London on it, the place is nearly empty of foreign guests. Except indeed a few Gipsies, squatted comfortably in some woody bank, on one’s evening ride.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-EF [EFO], [12 June]. Addr: care of John Forster Esqr / near Camden Tavern / Kensington / London. PM: St. Leonards, 12 June 1864. MS: NLS 1797.89. Hitherto unpbd. TC inserted after “Tavern“: “Palace-Gate House / (head of Gloster road).” The Campden Arms, 18 Hyde Park Gate, was near Palace Gate House where the Forsters now lived.
div3.head: JWC TO ELIZA FORSTER

docBody.dateline: 117 Marina / St Leonards on Sea [12 June 1864]
docBody.p: I am not up to writing letters yet. I cannot steady my hand nor my head—nor my heart— But the nice girl who has succeeded to Maggie Welsh is too shy for writing letters for me to strangers; so I must scrawl a few lines to ask news of you, which it seems I am not to have without asking.

What are you doing? How are you? and where and how is your Husband? and why has he never appeared here according to promise?Forster wrote, 6 May: “I have been made very happy, my dear dear Mrs Carlyle, by somewhat better news of you lately. I shall be thinking of you continually while I am away, and hoping at my return to see you. … I have work that will detain me about three weeks—and after that I have work that will take me, for a couple of days at least … to Hastings!
