So, mind and be sure to go on improving.”
My Husband gets along well enough—considering—

For myself— I have made little way since Maggie told you about me. I am very weak and suffer horribly—but with breaks in my suffering— Sometimes
I think myself slowly recovering; at other times I despair utterly. God help me! On earth is no help

div3.sourceNote: TC-JN, [13 June]. Addr: Roslyn Park, Hampstead / London. PM: St. Leonards, 13 June 1864. MS: NLS 553.268. Hitherto unpbd. TC’s notes, written on a scrap of paper, were possibly enclosed with a letter, now missing.
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p: n.b. I want to have a precise acct of what Goethe (in Dichtung & Wahrht,Goethe’s autobiography Aus meinen Leben: Dichtung und Wahrheit, 8 vols. (Tübingen, 1811–22). 16mo editn 30 voll)TC’s copy of Goethe’s Werke, 55 vols. in 31 (Stuttgart, 1827), was a wedding present from Goethe to the Carlyles (sold at Sotheby’s, Lot 64, June 1932). says of Gellert: “melancholy, nasal; mir schiener gewaltig zu hapern [seemed to me very narrow]“: the year of this;Christian Fürchtegott Gellert (1715–69), poet and professor of philosophy at the University of Leipzig; Goethe attended his lectures, 1765–68, and described Gellert as having “soft and rather pensive eyes; a very fine forehead; a nose aquiline”; of his lectures, he wrote: “the philosophy would not enlighten me at all. … Of the thing itself, of the world, and of God, I thought I knew about as much as the professor himself; and, in more places than one, the affair seemed to me to come into a tremendous strait” (Goethe, Dichtung und Wahrheit, trans. John Oxenford [1971] 265). For TC on Gellert, see Carlyle, Works 18:337–44. the &c
t.o. for some other question

(item, howr: Do you know anything abt “Chevr d’Assas”For the alleged heroism of the Chevalier Nicolas Louis d’Assas (1733–60) at the Battle of Kloster Kampen, 1760, see Carlyle, Works 18:328. Prs ii.270); and on what authority Prs contradicts all mankind, & calls him “Dubois”? Was not there a Pension granted to the Family of D’Assas?)Preuss appears to be the only historian who believed the hero to be a private soldier called Dubois; in 1777 Louis XVI (1754–93), king of France 1774–91, gave the d’Assas family a pension of 1,000 francs a year in recognition of the chevalier’s bravery. The Gellert thing first howevr; but at soonest t.o.

Nicolai, Anekdoten?See TC to JN, [6 March]. Frh feeding his Dogs (Preuss ii.282 who gives no authority):In Carlyle, Works 18:336–37, TC says the anecdote came from Jean Baptiste de Boyer, Marquis D’Argens (1704–71), French philosopher and writer, who spent much of his career at Frederick’s court, quoting Preuss as his source. is it fromTC drew a line in blue pencil from “from” up to “Nicolai.”
In Örtel Dates:Friedrich Maximilian Örtel, Genealogische Tafeln (Leipzig, 1847). Nephew of Frh Wm (Prinz v. Preussen): born abt 1745?

Wedded died younger Nephew Hi (died 1767)Frederick’s nephews, sons of his brother Prince Augustus William II (1722–58), were Frederick William II (1744–97), king of Prussia 1786–97, m., 1765, and Frederick Henry Charles (1747–67); see Carlyle, Works 18:336. TC left spaces after “wedded” and “died” for Neuberg to insert dates; Frederick William’s birth and death dates, inserted in red pencil, as well as various underlinings, were presumably by Neuberg. I have found

Siege of WeselFor the siege of Wesel by Prince Ferdinand of Brunswick (1721–92), Frederick’s field marshal, see Carlyle, Works 18:327–29. (in Walpole end of 1760): W.’s dour acct of it.Horace Walpole, Memoirs of the Reign of King George the Second; see TC to JN, 31 May. Walpole disparaged Prince Ferdinand’s exploits. “Nonsense that” &c (reduce to a sentence or two.

div3.sourceNote: TC-UC, 19 June. MS: Hilles. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO AN UNIDENTIFIED CORRESPONDENT

docBody.p: The “Petition” (whh is merely a titular one, and was never presented, nor meant to be) stands in the Book called Carlyle’s Works (Chapman & Hall Publishers),TC presumably refers to Collected Works, 16 vols. (1858). There are references to various petitions in the indexes to both The French Revolution and Oliver Cromwell’s Letters and Speeches, but these concerned petitions that were “presented,” so it is unclear to what TC refers. whh has an Index that will at once direct you to volume & page.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

ps.p:
117. Marina St Leonards
19 June 1864.

div3.sourceNote: TC-HL, 19 June. MS: Duke. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO HENRY LARKIN

docBody.p:
Dear Larkin,—Will you manage the Inclosed for me;TC is presumably referring to the medal sent him by E. J. Woolsey (d. 1895), a wealthy sugar-merchant from Astoria, New York; he wrote to TC, 30 April: “A newspaper paragraph stated that you were collecting articles illustrating the history of the subject of one of your works & thinking you might possibly value a medal of one of the ablest medallistes the world has produced, Engraved by him from a model which he executed from the original when he was at Berlin I take the liberty of sending it to you to place in your collection. It is not to be found anywhere even in Berlin. … Fine Medals have been my hobby & I have almost all the works of Hedlinger but this one I never saw until I accidentally found the dies. … Hedlinger was too good an artist to flatter & yet I can hardly understand the alteration time must have made in the Great Fritz, when I hold it side by side with an old Basso relievo of Fritz on horseback, which I have, taken when he was advanced in life.” Johann Carl Hedlinger (1691–1771), Swiss medal- and coin-maker. Woolsey gave TC the reference to an engraving of the medal, Johann Carl Hedlinger, Oeuvre du chevalier Hedlinger ou receuil des medailles de ce celebre artiste (Basle, 1776–78), plate 32; see above. i.e.: Get the “medal” (whatr it may be), put it on the mantel-piece, & inform the Mr “Riddel”
(whom I never heard of before)Presumably an intermediary of Woolsey’s in London; there were no Riddels but two Riddells listed in the 1861 census with U.S. connections: Joseph H. Riddell (b. ca. 1811), agent to American stovemaker, St. Johns Lodge, Tottenham, and Robert Riddell (b. ca. 1815 in Philadelphia), writer on architecture, 2 New North St., London. that it is come, & will wait my return.—
J. C. Hedlinger, Medal of Frederick
Courtesy of the National Library of Scotland
You can also send me one of these days (the first day anything comes “to be forwarded”), the Tax-AcctSee TC to HL, 29 May. you paid for me; and I will repay.
Things are rather aback with us here (our poor Patient out of sleep agn, &c); but we hope it is only a “fluctuatn,” in our otherwise not rapid Progress.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAF, 23 June. MS: EUL. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JAMES ANTHONY FROUDE

docBody.p: I have nothing that can be called good news to send you. In sanguine moments I persuade myself that my poor Wife is actually recovering; but at all times I have to own that the process is slow, very slow; and there are continual fluctuations (as at this moment, and for days past), whh drive one into gloomy enough misgivings, and too evidtly indicate immense suffering on the part of my poor Patient.John A. Carlyle reported to James Carlyle Jr., 21 June: “Your aunt has ups & downs & does not get on so steadily as we could hope for. From Friday last till yesterday she was much depressed & had much of her old pain. Last night she has slept well & looks much better this morning. Her disease is one that comes & goes unaccountably. It might entirely cease at any time. On the whole I think she does make progress. Your uncle & I are as well as usual—both working hard each at his own task” (MS: NLS Acc. 9086).— As my one consolatn, I try diligently to extort something of Work Done from this sad Hurlyburly; but, as you may fancy, it is unclear baddish conditns, and does not go so well as I cd wish. Thank God, “the Battle of Torgau”The Battle of Torgau, 3 Nov. 1760, where an outnumbered Prussian army led by Frederick defeated the Austrians; see Carlyle, Works 18:296–330. is this day corrected for the last, or as good as the last time;—it is the finis of Friedrich’s Battles; & I can trust in Heaven never to have another of those Phenomena to describe, in this world or in any other! If I cd have abt six months, and the decks approximately clear, I shd finish this Book after all; whh, to my poor self if to no other, will be little short of a miracle, were it once here. Esperons [Let us hope].

The air, the sea, the sky are all beautifully pure, fresh and wholesome here; my rides, so soon as I get into the green silent country-lanes, among the queer old Hamlets, low-lying Farms and Cottages, all in the innocent old South-Saxon type (as they were when Wilhelmus Conquestr first saw them), are of a charming quality,—something almost of a devotional character, to be left alone with the Earth and the Universe, instead of being driven delirious with Cockneydom & its squealings & sooty canailleries. My little Horse likes the steep descents (almost precipitous in places) very ill, & I think wd prefer London on the whole,—where he gets beans. I had a view of Rye this evg; Rye, Winchelsea, Dungeness, Romney Marsh, Dover Cliffs all visible where I was.TC wrote later: “I rode far and wide, saw strange old villages (a pair of storks in one), saw Battle by many routes (and even began to understand the Harold-William duel there. Strange that no English soldier, scholar, or mortal ever yet tried to do it). Battle, town and monastery, in the calm or in the windy summer gloaming, was a favourite sight of mine; only the roads were in part distressing (new cuts, new cockney scamped edifices, and railways and much dust). Crowhirst and its yew, that has seen (probably) the days of Julius Caesar as well as William the Conqueror’s, and ours. But that is not my topic. In the green old lanes with their quaint old cottages, good old cottagers, valiant, frugal, patient, I could have wept. In the disastrous, dust-covered cockneyfying parts my own feeling had something of rage in it, rage and disgust. It was usually after nightfall when I got home. Tea was waiting for me; and silently my Jeannie (as I at length observed) to preside over it (ah, me! ah, me!), directly after which she went up to bed. Hastings, St. Leonards, Battle, Rye, Winchelsea, Beachy Head, intrinsically all a beautiful region (when not cockneyfied, and turned to cheap and nasty chaos and the mortar tubs), and yet in the world is no place I should so much shudder to see again” (TC’s note in Froude, LM 3:199–200).

I can say nothing abt Table-rapping; I am really saddened by Ruskin’s taking it up even in mockery.Ruskin attended a séance, 23 Feb., at the home of Mrs. William Makdougall Gregory (ca. 1805–85), Grafton St., Mayfair. He was introduced by Georgina Cowper, b. Tollemache (1821?—1901; ODNB), an enthusiast, and her husband, the politician William Francis Cowper (1811–88; ODNB), later Cowper-Temple (1869), then Baron Mount-Temple (1880). Soon after the evening Ruskin wrote to Mrs. Cowper: “I am very grateful to you for having set me in the sight and hearing of this new world” (The Letters of John Ruskin to Lord and Lady Mount-Temple, ed. John Lewis Bradley [Columbus, Ohio, 1964] 30). He wrote to her, 24 Jan., “I had a long talk with Carlyle yesterday. He says Spiritualism is real witchcraft, and quite wrong (Wicked he meant—no, I mean, he said). It is all very wonderful; I have a great notion he’s right—he knows a thing or two”; and mid-April: “On the whole I am much happier for it, and very anxious for next time” (Letters of John Ruskin to Lord and Lady Mount-Temple 29, 31). The most blasphemous, detestable, contemptible subter[low]-doggery the Sons of Adam ever sank to, poor devils; as the Apostle says, let not such things once be named among you!Cf. Eph. 5:3. I ignore them, however blatant; strictly refuse to mentn them; that wd be the rule.— Yours ever T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-HL, 23 June. Pbd: Larkin, BQR 78.
div3.head: TC TO HENRY LARKIN

docBody.p: Dear Larkin,—We are not very flourishing here; my poor Wife being in a sleepless way again, for a couple of weeks past (tho’ with less of pain than formerly), and is at present in great suffering from that cause.

Are you doing anything at the Maps?Larkin helped prepare maps for Frederick; see 34:57JWC to TC, [19 July 1858], and 36:114TC to HL, 16 May 1860. Torgau is off in a complete state, this evening; and all the ‘Battles’ (some 7 or 8 of them unmapped yet, I think?) are ready for you. I am fighting as if for life to get forward! Yours always,

div3.sourceNote: JWC-HL, [25 June]. Pbd: Larkin, BQR 78–79 inc. Dated by Larkin in his introduction to the letter: “Two days after [TC’s letter of 23 June] I had a letter from Mrs. Carlyle, but not in her own handwriting, only dictated and feebly signed by her, asking me to look for a small box and send it to her: a letter evidently dictated in great depression of heart.“
div3.head: JWC TO HENRY LARKIN

docBody.p: I think you must curse the day you wrote that first letter to Carlyle,Larkin first wrote to TC in Dec. 1850; see 25:322TC to HL, 29 Dec. 1850. which brought you into never ending trouble with us. … Every emotion, even one of gladness, brings on my torture: a fine state of nerves to front such a world as this in. Kind regards to your Wife.Louisa Larkin. Ever affectionately yours,
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle.

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady A [LLA], 25 June. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p: We apply to you in every extremity, well knowing that yr Highland Heart will ansr, if Fate permit!

The poor Wife has fallen into almost utter sleeplessness agn (as have others of us that cd be named, in consequence of her): I persuade myself it is not a relapse into the old misery, but a kind of stage, tho’ a perverse one, in the slow fluctuating process of “recovery“:—enough, she has got quite wretched in noisy Marina,—is in horror even at the Sea; and we must all, evidently, march agn; if we will know whitherward. I myself have no resource (or had till she spoke, poor soul, who has always such a practical clearness left),—no resource except back to Chelsea, where I know of sleep, but she remembers only horrors of the 5 last months:—but in a word she suggests, “Wd na perhaps the Lady let us go to AddiscombeThe Ashburton estate nr. Croydon, Surrey. and try it?” I eagerly assent, if the place be empty & the thing otherwise possible. And that is the purport of my hurried Note (to save post) this morning.

There wd be three of us; Miss Craik (an excellt wholesome quiet little woman) besides Jane & me. We shd take our Maid, both or one, and do for ourselves witht troubling yours: yr Farmer wd take care of my little Horse (as in days long past!)—my Books are in boxes (whh become presses with shelves, when set up); I know well what room I shd settle in for writing, if you
permitted. It is within a ride of LondonAddiscombe was about 10 mi. (16 km.) S of Chelsea. and my Printer, too; and wd to me (not to speak of her, and her horror at the noises here) be a very great improvet of positn.
Answer, pray, in one word by return. And forgive, do forgive even if you have to ansr No.

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady A [LLA], 28 June. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Quot: Hansons, NE 520.
div3.head: TC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p: You are the kindest of friends: a thousand thanks, and regrets for troubling you.Addiscombe had been let; see TC to TWTWO, 28 June. The poor Wife, at first, seemed to grasp at the possibility of The Grange; but on reflexion, saw that, in yr absence, or even in your presence just now, it fairly wd not do. She is too weak and miserable to produce herself as company anywhere (regularly refuses to see visitors, of whom there have been three from London, who got no farther, except the first of them, than my little workshop down here);TC wrote later: “We had various visitors—Forster, Twisleton, Woolner—and none of these could she see; not even Miss Bromley, who came twice for a day or more, but in vain—except the last time, just one hurried glimpse. Nothing could so indicate to what a depth of despair the ever-gnawing pain and boundless misery had sunk this once brightest and openest of human souls. The B[lakiston]s continued with unwearied kindness doing, and hoping, and endeavouring; but that also, even on the Doctor’s part, much more on her own, began to seem futile, unsuccessful; good old Barnes came once (fast falling into imbecility and finis, poor man), said: ‘Hah! instrinsically just the same; however, the disease will burn itself out!’” (TC’s note in Froude, LM 3:200). and to organize ourselves, as a house within a house, in yr big Establishment, was felt to be, in present circumstances, too difficult a problem. We tried for furnished houses in Bexhill (a beautiful inland villageBexhill was 3 mi. (5 km.) W of St. Leonards. where somebody said they were), but found none, nor the likelihood of any in such places.

Back to Chelsea, the thot of it was horrible to her.TC wrote later: “About the middle of June (lease was to end with that month, and her own house, especially her own room there, had grown horrible to her thoughts) she moved that we should engage the house till end of July; which was done. But, alas! before June ended things had grown still more intolerable; sleep more and more impossible, and she wished to be off from the July bargain—would the people have consented? (which they would not)—so that the question what to do became darker and darker” (TC’s note in Froude, LM 3:200). My Brother, observing
how much good a long drive into the country did, proposed that, leaving me for Chelsea, the rest of them shd move off in a wandering way, by short stages, for Dumfriesshire, where many friends, and kindly conveniences and possibilities are; thence to return in Autumn, if strength enough had returned. This project she liked; but found it questionable in her prest weakness,—impossible till after some preliminary experiments in railwaying to short distances. In the interim a little of broken sleep had come back:—it was resolved, on the whole, to continue here (she in the landward side of the house, sea inaudible if she like to be silent from it), and to go upon the above program:—first journey, or long drive, shd have been today; but rain came, and it had to be given up.TC wrote later: “She drove out at lowest three or four times a day—ultimately long drives (which John took charge of to Battle, to Bexhill regions seeking new lodgings—alas, in vain!). Her last, daily drive from four to half-past five was always with me, my day’s work now done. She was evidently thankful, but spoke hardly at all; or, if she did for my sake, on some indifferent matter, naming to me some street oddity, locality, or the like; those poor efforts now in my memory are the saddest of all, beautiful to me, and sad and pathetic to me beyond all the rest. On setting her down at home I directly stepped across to the livery stable, and mounted for a rapid obligato ride of three hours: rides unlike any I have ever had in the world; more gloomy and mournful even than the London ones, though by no means so abominable even, one’s company here being mainly God’s sky and earth, not cockneydom with its slums, enchanted aperies and infernalities” (TC’s note in Froude, LM 3:199). That is how we stand; once more in a fixed conditn better or worse. I do not think there is in the world a wholesomer place than this,—provided there were to be had a house one could sleep in. But such bedrooms; such houses altogether,—rickety rotten abominatns, that ought to be flung into the Sea the instant they are built,—I find the above conditn cannot be complied with.—— You will write to us from Bath, if not sooner; I wish you had said how the bonny little Bairn is, and also how her Mother? Courage; there are better days coming, surely!

ps.p: Bountiful Addiscombe is excellt in bread, as in other things: thanks, thanks.

div3.sourceNote: TC-TW [TWO], 28 June. Pbd: Woolner 251–52.
div3.head: TC TO THOMAS WOOLNER

docBody.p:
You were right as to Addiscombe; next morning we heard it was let. Various projects were canvassed, other kind possibilities there still were, but all had their difficulties: the end was, We are to stay here till July is out; by which
time, it is hoped, a slow journey toward Scotland may be undertaken—my Brother superintending; I returning then to Cheyne Row, and waiting,—with Work and Silence as company. This is what suits me best; and her too, I really think.

There has been a little more of sleep (not at all a much) since you were here; and aspects are slightly brightening again. For this is the “Place of Hope!”See Carlyle, Sartor 121. Your amiable Young LadyWoolner’s fiancée, Alice Gertrude Waugh; see TC to TW[TWO], 11 June. sent flowers today; thank her, and say you wish her well (unless perhaps you have hinted that already!).

div3.sourceNote: TC-UC, 3 July. MS: Hilles. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO UNIDENTIFIED CORRESPONDENT

docBody.p: I am sorry not to be able to throw any light on the interesting inquiry you make. Mr CochraneJohn George Cochrane (1781–1852; ODNB), publisher and librarian; see 5:123TC to JAC, 14 July 1830. left no children or other representative; his Widow was an aged person, to whom he had been wedded very short while,Cochrane’s second wife, m. 1848, was Maria, b. Vaughan (b. ca. 1806); Maria was listed under Cochrane in the 1851 but not in the 1861 census; perhaps she remarried. and who, on his death, immediately went out of sight. It is possible her Address might still be known at The London LibraryCochrane was the first librarian of the London Lib., from its opening in 1841 until his death. 12. St. James’s Square: the person to inquire of there wd be Mr Jones the Chief Sub-Librarian.John Edward Jones (ca. 1824–93), sublibrarian, London Lib.; see 33:274–7533:biographical notes.

The Booksellers Treutel and Würz who used to publish the F. Q. Review,Treuttel & Würtz, 30 Soho Sq., foreign booksellers, pbd. the Foreign Quarterly Review 1827–34; Cochrane managed the business and edited the magazine until 1834. I suppose, have disappeared: but they must have some Successor,The magazine, initially taken over by Black & Armstrong, was bought by Chapman & Hall in 1841, at which time JWC helped John Forster find articles for it; see 14:18–19JWC to JOST, [19 Jan. 1842]; it was later incorporated into the Westminster Review. in possessn of their old records?
This unluckily is all I can say. With many regrets,

div3.sourceNote: TC-JN, 3 July. Addr: Roslyn Park / Hampstead / London. PM: St. Leonards, 3 July 1864. MS: NLS 553.266. Quot: Wilson, Carlyle 5:547.
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p: Dear Neuberg,—I now want that Letter of “Old Queen Charlottes,”Princess Charlotte of Mecklenburg-Strelitz, later Queen Charlotte; see TC to JN, 9 Jan. whh is in the Stettin School Publication;Programm des vereinigten Königlichen und Stadt-Gymnasiums (Stettin, 1863); see Carlyle, Works 18:357.—that is to say, I want your summary of the proof of date (“just after Charlotte’s confirmatn,” both PrnsPrussians. & Swedes in Mecklg-SchwerinMecklenburg-Schwerin. &c &c); your brief of all that: the Letter itself I have here (in Preuss the German, in G. MagneGentleman’s Magazine. the Englh). Perhaps it will be best to send me, along with yr summary, the Stettin Book itself;—I have told Larkin to expect on Tuesday till 11 a.m. in case (for Ln is sending me a Stenzel VGustav Adolf Harald Stenzel, Geschichte des preussischen Staats, 5 vols. (Hamburg, 1830–54). For TC’s instructions to Larkin, see TC to HL, 3 July. that day at any rate); but, if inconvent for you to leave it at Ln’s before that hour,—never mind; yr sumary by post will itself probably do.

The weather here is delightfully clear & cool; sea & sky and land very beautiful:—sleep, even to me, much more to my poor Patient, is unluckily not an adjunct. I fear she is making no clear way; but for the last 2 or almost 3 weeks, has again a great deal of misery from that old cause. The Doctors happily have left us, however; she herself quite sick of them: there is now nothing but the Disease to struggle with. I still keep hoping, hoping. Yrs always
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-HL, 3 July. MS: Duke. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO HENRY LARKIN

docBody.p: Dear Larkin,—I hope you recd the £10, and have paid those Tax-harpies?See TC to HL, 29 May. Please send me some acct, and whether you need more money to keep them out of yr eyes.

I want you at prest to send me “Stenzel vol V” (a Germn Histy of Frh (or of
Preussen?) you will find it standing on the shelves directly behind me,—voll. 4 & 5 bound in one. Note, howr: Neuberg has perhaps something to send me; I have promised him that you that youRepeated at turn of page. will wait till “Tuesday 11 a.m.,”TC told Neuberg as well as Larkin that he had already written to the other; see TC to JN, 3 July.—if after thenTC wrote “then” above “after.” that, there is no Ng, send me the Stenzel by itself.
Battle of Torgau, that is to say all the Battles are now with Robson, ready for you;Larkin drew the maps of the battles. perhaps you already have them?

I fear you have got no Tenant?See TC to HL, [ca. 3 June]. I am coming home (I suppose) abt Augt 1st: my poor Wife not; who is not doing well for the last two weeks or more (short of sleep agn &c, alas! alas!),—who has a horror of her old Chelsea bedroom (no wonder), and must try something else. Yrs always T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-HL, [5 July]. Addr: 6. Cheyne Row, Chelsea / London. PM: St. Leonards, 6 July 1864. MS: Huntington Lib. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO HENRY LARKIN

docBody.p: Dear Larkin,—Will you put (carefully) into yr final Map,The last map in Frederick is “Kingdom of Prussia” (Carlyle, Works 19:opp. 321). a little place near StrehlenTC wrote “near Strehlen” above “place called”; Strehlen (now Strzelin) in Silesia, 24 mi. (38.5 km.) S of Breslau (now Wroclaw). All the places TC listed are now in Poland. called Gross-TinzGross-Tinz, village where Frederick reviewed his troops, 22–25 Aug. 1785; during the review he was soaked by the rain, developing a feverish chill; see Carlyle, Works 19:283–84. (you will find it in Stieler 15o;Adolf Stieler, Karte von Deutschland (Gotha, ca. 1829–36); presumably the 15th section of the “excellent Map in 25 Pieces” (Carlyle, Works 14:352). abt 10 miles straightTC wrote “straight” above “miles” and “n.” n. of Strehlen, and 10 straight e. of the Zobtenberg;Zobtenberg, mountain.—it is where Frh got his death brot on him!) Don’t forget; & Klein Tinz too, if quite convent.Klein Tinz was not included on Larkin’s map.
n. b. however. There is another Tinz perhaps abt twice or thrice as far n. of Strehlen—carefully omit that!—
Yours always / T.C. (Tuesday).

div3.sourceNote: JWC-GLC, [9 July]. Addr: 2 Chlorine Place / Belfast / Ireland. PM: St. Leonards, 9 July 1864. MS: Strouse. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO GEORGE LILLIE CRAIK

docBody.p: I have been wishing and meaning to write to you every day for the last week but I have been in such torture that it was impossible. Today I have a slight respite, and I hasten to thank you from the bottom of my sorrowful heart, for the blessing you have granted me in dear Mary,For a photograph of Mary Craik, probably taken around this time, see opp.above. and to implore you to leave her to me yet a while; till we see whether I am to die or live.

p.hi: Courtesy of Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Columbia University

docBody.p: It may be a great inconvenience to you doing without her—must be—so helpful and good as she is!—but you are a good and merciful man, and a true friend, and you will put up with her absence when I assure you that the loss of her dear kind attentions would make my life at present even more terrible than it is—
I cannot write as I would—my hand shakes like a drunkards—only best love to you and GeorgyHis youngest da., Georgiana.

div3.sourceNote: TC-HL, 9 July. MS: Huntington Lib. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO HENRY LARKIN

docBody.p: Dear Larkin,—I am to send you back this Document, that you may pay as you proposed.Presumably a document connected to TC’s tax returns; see TC to HL, 3 July. The rest, it appears, are all right. Much hurry and confusion here, as usual; our poor Patient slightly better agn since last time.

I want you to look out Sir R. Murray Keith’s (Correspondence? Life? or whatever it is:Sir Robert Murray Keith (1730–95; ODNB), army officer and diplomat, Memoirs and Correspondence (official and familiar) of Sir Robert Murray Keith, K.B., envoy extraordinary and Minister Plenipotentiary at the Courts of Dresden, Copenhagen, and Vienna, from 1769 to 1792. … 2 vols. (1849); see Carlyle, Works 18:380–81. a small two-volume Book, on the shelves behind me); a Letter, or more than one there (it consists nearly of Letters in the order of time), date abt 16 or 17 July 1761, says something of a Battle of Vellinghausen (or Felinghn, may also be called Kirch-Denkern perhaps)Vellinghausen, village in NW Germany, about 30 mi. (48 km.) SSE of Münster; for the Battle of Vellinghausen, 15–16 July 1761, see Carlyle, Works 18:377–81; Kirch-Denkern was a nearby village. at whh Sir R. was prest
as Coll of Highlanders:—I want you to tell me, with practical exactitude what he says;—not much, if I remember. You need not transcribe all, only the few sentences that promise to be of use. On monday if I cd have them?— On the same she[l]ves is a little damp volume of Pamphlets abt Germany in 7-Yrs War, one of them Consideratns on the German War I think the last or nearly so of the Vol. is of importance to me: Please transcribe the Title (date, bookseller, number of pages &c)Israel Mauduit, Considerations on the Present German War; see TC to JN, 31 May. TC’s copy, 1761, printed for John Wilkie, bookseller in St. Paul’s Churchyard, had 144 pages; see Carlyle, Works 18:332. and let me have it. Or perhaps Robson will send to you abt it;—in whh case copy it agn for him. I am glad you have got part of yr House off yr shoulders. Augt I expect to be home. Yours always T.C

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, [13 July]. MS: NLS 616.627. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: John’s Letter whh I stopped on the street this morning, tells me you got “easily to town,” and were lodged &c:After the most recent spell of sleeplessness, JWC left St. Leonards, 12 July; TC wrote later: “But in the meanwhile, hour by hour, things were growing more intolerable. Twelve successive nights of burning summer, totally without sleep; morning after the eleventh of them she announced a fixed resolution of her own, and the next morning executed it. Set off by express train, with John for escort, to London; would try Mrs. Forster’s instead of her own horrible room; but would go (we could all see) or else die. Miss Bromley, who had again come, she consented to see in passing into the train; one moment only, a squeeze of the hand, and adieu. With a stately, almost proud step, my poor martyred darling took her place, John opposite her, and shot away” (TC’s note in Froude, LM 3:201). John A. Carlyle wrote from his lodgings, 48 Brompton Row, 12 July: “Jane stood the journey quite easily & pleasantly. We did not find Mrs Forster at home, but she soon came in. I could not get writing materials & have much difficulty in making the post. I will send you another letter tomorrow. I am to call & see Jane at ten o’clock or eleven in the forenoon. I hope to get some sleep as I am in my old room. Jane thought it unwise for me to go to Cheyne Row.” whh was a great relief to me;—but there is no news since; none will now come, tho’ I have expected to the last! Nothing but Chorley’sJohn Rutter Chorley. Proof lay waiting me after my ride;—a second Letter of John’s with nothing but Larkin matter in it, had come before. Ah me!—

We are very quiet here; the house fallen suddenly dead. I am as wae all day as wae can be. Oh that I may hear tomorrow my poor woman has got a taste of sleep agn; that wd be a comfort like no other! I inclose a Letter come from
Maggy, whh has news of Liverpool.Maggie Welsh was in Liverpool nursing her nephew; see JWC to MR, [ca. 31 May]. The Slippers came by post; need not hasten farther: Mary Craik is copying Ms. for me:—I have got no work done.

Oh Darling may God grant thee sleep! That will still make all right; and lift us all from this dark pit. Good night good night (many regards to Mrs Forster); God give you all a good night. Ever (in haste, haste!)
docBody.name: T.C.

ps.p: St Lds. Wednesday Evg 9.10.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JN, 14 July. Addr: Roslyn Park, / Hampstead / London. PM: St. Leonards, 14 July 1864. MS: NLS 553.267. Quot: Wilson, Carlyle 5:547.
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p: Dear Neuberg,—I got the GellertSee TC to JN, [13 June]. corrections; that is all right now: thanks. I am sorry to hear yr sea-side scheme has gone to smoke (in consequence of mine so doing),—and am still in hope to make you revoke that decision. As you will now see.

My poor Jane, DrJohn A. Carlyle. attending her, started for London morning before yesterday. Utterly witht sleep the night before, and nearly so for nights, it was no wonder she shd run: she had a horror at our own house, and drove straight to a Friend’s (at the end of Kensington): the journey had not hurt her, but at Kensington too there was little or no sleep (noise &c &c);—and a Letter of John’s, this morning, informs me that according to program they were to go by Mail Train, last night, direct thro’ to Carl Calisle;Repeated at turn of page.—and that, in all probability, if nothing have happened, she is at this time in the house of my Sister,Mary Carlyle Austin. and among her Dumfriesshire friends, at the very end of her wildest scheme of escape! Alas, alas! And yet I cannot say but it may have been wise, and in the torturing circs the best thing to do.— But the busss part is now this:

I intend to be home abt the end of this week,—or say likelier not till Monday. We have the House taken here till end of july; and shall have to pay for it: the House is a very clean excellently kept good little House (5 bedrooms, besides servts, good drawing room, dining do, “study” &c); and is in the very best and wholesomest part of the Town (western extremity, sea within a few
yards, & fresh air to America);—and now if you will accept it from me, it will be turning lost money to toRepeated in error by TC. some kindly acct; and till the end of july, it is yr own. Answer me at once; nay if you like to come down & see, there is a bed (there are 3 beds unoccupied), and you can accept by word of m mouth.Repeated at turn of page. Only let it be at once; for we are in correspe with the Owner,Mrs. Parker. and must settle directly abt the when & the how of all things. Say yes, if you will have a swash of sea-bathing, all of you, and do me a favr! Yrs always / T.C.

ps.p: (n.b. I have got only four pens left!)

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 14 July. Addr: The Gill, Cummertrees / Annan / N.B. PM: St. Leonards, 14 July 1864. MS: NLS 616.628. Pbd: Bliss, TC 368 inc.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Conceive my amazet, Dear, and my emotions many when I met the Postman this morning; and counted that you were probably at The Gill while I was reading!— In the terrible circs it was probably the real best you cd do. God grant you may have got thro’ the hideous journey witht hurt; I shall then hope actually for some repose agn and sleep to your wearied eyelids & worn-out soul. Oh my Darling, what a Birthday is this for thee! Flying from the Tormentor; panting like the hunted Doe with all the Hounds of the Pit in chace. Mrs Symmonds’sIsabella Simmonds. letter, whh I cannot read, has filled me with the saddest reflexions.

Poor Mary will do her very best and sisterliest for you. A kinder soul is not in the Earth. I try to flatter myself with hopes that in the simple silences and the environt of safety and affectionate Offices, there may sleep come at The Gill;—real “warm milk” will be procurable there; and much, I always think, cd be done by change to better diet:—there is water at The Gill, the like of whh you seldom tasted.— Jack may think with what anxiety I wait for news “tomorrow afternoon” and afterwds. I ran, last night, the whole way nearly to the Post-office; saved my time by one minute;—and it was of no consequence for my Note to you or to him.

The Lady of this mansnMrs. Parker. holds us fixed (as she has the right) till the end of July. I have just written to Neubg apprising him of the chance he has (gratis here till july 31); but don’t much think he will accept. I intend to be home abt
Monday in any case (that is my vague intentn, whh I think will hold); Mary I will not send for from Chelsea; Helen is busy scouring here;The Carlyles’ servants Mary and Helen; Mary accompanied JWC to London. Miss Craik packing, corresponding with &c &c—and nearly done.
Adieu, dear own little Woman; Oh for good news soon!

closer.salute: Yrs ever (on this day & on all days!) /

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, 15 July. Addr: 117 Marina / St Leonards on Sea. PM: Dumfries, 15 July 1864. MS: NLS 608.632. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:202–3; Bliss, JWC 312–13.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p: Oh my Dear! I am quite as amazed as you to find myself here! so promiscuous!Cf. “quite promiscuously”; coterie speech; see 10:72TCJWC to JCA, 1 May 1838. I had given up all idea of Scotland when I left St Leonards—felt neither strength nor courage for it—but postponed projects till I saw what lay for me at Palace Gate HouseThe Forsters’ home.—

I found there much kindness, and much state, and a firm expectation that I was merely passing thro! and if they had wanted me ever so much to stay; there was not a bed in the house fit to be slept in—from the noise point of view!— Cheyne Row full of LarkinsThe Larkins were temporarily in the Carlyles’ house, having sublet their own house at 6 Cheyne Row. and my old room in the same state—horrible was the idea to me!Coterie speech; see 18:83JWC to TC, [25 June 1844].— The Blunts perhaps out of town— London very hot!

I did sleep some human sleep in my luxurious bedroom, all crashing with wheels—but only the having had no sleep the night before made me so clever!TC wrote later: “At the Forsters’ she had some disturbed sleep, not much; and next morning ordered John to make ready for the evening train to Dumfries (to sister Mary’s, at the Gill), and rushed along all night, 330 miles at once—a truly heroic remedy of nature’s own prescribing, which did by quick steps and struggles bring relief” (TC’s note in Froude, LM 3:201).

I could not have slept a second night—no—there was nothing to be done but what I did!— turn that second night to use!—travel thro’ it—and not try for any sleep until there was some chance of getting it!— that night on the road was nothing like so wretched as those nights at Marina— I drank four glasses of champagne in the night—!! and took a good breakfast at Carlisle— John was dreadfully ill-tempered— We quarrelled incessantly—but he had
the grace to be ashamed of himself after, and apologize—on the whole it was a Birthday of good omen my horrible ailment kept off as by enchantment!John A. Carlyle wrote, 14 July: “We were fortunate enough to get a compartment to ourselves all the way to Carlisle last night, & Jane stood the journey quite well, suffering much less than she has often done of late from one night of sleeplessness. Mary had a comfortable carriage to meet us with at Cummertrees. The rooms here look very nice & tidy. … Jane looks better today than I have seen her since April—partly perhaps owing to her having accomplished the long journey so successfully. Let us hope that she may now make more rapid progress, & let us also be thankful that she has got through last night’s fatigue so satisfactorily. … Mrs Forster had provided Jane with sandwiches sherry & champagne for the journey when I went to Palace Gate House last night; & all were very useful in making her journey comfortable.”—
Mary is all that mortal could wish as hostess, nurse and Sister— She has had something of the sort herself and her sympathy is intelligent—

I am gone in for milk diet took porridge and buttermilk, in quantity last night!!!! and slept with few awakings all night—had a tumbler of new milk at eight and got up to breakfast at nine!!!TC wrote later: “The Gill, sister Mary’s poor but ever kind and generous human habitation, is a small farmhouse, seven miles beyond Annan, twenty-seven beyond Carlisle, eight or ten miles short of Dumfries, and, therefore, twenty-two or twenty-four short of Thornhill, through both of which the S.W. Railway passes. Scotsbrig lies some ten miles northward of the Gill (road at right angles to the Carlisle and Dumfries Railway): passes by Hoddam Hill, even as of old—and at Ecclefechan, two miles from Scotsbrig, crosses the Carlisle, Moffat, or Caledonian Railway—enough for the topography of these tragic things.—T. C.” (TC’s note in Froude, LM 201).
I am very shaky you will see; but oh so thankful for my sleep and ease—would it last!

John went to Dumfries yesterday afternoon—and all who had been about me being gone; I felt like a child set down out of arms—but am contriving to totter pretty well so far— John was to be here today some timeJohn wrote to his brother James, 15 July: “I have been at the Gill to see her again today; & she told me she had had ‘some excellent natural sleep’ last night after a supper of porridge & milk. She certainly looked much better than at any time during her illness, & one may hope that she will soon get back to her usual health. She will likely soon go to Mrs Russell at Thornhill, who has invited her several times. … It is likely that [TC] will soon return to Cheyne Row, though he has the house taken till the end of this month, for the weather was getting very hot at St Leonards, & he wanted more books which are not to be had from home. / I have to go back to the Gill by the forenoon train again tomorrow & stay till four in the afternoon” (MS: NLS Acc. 9086).— I am very sorry for you with those idiot Servants— Mary“Servant now (privately) in a bad way, as turned out!” (TC’s note in Froude, LM 3:203). Mary was pregnant and gave birth secretly, 29 July. proved herself of no earthly use to me; besides being sulky and conceited— Mary Craik is your only present stay—kiss her for me! dear kind good girl. I will write to her next— I am so sorry at having had to leave her in such a mess
James Austin had already got a nice carriage for Mary to drive me about in!! Oh they are so kind! and so polite!

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MR, 15 July. MS: NLS 608.631. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO MARY RUSSELL

docBody.p: Oh Mary! what a sudden astounding unimaginable thing to find myself here! Desperation is a fine thing, supplies the place of courage hope and strength! Desperation carried me here—in spite of all!—no sleep was to to be got at St Leonards— I was mad for want of sleep—all had been tried vainly except Change—so change I must take, and I could endure the thought of no place but Dumfriesshire
who but you and Mary Austin could bear with me in my present state or I with them—

I got thro the night journey (Dr Blakiston recommend me to go by night at one stretch) better than most of my nights at St Leonards of late and arrived here what I called alarmingly well— I fell at once to drinking new milk—eat an enormous supper of porridge and butter milk and had the longest sleep I have had for months— To night not being exhausted I shall not have the same chance but all is so comfortable and kept so quiet about me that I may still hope the porridge will help me to sleep more or less— I must stay here so long as it answers the end—and I hope it may be a little while before I fly to you—a strange hope you will say!
I will write again tomorrow or next day—
How glad I shall be to have you beside me to tell all my misery to!

ps.p: With such short notice, by telegram the Austins had already when I arrived hired a Carriage from Annan for my use while here— Oh they are so kind

div3.sourceNote: TC-HL, 16 July. Addr: 6. Cheyne Row, Chelsea / London. PM: St. Leonards, 16 July 1864. MS: Huntington Lib. Hitherto unpbd. 16 July was a Sat.
div3.head: TC TO HENRY LARKIN

docBody.p:
We are to be home on Tuesday afternoon;—I hope it won’t put you to much inconvenience, if you still are on our side of the wall. I cannot yet tell Mary
by you what the hour will be on Tuesday; but will, or Miss Craik will, send her word in time. I was to say also, Miss Crk had found on the road a key whh she supposed might be Mary’s;—and that if Mary cd get up the carpet of my bedroom (that is, take it off altogether with a view to being beaten), and thoroughly clean the floor, it wd be an improvet in the hot weather.Larkin wrote, 18 July: “We left Cheyne Row Saturday afternoon. … I called at No 5 this morning and found your note, and one for you from Scotland which I will enclose. I gave your message to Mary, she has been working very hard, and says she will do her best to have everything as forward as possible by tomorrow.”

I did not know till this instant (shd have known yesterday, had every one been sharp) that Tuesday must be the day.— We had word yesterday from Scotland that the Dr & his poor suffering Patient got duly to my Sister’s, witht accidt or injury,—on Thursday morng: since whh we can have no news till this afternoon.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MC [MCR], 16 July. Addr: 117 Marina / St Leonards on Sea. PM: Annan, 16 July 1864; Hastings, 18 July 1864. MS: Strouse. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO MARY CRAIK

docBody.dateline: The Gill / Cummertrees Annan N. B. Saturday [16 July 1864]
docBody.p: My dear, good, kind, patient Mary! I should have been more unhappy at leaving you, if I had not renounced all idea of Scotland, and looked forward to your joining me in London. But as things turned out, on my looking about me, at Palace Gate House; the sudden astounding resolution I took was the only feasable one—“Fortune favours the Brave”!See Terence, Phormio line 203. that long night journey was the bravest step I had taken for some time, and it did not kill me, but gave me a much less miserable tho’ sleepless night than I could have had in my torture-bed at Marina—and even now that the excitement is past I feel better than when I started

The first night I had an excellent sleep—last night I have also slept, not so well of course being not so worn out, but much better than at Marina— I eat such a supper of porridge and butter milk as is better than all the morphia in the world!—and I drink new milk three times a day— My horrible ailment has been much abated—but I dare not trust to its continuing so, I am so weak and nervous still! Enough of that
How I do pity you in all that packing and worrying and how thankful to Heaven I am that Mr C has such kind help—while I am fit for nothing

I found MaryMary the servant. most provoking—and augur ill for the help she will give— I left with her all the keys sealed up—recollect there will be no clean sheets but those you bring with you—and recollect to seek in my drawers for the blue moire dress I spoke of—and wear it for my sake—
For heaven’s sake dont be robbed of my leather box! it contains all of valuable and precious that I have in the world!
There is a silver-topped ink glass about which is not Mrs Parkers but mine—
I fear this wont reach you till MondayJWC was correct; see the second postmark.
I cannot write any better—
I think much of you dear girl—much and gratefully!—
They are very kind to me here too— If I were only well enough to prove my gratitude to you all!
Love to my Husband

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 18 [17] July. MS: NLS 616.629. Hitherto unpbd. TC misdated; he wrote this letter the morning of 17 July; see TC to JAC, 17 July.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Oh my Darling, what a blessing of blessings! It is like a miracle; and lifts us from such a pit of misery! Till yesterday afternoon, I did not know what had become of you after shooting off to The Gill, like a wild rocket (driven not by choice);—but the Postman yesterday far exceeds all that I had dared to hope. There has not been a tone of yr old self in any Letter till that of yesterday;—and here you are audibly again, my dear little woman still.— Tell Mary she never in her life did me such a favour, and she has done me a great mercy, as this of helping you to a little sleep in yr sore extremity. But I must hurry (& you see how my hand is shaking); I have slept too long this morning; and the post hour is close at hand.

We go on Tuesday Evg (5 o’clock train, Chelsea abt 8); Neuberg is not coming (it was he that detained me another day, the pig); the Larkins are written to, & Mary will be ready for us. Don’t bother yr head abt me, Dear; nothing is wrong here (only a great heap of Proofsheets, whh also is right); Mary Craik, walking gingerly, keeps all straight & clean for me; after I am installed in Chelsea she is off (she says), and then too I shall make no doubts of getting services of Maid Mary, shd the Helen require even to be turned away. Never
bother at all:—and (what is far more importt) don’t break down into despair agn, when you have a bad night:—Oh Darling pluck up, save self & me!—T.C.

ps.p: KingThus in MS; for “Kind.” regards to Jas & Mary and all the Household

div3.sourceNote: TC-HL, 17 July. Addr: 6. Cheyne Row, Chelsea / London. PM: St. Leonards, 18 July 1864. MS: Huntington Lib. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO HENRY LARKIN

docBody.p: One of my Letters tomorrow (Monday morning) will probably be from my Brother, specifying how his Patient is. Our last accts were excellt (singular to say!)— I need not tell you how anxious we are abt the next that fall due!

Will you therefore push all my Monday Letters off witht delay hither:TC addressed the envelope “To Mr (or Mrs) Larkin” and wrote “speed” in the bottom left-hand corner. off witht delay, I shall perhaps get the morning ones at 6 p.m., and at latest all will reach me Tuesday morning early,—instead of lying 12 hours longer at Chelsea unread. We expect to arrive by the five 4.55 p.m.TC writes “4.55 p.m.” above “the five.” o’clock train; whh gets to Victoria Station at 7.45:—wd you be so good as tell our Mary (in case she be not written to) of that fact, and that we shall have dined;—also, more specially, warn Sylvester of his Four-footed Friend and mine, and that if the younger Mr S. will be at the railway station to take delivery I shall be glad. This is all.

ps.p: I think you will get this sometime early in the afternoon; it leaves this tomorrow morning at 8.— If you are quite too late for evg post, when this comes, do nothing with the Letters.
St Lds 17 july 1864 (late).

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 17 July. MS: NLS Acc. 9086. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p:
Dear Brother, a thousand thanks. I got all yr Letters whh were abundantly interesting, and in the end you may fancy how agreeable! Poor little soul, what a bound she made, to get out of the fiery element! Her Letter of yesterday is quite in spirits, quite like her old self, after the sleep and kind nursing at The
Gill. We must not expectedThus in MS. continued prosperity; but surely these are the best aspects we have yet had. God grant they may continue!

Neuberg is not coming; you will see he intended the “Lodging” to be for himself alone, and concluded you might suit him by guess. He missed a post, the sluggardly fel- fellowRepeated at turn of page. (not reckoning sharp): so that we cannot get away till Tuesday. Tuesday Evg (5 o’clock, arrive abt 8 if all prosper); then will be a busy day,—full of work, but not otherwise awry; all things going on smooth since you went. I have written to have yr Letter forwarded so that I may get it on Tuesday morning: Oh may the news continue good! “Tom Spedding” is to give me his acct tomorrowThe account was for the stabling of Noggs; the name of the stabler was Thomas Skinner, not Spedding; see TC to JWC, 11 May. TC recorded: “19 july 1864 / to Skinner / (Horse at St Leonards) / £11 .. 7 .. 0” (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753). (all right I have no doubt); do our Landlady do.Mrs. Parker; TC recorded: “19 july 1864 (St Leonards Rent) to Mrs Parker £54 .. 19 .. 0” (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753). TC repeated “do.” Miss Craik talks of being off before next week end. She is very gentle, quietly assiduous and punctual: but I shall like as well to be solitary agn over my sheets. Today I have done a fair spell of drudgery: 160 pages fairly gone, and another 100 well forward. I need not bid you write, write! My kindest regards to James & Jean and all the Household there. I am sadly driven for time; a line for Jane went off this morng, and perhaps this will reach as soon. Adieu. T.C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 18 July. Addr: Mrs Austin / The Gill Cummertrees / Annan / Dumfriesshire / N.B. PM: St. Leonards, 19 July 1864. MS: NLS 616.630. Pbd: Bliss, TC 368–69 inc. The envelope was addressed in another hand, presumably Mary Craik’s.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Tomorrow morning this will be under way betimes; and you will get it on Wednesday;—I shd have no time tomorrow morng, and my ha[n]dTC omitted the “n.” will perhaps be shaky in the hurry.

Oh my Dear, what a comfort it is to me in my prest dreary state that your wild adventure has succeeded! I got John’s Letter today (brings you down to Sunday at Scotsbrig),John A. Carlyle wrote, 17 July: “Jane had had some good sleep on the previous evening when I saw her yesterday (Saturday) at Gill. A small undeveloped cock had tried to crow under her window early in the morning & waked her, but it soon went off & she fell asleep again. … [S]he wrote a letter to you (addressed Cheyne Row), & one also to Mrs Braid her old nurse. She spoke of driving across to Scotsbrig today, & the weather is very favourable, but she has not yet arrived. I will add a little postscript, if she does come, & will send a copy of this to St Leonards, that you may not be without news tomorrow whether you have moved or not. … 1 o’clock p.m. Jane has just arrived, Mary & James Austin with her, & she looks pretty well; but she says she had a slight attack of colic last night about bed-time—owing to have taken too abundant milk, whey &c. & got little or no sleep during the night.” and things still looking rather well. Your own dear
Letter (whh John speaks of) I have ordered to be forwarded hither tomorrow;—or I shall find it at Chelsea at latest. We must not expect continued smooth water, best be prepared for relapses and the like: but surely you are a great deal better than you once were, poor little soul; and I can think to myself (cannot I) “she is recovering to me; again we shall journey on together,—and have an easier time of it, my labours and drudgeries all thrown aside!”— O Jeannie, Jeannie; my poor little Fellow-Pilgrim, true as steel— — Yes, Yes!

This is our last night in this “Congeries of rotten Bandboxes,”Apparently TC’s phrase for the new built houses in St. Leonards, including 117 Marina; see Carlyle, Reminiscences 176. calling itself House No 117: tomorrow night I hope to sleep in my own bed agn,—and fairly get the decks cleared for farther actn on better terms. Poor St Lds, let us not be unjust to it either. I believe it did you essential good, and that I too have profited by it. Innocent silent country aspects; two hours a day of absolute silence and company with antic old cottages innocent good peasants (in the distance they too) and the everlasting fields and skies cannot but have been wholesome to me. I rode Crowhirst way this evg; visited my old giant YewThe yew was in St. George’s churchyard, Crowhurst, Sussex, about 4 mi. (6.5 km.) NW of St. Leonards; see also TC to JAF, 23 June. for the last time,—with many reflexions as I went along, upon it and other objects. All settlets &c are like to be perfectly quiet & comfortable; great part of the packing is done. Miss Craik is unweariedly industrious:—I worked today as usual; & mean to be idle (or busy otherwise and idle) tomorrow. I will write on Wedny if I live. Not a word more tonight;—I am only prosing, and keeping back “Supper.”
Good night Dearest; Oh might I hope you will agn have sleep! Kind regards to everybody. Yours ever.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [19 July]. Addr: 5 Cheyne Row / Chelsea / London. PM: Dumfries, 19 July 1864. MS: NLS 608.633. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p: Dearest I wish I had someone to write a letter for me today— I am very low myself— My second night was little like the first—a violent fit of colic kept me entirely awake— Nevertheless I drove to Scotsbrig on Sunday—where John was sitting amidst the usual litter of note paper—and “adding a postscript about me” without waiting to hear what there was to addJohn A. Carlyle’s postscript, 17 July, included information about her colic and lack of sleep; it was written before the accident happened; see TC to JWC, 18 July.—

The first carriage James Austin had got for me was sent for by the owner and another got from Dumfries “by the help of James Aitken—would never have been got without him”!— Oh that it never had!— I thought it just like those things that stand in wheelwrights yards for fowls to roost in—but i could make no criticism being the party obliged—

It took us to Scotsbrig and back in the evening past Kinmont Lodge,Lodge at entrance to Kinmount House grounds, 3 mi. (5 km.) E of The Gill. and then suddenly the world seemed coming to an end— Crash went everything The Horse rushed off with the pole and fore-wheels

James Austin was tossed in the air and dashed on the road—the body of the carriage fell forward, Mary and I heels over head— I instinctively clasped my knees, and made myself into a ball in falling—and both of us got off with the fright—

The carriage was all crumpled into dry rot! Jamie’s arm was sore hurt but he got up, and ran after the horse with the wheels driving it mad! It was upset some three miles off and its hind legs sorely cut—it was Jamie of Scotsbrig’s horse— Mary and I sat in the ruins of the carriage more than an hour—when a flock of children arrived from Cummertrees with news for us that James Austin was bringing the Minister’s Gig.Probably belonging to George Gillespie (1795–1870), Church of Scotland minister of Cummertrees 1828–70; see 31:154TC to JWC, 7 Aug. 1856. And we returned home in it— A nice sleeping draught—nevertheless in spite of all I slept some, in virtue of having slept none the night before—but yesterday I was terribly nervous—and today I am not better—had little sleep and that very painful—my feet are swelled worse than ever and I cannot walk out— I wanted to write you a nice letter but I can’t— I am terribly out of spirits—the worst of being here is that I am so much alone alone and nothing but dismal thoughts

p.name: Jane Carlyle
p.note: TC wrote later on MS: “19 july 1864 (two days after her arrival;—oh in what misery and now read!)—T.C. augt 1868.”

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 20 July. MS: NLS 616.631. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.dateline: Chelsea, 20 July (Wedny) / 1864 (Under the sky, back area, & beautifully cool: 3 p.m.
docBody.p: This day I got yr Letter direct, and have had successively two from John (yours & they all of yesterday’s date); but shd have known almost nothing of yr real conditn, had it not been for yr own clear but dispirited acct. Oh my poor Jeannie, what a villain of an accident from that accursed dry-rotten Clatch! And how easily withal it might [have]Word omitted. smashed poor you and Mary & the Driver into utter ruin. He James, it seems, is the only one really lamed, and even he not very seriously, while the and you the weakest are let off for the fright. The last view of you was that of yr embarking at Dumfries with James agn for driver “abt 7 in the beautiful evening,” for drive of two hours home agn. I cannot but persuade myself there is real profit in present course of life; and that you cd be in no better place than whereabts you have landed. Diet, regimen, driving,—milk, whey, cream (with a little brandy), chicken broth; Gill eggs (there used to be fine brown bread in Annan): poor Mary, I know well, will let you want for nothing that lies within the uttermost of her endeavours: Country fare (with say 4 glasses of yr bitter sherry daily), and always in the air when you can manage;— —it is impossible but it must do you good, whh no medicine evidtly is fit to do. You can change abt, “vaary the schene” as poor old GrandfrJWC’s maternal grandfather, Walter Welsh (1752–1832); see 31:189JWC to TC, [23 Aug. 1856], and Carlyle, Reminiscences 72. used to say (and a wicked little imp he had for granddr); you can go to Thornhill for days, then back to Mary &c &c: Do yr very wisest, poor lame Schatz [Darling]; and oh get into Sleep agn,—you want and I want nothing more!

We had a great deal of busss yesterday; or at least Miss Craik had, for she took it wonderfully off me,—and I even went in for a sleep in the middle of it; while the “Inventory” people were chatter-chattering (their acct of breakages not heavy): I wrote Mrs Landlady a (crossed) cheque for the full of her demand;Mrs. Parker; see TC to JAC, 17 July. & Miss Craik has just added her Post-Office order 11 shillgs on the Inventory score: so that we are now completely out of the Affair (to the joy of some of us),—heavy luggage having all arrived in full tale, and most of the Books &c got to their places (so industrious, eagerly ready, swift and judics is the excellt “Mary” Craik): and I have even been working, in a canny fashion, in the cool of the House-shadow since morning. We came off at 5 as
arranged, yesterday evg (were abt ReigateReigate, town in Surrey, 22 mi. (35.5 km.) S of London. while you started from Dumfries); got here (horse to Silvestr, who was waiting, was visible once from the cab) before 8; had got our “six pieces of luggage, sir” (that was the only fault in our packing, Mary’s packing, so many pieces of it) safely stowed, and were at tea in the Drawingroom, sorely in miss of you, but else all right. It is uncountable what trouble that good girl saved me: in the end I quite retired and left her to act. The contrast betn Miss Craik at the Luggage Van (when we arrived) and that mass of impertt crinoline whh calls itself “Housemaid Helen” was almost amusing! London was hotter than I liked;During July the Times regularly reported temperatures above 86° F (30° C). dreadfully noisy (from CremornePleasure gardens nr. Cheyne Row; see 37:169TC to JAC, 2 June 1861; no closing parenthesis. especially all except in our own quiet street;—I actually slept 6 unbroken hours, in my old bedroom after 1 a.m. when Cremorne had died. This morning, I comenced readjustments; gave my two foolish domestics, something of an awakening,—in fact clutched up the reins, & shall make the team go, no fear of it! Never bother abt me or it: Get better, darling: that is it! And write. Yrs ever T.C.

ps.p: A sheet (concluded) goes to the Printer by this same post: think of that! Excuse me to Jack; his overshoes are come, Hat given away &c &c
Tell me when you want money (or anything else I have)

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [21 July]. Addr: 5 Cheyne Row / Chelsea / London. PM: Annan, 21 July 1864. MS: NLS 608.635. Quot: Fielding and Sorensen 300–301. TC wrote later on the envelope: “The Gill: (21 july 1864).“
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p: Oh what a fool I was to dream that by putting myself on a railway I could get whirled away from my misery! or that there was any place quiet enough for me to sleep in but the grave! I could not write a line yesterday—and perhaps no news was better than the bad news I might have sent. Not one wink of sleep all night and the pain raging! that was all I got by my long drive from Dumfries where John over-persuaded me to go to shake off my headache— I have put hundreds of miles between us—and am as ill and need you as much as ever.—

Last night I got a little sleep towards morning all the animals are shut up on the premises but the railway screechs and roars all thro the night,The railway between Annan and Dumfries passed within 200 yds. (183 m.) of The Gill. and other peoples dogs bark all about.
The porridge, like every thing else succeeded once— I have had to go back to my magnesiaMagnesia was widely used as a remedy for acidity of the stomach and as a mild laxative.

John was not here yesterday he is bent on making me out “much better“—because he had had charge of me—just like Dr Blackiston— I was a fool to go to Dumfries at his bidding— Oh my Dear my Dear I am so lonely and miserable!— Mary is all kindness but I miss the faces I have been used to—and I am too weak for roughing it! God help me!

Miss Bromley was to take charge of getting the Drawingroom and my bedroom papered—it will be done in a one time as there is no painting— If I ever get back I should like some difference in the lookTC wrote later: “‘If your room at Chelsea had a new paper?’ somebody suggested; and Miss Bromley had undertaken to get it done. This of the ‘new paper’ went into my heart as nothing else had done, ‘so small, so helpless, faint’; and to the present hour it could almost make me weep! It was done, however, by-and-by; and under changed omens. Thank God” (TC’s note in Froude, LM 3:200–201).
Jane has got a very grand houseJean Aitken’s new home, The Hill, Lochmaben Rd., Dumfries.—but I was too ill to give it all the admiration expected from me—she looked more natural in the old house.

I wish I could tell you all about them—but I am so shaky and nervous— The effort of writing costs more than it is worth— Do call on Lady William Russell she has written to meFor Lady William Russell’s letter to TC, 30 April, see TC to JWC, 30 April. and I cannot answer— Tell Mary Craik to seek for the black hat with the white feather she was to have— Tell her I shall be for ever grateful to her

ps.p: I will write to Mrs Russell that I will come the day after tomorrow (Saturday)

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MR, [21 July]. MS: NLS 608.634. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO MARY RUSSELL

docBody.p: Dearest I will come please God on Saturday (the day after tomorrow) I have been getting on very ill—awake all night again and my ailment worse of course— I regret dreadfully that I have rushed away so far to plague others with my wretchedness—
I mean to come by a train that passes here at 12—but I will tell you the hour when I have seen Dr Carlyle who is a walking Bradshaw—
I think I should like best the old room that I knowPresumably Mary Russell’s “own room” where JWC slept on her last visit; see 38:132JWC to TC, [12 Aug. 1862].

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 22 July. Addr: Dr Russell / Holmhill / Thornhill / Dumfriesshire. PM: London, 22 July 1864. MS: NLS 616.632. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Oh my Darling, I hoped I had still half an hour for you good;Probably for “Goody,” JWC’s nickname; see 34:85TC to JWC, 30 July 1858. and they came suddenly with dinner to me. Oh what a day of down-hearted humour this has been with me, since yr Letter came! You are very miserable agn; no Dr needed to convince me of that. Alas, alas! But don’t be quite downcast, Dearest; your very pain increases, in a frightful ration, the real amount of worseness that there is. Think of that too in the corner of yr clear mind. One of the clearest little minds I ever met in this world! And Thornhill, if only as a change, will certainly do something. I will hope for improvet of news:—alas, I think I cannot hear from you till MondayTC wrote on Friday. (except today from The Gill?)—and you are the indubitable authority.

Last night, what was a great necessity even for me, I got a fine reasonable sleep here: there is not so quiet a place practically in the world,—thanks to my dear little Woman from of of old! I had a gallop yesterday evg, whh perhaps contributed. I called for Miss Bromley,—found her in, to my disappointt rather, in such haste. She said nothing abt papering here; indeed there were people with her, and I made no stay. Cannot I and Larkin get the Papering done? We cd send you the Patterns &c. Yes, yr old room shall be made new; and you will join me here till I get done with the Book (it is really going; a great truss of embroiled sheets lying tied up, for this day’s produce);—Book done, I will shift to where you like; you shall have my pony to a brougham: Oh Jeannie, Jeannie, do pluck up a heart, and get better for my sake.— Miss Craik goes on Monday I think: very well,—tho’ she is an excellt young soul. The GirlsThe servants Mary and Helen. will do, I think; & in case of need shall. God bless thee Dearest of Beings: I am now off for a little sleep, if I can get it. With kindest regards to Dr & Mrs Rll,—old friends & tried. Adieu T.C.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MC [MCR], [22 July]. T Carlyle Esq / 5 Gt Cheyne Row / Chelsea / London. PM: Annan, 22 July 1864. MS: Strouse. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO MARY CRAIK

docBody.p: Dearest Mary I am totally unfit to give you either directions or suggestions— My sleep is quite gone again and I am nearly mad with suffering—last night was horrible, just some snatches of broken painful sleep in the morning—

I can only refer you to the bundle of carefully marked receipts from Chelsea that were in the little drawer— The PoultererPossibly James Walker, fishmonger, poulterer, and dealer in game, 94 King’s Rd., Chelsea. I have always found a perfectly honest man—but I cannot think how Maggie neglected to pay him—

Certainly Mary should pay the bills once a week but Mr Carlyle must look at them—it is not fair even, to Servants, to put so much in their power— Yes they are not fit to take care of him, but what to do when I am quite helpless?—and I may say hopeless—
I mean to go to Holme Hill tomorrow but what better will it be there than here? Oh I am a miserable wretch—my burden is greater than I can bear!
If Mr C would like Maggie Welsh I have no doubt she would gladly go to him—
I am sure he will be for ever grateful to you—
It is not hot here, cold, wind, and rain for the two last days.
I think if Mr C would keep only Mary he would be better served—but then, if I return, another would be needed and I no power to seek!— God help him! God help me! Yours ever affly
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [23 July]. Addr: 5 Gt Cheyne Row / Chelsea / London. PM: Thornhill, 23 July 1864. MS: NLS 608.636. Quot: Froude, LM 3:204–5; Bliss, JWC 313; Hansons, NE 520; Ashton 432.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p: I find if I do not write today no letter will reach you till Tuesday— So just two lines to say I have arrived safe and got your note.

They met me at the station and are kind kind—as indeed many are— John
offered to accompany me here but I declinedJohn A. Carlyle wrote, 24 July: “Jane was looking much better yesterday when I saw her at the station here, & said she had had more sleep the night before. … I was all ready to go with her to Thornhill, & had offered to do so the previous day, but she thought it better for me not to go, as Mrs R might make a fuss in preparing some formal dinner if I went.” — I have not had so much pleasure in him as to prolong our intercourse a moment beyond what I could help—

He has been very hard and cruel—and mean inconceivably! but that, is his own affair! Fancy him telling me in my agony yesterday that “if I had ever done anything in my life, this would not have been! that no poor woman with work to mind had ever had such an ailment as this of mine since the world began!!!”“Poor John! well-intending, but with hand unconsciously rough, even cruel, as in this last instance, which she never could forget again” (TC’s later note in Froude, LM 3:204). John commented, 28 July: “She will have ups & downs at Holmhill as elsewhere; but at no other place will she have so good a chance of getting back to her usual old state of health; for the quiet there is perfect, the kindness of Mrs R unquestionable, and Dr Russell’s patient & firm & quiet skill will help her greatly to keep herself in order & free from such unwholesome rudeness as she has been liable to fall into with her own relations.”—

I am not so ill today but that was of course—movement—change—change—! and I have but one wish—to stay still— I slept last night the first part of the night—and awoke at four—better than the other way of it lying awake till morning

Oh my Dear I think how near my Mother I am!JWC was near to Crawford Churchyard, about 18 mi. (29 km.) NE of Thornhill, where Grace Welsh was buried, and Templand, the house where she d., was within sight of Holmhill; see 38:132JWC to TC, [12 Aug. 1862].—how still I should be laid beside her!“Oh, Heaven!” (TC’s note in Froude, LM 3:205).— But I wish to live—for youFroude commented in his introduction to the extracts from JWC’s letters this summer from Holmhill to TC (Froude, LM 204–10): “A series of short extracts from the letters to her husband will convey a sufficient picture of her condition in body and mind. The most touching feature in them is the affection with which she now clung to him. Carlyle’s anxiety, at last awake, had convinced her that his strange humours had not risen from real indifference” (Froude, LM 3:204).—if only—I could live out of torment—

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 25 July. Addr: Dr Russell &c &c / Thornhill / Dumfriesshire. PM: London, 25 July 1864. MS: NLS 616.633. Quot: Bliss, TC 369–70.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: This morning I had slept too long; and Oh what relief it was to find, on coming down stairs, yr poor Little Letter on the table; and tear it open for news, as I hurried along! Thank God it is a little better: I have had such a two days since the last sad Note, yr last night but one, at The Gill. “Sleep till four” is a very poor allowance; but it is better, as you always feel, than after four:—and the pain is a little gone. We must hope; we must not complain. Oh that I may hear good news tomorrow; there are now two nights,—surely the very change will have done something!

Don’t be discouraged, Darling; the brae is steep, but you have set a stout little heart to many braes in yr time. Yes, we have had a sore spiel together, many a time; and never did my little woman fail me.— You did evidently well to omit John; unless when absolutely needed, he is not good. It was cruelly absurd of him to say that thing to you; cruel and absurd both:—oh dear! Perhaps if he had stood to his “Work” as well as you have done to yours, he might have been far ahead of where he now is! But never mind him. He really does desire to help, I believe, and tries, and flatters himself with succeeding: but his sympathy is dull and coarse;—and he has great vanity. Poor ill-less even well-meaning soul,—keep not too close to him!—

This is miserable paper; and I am writing after dinner (sleep given up; I had enough of it last night):—let me hasten with the essential. Yesterday I called on Lady Stanley and Lady Wm,Lady William Russell.—feverish and ill, the latter; seems to have intermittent daily fever in the afternoons; is still unable to walk at all, seldom or never gets out; has been “two years in that room.” The Stanley Rosalind Husband Elect,Rosalind Stanley m. George James Howard 4 Oct. all the Stanleys were vivacs, joyous. Great inquiries, in both Houses, made abt you;—to whh I cd not to my own satisfactn be brief enough. Home slowly thro’ the Park, in grey dusk, to tea & a night of such silence as was quite rare; sorrowful, but solemn and good for me. Miss Craik was out for the night at some Friend’s; did not return till afternoon today;—goes tomorrow morning at 8 altogether (some Miss WhinyardNot further identified. with her) direct home. I shall like as well to be solitary;—she is a good soul: I must not forget a travelling £10 to her! The little Edinr French woman (Otthenin “Jane Johnston’s” Daughter)Irma Otthenin. is coming tonight; Geraldine to help withal:—
after whh, silence, work, & no matter how sad. The Girls do well; never mind them.— Lady An’s Letter came this morning; I had heard nothing from Bath. Addiscombe hampers are quite stopped; tant mieux [so much the better]. God keep thee for me, Darling; & send good news tomorrow!— Yours ewig [ever] T.C.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [25 July]. Addr: 5 Cheyne Row / Chelsea / London. PM: Thornhill, 25 July 1864. MS: NLS 608.637. Quot: Froude, LM 3:205.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p: Oh my Dear! writing letters to you is now disheartening work. I have so little to tell that will do anything but make you sorrowful. But if I dont write at all, you would be thinking me even worse than I am. Know this at least for your comfort, that nowhere on Earth would I be better off externally than I am here. Mrs Russell is a nurse like my own mother— I have had no such nursing— Mary Austin is kind kind but knows not what to do and has not means. Then the DrDr. James Russell, Mary’s husband. seems to me to have more sense, if not more skill, than any of these fine Drs— He says, like you, that my illness is only to be acted on thro’ the stomach but does not make light of my nervousness—does not say slightingly that “nervous pain does not kill.” that people can live without sleep

My first night here was passed wide awake—not one wink of sleep again—and of course a day of pain—last night he made me bathe my feet in hot water, and I slept—very brokenly but still I slept—oh thank god! I go on with the warm milk in the morning, which I think has a good effect on my bowels— I have taken physic only once since I left St Leonards but tobacco after breakfast is indispensable—

Mary Craik will go today and you will be alone—with these maids! And if I were there I could but add to your troubles—we are sorely tried— And god alone knows what the end will be— It is no wonder if my stock of hope and courage is quite worn out—
I cannot write more— I must send a line to the Gill and my pulses throb like mad when I take a pen in my hand.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MCA, [25 July]. MS: NLS Acc. 7864. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO MARY CARLYLE AUSTIN

docBody.p: When I said I would send you word “next day,” we both forgot that “next day” was sunday, when no post leaves Thornhill— All the better—for again I never closed my eyes all night—and got up most miserable— Last night I had sleep, thank God—restless and broken—but oh so much better than none!—
Thank you and Jamie for all your kindness— I was very sensible of it though I had to fly away from it so soon—and could look nothing but what I was—utterly wretched with constant suffering
God help me—

p.name: Jane W Carlyle
p.note: TC wrote later on MS: “(july 1864) sad, sad!”

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 27 [26] July. Addr: Dr Russell &c &c / Thornhill / Dumfriesshire. PM: London, 26 July 1864. Copy: Mrs. J. Thomson, Thornhill. Pbd: Glasgow Herald, 30 June 1890 (when owned by Mr. R. Thomson); Ireland, JWC 320–21. Quot: Wilson, Carlyle 5:547–58.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Dearest, It was well they kept their Pharisaic Sabbath, and prevented yr telling me, what wd not have lightened the gloom of mind. Oh dear, oh dear;—and but little sleep yet, in spite of all the chances, and all the kindnesses! Nevertheless hold on to yr milk, to yr dietings, to yr bathings,—under Dr Rs.’s directn, and the kind lady’s nursing. What strange old days (sunk like old ages) you look out upon from yr windows there, my poor little heavy-laden Woman! Yes: but it is for ever true, “The Eternal rules above us,”Cf.
