Goethe, “Novelle” (1832); see Carlyle, Works 27:495. and in us and round us; and this is not Hell or Hades, but the “Place of Hope,“—the Place when what is right will be fulfilled! And you know that too, in yr way, my own little Jeannie;—and you will not, and must not forget it: forgetting it, one might grow mad.

I think with you of Dr Russell, that his advice is probably worth more than that of all the Doctors you have yet had. A sound-headed honest-hearted man passing his life in silent company with facts; earnestly studying Disease at a thousand bedsides, with an eye only to knowing it and helping it,—what a difft man from one, or from a thousand ones, who are always “on the stage,”
and have no time to think of anything, except of claptrap & how they shall get a reputatn in a totally stupid world! I beg him very much to survey and investigate your case; and throw what light on it for us he can. Darkness he will not throw on it;—I suppose there is but little “light,”Cf. Gen. 1:3. except what our own common-sense might bid us to? “Time and the hours,” whh wear out the roughest day,Cf. Macbeth 1.3. are what I have looked to mainly, from the first.

This morng at 8 Miss Craik stole out, softly as a dream,—I heard her, having been awake and smoking, but said nothing. She has been perfect, poor little soul; nevertheless I am glad to be in perfect solitude rather. I intend to work with double energy; no other resource for me, to keep the demons chained in their caves. I have this Note from CraikMary’s father, George Lillie Craik; see TC to GLC, 1 Aug. since she went,—can hardly read it. I had given her the Bank viaticum [travel expenses] last night; whh she protested was too &c &c: but all in a modest natural way. The Poulterer &c we discover to be right;See JWC to MC, [22 July]. & today I have paid accordly. Every monday I am to count & reckon; and will. The Girls look fairly promising; and I do not fear mischance on that side. My floor (bedroom) is stript bare, bed-top off; extremely cool & clean; Larkin’s tenantLarkin sublet his own house and moved into 5 Cheyne Row while the Carlyles were at St. Leonards; see TC to GJ, 8 May. The tenant is unidentified further; see also TC to JWC, 1 Aug. does me no damage: where cd I be better,—were my poor sick Dear but back to me, as by God’s blessing she will be, perhaps a little better, were the heat gone somewhat!— Don’t mind writing me above a word, when you feel weary; one word (as you say) to keep away worse. Heaven grant it be a good one tomorrow. Adieu, my own poor Jeannie. T.C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 27 July. MS: NLS 526.16. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: My dear Brother,—Today I have no news at all; whh obviously cannot mean good news: alas, no! And yesterday the news was none of the best by any means. I must do my best agt these demons of Uncertainty; and say to them, “I will not believe you!”—

Miss Craik went away yesterday morng: since whh there is silence, is solitude, like the grave. I like it better so; than with people jostling me abt: I must, as the one resource, grapple, beak & claws, to my Work; and push it on,
on: that I have found to be curative agn and agn.— The little Irma,Irma Otthenin. running abt the world is one small item of my interruptions (whh, as you know, are manifold): Monday Evg I had asked Miss Jewsby; and Miss Craik had set the House in order;—but it wd not do you see (by the Inclosed). I restrict myself now to the Passive, however.

Pray send me yr acct of Monies due. Twenty-pounds of cash I found in my Writing (£25 was what you gave, was it not?):—put in whatever the Carriageings at St Lds cost you, the bath; everything, then & since;—and I pray you oblige me by forgetting nothing.TC noted: “27 june 1864 to Dr Carlyle (for myself) 25 .. 0 .. 0” (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753). For John A. Carlyle’s account, see TC to JAC, 1 Aug. It will [be]Word omitted. one piece of busss off my hand.

This is the hottest day we have had;—a yellow demon grindsOrgan-grinder; see 37:203TC to JWC, 7 Aug. 1861. at my left, while I write in the back area here; awning up &c &c: I have not yet made very brillt progress, but find I do get on. Page 175 is now gone & out. It will not be long till I do end the whole 7-yrs misery. I am recovering my sleep: I am wonderfully quiet by night; quiet & airy both.

I suppose you have not yet been up to Thornhill; and know not that you can do much good by going. Consider for yrself; do what you find will be serviceablest. Help to me is very desirable at present; on that hand first, and indeed on many hands: but it is not possible to help me much.
My kind regards to all The Hill.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 29 [27] July. Dr Russell &c &c / Thornhill / Dumfriesshire. PM: London, 27 July 1864. MS: NLS 616.634. Quot: Froude, Carlyle 4:277. TC misdated.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Alas, there is no news at all today; whh, as I say to myself, cannot mean “good news.” No; and how bad, I struggle not to guess.— Today I slept too long (still swinging abt, uncertain in that respect, but clearly coming to); I have tried hard to make some kind of days work, but cd hardly: and there is to be no nap (dinner done, some time ago, and only room for this poor word: oh dear, oh dear!)— I said yesterday you were not to write, when it did you ill. One small word perhaps:—but I must be subject to yr discretion.

This is the hottest day we have had; hot here under the awning & the shadow tho’ there is a kind of wind. Solitude complete, silence do since Mary Crk went away. This night, a little wandering Otthenin has “tea & two hours,“—cd not be put off (missed on Monday night, even, the little wretch);—Archy
Glen,Archibald Glen (ca. 1800–1870), Glasgow businessman; see 11:122–23TC to AG, 7 June 1839. TC and John A. Carlyle previously asked him for help in finding work for their nephews James Carlyle and James Aitken; see 28:1TC to AG, 3 Jan. 1853, and 29:186TC to JAC, 4 Nov. 1854. “a gentn Sir!” I fairly refused to see, & be bored with so soon agn.— People do not help me much. Oh Darling when will you come back & protect me? God above will have arranged that for both of us;—and it will be His will, not ours, that can rule it. My thots are all a prayer for my poor little Life-partner, who has fallen lame beside me, after travelling so many steep & thorny ways. Upon the whole I will stop this; lest I fall to crying altogether.

closer.salute: Adieu; God bless my little Jeannie.

docBody.name: T.C.

ps.p: Chelsea, 29 [27] july 1864

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [27 July]. Addr: 5 Cheyne Row / London. PM: Thornhill, 27 July 1864. MS: letter NLS 608.639; envelope NLS 608.641. Pbd: Bliss, JWC 314. Quot: Froude, LM 3:205.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p: Dearest—I could not write yesterday— I was too ill and desperate— Again without assignable cause I had got no wink of sleep— It is become a regular thing that I should pass alternate nights entirely and absolutely awake—sleeping the intermediate nights only from exhaustion—little and brokenly—last night—my sleeping night—I was saved from waking for good at four, by taking as Dr Russell had advised me a glass of my own wine—“if I was not feverish“— But I am still terribly weak—yesterday was so wearing out.

If I had not such kind people beside me I should be wretched indeed I am trying quinine again—in no newfangled combination—but simple, and in solution—“to guard against accidents of the stomach in dissolving a pill.“— In a day or two we shall see if it is to be continued—
It is not hot at all here—today is in fact cold and misty.
You have been very good to Mary Craik, and she may well remember it all her life

—I do not feel so agitated by the Sights about me here as I used to do— I seem already to belong to the passed away as much as to the present—nay more— I will not write any more— I can say no hopeful comforting word.

closer.salute: God bless you on your solitary way

docBody.name: Jane W Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [28 July]. 5 Cheyne Row / Chelsea / London. PM: Thornhill, 28 July 1864. MS: letter NLS 608.641; envelope NLS 608.639. Quot: Froude, LM 3:205.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p: I will write two lines Dearest. that you may not be frightened—and I write the more willingly, that I can tell you I got some snatches of sleep last night altho’ it was my night for lying awake

There had been some deliberation about giving me tincture of HopsHops were often used in the treatment of sleeplessness; see 37:96TC to JAC, 16 Jan. 1861.—“hardly to be called a narcotic” Dr R says— But I decided to try again—with only bathing my feet—and taking a glass of wine during the night—or two glasses he said would be no hurt to me I “needed it so much“— So I took the wine at 3 o’clock—and had bits of sleep both before and after that— By the by—or by the direct—will you make them send me a dozen or two of that sherry from LeithFrom Hutchison & Co.— I am in the fourth bottle of what I brought from St Leonards!! The wine, like every thing else, is good here—but I should be ashamed to take so much of other peoples wine—besides Dr says ours is “uncommonly pure—no sediment in it whatever.” I go on with the quinine having found no bad effects from it yet—and it is certainly good for the fluttering at my heart. When will I be back? Ah my God! when?—for it is no good going back to be a trouble to you, and a torment to myself— I must not look forward—but try to bear my life from day to day—thankful that for the present I am so well cared for—
Instead of writing to me next time write just a few lines to Mrs Russell to say you are thankful to them
It will take up the same time and no more—
It is a regular wet day here but I am to have a drive all the same—

The place is very quiet—all cocks and noisy animals shut up till I have risen—and there is the same kind thoughtful little HousemaidPresumably Mary; see 39:80JWC to MR, 2 March 1863. that was here formerly, and who waits on me very differently from my own maids God forgive them!
docBody.name: Jane W Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MCA, [28 July]. Copy: NLS Acc. 7864. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO MARY CARLYLE AUSTIN

docBody.dateline: Holm Hill, Thursday ([28] July 1864 (2)Possibly a reference by JWC (or inserted by the copyist) to this being the second letter from JWC to Mary Austin, the first being JWC to MCA, [25 July]. ah dear!)
docBody.p: Thanks for your letter dear kind Mary—“offensive to me!!” Oh no what you say is true, and the best that could be said to me!Mary Austin wrote, [26 July]: “Oh my dear let none of us say we are utterly wretched so long as we are on this side hell and the grave I verily believe it is not in vain to call on God’s help try my dear to lean on the arm that is omnipotent I believe that nothing happens to any of us without his permission God does not afflict you willingly I hope it will be all for your good He is able to support and has never said to any seek ye my face in vain try to cast your cares on him he will never leave you nor forsake you My dear forgive me if I have said anything offencive to you I trust I am speaking from experience what a blessing to have an anchor whereupon to rest in this weary world you will mabie come back and stay a few days with us here We would be so glad to meet you anywhere.” If I could but take it rightly to heart!

I have not got into sleeping yet—am much as I was at the Gill—. Every thing is done for me that human kindness, backed by plenty of means, can suggest; but the power of curing me is not in human hands.
I cannot write much; and have already written a note to my husband. Love to you all.
docBody.name: Jane W. Carlyle.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 29 [28] July. Addr: Dr Russell &c &c / Thornhill / Dumfriesshire. PM: London, 28 July 1864. MS: NLS 616.635. Hitherto unpbd. TC misdated.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Alas my poor little Jeannie, what a melancholy Letter this morng;—and yet so much better than none! It is all I have got to live upon thro’ the day. Oh that the quinine liquid, and Dr Russell’s skill cd abate that horrid dualism, “one night bad, & the other none”; and restore my poor little Soul to the common conditn of human life!—

No wonder, you have got almost desperate, and lost patience! Human nature (I know as well as another) is weak and fretful; yes, truly. But yet, Dearest,—did not that poor Letter of Mary’sJWC presumably forwarded to TC Mary Austin’s note of 26 July (see JWC to MCA, [28 July]). strike you as truer, and in essence
right! That is really so as the poor Sister says;—and, in your good moments, you too strive that way, don’t you? We shd both of us, you and I, to whom it is the easier of the two. God help us, Darling!

I have not a word to say; and had better go up stairs. I am solitary as sparrow of house-top:Cf. Ps. 102:7. but better so than otherwise at prest. The girls do really well. My little horse goes visibly better, under Silvr & his old diet. Last night the Otthenin did very well,—cleverish, prettyish (tho’ with hard eyes & too much of nose); easy to talk with— WoolnerJean Otthenin, Irma’s mother, wrote, 25 Aug.: “I had a letter from Irma to day. … She is at the zenith of her glory, she has seen you dear Sir, and she has got acquainted, with if not the first, some of the first painters of the Age.” came in by accidt abt 9½ & helped me out with the last hour. Adieu, Dearest. Be of hope, I bid thee always!— T.C.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [29 July]. Addr: 5 Cheyne Row / Chelsea / London. PM: Thornhill, 29 July 1864. MS: NLS 608.642. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p: My sleep has taken, or is taking a new turn—the two last nights I have been, all thro’, quite conscious that I was in bed at Holme Hill, trying to sleep—have heard the large clock strike—have got up and taken a glass of wine, to all appearance have been wide awake—and yet I know that I have had a good deal of sleep, by the hours passing much faster than in the course of nature, and by not feeling feverish and desperate in the morning— Dr Russell says this is not an uncommon form of sleep with invalids— I like it better than being all night really awake and that is just all!— For the rest I take porridge again—in less quantity than at the Gill when it hurt me— I take warm milk—take all sorts of nourishing things—and wonder they make no more perceptible difference in my strength—“there has not been time yet“—Dr Russell says— The excitement of the journey making me unnaturally incapable of fatigue—and of that absurd carriage disasterSee JWC to TC, [19 July].—did me much mischief I think— Tho at the time John called it “wonderful improvement in so short a time”
He, John, was here yesterday—dined—and superadded more strawberries and cream than was good for him, I should say.

Miss Bromley writes to day about the paper—is going away next Thursday—therefore no time evidently to fulfill her voluntary engagement—tho she asks shall she send patterns Never mind about the papering—till it is seen
what becomes of me here— I think often enough that I shall never see that house again—
If you see Miss Bromley tell her I am able to write to nobody but yourself

ps.p: Make the sofa be taken out of my bedroom—back to the diningroom—if they have not had the sense to do it already!—
I abhor the imagination of the room with that sofa in it.
Dont show the letters I write you to anyone—

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 29 July. Addr: Dr Russell &c &c / Thornhill / Dumfriesshire. PM: London, 29 July 1864. MS: NLS 616.636. Hitherto unpbd. Friday was 29 July.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Dearest,—Tomorrow I will write to Mrs Russell (for certn, if I be on foot at all,—and you may send to the Post Office if you like);—today I am up to the chin in welters of imbroglio; ill off for Sleep too, and dinner just due. The wine too, two dozn of itWine ordered from Hutchison & Co., Leith, to be sent to JWC. (“Dinners on the table, Sir,“—& an accursed yellow Scoundrel just begun to grind agn)—

Today the news are a little better; oh what a relief to me;—John writes too (really rationally) to the same effect.Mary Russell wrote to Jean Aitken, 27 July: “She has had but little sleep and has suffered much pain, often very distressing. Yet she has had a drive each day about two hours, and seems most comfortable when in the Carriage. She looks certainly very ill and these sleepless nights must be terribly wearing out for her in the weak state she is in. … Perhaps Dr Carlyle (who I suppose is still with you) would come up some day and see how she is getting on. We would be very happy to see him” (MS: NLS 1775B.291A). John A. Carlyle wrote to TC, 28 July: “Jean had the enclosed note from Mrs Russell today at the time I received yours … & the two made me start by the first train to Thornhill. … [Dr. Russell] told me that Jane had slept moderately well the last two nights, & had just gone out for a long drive with Mrs Russell. We had abundant time for talking over the case in all its details. He has the same general idea of it as the other physicians—thinks there will be most room for hope of amelioration from patient & steady regulation of diet, using simple medicines only when absolutely required—not including any forms of opium.” May it only continue, continue!—

Mrs Welsh’sMargaret Welsh, widow of JWC’s paternal Uncle George. Letter came yesterday (partly addressed in Geraldine’s hand).Geraldine Jewsbury visited TC, 29 July, and presumably readdressed Margaret Welsh’s letter. No ansr needed;—nor perhaps will Mrs W. be at any time much yr choice: “Too much of hovering and of whinnering!” But she is still in reserve.
Time & the yellow ScoundrelOrgan-grinder. loudly admonish me to go in. God keep my own Dearest for me; and send me good news tomorrow!

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 1 Aug. MS: NLS 526.17. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: Not to be agn disappointed, as I have already twice been, I take you the first thing, and will write to you the necessary word before going farther.

I am very much obliged by your punctuality in writing, in doing whatever is helpful to me in this time of extremity. I consider yr consultations and Dr Russell’s to be based on sound insight into the facts of the Case; and do generally hope (tho’ at times there are the gloomiest misgivings) that my poor little much-afflicted Partner may be restored to me before very long,—able to help, as heretofore continually, in this final part of the rather thorny pilgrimage I have thro’ Existence. Her last accts were of sleeping half-and-half; that is, of fancying herself awake all the night, but feeling that she really had slept;—whh the Dr tells her is a common form of invalid Sleep. On the whole there does seem to be an improvet, since those horrible St Lds times.

I enclose yr Cheque (£34 .. 14 .. 0), & am greatly obliged for yr succinct, clear & complete performance in regard to that of sorting up the matter into indisputable arithmetic,—I never saw a shorter acct nor one more lucid in every point.TC noted: “1 Augt 1864 / To Dr Carlyle / (St Leonards things) £34 .. 14 .. 0” (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753). John A. Carlyle wrote, 28 July: “I enclose the Accts you ask for. £34 .. 14 .. 0 is the sum, & Jane has had ten pounds of it & yourself twenty in cash”; he enclosed two itemized lists of the various costs (some repeated) of helping JWC and TC: “Tuesday 28th June Bexhill &c 6 .. 0 / 29th—Crowhurst &c—8 .. 0 / 30th—Battle 9 .. 0 / 1st July Fairlight 6 .. 0 / 2nd—Catsfield 9 .. 0 / 4th Mill Hill &c 6 .. 0 / 5th Cemetery 5 .. 0 / 6th Beyond Bexhill towds Hove 5 .. 0 / £2 .. 14 .. 0 / 11th Hip Bath from 7th May to 18th July 10 .. 0 / £3 .. 4 .. 0” (MS: NLS 1775B.277); “From 28th June to 6th July, for Cabs £2 .. 14 .. 0 / 11th July. Paid for hip-bath (7th May-18th July 10 .. 0 / 12th July. In cash to yourself— —£20 .. 0 .. 0 / [total] £23 .. 4 .. 0 / 15th July settled with Jane at Carlisle, & gave her £4 .. 14 .. 6 to make the whole sum received from me £10–£10 .. 0 .. 0 / cost of the two carriages 10/ & 20/ for ten days 1 .. 10 .. 0 / Brought over £23 .. 4 .. 0 / In all paid £34 .. 14 .. 0” (MS: NLS 1775B.276). Thank you very much, too, for writing to Mr Butler:Charles Butler, TC’s U.S. broker. John A. Carlyle wrote, 1 Aug.: “I did send off a letter to Mr Butler of New York on Saturday, asking him to report what investments have been made for you up to the date, & telling him that you hold only one certificate for 7000 Dolls of Chicago Railway Stock. Adamson’s letter of last year on the subject was too stiff & technical, with Scotch law terms &c. as I saw by the copy of it.” Samuel Adamson (1831–80), writer (i.e., solicitor), agent for British Linen Co., Dumfries; son (not nephew as previously noted at CL 35:84 and 38:273; see TC to JAC, 4 May 1859, and 38:biographical notes) of Robert Adamson (1787–1861; see 10:23TC to JA, 14 Feb. 1838, and 37:26137:biographical notes). I hope you
said nothing the least impatt to him; he is an honest, beneficent and obliging man (I do firmly believe);—and he works gratis for me; whh is a clause I do not like, tho’ in my prest embroilments I cannot yet get it mended. Jean’s Letter came this morning; & told me you had written.

I sit in the Back-Area here; more wholesomely than I did at St Lds: the Town is “empty” (so far as emptiable), the weather hot; the yellow demons sometimes disagreeable: but I have agn a human bedroom (thank Heaven), & genlly get sleep; my Horse too, on his beans, is sensibly brisker:—on the whole I do manage to screw out a little work daily, whh is my one consolatn at present. We are actually at the 200th page; 200 pages done and gone;—before Augt end I shall surely be in Book 21st (last “Book” of all!). It often seems to me I cd be there in two or three good days: but is at every paragraph certn to be some botheratn or other. Never was such a Task invented before! Neubg went yesterday for Langen Schwalbach.Langenschwalbach (now Bad Schwalbach), German spa town about 28 mi. (45 km.) W of Frankfurt; see 37:176TC to JAC, 24 June 1861; Neuberg went each summer to German or Swiss spas in search of better health; see 38:119TC to JN, [10 July 1862]. My solitude ought to be profound (FarieRobert Farie. nevertheless plunged in, the other night, & stole my evg from me;—wd not go, tho’ he saw me up to the chin in Proofs &c: stupid, stupid!)— Thank Jean for her Letter; keep writing with or witht ansr; and let us hope to get out of this bad quagmire. To get gone done with our wretched Book; and then— Sleep! Yr affecte Brr
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-GLC, 1 Aug. Addr: Belfast / Ireland. PM: London, 1 Aug. 1864. MS: Strouse. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO GEORGE LILLIE CRAIK

docBody.p:
Abt 3 hours before your Note was handed in to me, your excellent Mary had glided away,—vanished from me softly as a Dream. You can tell her from me that I hold, and shall hold, the remembrance of her fine quiet ways and her, as of one of the wholesomest phenomena I have seen for long years, in this tumultuary dog-kennel of what they call a world. You may depend on it, her behavr in all points (to my poor Wife first of all) was exemplary; of kindness unsurpassable, modesty, good sense, quiet helpfulness her
characteristics throughout. Make much of the excellt Mary, I advise;—and think yrself rich indeed in having such a Daughter agt yr Old Age.

The news from Scotland are none of the best; but do perhaps seem slowly mending. The address now is, “Dr Russell &c &c, Thornhill Dumfriesshire” (for there is one in Stirlingshire too),—if Mary shd think of writing.

Tell her I sit in the back Area here, under shade & air, with clean cool flags under my feet; and, if it be not the yellow Organ-demons, suffer little interruptn. Better off than perhaps she thinks with my two fools of maids. I employ all moments at my unutterable rubbish-continent of a Task,—really not far from half-thro’ the last volume (7-years War just abt to close to all Eternity); and, I do think, were chance given me, cd finish altogether before Winter quite return. In whh case, we may hope to meet agn!—
Adieu, dear Craik; all good be with you and yours. And we will hope always, in this “Place of Hope”!—

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 1 Aug. Addr: Dr Russell &c &c / Thornhill / Dumfriesshire. PM: London, 1 Aug. 1864. MS: NLS 616.637. Quot: Froude, Carlyle 4:277.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: No news at all today, my poor little Darling;—or have you no post on Sunday night? (what a blessed moral duty that is, the sole one seemingly for poor Scotland, that of stopping Letters on the seventh day of the week: Oh dear, oh dear!)— But perhaps I shall hear something not quite bad,—something more of that Half-sleep at least,—tomorrow morning. Hope, always Hope!

Nothing is gone wrong here; Mary been abed 2 days with some “bowel” affair;Mary, the maid, secretly gave birth, 29 July. is up today, and astir as usual. I have nothing to say agt the two poor sluts (never you bother yr little heart abt them at all). The one thing wrong here is, I can get no work done this day: none, tho’ I have stood, or sat, to it, since an early hour. Yesterday I probably was too obstinate; wd not quit till I had finished,—put off dinner; finished (in a sort); had half-an-hour of sleep before dinner;—and on the whole, walked out, for my exercise, at 7 p.m. Wild windy sky; streets (thank God) nearly empty; rain threatening (none came till after midnight, & then very little): my walk was gloomy, sad as death, but not provoking, not so miserable as many. Gloom, sorrow, as of death; but instead of rage, suppressed-rage (as too often, pious grief, heavy but blessed rather). I read till midnight (not study, merely “Macmillan”),—then out agn, solitary as a ghost; and to bed abt 1. I see nobody, wish to see nobody; have
had four or five paltry little Notes to write this morng (whh too, or mainly, has been the ruin of my work);—& now, dinner waiting, write this one, the only one I had the least wish to write. So it goes on.— — Miss Bromley I shall probably not see; unless you order me before Thursday. Her “choosing of paper” is a thing any of us can do: Geraldine, who was here the other night (but went loyally, when my tea was done), will be too happy. Neuberg is gone (yesterday, I understood) to the German Baths for a month. The Larkins are all away,—as if for good: Larkin with his Sister, or in the country somewhere near; Wife “gone to Northampton“: “uncertn” when we shall be back”;Larkin wrote, 18 July: “My Wife has gone to Northampton for a few weeks, and I have taken my Maps … to my Sister’s at Islington where I shall stay for a short time.”—a gray old hushel of a gentn, very harmless seemingly, with children who do no hurt to me, occupies No 6.— The “Little Darling”JWC’s name for Joseph Edwards, the Carlyles’ gardener; see 36:219JWC to TC, [2 Sept. 1860]. has fallen, trailing a Garden-roller somewhere, & hurt his back (poor body): I had sent for him to mow the grass here; & he came at once, with a famulus [attendant] & scythe; & indeed has clipt “snod” all the Garden agn; and made it ready for—ah for what I must not expect so soon yet! But you will get slowly better, won’t you, for me; and come back to yr poor old House, new-papered to yr will:—I shall have my Book done too; and it will be like a rising into life agn and daylight!— “Dinner ready, sir!” I did write to Mrs Russell. Yr wine, I think, will arrive abt Thursday (2 doz. carriage paid). Adieu, my poor little Treasure!— T.C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 2 Aug. Addr: Dr Russell &c &c / Thornhill / Dumfriesshire. PM: London, 2 Aug. 1864. MS: NLS 616.638. Quot: Froude, Carlyle 4:277–78; Hansons, NE 521.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p:
Alas, poor Darling, what an outlook today. No news from you (too ill to write, I can fancy, after yr no-night),—John seems to intimate afar that you perhaps might have done better, had you taken Dr R.’s prescription:John wrote, 1 Aug.: “Jane it seemed had not slept last night. … I did not find her looking at all worse than on Thursday last. She desired me to say that she did not intend to write to you by this day’s post. / Dr Russell had wished to give her some medicine at bed-time last night, & I spent most of the time I saw her in trying to convince her that her best plan would be to take whatever he ventures to give her, and without asking him about either name or dose. He knows all the particulars of the case now, at least as far as she herself or I can tell him; & he is most cautious & prudent in giving medicines of any decided power. She knows all this herself even better than I do, & I hope she will see her way in the matter more clearly than she seems to have done yesternight.” but of course, what can he know of what he only looks at from the safe distance?
Alas, alas. I myself am out of sorts; pill, noises, no-work hardly, &c &c;—and am abt as miserable as my worst enemy need wish. And my poor little friend of friends,—she has fallen wounded to the ground; and I am alone, alone!—

Plattnauer was here this morning; but I did not let him in; sent him yr Address out, & word that you were very poorly indeed. I have got one nasty bit of bother (in my Book) put by;—but there are so many. My spirits are so sunk, “my hand is quite out.” Never mind, however; that is only temporary; that won’t and shan’t last. Oh if I cd hear something good of you!— I have set Helen to lift the Carpet of my Study, and clean out the two-years dust there. “Knows not whether she can do it.” Better try; I know another thing if you cant! ansd I.— The nights have grown cooler; at least yesternight specially was. Day is still hot; but I never try it till 5½ p.m. Postman Bullock wants me to get his sonJohn Joseph Bullock. promoted: can’t I? Somebody else wants £50 till he prove the Bible out of square: another requests me to induct him into Literature; another to say How he can save mankind, whh is much his wish,All unidentified. &c &c Oh Darling, may God help us,—teach us to help ourselves. My heart is sore for thee; very sick and sore: a sadness beyond tears. God bless thee. T.C.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [2 Aug.]. Addr: 5 Cheyne Row / Chelsea / London. PM: Thornhill, 2 Aug. 1864. MS: NLS 608.643. Quot: Froude, LM 3:205–6; Hansons, NE 521.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p:
Oh yes Dear! Nobody can either receive or send off a letter here on Sunday—and I was glad of it this week— I had nothing good to tell and no strength to tell it. I was glad too that John undertook the writing yesterday. He would give not only a more sententious, but a more pleasing account of me than I myself could have given. The waking sleep had been succeeded by absolute wakefulness— I feared going out of my senses— The Hops was tried—no use—the next night a small doze of HenbaneUsed as a sedative; see 35:216JWC to TC, [24 Sept. 1859]. —still worse— The quinine did much good in some respects but I had an idea it helped the excitation.—that prevented me going to sleep—and much to John’s disgust, who said that “I, being in the thing, could not see my way—whereas Dr R was a man of great candour &c &c“— Dr Russell himself thought it best to discontinue the
quinine—that being my idea—and last night I had what, for me, may be called a good night with no aids but utter exhaustion and Gods mercy. I had to take to bed yesterday afternoon, the irritation was so terrible—so it was time to get some sleep!— Today I feel better of course. but the night will come, and experience has taught me to expect sleep only from utter exhaustion— It is well I am out of your way—well for you and myself too.

Mrs Russells letterJWC told TC to write a few lines to Mary Russell; see JWC to TC, [28 July]. came with mine this morning— She is immensely delighted with it, good kind soul! bids me say no end of things for she “durst’nt write to you herself for her very life”!

Miss Bromley wrote to me about the patternsWallpaper patterns. too late— I sent no answer— Do nothing till we see! above all do not let Geraldine interfere in it— She has the least taste of any woman I know—

I am cared for here as I have never been since I lost my mothers nursing—and everything is good for me—the quiet airy bedroom—the new milk—the beautiful drives—and when all this fails to bring human sleep, or endurable nervousness can you wonder that I am in the lowest spirits about myself so long as I had a noisy bedroom or food miscooked—&c &c I had something to attribute my sleeplessness to—now, I can only lay it to my diseased nerves—and to my age such illness does not right itself—

ps.p: I do entreat you to put these miserable letters of mine out of everybodys way

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 3 Aug. Addr: Dr Russell &c &c / Thornhill / Dumfriesshire. PM: London, 3 Aug. 1864; Edinburgh, 4 Aug. 1864; Thornhill, 5 Aug. 1864. MS: NLS 616.639. Pbd: A. Carlyle, NL 221–23 inc. Quot: Froude, Carlyle 4:278; Hansons, NE 522.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p:
Oh my poor little Woman, it is indeed terrible. Night after night, the ‘wakeful sleep’ itself go, nothing but miserable vigilance, and the desperate unrest you have been so long used to! Would I might hope tomorrow for news of a second sleep following: but I dare not hope yet;—tho’ every circumstance as you is in your favr, were it not for yr own poor nervous system ruined (for the prest), not by those late months only, but by long years of more or less the like. Oh, you have had a hard life; I too not a soft one,—but yours, beside me, alas, alas!— Nevertheless I by no means permit you or myself to despair. No; I seem even to discern some rays of fluctuating (real tho’ fitful) even in yr prest
sad state: Hold on, hold on! Try all that you can by diet, by study to yr best of what hurts and what answers;—that clearly is the one strength we have; but that also is a thrice-importt. The centre of all: consider it so. Dr Russell will do and forbear what the kindest & wisest of Doctors attainable on the Earth wd! Quinine (or Jesuits Bark simple)Medicinal bark of the cinchona tree, from which quinine is extracted; called Jesuit bark after the Jesuit missionaries in Peru who introduced it into Europe; see also 39:219JWC to MR, 19 Oct. 1863. is the hopefullest drug I ever heard of to you: so too, I dare say, he thinks; but gives it over too, while you object (whh also I reckon wise altogether). Perhaps you may come back on it again.— Oh what is my poor woman doing at this hour (this warm, still Augt day,—whh here wd be very hot for horses & her at 3 p.m.)? Oh that I might believe you have had some sleep, while driving thro’ those old scenes,—so full of prophetic and supernal thots looking behind and before! I will pray for a Letter. I have not ansd Froude;See TC to JAF, 6 Aug. I shudder to ansr anybody, on a subject so indifft to him in comparison. Indeed I have not spoken a word to anybody these 3 days.

Geraldine has & shall have nothing to do with the “Papering” or any of our affairs.Geraldine Jewsbury wrote to Walter Mantell, 2 Aug.: “The reports of poor Mrs Carlyle are no better—She is in Scotland. Mr Carlyle is very good & shews a tenderness & gentleness one never expected at his hands.— Woolner the sculptor is going to be married almost directly— I dined at the Dilglues [Dilberoglues] last Wednesday” (Mantell). In-[deed]TC omitted “deed” at the turn of the page. she handsomely keeps silent and away.

I am better than yesterday; still not quite up to par. The noises have considerably increased abt me; but I care much less abt them, in genl: Night always brings her coolness, her silence deep as cd be,—whh is an infinite solace to me, body and soul. Nothing of blockhead mankind’s procedure seems madder and more condemnable to me than this of their brutish bedlamish creatn of needless noises. At St. Lds before I got away all was breaking out in pianos,—quite a relief to leave. Maid Hellen has (after two days) got up the Carpet in my “study,“—black dust the thickness of a shilling in some places. She will, and shall, clean it for me; tragic as it seems to her! My work has been intense today; but far from brilltly successful. But I do make progress, nearly daily,—altogether daily, I may say, tho’ not always visible daily. Oh if I but had my Jeannie agn! But Patience, there too, and Hope, hope! At Spes infracta [but Hope is unbroken]. God bless thee Darling. T.C.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [3 Aug.]. Addr: 5 Cheyne Row / Chelsea / London. PM: Thornhill, 3 Aug. 1864. MS: NLS 608.644. Pbd: Fielding and Sorensen 301–2 inc.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p: I write today less unwilling, for, thank God, I can report a second night with some sleep in it. not much; nor sound; but to have slept at all two nights running is a blessed novelty in my life. There had been grave consultation between Dr Russell and me, whether I should try that Indian HempCannabis sativa, used for easing pain and inducing sleep; unlike opium, it does not cause constipation or loss of appetite.— Dr Quain had given it me in the winter without result; but Dr Russell judged from its having been given twice or thrice during the day, that the trial had not been fairly made—it should be taken he says in one dose at bedtime. Still he would not press it on me, tho’ evidently alarmed at this sleeplessness;—because, tho’ he had seen excellent effects from it in several cases, he had not seen and could not positively predict its effects on me. I must decide for myself. and I decided to appeal to Nature once more—the day of comparative ease, which had yesterday followed my night of comparative sleep, having strengthened my mind to make a decision—and I was rewarded by Nature with a not intolerable nightJohn A. Carlyle wrote, 4 Aug., reporting Dr. Russell’s letter of 3 Aug.: “He says of Jane ‘Having slept pretty well she looked much refreshed yesterday morning, & enjoyed her drive very much. Mrs Russell thought yesterday one of her best days, if not the best, since she came to Holmhill. She would have taken the Hemp’ (Indian hemp wh Dr R. & I had recommended) ‘in the evening if I had pressed her, but was very anxious to trust nature for another night.’”— Poor Mrs Russell is in raptures—I “shall soon be all right now“—am “getting like myself again”!— Ah! she has not seen enough of me yet, to know how soon these gleams of wellness fade away, and I am plunged again into torture and despair

These maidsCheyne Row servants Mary and Helen. are perfectly disgusting—when I compare them with the servants here who wear no crinolines, and have heads that they make use of, I am impatient that I have no power to set all that to rights

One night it was windy and the open window of my dressing closet rattled—having no wedges I made it firm with four or five different bundles of paper—next day the papers had been removed, when the window was thrown up—but at night great was my admiration to find my paper-wedges all stuck back exactly as I had put them—and without a word said to, or by, the little
housemaid!Mary at Holmhill. this has been done every night since!—the same attentive thoughtfulness marks her whole service—
I have a long lovely drive every day and when the pain is not too great I enjoy the sight of these old beautiful places—
Now I have written as much as I am up to—resting my hand firmly on the paper to keep it sort of steady—which makes my writing more legible, I flatter myself—. God help you and me

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 4 Aug. Addr: Dr Russell &c &c / Thornhill / Dumfriesshire. PM: London, 4 Aug. 1864. MS: NLS 616.640. Quot: Bliss, TC 370. The MS is torn; missing words and letters are in square brackets.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: You know my joy this morning, witht my needing to write. Oh if I cd get such a Letter every morning:—but I cannot,—and know better than Mrs Russell how fickle you are! Yet surely this is something; courage, courage;—and tell me, Dear, at any rate.

I like you better witht any Hemlock: but Dr Rll is a good judge, too. May you all do your wisest; I can wish no more,—with probability of getting it! Will you or Dr R. have anything to do with the enclosed “Oxygen”? The inclosed is a Letter from Craik (hardly worth much reading), and it enclose[d the] thing abt Oxygen.George Lillie Craik possibly sent a notice of “Barth’s Patent Oxygen Water,” advertised in many newspapers at the time as “strongly charged with the vital element that sustains life and is a highly invigorating beverage, a tonic, restorative, and alternative; it provokes the appetite and promotes digestion. Tendency to constipation and the effects of breathing the impure air of crowded assemblies are quietly removed” (Freeman’s Journal and Daily Commercial Advertiser [Dublin], 1 March).— — [I] am suffering from my [“]slow Printer”;—also really somewhat from the [me]at and its indigestibilities (no potatoes, no &c): my gallop every evg is my one strong point. I called at Miss Bromley’s yester-evg; dismissed the Paper-speculation; she is off to CromerCromer, seaside resort in Norfolk. & the Norfolk BunsensGeorg Friedrich von Bunsen (1824–96), 4th son of TC’s old friend Christian Karl Josias Bunsen (1791–1860; ODNB; see 11:29TC to JCA, 13 Feb. 1839). Georg von Bunsen m., 1854, Emma, b. Birkbeck (1829–99), da. of Henry Birkbeck (1788–1848) and Elizabeth Lucy, b. Barclay (1800–74), of Keswick Old Hall, about 28 mi. (45 km.) S of Cromer. Bunsen lived mainly in Germany, but often visited England; in Aug. 1864 he also visited Lord Houghton at Fryston Hall; see Reid, RMM 2:126–27. thereabts. Lady Ashbn is gone to Melchet, it seems; is gone to,
is going to &c &c but nothing certn in her. Adieu, my own. It is past 4 (Chop keeping hot).

ps.p: Chelsea Augt 4, 1864—

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [4 Aug.]. Addr: 5 Cheyne Row / Chelsea / London. PM: Thornhill, 4 Aug. 1864. MS: NLS 608.645. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p: No line from you today Dear,TC’s letter of 3 Aug. was sent via Edinburgh and took an extra day; see TC to JWC, 3 Aug. and you had had a pill and a bad night— I fear you are not better— The time had been when such a fear would have started me off, right home!— but now! what help or comfort could I bring to any mortal?

Last night was bad—but not the worst sort. I did sleep—a little— Fell asleep about four o’clock, in the midst of rather wild wakefulness, as if stunned by a sudden blow; and slept off and on—from two to three hours, I should think, putting all the bits together— All this while I have refrained from trying that Hemp—considering that an hour of natural sleep is more desirable than a whole night of it by artificial means. Dr Russell seems to be of the same mind. This wakefulness is now my Disease—but for that, I should be getting better— After a tolerable sleep—of which indeed there have been few for the last two months the pain is comparitively slight—and the darkness around me is lightened—but a waking night crushes me down into the depths again—as today.
There is one positive improvement since I came to Holme Hill; I eat about twice as much as I was doing at Marina—where I had to order my own food, and often to order in vain!

Will you tell Mary to be sure and not have Mrs Cook’sThe laundry woman. washing-baskets carried up stairs but to take the clothes out of the basket, below—and before putting them (the clothes) by to examine them carefully—in case of bugs. Mrs Forster told me she would be obliged to give up Mrs Cook because she had sent home as many as four bugs with the clothes at different times It would be, you may tell Mary, a rather disgraceful as well as vexatious result of a Mistress’s illness to let bugs get into the house— In my time I never let the baskets go up

Helen’s quarter wages have been due since the end of June, I think, if not paid since I left—ask her the day— She has higher wages than she works for— I paid Mary’s last quarterFor the servants’ wages, see TC to JWC, [5 April], and TC to JWC, 16 April.— I hope to hear tomorrow that you are better
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MC, [4 Aug.]. Addr: Care of Professor Craik / Belfast / Ireland. PM: Thornhill, 4 Aug. 1864. MS: Strouse. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO MARY CRAIK

docBody.p: I cannot make “a suitable return”Coterie speech; see 19:227JWC to JW, [29 Sept. 1845]. for your nice long letter— I have not recovered my sleep yet—and the daily note to Mr C takes out of me all the work I am up to—just a line then, to say I am no worse—if I could sleep I should be better than when I left Marina—for my appetite is much improved—I eat twice as much—also I have something to eat! But these dreadful nights keep me crushed down in the Depths, and irritate the pain which would otherwise I think, wear off.

You may remember my telling you I had never seen a thing in you to find fault with—well I have seen something now!! How on Earth came a girl of your good sense and kindliness, to picture to me twice over—in two different letters—the advantages of having “a dear daughter” to nurse and care for me! It was like an irony!—the thing being so out of the question—suppose contrary to the laws of Nature I could still get myself “a dear Daughter” she would need sixteen years at the least to grow into use to me! by which time I should do well enough without a “dear Daughter’s” nursing or any one elses

My Dear! as my schoolmistressProbably Mrs. Hemmings, whose school in Haddington JWC attended for several months in 1812, rather than Miss Hall, whose school in Edinburgh she attended 1817–18; see 1:3JBW to MWE, 19 Nov [1812]. used to insist, “always think three times before you speak.”
Love to your Father and Georgina—
If I get any better I shall be so glad to tell you—

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MCA, [4 Aug.]. Copy: NLS Acc. 7864. Hitherto unpbd. Date and comment inserted by copyist (possibly Mary Carlyle, b. Aitken). Dated with reference to JWC’s sleepless nights at Holmhill; cf. JWC to MCA, [4 Aug.].
div3.head: JWC TO MARY CARLYLE AUSTIN

docBody.dateline: Holm Hill, Thursday [4 Aug. 1864] (July? 1864 very sad!)
docBody.p: My Dear, I have had nothing good to tell, or I would have told you. My nights go on very distressed—a trifle improved however latterly—. If I could only sleep, I should be getting well—my appetite is so good—and the life I lead here so well suited to me—but—but!—these terrible waking nights keep me down in the depths.
I will send another line soon. Pray for me.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 6 [5] Aug. Addr: Dr Russell &c &c / Thornhill / Dumfriesshire. PM: London, 5 Aug. 1864. MS: NLS 616.641. Quot: Bliss, TC 370. Fri. was 5 Aug.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: It was that accursed b—, my Darling; I cannot get herHelen, the maid. to take away the letters in time: yesterday, I had to get into a fury (whh cost me my nap of sleep),—today I will take surer methods. Never was I concerned with a creature so incurably careless,—tho’ she has good qualities too. I have paid her no wages (since you last ordered me); some day, it is very possible, I may suddenly pay her; and bid her walk. This of forgetting yr Letter (or neglecting to go till she was decorated to the due pitch) is, considering my posture in writing it and hers in carrying it, the intolerablest thing she has yet done. Never mind the canaille [wretch].

Bullock met me with yr Letter this morning (an hour earlier),—you may judge how welcome! Really, Dearest, things are looking up; all things, if only this thing will continue. John copies me a bit of Dr Russell’s Letter to him; whh is very rational, and quite of favourable tenor. Don’t I hope!— That is an immense point too, that of the better eating. Has yr wine come. I don’t pay till I hear. I think (and privately hope) you & Dr R. will sneer at that “Oxygen” of Craik’s: I confess I have no faith, nor ever had, except in the course you are now following. Oh Heavens, to get on yr feet agn, even in a weak way!—

Last evg, out of virtue, feeling poor & desolate, I went to Ruskin; found him and his old mother,Margaret Ruskin.—had mainly an unpleast evg, bad tea, bad talk,
desultory, insincere;TC lost some of his earlier regard for John Ruskin after the latter took up spiritualism; see TC to JAF, 23 June. came uncomfortably home at a quick pace,—shortly before eleven. Ruskin has no real regard for one. His eye is hard, rayless, in comparisn; his face lean: tho he says he is gathering health. I have sent Larkin to poke up Robson, & indicate that he will have a bad time at this rate of going. Oh send me good news!—

p.name: T. C.
p.note: Despite his expressed misery and bad temper, TC was still capable of kindness; Moncure Conway’s son Emerson (1861–64), ill for several months, d. 4 Aug. Conway wrote later: “when our child died … (we lonely in a foreign land) Carlyle came and sat with us; and his tenderness, his healing words, his inspiration of courage, made the one rainbow on that black cloud. … Ah, when one was in grief and pain, what a providential heart he had!” (Conway, Carlyle 80).

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [5 Aug.]. Addr: 5 Cheyne Row / Chelsea / London. PM: Thornhill, 5 Aug. 1864. MS: NLS 608.646. Quot: Froude, LM 3:206; Hansons, NE 521.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p: Again no word from you! Merciful Heaven what can this mean? Not that you are ill surely! ill there—by yourself, and I here in this state of abject helplessness! What a time I shall have till a letter comes!— Is it only that you are busy?— I did not need this today, to make me horribly nervous. Last night was the worst of the last four nights—no sleep till seven in the morning and then only some half-hour. In all other respects, except for this wakefulness, I am better than when I left Marina—and it is unaccountable that I should be so well, in spite of getting less sleep than I never heard of anyone out of a Medical Book getting, and living with!— I was weighed yesterday and found a gain of five pounds since Dr Blakiston weighed me in April—and much of the poor increase has been gained since I came to Scotland and the new milk, I think; for the bags of skin inside my thighs, which was frightening me when I left Marina, are now filled up again

Oh gracious goodness! here is the PostmanPossibly William Milligan (b. 1835); see 38:147JWC to TC, [18 Aug. 1862].—three quarters of an hour past his time! with not only one but two letters from you— The first has the postmark Edinburgh on itSee TC to JWC, 3 Aug.— What a relief! a fine thing to have tried for sleep with, tonight,—the notion of your being too ill to write!

In case I forget again let me say at once the wine is come—was come when I wrote yesterday—but like a careless creature I forgot to tell you— It was all right—exactly the same, I think, as was sent to Marina— I never took as much wine in my life— Dr Russell makes a point of the four glasses a day and one during the night sometimes two—not for sleeping but for strengthening me to bear the waking— If sleep would come; I think I should recover!—the first time I have had this hope seriously—but—if it wont come—I must break down sooner or later—being no Dutchman nor Jeffrey“In Cabanis, case of a Dutch gentleman who lived twenty years without sleep! which I often remembered for my own sake and hers. Jeffrey is Lord Jeffrey; sad trait of insomnia reported by himself” (TC’s note in Froude, LM 3:206). Georg Wilhelm Heinrich Häring (1798–1871) (under the pseudonym Willibald Alexis), Cabanis (Berlin, 1832), a novel set in the time of Frederick the Great; see 32:82TC to JAC, 25 Jan. 1857. Francis Jeffrey (1773–1850; ODNB), old friend of the Carlyles; for his sleeplessness, see Carlyle, Reminiscences 369.—and I fear horribly for—not my life—but my reason— It is almost sinfully ungrateful, when God has born me thro’ such prolonged agonies, with my senses intact, to have so little confidence in the future—but courage and hope have been ground out of me—submission—acknowledgment that my sufferings have been no greater than I deserve is just the most I am up to.
Make that absurd Helen do whatever there is to be done— She is well paid—and if she gets rebellious I see not what virtue she has left and I could seek a housemaid here— God be with you

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAF, 6 Aug. Pbd: “Carlyle’s Last Letters to Froude,” ed. Waldo H. Dunn, Twentieth Century (Jan. 1956) 159:46–47. Quot: Froude, Carlyle 4:278–79.
div3.head: TC TO J. A. FROUDE

docBody.p:
Your reading of the omen was, alas, far too favourable. It was not continued improvement (of which there has been some), but the reverse that hurried us away from St. Leonards. About the middle of June, want of sleep, which I now discover to be the sole malady (one of long continuance, but brought suddenly to a crisis last year), suddenly returned; would not yield to any treatment, but in a fluctuating way grew always worse,—till in the beginning of July, my poor Patient, desperate by two successive nights, suddenly made off for London (under escort of my Brother, a Doctor of some skill, who never would practice, but who has come to us taliter qualiter [for better or worse]); she went to Mrs. Forster’s; horror-struck at the notion of her own room, and of the miseries suffered there: slept very little, found she would next night
do still worse; and instead of trying,—shot off by express train, travelled all night with her escort above said; and next morning, was 30 miles beyond Carlisle (330 from here), in the cottage of a sister of mine (innocent Farmhouse by the shore of the Solway); slept there two nights in succession: so that my first accounts were triumphant,—had they not so soon altered their tone! For the last two weeks or more, she has been deeper into Dumfriesshire,—in the House of an Ex-Doctor, an honest skilful man, whose wife is a special intimate. The accounts have mostly been bad; but, for two days past, seem (to myself) to indicate something of real improvement. I am always very sanguine, in the matter;—but get the saddest rebukes, as you see. God only knows what is to become of it all. But I keep as busy as the Fates will allow; and in that, find the summary of any consolation there remains to me. My progress, partly owing to the Printer just now, is as it has always been, frightfully slow; but if I live a few months, I always think I shall get the accursed millstone honourably sawed from my neck, and once more revisit the daylight and the dry land; and see better what steps are to be taken. I have no company here but my Horse, indeed I have mainly consorted with my Horse for 8 years back;—and he, the staff of my life otherwise, is better company than any I could get at present in these latitudes; an honest creature that is always candid with me, and actually useful in a small way, which so few are!—

Wish me well;—and return, the sooner the better. How well I remember the last night you and Mrs Froude were here:The Froudes visited the Carlyles 23 Nov. 1863; see 39:254–55TC to JAC, 6 Dec. 1863. it was the last night I had of my poor little Life-Companion still afoot by my side, cheerily footing the rough ways along with me, not overwhelmed in wild deluges of misery as now. At spes infracta [but hope is unbroken]; this is the Place of Hope!

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [8 Aug.]. Addr: 5 Cheyne Row / Chelsea / London. PM: Thornhill, 8 Aug. 1864. MS: NLS 608.647. Quot: Froude, LM 3:206, as part of JWC to TC, [5 Aug.].
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p: Again the enforced silence at the end of the week has been an advantage.

If I had written to you on Saturday what a letter it would have been! For my wakefulness had reached a height! Friday night had been the counterpart of the preceding night:—about half an hour of partial unconsciousness, after seven in the morning.

Still I was not the least tired; only wild, and the irritation dreadful, so I took to bed in the afternoon. Something I said about my bowels, which I had assured Dr R all this time were in a charming state, put him on ascertaining with his own eyes and the result was a discovery that I was excessively bilious, and needed four grains of blue pill!! (He wouldnt have me take one of Dr Balkiston’s mild compound articles)—and he was justified by my falling asleep soon after, and sleeping thro’ the whole night!! I woke some twenty or thirty times—but just to think; “Oh God! what a mercy this is!” and go to sleep again. Much bile was got rid of yesterday, and I was sanguine enough to expect another such night— But not so—last night I lay awake, very restless till half after two—then I took a glass of wine, and calmed down into what I call waking sleep, which continued till seven. How it will go on I cannot predict I only feel sure if I had tried narcotics on the top of all that bile, it must have produced a brain fever—and also; that until this terrible wakefulness of the last two months is quenched, there can be no real basis for hopes of recovery— Oh my Dear! I am very weary! My agony has lasted long!

—I am tempted to take a “long cry over myself“—and no good will come of that! I will go and get ready for my drive.Dr. Russell reported to John A. Carlyle, [8 Aug.]: “Mrs. Carlyle had one of her bad days on Saturday. She did not suffer positive pain, but great uneasiness & unhappiness, having slept but little the preceding night. Towards evening she complained of Acidity in the stomach, and had no appetite for her supper. I persuaded her to take a Blue Pill (5 grains). After that she slept, I think well. Indeed she said it was the only night she had slept soundly since she came here. Last night she had a little Rhubarb and Magnesia and slept tolerably. To day she has had a long drive which she speaks of as having enjoyed it much. On the whole I am inclined to think her some better. / I will be glad to see you up any of these days that you have an opportunity of comparing her present with her previous state” (MS: NLS 1775B.292).

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 8 Aug. Addr: Dr Russell &c &c / Thornhill / Dumfriesshire. PM: London, 8 Aug. 1864. MS: NLS 616.642. Quot: Froude, Carlyle 4:278, dated 4 Aug.; Wilson, Carlyle 5:549.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p:
No news since Friday morng, and then none of the best. What a blessed course of religious industry is that of Scotland; to guard agt Letters coming or going, during 12 days every month! The Seventh Day, Fourth-part of a Lunation (that is the real fact it all rests on); and such a hubbub made of it, by the vile flunkey souls, who call themselves special worshippers of the Most
High.— Mumbo-Jumbo, on the Coast of Guinea,Cf. The French Revolution, Carlyle, Works 4:267. almost seems a shade more respectable.

From John, on Saturday, I got a Note to him from Dr Russell: Dr R. seems quite in good spirits abt you; does not understand how you are still so weak on yr feet; sees evidt improvet otherwise; and hopes as we all do. Indeed, Dearest, you look to me as if actually now, slowly and with fluctatn,Thus in MS, for “fluctuation.” but surely, coming round. In spite of Thursdays bad night too (or alas, it wd be Wedny’s; how far am I behind!) you are visibly plucking up heart agn. Oh that you cd, Oh that you cd! This is the best sign of all:—but I must not be too confidt abt it till Tomorrow’s Post come!—

Yesterday I sat all day, in the shade here; up to the neck in horrible Proofs (and even my very pencils had all struck work, and fallen to ruin,—Larkin has them all off today to the Doctors!)—but by obstinacy I got thro’; had done abt 5½ p.m.,—and then (almost gnashing my teeth, with anger at the engaget) I had to rush off to Fuz’sJohn Forster’s. (see his Note). Poor Fuz did me nothing but good howr; I came home better, and am getting on still today. Adieu, Darling; the time is out. Oh for Tomorrow, if it be good! T.C.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-CS [CSO], 8 Aug. PM: Thornhill, 8 Aug. 1864. MS: Chelsea Public Lib. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO CHARLOTTE SOUTHAM

docBody.p: I want to know where you are, and how you are? Are you still at Lord CambdensCharlotte Southam, the Carlyles’ maid until 1861, was now housemaid at Wilderness Park, the Kent home of George Charles Pratt (1799–1866), 2d marquis of Camden; see 39:103JWC to CSO, 29 March 1863. and remaining there yet a while? Answer me at your earliest convenience and I will write further— But I have no strength to throw away. I have had a terrible time ever since you saw me in my bed.JWC wrote to Charlotte in Oct. 1863, telling her of her accident and illness (see 39:215–16JWC to CSO, [15 Oct. 1863]); it is likely that Charlotte visited her around that time; her last recorded visit was 21 May 1863; see 39:136JWC to BB, [22 May 1863]. That I am still living and in my senses is a wonder! I suffer less now but still about as much as I can bear.
Address to

Mrs Carlyle
Dr Russell’s
Holm Hill
Thornhill
Dumfrieshire
N. B.
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-H & Co. [HAC], 8 Aug. MS: NLS 8992.137. Hitherto unpbd. See the frontispiece for volume 40, available in the CLO on the table of contents page.
div3.head: TC TO HUTCHISON & CO.

docBody.p: The Wine has got to Thornhill, all right;For the order, see JWC to TC, [28 July]; it arrived 4 Aug.; see JWC to TC, [5 Aug.]. TC recorded: “8 augt 1864 / (Hutchn & Co / wine for Thornhill) / £5 .. 7 .. 0 (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753). I now enclose Cheque for the amount (£5. .7. .0): please send me a receipt, and all will be well finished

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 8 [9] Aug. Addr: Dr Russell &c &c / Thornhill / Dumfriesshire. PM: London, 10 Aug. 1864. MS: NLS 616.643. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Oh my poor Darling—But it is not so bad as I might have feared! That discovery of Dr Russell’s is perhaps worth all the others together;—it is deeply my own experience that whh you now;Thus in MS. calm sleep when nothing else will in the least try to give it. In fact I find liver and bowels simply to be the parent or else the murderer of sleep. And have told you so, many times,—have not I, tho’ you wd not believe me! Believe it now better; Oh believe it, and apply it, it is of the highest importance. You have really no disease but want of sleep; and the road to sleep is that way (regimen, regimen, carefully considered and adopted, blue pill or so in minimum;No closing parenthesis. —you have no idea of all that can be done that way. I assure you!—

We have got rain this morning; plunging rain,—thank Heaven! The ground is brown utterly for weeks back,The Times reported in “Weather for August,” 2 Sept.: “From the 1st to the 8th the weather was hot and seasonable, and the ground bronzed and fissured by the long-continued drought.” not a green patch (except some damp spots
of the Regent’s Park) to be seen in all Nature:—weather not to my liking at all!— In fact, I am myself for blue pill; must,—but have postponed it for two days such my hurry and hurly burly at prest. I am in the Drawing-room (does very well, with windows all open);—study is to be “ready tomorrow”; but I fear there will be no need of it.— — Alas, I have two scrubby Notes to write (Lady Ashn one, and worst); och, och! And mad PiperJohn Piper (1817–83?), the Carlyles’ postman until 1857; by 1881 he was in a lunatic asylum; see 35:26235:biographical notes. came to the door, wishing to see me! “Can’t indeed.” — Oh Darling, that I had you back agn; that I had done with this sore Book!— God bless you. T.C.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [9 Aug.]. Addr: 5 Cheyne Row / Chelsea / London. PM: Thornhill, 9 Aug. 1864. MS: NLS 608.648. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p: Dearest—Last night again I never once closed my eyes—and today I can write no letter—none at least that should be written. I am pretty desperate! The only Words that suggest themselves are words of dread and despair, best crushed down in my miserable heart!— They none of them know what I am suffering! what it is to have no more sleep in a fortnight than ordinary mortals get in one night!—you can understand it

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 9 [10] Aug. Addr: Dr Russell &c &c / Thornhill / Dumfriesshire. PM: London, 10 Aug. 1864. MS: NLS 616.644. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p:
My poor Darling, my very heart bleeds for thee! I got no Letter this morning (fault of the Post people), and sank low enough (I was in bad spirits anyway; far too “busy” yesterday, from early morn till late night, but will not agn!)—at 2½ p.m. yr poor Letter did come: Ah me, ah me!— Yes, I have a kind of notion of yr agonies: my poor little woman, chaced like Orestes “by the Furies”; that is often my dismal reading of it: Oh that we knew some “Expiation,” or cd find it out, as Orestes’s Sister did!In Greek mythology Orestes was pursued by the Furies because he killed his mother in revenge for her killing of his father; he was eventually reunited with his sister Iphigenia, putting an end to the cycle of crime and retribution. But we cannot. We know
only that Expiation is;—that these Agonies do withdraw; that the Gates of the Abyss are heard slamming-to upon them in distant thunder;—the Great Maker of us having lifted his hand. Oh don’t despair; I will not, and do not,—but these things are hard to bear.

You may think with what cheer I shall ansr that illegible Note of Milnes’sRichard Monckton Milnes, now Lord Houghton; see TC to Lord HRMM, 11 Aug. (how I like to speak to any third-party abt you);—what a pleasure all these paltrinesses are to me. No more Four is struck. I will agn hope in “tomorrow.” God above keep thee.
docBody.name: T.C.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [10 Aug.]. Addr: 5 Cheyne Row / Chelsea / London. PM: Thornhill, 10 Aug. 1864. MS: NLS 608.649. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p: Nothing for me today. Has the gooseThe maid Helen. been too late for the post?

Any how I am not delirious this morning, as I partly expected last night!— I have had some sleep—Oh God be thanked for it! I fell asleep about twelve, and slept, with interruptions, till about six. Eight times I was awake, and out of bed. Still it was a wonderfully good night compared with my usual nights. To think that there are numbers of people who sleep soundly every night of their lives! And who never think how blessed they are!—

Margaret HiddlestonMargaret Hiddleston, maid to JWC’s mother at Templand. had “something lame with her ancle” about a year ago (rheumatism Dr R thinks) which she leeched; and, “the DukeWalter Francis Montagu-Douglas-Scott, duke of Buccleuch. being expecket, (she washed at “the Castle”) was maybe more impatient than she should hae been.” The result was a terrible gathering at the ancle which has confined her to bed for a year—and lamed her for life.Her death certificate recorded that she d. from “disease of the ankle joints.” That she does not believe—she has less pain now, and can sit up “when the house is cleaned”; and her brisk hopefulness made me ashamed! She lives with her married daughterMargaret McCaig. who nurses her most tenderly. The other DaughterJessie Hiddleston. at service in Edinr
had sent her a nice easy Chair and Leg-rest—of which Margaret was very proud. She is kept as clean as a new pin— How many a rich Lady has no such attention and consolation!

Hunter of Morton MillThomas Hunter (1799–1864), lawyer, of Morton Mill, nr. Thornhill, former agent for the duke of Buccleuch; see 14:58TC to JWC, [5 March 1842]. was buried yesterday— The people here, when I used to live at Templand, are almost entirely swept away. One fancies the place must be quite desolate— But I suppose it is just as gay as ever to a generation one knows nothing about—
docBody.name: Jane W. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 11 Aug. Addr: Dr Russell &c &c / Thornhill / Dumfriesshire. PM: London, 11 Aug. 1864. MS: NLS 616.645. Quot: Froude, Carlyle 4:279. TC wrote an instruction on the envelope for Post Office staff: “n.b. goes by Carlisle & Dumfries;—don’t try ‘Edinburgh’ any more!”
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: I stopped Bullock on the Street, and got yr Letter: Oh what a deliverance to the loaded heart of me! One ought not to be so desperate; but I was too early awake again—and flesh is weak. Oh I am so sad, my Dear; sad, sad, but have often been far more miserable, far. The sorrow has forgiveness in it; reconciliatn to all men and things, especially to all men; not secret rage and vain struggle as too often. Oh do but get better for me, my own Schatz [Darling]; we shall have good days yet, please God.— I am pushing on famously with my Book; really fast in comparison—(for the last few days!)—I shall certainly, unless accidt befal, have done with it in fact, before Winter quite come! Esperons espérons [Let us hope]!——

It was not the GooseHelen the maid. that wronged yr Letter of Tuesday; it is the Post people (and indeed it was they the former time,—shooting round “by Edinburgh,” the fools!)— Goose always goes now, during my dinner, Mary to bring up the “second course” forsooth); so that there is no danger.

Today I have come up to my old garret agn; whh is a gain of abt 15 or 20 per cent in regard to getting work thro’; and a great comfort to me,—if it wd but last, and continue to be cool enough. How I love my old solid Table,—yr Father’s contriving (I often think, with a variety of pious, or not impious feelings, tho’ pride I fear is a part of them): “An honest manful article produced
by her Father (who has given to such, as my own was),—and, by the Eternal, may not one still do some honest work at it, in spite of the Earth! And if it be forgotten, as better has been, let the blockhead world forget it too,—by Allah! And the brave shall be all blessed; are all blessed!”—

I thot there wd be time enough for not you only but for the Line to Milnes, the Line to &c: and already it is past 4, and dinner is waiting, & time not. Adieu Darling; oh send me good news tomorrow!— T.C.

P.S. not to be forgotten. Give Mary Huddlestone a sovn from me. I remember her well poor worthy soul; her and her two bits of orphan children: what a blessing one of them has come up to take care of its mother. I decided on this Sovn as I read yr Letter (from Margaretta to Cook’s GroundMargaretta Ter. was two blocks from Cook’s Grounds, which led into Cheyne Row.). I thot to send you a Draught for Dr Russell’s cashing (and will if you like, but thot there might be objectns): remember, any way, it is to be my Sovn, not yours. God be with us all!— Oh for tomorrow, if it wd be good!—

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lord H [RMM], 11 Aug. MS: Trinity. Pbd: Reid, RMM 2:127–28.
div3.head: TC To LORD HOUGHTON

docBody.p: I fear you overrate any real improvet there is in my poor Wife’s situation: she is still almost continually in very great suffering;—tho’ I think the prospect does now clear up a little to myself (and also to her, whh is still more importt) by the better insight one now has of what the real ailment is. Want of Sleep, want of Sleep,—whh has been going on, gradually on the increase, for long years back; and has now reached some crisis or consummation:—that is the root of all the mischief, the one thing wrong; and for that, it is now evident enough (even to herself that Medicine in any form or degree can do nothing; tho’ carefully studied regimen, with the aid of time and nature perhaps still may. The accounts from Scotland are changeful and fitful, oftenest extremely miserable to me; but they do rather improve than otherwise. God be merciful!—

As to myself, night and day every moment of my time (for her sake as my own) is religiously devoted to getting that frightful millstone of a Book sawed off the neck of me, in some not dishonest way;—and in the Universe there is nothing but working at it that cd be any consolatn to me in prest circs.

May the Waters of VichyVichy, spa town in central France; Lord Houghton wrote to Georg von Bunsen, 13 July: “I shall go to Vichy for three weeks after the 20th of August” (Reid, RMM 2:127). do you good; may you be happy and merry, Dear
old Friend, for many years to come! I still hope to see FrystoneFryston Hall, Lord Houghton’s home in Yorkshire, where he was currently entertaining guests and had presumably invited TC to join them. agn, under good omens, were these black tornadoes done. My kind remembrances to Venables,George Stovin Venables was among Lord Houghton’s guests; see Reid, RMM 2:127.—after (not before) My Lady and the little ones!Lady Houghton and their three children. —

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [11 Aug.]. Addr: 5 Cheyne Row / Chelsea / London. MS: NLS 608.650. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p: Again your two letters are come together, Dearest. Both having the Post-mark London 10—so if the first was posted on the 9th, it must have been too late.— The delay of my letter was caused by Mrs Russells mistake in supposing it all the same whether we put in the letters in Thornhill Postoffice or the one at Closeburn, which we were passing in our drive.

John Carlyle appeared last evening to tea—he plays the part of consulting Physician here which I find a farce— When I needed his help—if he had had any, at the Gill, he only aggravated me with brutal impertinence. As I was more even than usually ill with my pain last evening, he kept assuring me I “looked well—fuller in the face”John A. Carlyle reported, 11 Aug.: “Jane looked better & rather more cheerful. She says that she slept unusually well on the Sunday night after taking a blue [pill] by Dr Russell’s recommendation, then on Monday night hardly at all, & on Tuesday night moderately well. Dr Russell who speaks cautiously says he thinks she is better at least for the time. At Holmhill the quiet continues perfect, & she has long drives daily. … She has gained, I think, nine pounds in weight since she has left Dr Blakiston’s in April. In all respects she has the best possible chance of getting back to her usual health under the judicious management of Dr Russell & his household. … Dr R. told me yesterday that Jane, so far as he could learn, does not seem to have had any positive pain of late.”—

Last night was bad, but not the worst sort— I tossed about—till two—then took my wine and after that, waking sleep till six. It is the strangest thing this sleep in all my sick experience! I believe I sleep it with my eyes open; for when I wake wide up, there is no difference in what I am seeing—the chinks in the shutters &c &c—

We drove to Durisdeer yesterday and I looked at the monumentProbably the marble monument to James Douglas (1672–1711; ODNB), 2d duke of Queensberry, and his wife, Mary, b. Boyle (d. 1709), carved ca. 1711 by John van Nost the elder (d. 1729), Belgian sculptor, in Durisdeer church, 5 mi. (8 km.) N of Thornhill; see Carlyle, Reminiscences 127. The piece consists of life-size figures of the duke and duchess under a great baldachino supported by four Corinthian columns, all in white marble. Or possibly the small monument in the churchyard (erected 1836), marking the spot where Daniel McMichael, Covenanter martyr, was shot 1685; it had the inscription: “Sacred To the Memory of Daniel M’Michael Who Suffered Martyrdom here By Sir John Dalziell. A.D. 1685.” while
poor Mrs Russell cried at he[r] Fathers graveMary Russell’s father, the Rev. Edward Dobbie (1773–1857; see 14:65TC to JWC, 9 March 1842), was buried in the churchyard.— I am never tired with my drives but I cannot walk ten yards without being ready to sink. I walked as well, indeed I think better four months ago—

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [12 Aug.]. Addr: 5 Cheyne Row / Chelsea / London. PM: Thornhill, 12 Aug. 1864. MS: NLS 608.651. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p: Just one line Today Dear. The letter you inclosed was from my Aunt Grace,Grace Welsh, one of JWC’s three paternal aunts, living in Edinburgh. and needs an answer; and being up to little writing, I must take off you what I give to her. last night was much like the two preceding ones. awake and wildish till after two o’clock—then the wine—then a sort of sleep— Last night or rather this morning—for it was after seven—I dreamt about the Blakistons, and—my Mother was in it! All thro’ this weary illness I have hardly dreamt at all and never about my Mother before. I could not help regarding her return to me this morning as a good sign—yet I was doing something to vex her—going away with Dr Blakiston when she expected me home.

I shall be glad to take your sovereign to Margaret Hiddleston. The day I called (my only call for near twelve months) I gave her five shillings. You need not send any check just now— You know I was to get money from John. He paid my travelling expenses—which reckoned up by him at the Gill, to the minutest farthing, amounted to five pounds five shillings. I did think that in his place I would not have charged for “half the breakfast” at Carlisle considering how long he had been breakfasting with us, without paying for it—nor suddenly bethought myself of a “sixpence for peppermint drops got for you at Dumfries“— But that was the sum—he gave me the change of ten
pounds—four pounds fifteen—so it is ten pounds you owe him.For John A. Carlyle’s detailed expenditure accounts for St. Leonards and the trip north, paid by TC, 1 Aug., see TC to JAC, 1 Aug.— Yes and some trifle for the three days of a carriage got from Dumfries— He very much impressed it on me that I was to stand that expense myself— Oh mercy, that man is mean, mean! “I hope you understand that I have only charged you half of all the cabs!”— Ach!—and his voice tremulous with emotion!—
Good by Dear. God grant the Book may be done before winter. for your sake— I have never calculated on seeing the end of that Book.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 12 Aug. Addr: Dr Russell (Holme Hill) / Thornhill / Dumfriesshire. PM: London, 12 Aug. 1864. MS: NLS 616.646. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Thank Heaven and you for yr Letter; bad as it is it is the best that has happened me today: a very poor day with me;—driven from my garret agn by the heat; almost the whole day wasted in sorrowful preliminaries; next to no work got done! Bad enough;—and 4 struck some minutes ago:—but unless by this chance, there will be nothing for you till Tuesday,TC wrote on Friday; post was not delivered on Sundays in Dumfriesshire and not collected on Sundays in London. poor little creature; and God knows what of vigilance & wild thinking in the interim. Tomorrow I can hope to hear agn: after that, nothing till Tuesday morning!—

It really was “the Goose”;The maid Helen.—but also not her blame! Tuesday was our plunge of rain; I did not even dine that day till after 5 (slept after that; rode from 6½ to 8½, such the rain): Goosey went after bringing up the soup; “knew I was too late for the first post, Sir” (imagined another post wd do for Nature genlly as it does for London here; but will not make the mistake agn!) A willing soul really, but a dreadfully foolish.

John as “consulting Physicn,” truly, will not help much; but he never advises anything incautious, almost anything at all; wd willingly enough help if he cd.—writes to me too (inclosing Dr Russell;—be patt with him, Dear. Oh we are not rich in friends as we used to be!— — Yesterday young Highlander-Canadian SchoolmasterWilliam Carlyle, son of TC’s half brother, John Carlyle, and John’s wife, Peggy. got in to me expressly “for 5 minutes”; left me Photograph of my Half-Brother John & his Old Wife (once the briskest pretty Cumberland Lass,—and now!)— I have seldom seen anything so grimly authentic, strange, earnest, tragic in a sense (and not all tragic), as this
Photograph, & a Carte de VisiteThe photographs were apparently not kept for JWC’s photograph albums (now in Rare Book and Manuscript Lib., Columbia Univ.). (bless it) of their Son & his Wife (“Professor” at GaltWilliam and his wife, Emily; William had recently been appointed principal of the Graded School, Galt, Ontario.
