Their eldest da., Florence Emily Carlyle, was b. 24 Sept. in Galt. &c &c). Oh dear!
But the very Post time is done. Adieu my Dearest T.C. (Friday, Augt 12)

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 15 Aug. Addr: at Holme Hill / Thornhill / Dumfriesshire. PM: London, 15 Aug. 1864. MS: NLS 616.647. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: My dear little All,—I got a slight notice of you this morng as far down as Saturday (Dr Russell’s acct to John,—who religiously abstains from adding anything but three loose words or four): Dr R. thinks evidently rather well of you, cautious as he is. His detail of particrs was not so-so, defect of sleep, but not quite none, increase of weight pound by pound he seems to reckon a considerable thing (as do I!)—in short, I was thankful for the Letter tal qual [taliter qualiter: for better or for worse]; a better acct than I often enough get. And so I will wait, in timid hope of what you say to me tomorrow. Oh my poor Darling, what a time of it we now have,—you tenfold tha[n]Letter omitted. me; but I too coming in for my sad share!—

I have blue-pill in me for the second day (Castor cd not be got ready in time this morning, as I had neglected to warn; is positively to be tomorrow): I was obliged to it: nasty continuous headache, my sleep going &c;—it comes partly of the hot weather; still more, I believe, of the want of potatoes; nothing for me but riding, with good supplement of walking, and care every way, and patience till the potatoes ripen. If my Good were here— But alas, she is not; and I cannot pause from the fierce hunt I am running in,—chaced, not chacing; or perhaps both ways!

I have bullied my Printers into the top of their speed. Yesterday I sat till towards 5, getting out of their very claws (for I had come upon a bit of thicket unexpectedly ahead): I am now quite out of arm’s-length; and expect to be across the thicket also tomorrow. I am not a mirthful man, as you may fancy! But in fact I am not so miserable either;—never mind me, Dear: only if you cd get well for me! Be patient, hope; both of us!—— The PollocksWilliam Frederick and Juliet Pollock. Pollock visited TC with J. A. Froude, 9 Jan. 1863; see 39:32TC to JN, [8 Jan. 1863]. with Woolner
came (volunteers the former, Wr by request to quench them); did me no ill: a really innocent good kind of soul, poor Pk. Wollnr. brot brotTC repeats “brot” with a line over it at the turn of the page. “Wollnr“: thus in MS. down, with some solemnity, a “Photograph of his Bride” (to be married in a fortnight, then off for long weeks)Woolner and Alice Waugh married, 6 Sept., in St. James’s Church, Paddington, then went to Guernsey on honeymoon until mid-Oct. (Woolner 253). “for Mrs Carlyle’s amuset“:Woolner wrote “for Mrs Carlyle” underneath the photograph of Alice Waugh; see 187TC to JWC, 16 [17] Aug.—alas, alas! I have it not in this Coat-pocket, & spare it you today. Wind like to blow my awning to stripes, & makes the Papers dance: herald of rain I hope. Oh God keep thee, my Jeannie!— T.C.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, 15 Aug. Addr: 5 Cheyne Row / Chelsea / London. PM: Thornhill, 15 Aug. 1864. MS: NLS 608.652. Pbd: A. Carlyle, NLM 2:294–96 inc.; Bliss, JWC 314–15 inc. Quot: Hansons, NE 521.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p: Oh my Dear! I have great cause for thankfulness! and I am thankful! I have no entire night of wakefulness to report! For five nights now I have gone to sleep about 2 and slept, off and on, till about 6– It is not refreshing sleep—but any sleep is such a mercy—after wakefulness enough to have turned my brain—if it had been in the habit of turning!“A big fellow, in a pugnacious mood, coming up to Carlyle’s Brother Alick, said: ‘Thou canna gar me trimle the day!’ (You can’t make me tremble today!) To whom Alick Carlyle replied: ‘I kenna what’s to hinner thee frae trimling the day mair than ony ither day, if thou’s i’ the habit o’ trimling!’ Big fellow, who hadn’t thought of it in that light, at once departs again trimling.—T. C. loq.” (A. Carlyle’s note in NLM 2:295). I am afraid however, from the aspect of things, that I shall need another blue pill presently; but I shall not have such misgivings about it this time as I had the last time— It certainly brought the first relief to my bad nights.

Another piece of intelligence I have for you, which you will regard as first rate; and so should I too, if, with the gain of weight, there was proportionate gain of strength. when weighed last Friday I was found to have gained a pound and half in ten days!!! I am now seven stones twelve and a half!— Still I cannot walk! but go tottering like a Chinese woman!That is, as though she had bound feet, like a Chinese woman. —and am ready to sink with fatigue if I have gone some twenty yards on the smooth sward! Dr Russell insists on my “exercising my legs,” and I do my best; but no good seems to come of it!

This morning the little housemade, bringing my new milk, having asked in a modest whisper; “Hae ye had ony sleep”? and received an affirmative answer,
looked at me with such a bright smile, and said; “I think ye’r g’n to get bitter noo”!— Ach! if I hadn’t had so many disappointments, i should be thinking so too!— But my Hope is like Humpy DumpyThus in MS; the nursery rhyme “Humpty Dumpty.” that “sat on a wall,” and “had a great fall,” and “all the Kings Horses and all the Kings men couldnt set Humpy Dumpy up again”!
I went with your sovereign to Margaret Hiddleston on Saturday. She looked very glad, and her eyes reddened when she said “I canna show him my gratitude, but I am grateful”!

Then she expatiated on how well you and she got on together at Templand.TC spent several weeks at Templand, March–April 1842, after Grace Welsh’s death, sorting out her affairs, and was much impressed by Margaret Hiddleston; see 14:60TC to JWC, 7 March 1842. “ye see we just suited ane anither”!—“oh yes,”! she concluded, “I thocht a power o’ Mr Carlyle!—thocht far mair o’ him Mem, than I did o’ you when I saw ye”!!
She is impatient to “jist get back into my ain hoos and doe for mysel.“—for all so well cared for as she is!— The Daughter she lives with is married to a cabinet-maker, and they are well to do.
Oh dear I must now go and “exercise my legs“—the most disagreeable thing I do all day

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, 16 Aug. Addr: 5 Cheyne Row / Chelsea / London. PM: Thornhill, 16 Aug. 1864. MS: NLS 608.653. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p: My Dear! we are at “eighty two in the shade.” I have for a long time—eighteen months or so—been insensible to either heat or cold; but I must have returned to a more human state; for this heat makes me ready to drop!— It did not however keep me awake all night, thank god! again I “slept—more or less“— I begin to undress myself at night now, without a feeling of positive terror making my hands shake!—as I never fall asleep till above 2, I was proposing to Dr Russell that I should try sitting up till 2–but he was strong for my going to bed at ten, and “soliciting nature” for more timely sleep.—

Not able to have castor oil in time? and two women to get it—and only you to attend to! Oh if I were well! wouldn’t I make these lazy stupid creatures alter their figure or “sklant the bog”!“Sklant the bog” means literally “across the bog”; JWC’s meaning is “away with them.” For TC’s father’s use, see 3:434TC to JAC, 15 Dec 1825, and Carlyle, Reminiscences 9.

The harvest has begun here this morning—two men mowing and two women gathering!—a very simple matter to what used to be— I was afraid my drives would have to stand by, while the harvest was going on—but no! some arrangement is made with the InkeeperThus in MS. Possibly Mrs. Anne McIntyre (b. ca. 1826), proprietor of the Buccleuch and Queensberry Arms Hotel, Thornhill. to furnish a man and horse. Nothing that human kindness and forethought can do for my recovery is omitted— Don’t say “we are not rich in Friends”! I think myself very rich Good by—

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, [16 Aug.]. Addr: Holm Hill / Thornhill / Dumfriesshire. PM: London, 17 Aug. 1864. MS: NLS 616.648. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Dearest you may judge if I am happy today! Happy in spite of all things:—oh God be thanked for the news you send! I understand the “weakness of walking” too,—yes, very well (on considering it), and will tell you tomorrow. Nor shall “fluctuation,” tempy temporaryRepeated at turn of page. retrogression dismay me!
But it is haste, such haste as was never seen. Up in Study (busy, busy), & knew not the time till 5 minutes ago. Castor doing exquisitely.
docBody.name: T. C. (5½ p.m.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 16 [17] Aug. Addr: Holme Hill / Thornhill / Dumfriesshire. PM: London, 17 Aug. 1864. MS: 616.649. Quot: Froude, Carlyle 4:279–80 (Froude dated the excerpts 11 and 18 Aug.).
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p:
Dearest, it was very mortifying yesterday, when so much else was going well, that yrI.e., TC’s letter for JWC. poor scraping of a Letter cd not even get to you. I hope you are not fretting abt the want of it today! I was up hear,Thus in MS. over the eyes in dirty Neuberg stuff (in the form of Proofs), and had not the least idea of the time when BurdWord for a young woman, often derogatory. Helen stumbled in, “Any Letters, Sir?” By my watch there was still 12
minutes; I gave her, I thot, nearly 4 of them (to run across); but my watch had been wrong,—“5 minutes too late, Sir” (and the Letter put in too, or I cd have saved it by speed to Sloane Square)!Presumably to the nearest post office, from which letters would be collected later. I was much vexed; ordered rectificatn (explaining Sloane Sqre &c) for the future. I am very sorry yet;—tho all else is going well enough. And yr Letter of today too is better than many I have got.

p.hi: Courtesy of Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Columbia University

docBody.p: Yes, my Dearest, you are evidtly mending; & ought to think so, if you cd! That increase of weight is itself an undeniable symptom. And as to the weakness,—is it not even this: that the coming back of sleep, long wanting, makes us feel weaker than ever. How often have we spoken of that bit of experience! On the morrow of yr sleepless night, you are twice as strong & clever as usual; on the morrow of yr successful, only half the comon allowance. That, I believe, is really it. Dr R. does well to make you try (not over-much); but never fear, continue to gather weight & to sleep better, and you are very sure to get back the use of yr feet!— Oh my Darling, and may I really think that the vengeful Furies are abating, going gradually to their home;—or that my poor little EurydiceIn Greek mythology Eurydice was brought back from the dead by Orpheus, then lost forever, as he turned to look at her before they were out of the underworld. will come back agn, and make me rich! God of his mercy grant it to me & to you. Amen.

Yesterday in the Physic way, as I intimated, was quite successful: I had to miss my ride after haggling abt it,—cd not have any sleep either, when I tried. Went sauntering out after sunset; streets were still like the bottom of a baker’s oven more or less (tho’ there had been a send of light rain in the morning,—quite gone ever since); and terrestrial nature (at least Cockney Dm all uninviting to a weak soul under physic. I took a steamboat at the Pier here,Cadogan Pier, just E of Cheyne Row. “Cockney Dm“: cockneydom. sailed to Hungerford market, walked abt by Covent GardenHungerford Market had been a general food market on the Strand, on the N bank of the Thames, since the 1680s, but was demolished to make way for Charing Cross railway stn., opened Jan. 1864. Covent Garden was a fruit and vegetable market, to the N of Charing Cross. &c &c: river and sky had been dirty black, no wind; all things by land and water distressingly opaque (chiefly by dirt), dirty, ugly: however I got home by 8½, and made a good swill of tea;—feeling greatly better than for the last two weeks. Slept agn handsomely well; and have the feeling of notable improvet (if it wd but continue) very clear amid my weakness. Also I am promising to get on (with Work) rather well agn. Fear nothing for me, Dearest; only thou, get well agn, and come back!— God forever bless thee.
docBody.name: T. C.

ps.p: I send Woolner today;The photograph of Alice Waugh; see 187. you can fling it aside anywhere, if it bother you:JWC put it in her second photograph album (vol. 2, Thomas Carlyle Photograph Albums, Rare Book and Manuscript Lib., Columbia Univ.). item, that Greenhow, into the fire with it. Ask her “to write to me”?A letter from Rose Greenhow, who visited and corresponded with TC earlier in the year; see TC to JWC, 2 May. Neva-a!—
Greenow lost? tant mieux [so much the better]

div3.sourceNote: JWC-EF [EFO], [17 Aug.]. Addr: Palace Gate House / Kensington / London. PM: Thornhill, 17 Aug. 1864. MS: NLS 1797.92. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO ELIZA FORSTER

docBody.p: The flourishing accounts of me, circulated by my Brotherinlaw immediately after my arrival in Scotland,JWC spent one night at the Forsters’ home in London before her journey to Scotland; see TC to JN, 14 July, and JWC to TC, 15 July. showed him to be deficient not only in medical skill, but in common sense!— It did not need an M.D to ones name, to have perceived in that extraordinary Wellness, after such fatigues and agitations, neither more nor less than a terrible flare-up of bilious excitement! accordingly, in a day or two, the sleeplessness returned more inveterate than ever, and after one week at the Gill, I rushed from there just as I had rushed from ‘Marina’ with a pack of Furies at my heels. This Place had been all along my destination. The Dearest Friend I have in Scotland lives here— There is quiet, and beauty, and new milk, and kindness— Oh such kindness!— And there is Medical skill too; for the Master is a Doctor greatly esteemed—tho’ retired from practice a few years ago— No where in the wide world could I be so well situated under the present circumstances of my body and mind.

I have gained three pounds in weight, since I have been here—and am for the last week getting a few hours of sleep every night—my Friend says I “dont look nearly so haggard and wild” as I did when I came— Perhaps I shall actually be restored to Life after all! Perhaps my Life will cease to be a burden for me! Oh I am afraid to hope! My Hope and my Courage have been ground down in me by a whole year of suffering! But all the Drs say “there is no reason why I should not get well“—as I have no trace of organic disease— Ach! one may suffer terribly without organic disease it would seem!

My rooms are not papered! I was too ill to answer Miss Davenport
Bromley’s letter about patterns before she had to leave town. Besides; tho’ I considered her too highbred a woman to do anything in such bad taste, as to do my commission at her own expense, still your suggestion had made me uncomfortable.

If you are still in London and would send me some snips of nearly white papersTC wrote later on MS in blue pencil: “they were sent,—& used, to perfectn.” —I should be glad. I cannot go back to things as they were! Indeed I see not how I am to go back—ever—at all.

Kindest regards to your dear kind Husband— I have not ever been in such pain since as the day he was at MarinaPresumably John Forster visited St. Leonards late June or early July; see JWC to EFEFO, [12 June].— God bless you affectionately
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MCA, [18 Aug.]. Copy: NLS Acc. 7864. Hitherto unpbd. Dated on the copy: “(early in Augt 1864)”; dated mid-Aug. with reference to JWC having been at Holmhill “a month on Saturday.“
div3.head: JWC TO MARY CARLYLE AUSTIN

docBody.p: I would have written sooner, only that I knew you were hearing of me from Dr Carlyle. It is some days however since he was here; and I daresay I perhaps know better how I am, myself, than anybody else does!—however sagacious!— So I will write a few lines tonight, there is never any time in the morning for any writing but the daily letter to Mr C, as we go for a drive at 12, and are absent two or three hours, which brings one close on post time. I really think I have been better for the last week. I have had no wholly sleepless night, and the few hours of sleep I have had every night has been less unearthly! I have returned to dreaming—a habit discontinued since this illness—. I continue the new milk in the morning and the porridge at night, and the same plentiful supply of pudding and cream that I took at the Gill, and so well does this diet agree with me that when I was last weighed, I was found to have gained a pound and half in ten days!! The Irritation has been less distressing, and that is the most important item of improvement; for I could bear all the rest patiently if I were but delivered from that!

Oh my God! if I am after all to be restored to Life!—and not only that but Life without torment; shall I ever be able to show gratitude enough for such unlooked for mercy! I dare not let myself go to this novel feeling of Hope—for fear of preparing worse disappointment for myself!

I was very glad indeed to learn from Dr Carlyle that your Husband continued to feel no bad effects from his fall.For the carriage accident, see JWC to TC, [19 July]. I have such a horror of falls now! with good reason! I wish the weeks did not pass with such terrible speed, I shall have been here a month on Saturday!JWC arrived at Holmhill Sat. 23 July; Sat. 20 Aug. was four weeks later. and every week brings me nearer Chelsea and winter!—both of which I dread more than I can tell. But I am putting the thought of my departure as much out of my head as possible, and the unspeakable kindness of Dr and Mrs Russell helps me in doing so.
All good be with you dear kind Mary—love to Jamie
docBody.name: J. W. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [18 Aug.]. Addr: 5 Cheyne Row / Chelsea / London. PM: Thornhill, 18 Aug. 1864. MS: NLS 608.654. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p: I hope, Dear, you would interrupt the failure this morning into nothing worse than “a suitable return.”Coterie speech; see 19:227JWC to JW, [29 Sept. 1845].

The fact is; one letter per day is as much as I am up to, and yesterday I wrote to Mrs Forster, whom I had not thanked for her hospitality when I “passed thro’,” or for the letter she had written to me since.JWC did not thank Eliza Forster explicitly for either the hospitality or the letter; see JWC to EF, 17 Aug.

Last night, the fullness of time had arrived for a blue pill; Dr R thought—as yet, it has not succeeded like the former one. I slept rather more in quantity, but much worse sleep in quality. dreaming horrid dreams which I started awake out of every five minutes. I had a great deal to do with Lord Ashburton, whose face, I remarked, was become as pure and transparent as waxwork. Mine, he said, “would be as transparent when my illness was over.”

Dr Russells small harvest is almost over. My drives have not been stopt for it; an open carriage and horse and driver being procured every day from the Inn. I am out in it, with Mrs Russell, from two to three hours, starting at half-past twelve. If I find myself in spirits for it next week, we are going in the train to Dumfries to get somethings (woolen drawers &c)Probably from Marion Dinwiddie (1819–95), hosier, 131 High St., Dumfries; see 37:16JWC to MCA, [18 Oct. 1860]. greatly needed—for a year nearly I bought nothing new, thinking I should not live to wear out new
things. and the old things had been all let “fall into dotage”! Not a stich was put in for me unless I took the chief trouble on myself. till I came here—the Mary here looks over my things, and slips them quietly away, and brings them back mended.

I would give twenty pounds a year for such a Servant— I like the future Mrs Woolner much—and am pleased with his attentions in sending the photograph.See TC to JWC, 16 [17] Aug., and 187 tell him so with my kind regards.
My aunts invite me urgently to Morningside—but I am too well situated here, to desire any change. I shudder at the idea of leaving this refuge—as if I should be torn to pieces by dogs the next minute

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 18 Aug. Addr: at Holme Hill / Thornhill / Dumfriesshire. PM: London, 18 Aug. 1864. MS: NLS 616.650. Quot: Froude, Carlyle 4:280.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Nothing from you today at all;—whh, alas, I fear will mean nothing of good! I am in a poor cheepy humour (physically); prone to apprehension; but resist as well as I can. The burble of the “Two Notes at once” will have settled itself, any way.

There is not the least vestige of tidings to send. Absolutely nothing has happened; not even a Proofsheet come in,—tho’ I sent out (my one joy yesternight) a bundle of them. And abt 10 minutes ago, came upon a most importt (forgotten) clipping; whh in the hurry of Tuesday Night, Mary had handed me as blank, for writing and adding the Weeks items upon! I happened to turn the clip where I had put it (being very punctual, you observe) and saw—The Printer has now got it (marked in red-pencil “Grocer” so-much, “Baker” &c,—and on the other side Epic-Historical!);—and my poor Goody will never see that particr red-jotting (the rest are all in their Clip yet), to give me a little praise for it. Ochone, ochone, when will this boiling of the dead-dog chaos end, and hide itself forever from my weary eyes?— Mary & I are very punctual however, you see. I was stringent the first week; and since, the thing goes itself. The creature Mary seems perfectly honest, can give clear acct of everything;—frugal too, I shd judge (week per is from 30/ to 25/, never higher), whh, apart altogr from the unmomentous money, is a very pleast circe.

The weather is dry, parched as Sahara; but for the last 2 days grown almost
cold:—rain must come, and gentler air agn. Meanwhile I am aloft here, under roof, not the sport of winds; whh is a great advantage. Expect confidently to have my Book 20° ended (and all War dismissed forever more!) before Augt quite depart. At lowest I am aiming dreadfully that way!—

Yesternight I had hardly gone out when Fuz it seems called; said he had a Letter under way for me,—whh came after tea. Read it here. I also found the Greenw.The letter from Rose Greenhow that TC was unable to find the day before; see TC to JWC, 16 [17] Aug. and send it,—but dispense you with reading.

Oh Darling, what a humiliated, broken-down, poor cheepy wretch I am (today, most days),—condemned to dwell among the pots, and live upon unclean blockheadisms, and hug foul creatures to my bosom (coaxing them to tell me what they know), these long years past,—till I feel myself become foul & blockheadish! On, on, to get it pitched away from one, into the Bottomless Pool!—
Darling, Darling, get better for me; and all will be forgotten,—all will be victory yet. God send thee well; or at least better, to the supportable degree. I am ever my poor true Jeannie’s
docBody.name: T.C. (past 4 p.m., but in time still).

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [19 Aug.]. Addr: 5 Cheyne Row / Chelsea / London. PM: Thornhill, 19 Aug. 1864. MS: NLS 608.655. Pbd: A. Carlyle, NLM 2:296–97 inc. Quot: Hansons, NE 521, 522.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p: There is a question I have meant to ask in every letter for some time back, and which has always been put aside, and “eventually”Coterie speech; see 33:41JWC to TC, [20 Aug. 1857]. forgotten till the letter had been posted. What became of our kitten? Was it left with anyone “in particular” at St Leonards?The kitten (see TC to JWC, 11 March, and TC to JWC, [14 April]) that Mary Craik gave to the maid at Marina; see TC to JWC, 24 [25] Aug. or was it brought back to Chelsea? Surely Mary Craik would secure its Future?

Something occurred here last evening between the hours of 8 and 9, which produced an extraordinary sensation! Mrs Russell has not got over it yet! My Dear, i laughed!!! “the first time I had laughed since I came”! And it was no feeble attempt; but a good loud hearty laugh!— Perhaps you will wonder what could have produced an effect so startling? The cause was a nothing—Mrs Russell had been telling of a row Mrs Ewart at Nith Bank had had with her servants.Alicia Ewart, b. Yorston (b. ca. 1789), widow of Thomas Ewart (d. 1831), m. 1828; she lived with her elder sister, Agnes Lawson (b. ca. 1778), at Nithbank, Thornhill. They had three servants: Catherine Maxwell (b. 1830), Mary Hunter (b. 1833), and Violet Cowan (b. 1834). Hearing some disturbance in the room where her Maids slept,
she got out of bed to see what it was, and found a stranger man in one of their beds. “Only think what a terrible thing! said Mrs R—and a great big man!”— “My Dear,” said the Dr in his quiet, dry way; “would it have been any better had it been a little man?“— I don’t know why this tickled me so much—but I laughed; and if I had cried I couldn’t have surprised them more—or so much!

Along with Forsters letter to you, there is come this morning a kind little letter from Forster to me. Nobody else has written to me for long.According to JWC, Eliza Forster at least had written to her; see JWC to TC, [18 Aug.]. which makes me feel sometimes as if I were officially dead. Curious that Geraldine, above all, who made more protestations of undying love to me than all my other friends put together, does not see what “a bad effect” such inconstancy would have in a novel!

Again I have not lain awake all night; tho’, for the rest, my sleep was as little satisfactory as sleep, at all, could well be. The blue pill has done “neither good nor ill”Coterie speech; see 4:369TC to MAC, 20 April 1828. this time, I think. Perhaps because I had not such dreadful need of it!

You are quite right about Mary—honesty and frugality are her ostensible virtues. She has some latent ones besides, especially goodheartedness—but these are sadly overlaid with a constitutional apathy, and a morbid self-conceit.

I read in Forster’s Essays the other day a charming paragraph about Frederick. After telling the story of Frederick making ZeiternHans Joachim von Ziethen (1699–1786), Prussian general; see 35:31TC to JN, 11 Feb. 1859. The anecdote is untraced; it is unclear whether JWC refers to an essay by John Forster, or one by Friedrich Förster, German historian and biographer of Frederick; see 38:100TC to JN, 18 June 1862. add a line to his letter to his wife, to the effect that “next day at two o’clock he would be dead.” Forster remarks; there are people who have called in question the truth of this incident; but it accords so well with the cruel tyrannical disposition of the man, than if it did not actually take place it might have done so!!
There—you have a long letter today, tho’ I am rather shaky—for you will get no more till Tuesday— Your ever affte
docBody.name: Jane W Carlyle

ps.p: I hope Mary is shaking my furs—to keep the moths off. If she knows where to find my shawls let her shake them too

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 19 Aug. Addr: Dr Russell &c &c / Thornhill / Dumfriesshire. PM: London, 19 Aug. 1864. MS: NLS 616.651. Quot: Bliss, TC 371.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: My Darling, Think if yr Letter was welcome to me; I thank Heaven for the news you are able to send. Oh God grant it may continue to me! It is my anchor, that hope, in the storms numerous enough that are abroad.— Don’t you want some money to “buy clothes”? Tell me how much. I paid John all his outlayings to a pennySee TC to JAC, 1 Aug. (as I required him to present them); there is no use or convenience to apply anywhere except to self.

If this had not been Friday, I think I shd hardly have written. I tried coffee agn today (have been on tea since the potatoes failed & heat came);—coffee itself was none of the best, and I think it must have helped me to this running at the nose, and paltry snivelling feeling, whh attends me since an an“An” repeated at turn of page. hour after. Not to mentn Proof-sheets, and my melancholy pluistering with them, and dispiritt over them. My ride will do me good;—and I will try no more coffee for some days. I have never gone into the new potatoes yet; dare not, and am upon wretched French beans these 3 days;—but must shortly.

Poor Ld Ashburton and his transfigured face:For JWC’s dream about Lord Ashburton, see JWC to TC, [18 Aug.]. I had him one night, too, in my dreams;—and my lonesome thots abt him are wae, wae. Thornton’s SermonPresumably a printed copy of a sermon given by Rev. Francis Vansittart Thornton (1816–95), rector of Chilton Candover, Hants, nr. The Grange, 1848–64; he transferred sometime in 1864 to South Hill with Callington, Cornwall, where he remained until 1882; both positions were in the patronage of Lord Ashburton; see 38:110JWC to TC, [1 July 1862]. Sermon not further identified. I read while at my coffee. It is less distressing than one might have feared.— Oh dear, and must I part with you in this way till Monday!— No, I am to have a word tomorrow morng if all prosper.— God be with us all. Your affecte T.C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady A [LLA], 21 Aug. Addr: Melchet / Southampton; forwarded in another hand to The Grange / Alresford / Hants. PM: London, 22 Aug. 1864. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Hitherto unpbd. Quot: Hansons, NE 521.
div3.head: TC TO LOUISA LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p: I got the poor little SermonFor Thornton’s sermon, see TC to JWC, 19 Aug. two mornings ago; and read it with many feelings: thank you much for sending it. There is something infinitely affecting in it to me: so small, and the topic so big; ah me, ah me! But really it is very honest, simple, true; and does Mr Thornton credit, so far as it goes. My poor Wife had been writing to me two or three days before, that she had met Him in her Dream; “his face was all transfigured, grown pellucid; he said to her, Yours will be so too, when you get out of yr sickness!” (whh, I cd see, she interpreted in a sad sense for herself). I have had him in my Dreams too:—what a “dreaming” one has, not by night only; and how one’s Life altogether is like a Dream!

I know not if you are still at Melchet;Lady Ashburton was presumably at The Grange, as the letter was forwarded there. but it is my likeliest Address. The news from my Wife (still at Thornhill with Dr & Mrs Russell) become really better,—or I do flatter myself so,—for the last two weeks. I am busy to a degree; struggling with my last strength to “have done before winter come!” Do not forget to warn me when you come to Bath House. Adieu dear Madam; and a kiss to yr little Jewel of a Mary,—who wd shriek if I tried it otherwise than symbolically or by proxy!

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 22 Aug. Addr: at Holme Hill / Thornhill / Dumfriesshire. PM: London, 22 Aug. 1864. MS: NLS 616.652. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Just a word Dearest,—in hopes of something good from you tomorrow. I am myself belated (as usual), and full of confusn,—witht news. Nothing wrong here; nothing new, mere “toil-and-slave, toil-and-slave!”—with less result than I wish, but still daily with some, thank God. If I live three months or four, this Egyptian or Algerian CaptivityTC refers to the Egyptians keeping the Jews as slaves; for Algerian pirates keeping European captives as slaves, see 37:135JWC to RMM, [20 March 1861]. shall have ended. In the name of Allah!—

Thro John, I heard of you till Saturday: you had slept badly friday night
(poor little soul); but he found you &c &c:—I know you consider him flowery and sanguine; and alas he does look at the matter from the outside (not as poor you do from the in);—nevertheless all things do encourage me to believe for certn that my poor little woman is really recovering, by visible degrees. Whh is the the best news I can get in the world.
Stauros Dilberoglue, n.d.
Courtesy of Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Columbia University

Yesterday I did not get out till 7 p.m or near it: the DilberogluesStauros Dilberoglue and his wife, Sarah Anderton. For a photograph (possibly taken around this time) of Stauros, see 197above; for one of Sarah, see 39:197JWC to LLA, [22 Sept. 1863]. JWC placed them in vol. 2 of her photograph albums (Thomas Carlyle Photograph Albums, Rare Books and Manuscript Lib., Columbia Univ.). came abt 4 & I had to go down to them, and narrate everything. I believe they are more faithfully interested than most others. Plenty of people come asking for you, day after day; you are by no means “officially dead,” if you are careful abt that. To me when you are very ill, most people’s inquiry (nearly everybody’s) is a positive pain. Little Mrs SymonsIsabella Simmonds. came here almost a week ago; actually had me down stairs (tho’ it must have been an effort);—and made me “tell her clearly.” She is off “to Leicestershire”Presumably to visit her husband’s family in Ashby de la Zouche, Leicestershire; see 37:139JWC to IEB, [3 April 1861]. (I think) “for 5 weeks.” Her Father is at Dublin, on visit; is “not to work any more” &c but is “well,” under such conditions.Dr. Barnes was apparently suffering from dementia; see TC to Lady ALLA, 28 June. Ruskin came to me one night; not so ungenial as at his own House that night;See TC to JWC, 6 [5] Aug. still not genial. FarieRobert Farie. (jackass-like) stumbled down another night; regardless of a table piled with proofs,—till I had to walk him out in a kind of despair. Poor Fie, he does rather wish us well; but is very wearisome. Tonight, Woolnr is coming down with some Youth called Peel (nephew of the late Sir R.’s,Presumably Archibald Peel (1828–1910), son of Jonathan Peel (1799–1879; ODNB) and nephew of Sir Robert Peel (1788–1850; ODNB), politician. Woolner and Archibald Peel were great friends; see Woolner 242.—once only, & nichts zu bedeuten [it is of no importance].

The weather has grown absolutely cold. I am for a bit of fire tonight! Yesterday there was a plunge of rain and thunder, whh I hoped had softened the air, but it has not. Stiff north-wind and sky of grey.— — I had hoped to be thro’ that Burble of a Neubergism (not poor N.’s blame either, poor soul); but in that hope too I must consent to disappt: have had to leave off sticking in the middle till a new day.
Oh favr me with good news tomorrow; Oh may Heaven’s favr have enabled you!

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [22 Aug.]. Addr: 5 Cheyne Row / Chelsea / London. PM: Thornhill, 22 Aug. 1864. MS: NLS 608.656. Quot: Froude, LM 3:207.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p: I cannot write longly and deliberately today, Dear, “The history of Panizzzi is this.”Coterie speech, referring to Panizzi’s long-winded pedantry; see 23:260JWC to JF, [27 March 1849], and 28:304TC to LA, 3 Nov. 1853.

I do not get up to breakfast. After the two first mornings at the Gill, I gave over that audacious attempt; so as I breakfast in bed at nine, having had warm milk at eight (!) it is after ten before I get myself dressed. This morning “a united presbeterian Clergyman,” from Glasgow, with his wife and grownup son,Possibly William Anderson (1799–1872; ODNB), United Presbyterian minister of John St., Glasgow, his second wife, Margaret Jane, b. Hamilton, and John, (ca. 1825–65), his son from his first marriage, to Isabella, b. Binnie (d. 1854). came to breakfast, and to spend “a long day in the Country.” And Mrs Russell according to an old promise has to take them to Krichup Linn,Crichope Linn, gorge and waterfall about 2 mi. (3 km.) E of Thornhill; for TC’s poem on Crichope, see 6:434–46TC to JWC, 7 Sept. 1833. and if I do not drive there with them at eleven, I shall miss my drive altogether; which is not to be thought of. Of course i am not to explore Krichup! Poor I, who when last there caused shuddering admiration to my party, by leaping over the chasm itself,Untraced; perhaps on one of her visits to her mother at Templand, July–Sept. 1836 (vol. 9), July–Aug. 1839 (vol. 11), and July–Aug. 1841 (vol. 12). For JWC’s similar leaping over the mill-dam when a child in Haddington, see 2:310JBW to TC, [24 Mar 1823]. must now “sit in the carriage’—ay and be thankful it is no worse!

You would perhaps hear of me from the consulting Physician this morning.John A. Carlyle wrote, 21 Aug.: “I went up to Thornhill yesterday [Sat., 20 Aug.] & found Jane looking decidedly better and more cheerful, though she had not slept well the night before. The thing she feels most want of now is power to walk, & it does not seem that there is any improvement in that respect though she walks more or less every day. The injury she got by the fall last year may perhaps have something to do with this defect, but she is not in the least degree lame & walks what she can walk without any visible check. When she was at Holmhill two or three years ago she often walked to Templand or Thornhill & back, though she is now so far from being able to attempt such a thing. … Neither Dr Russell nor I think that any thing beyond her present regimen & diet—which in other respects seems to have had so satisfactory effects—can be attempted for the defect in walking. … Please do not say aught to Jane herself about the reports you get from Dr Russell or me, for that only annoys her.” By road Thornhill was about ½ mi. (1 km.) and Templand about 1½ mi. (2.5 km.) from Holmhill. As he came up to dinner on Saturday. Every time I see him he expatiates on the misfortune of having nothing to doJean Aitken commented to TC about John who was staying with her at The Hill, Dumfries; she wrote to TC, [21 Aug.]: “The Dr leads a very quiet life sits smoking on the Know top with his Bk & has at all times a table covered with Icelandic Dictionaries &c &c up stairs. He is not ill to deal with when once the breakfast is over but is really much given to fault finding abt it. What his movements are I know not. Talks of taking possession of the two rooms up stairs ‘whither he occupy them or not’ But still thinks of having ‘a house of my own’ I sometimes feel inclined to tell him that a man turned of sixty shd either take a house of his own or at least give over talking abt it. I shall do my best for him while he is here poor fellow, that is all I can do for him. He has had sad want of a tetherstick since ever I knew him.”—not applying his words directly to
me any more, but in speaking to Dr Russell about Mr AirdThomas Aird (1802–76; ODNB; see 6:361TC to JAC, 29 March 1833), writer, ed. of the Dumfries Herald 1835–63; old friend of the Carlyles. He had recently retired; see 39:138TC to JAC, 27 May 1863.—whose ill health “proceeds from having nothing to do”; he says. I told Dr Russell; that was his theory of my illness. and Dr R said laughing; “Oh yes he endeavoured to impress that notion on me; but I took the liberty of saying I thought him quite wrong: as I had seen many cases of poor, and very hard working women, suffering from similar nervous illness.”

I have no wholly sleepless night to report yet! Oh God be thanked!— I don’t sleep well by any means—but to sleep at all is such an improvement! I continue to gain flesh. Andrew (“the man”)Andrew Hunter (b. ca. 1842), plowman, presumably weighed JWC on some agricultural weighing machine. declares that in the last ten days I had gained four pounds!!!John reported, 21 Aug.: “She was weighed yesterday again & had gained three pounds more.” But that must be nonsense! I should look fatter if I had. Dr Russell will weigh me himself next time.

Would you tell Mary while the weather is propitious to air all the bedding of the two empty rooms, in the garden. And tell Helen while she has so little to do, to wash all the stair-railing and balustrades with soap and water— I dare say it never occurs to them to do anything but the usual absolutely necessary daily routine. A long letter after all!

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 22 [23] Aug. Addr: Dr Russell &c &c / Thornhill / Dumfriesshire. PM: London, 23 Aug. 1864. MS: NLS 616.653. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p:
My Dearest, what a treat to me yr nice fresh Letter is;—something like yr own old Self agn: such a solace to me in my muddy difficulties here. For all is now mud instead of dust; bitterly cold too (I have sat all day with my old cape
on, & will have a fire tomorrow if this continue): upstairs here,—where I now am in permanence, the wind, this day, having quite torn to bits my old rag of an Awning, and definitely finished it!—

Your consulting Physicn is much of a goose in some respects (tho’ witht malice in the heart of him, poor soul); his talk abt “want of work,” in reference to you, is abundtly impertt and absurd: but never mind it. He talked to me of it slightly once; but I cut him short by the assurance That you had, if he knew it, worked a great deal, considerably to the purpose; that you had never “wanted work,” and that among my acquaintance nobody seemed less at a loss to spend her time! One is angry (as I, for certn hours, at “my meanness in regard to small sums of money,” & the necessity of his intervening in the properly magnans manner in that particr. Oh dear!—but it is really nothing; and, if he cd, I know there are few that wd so gladly help me withal.

Mary aired all yr furs, shawls &c, the day you ordered: she shall now do the bankts.Thus in MS; for “blankets.” Helen do the balustrades. Mary is holidaying (SistersMary’s sisters are unidentified. &c) today; Helen was yesterday:—of work I shd think they have a plentiful lack: but they don’t behave ill.
Peel & Woolnr did very well yesternight; Peel a speculative (flail-wise speculative) goodhumoured slack indivdl better than many. I have not a moment more. God bless my own little Jane.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [23 Aug.]. Addr: 5 Cheyne Row / Chelsea / London. PM: Thornhill, 23 Aug. 1864. MS: NLS 608.657. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p: I have sat this half hour with my writing-apparatus before me waiting for your letter. I knew it would come tho’ the Postman was so long beyond his time. And it has come—all right!

Along with it a letter from Charlotte Southam, in great woe, poor little soul!, telling me her “Father” (Uncle)Thomas Southam and his wife, Elizabeth, Charlotte’s uncle and aunt, adopted her in childhood. is dying.

Should you like to have Charlotte back, as housemaid, valet, and Ladys maid—in place of Helen who will never I fear be made into a satisfactory Servant. I think Charlotte, in spite of her bad behaviour of old, is deeply attached
to both you and me, and she had in her the making of a capital Servant, and she must have had good training since. I don’t know that she would like returning to “the middle classes,” after having been in “the family” of a Marquis;See JWC to CSCSO, 8 Aug. but I think she has so much respect for talent and personal regard for us that it would be worth while to give her the chance—if you see as much hope in the arrangement as I do. Tell me your mind quite truly, without reference to my perhaps too romantic idea of her.

Last night was badish—but better than I expected after the bustle of yesterday; (for besides the “Happy Family”“The Happy Family” was the name given to a collection of small animals (including cats, mice, rabbits, owls, pigeons, and hawks) kept in a cage in Trafalgar Sq., all supposedly living together in harmony; see 37:150JWC to WDO, [15 April 1861]. accompanying me in my drive, Mr & Mrs GladstoneThomas Steuart Gladstone (1805–82) and his wife, Elizabeth, b. Clarke (d. 1897), of Capenoch House, 4 mi. (6.5 km.) SW of Thornhill; see 38:149JWC to TC, [19 Aug. 1862]. came with a great basket of grapes for me just when I was wanting my dinner). They were in London this season presenting their DaughterThe Gladstones had two das., Margaret Maxwell (1839–1916) and Helen Steuart (b. 1843); their elder da., Margaret, m., 1871, Sir Henry Ralph Vane (1830–1909), 4th bart. at court, and made two attempts to see us. How successful you can figure when I tell you they called both times at “Mr Tumm Carlyle,” of Maida Hill! Mr Gladstone had got the address from Dr Russell, lost it, and looked in the Directory; where finding Thomas Carlyle Esq Maida Hill.The 1864 London post office directory listed Thomas Carlisle, Esq., 25 Clifton Villas, Warwick Rd., Maida Hill. They drove there, and neither Master nor Mistress Carlyle being at home, did not discover the mistake but left their cards, and went back again after a few days. This time they were shown into the Drawingroom, and Mrs Gladstone looking round her, said; “I am sure this is not Mrs Carlyle’s Drawingroom for I have seen a photograph of it, and this bears no resemblance”! Presently both “Mr Tumm Carlyle” and his Wife entered, and there was no need to tell them it wasn’t the Mr Tumm Carlyle who “was a very clever man“—they had only to apologize “Oh dear said the Wife, never mind! you are by no means the first nor will you be the last people who come to seek that Mr Carlyle here”!
What they must suffer!

We have had a cruel little disappointment this morning. After I had been here a week or two I discovered that there were old potatoes—of the most excellent quality, being given to the pigs!! Some have been boiled for my private use every day since—and finding you were ill off in that respect, I proposed to Mrs Russell to send you a little hamperful—carriage-paid. We got ready the hamper, and Mrs R went to sort out the potatoes and behold! “there were not as many left as would fill a tureen!”—I had hoped to give you a real treat!
I am glad you saw the DilsThe Dilberoglues.—they are true hearted friends— God keep you
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

ps.p: we speak of going to Dumfries on Thursday if the weather be favourable But I have a terrible shrinking from these efforts when it comes to the point

div3.sourceNote: JWC-CS [CSO], [23 Aug.]. MS: EUL. Pbd: Blunt, “CLC” 417–18, where dated ”?13 Sept.” Dated by JWC to TC, [23 Aug.], where JWC had just received a letter from Charlotte saying that Thomas Southam was dying, and by the state of JWC’s health, which by Tues. 30 Aug. was much worse again.
div3.head: JWC TO CHARLOTTE SOUTHAM

docBody.dateline: Holm Hill / Thornhill Dumfrieshire / N.B. Tuesday [23 August 1864]
docBody.p: I am heart[i]ly sorry for you! I know by experience what a terrible affliction is the loss of a kind, good Father, and that worthy uncle has been the kindest, best of Fathers to you!— I am sure of that from all that you have told me of him.

I can quite sympathize with you too under your cruel separation from him, and your poor “Mother,” in these last days of his Life. But such is this world!—not a joyful place at all for such as have thought and feeling; but a place of sore trial. It never enters entersThus in MS. into our heads, when we are young, to recognize this truth; but as we live on, and add experience to experience; it force’sThus in MS. itself upon us, and becomes like a part of our Being! God help us!

I wish you had never left my house, Dear! I should have been better able to help and console you under such a trial as this. and what opportunities you would have had to help and console me! Perhaps when you have found that “rising”Charlotte’s position was in the home of a marquis; see JWC to CS, 8 Aug. (as tall Charlotte“Tall Charlotte” (b. ca. 1826) was employed by the Carlyles Sept.–Nov. 1860; see 37:20JWC to MR, [22 Oct. 1860]. would say) is not the chief end of WomanFor JWC’s similar, earlier use, echoing the first question of the Shorter Catechism (“What is the chief end of man”), see 10:182JWC to TC, [18 Sept. 1838]. or Servant—does not best ensure either one’s dignity or happiness; you will come back to me to be housemaid, and valet and Lady’s maid, and friend, and little Daughter—as I used to feel you to be, my poor Child!

Thank God, I continue to have better sleep—and to suffer less pain—and to gain flesh. If I could only recover the use of my legs—which are still so feeble that I cannot walk many yards at a time! Now—for the first time since I fell ill; I begin to believe that I shall really recover!—to, at least, a bearable state of health! And then, I shall be thankful for all my sufferings; for they have taught me much, that I was needing to be taught.
God keep you my little Woman
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

ps.p: Your letter is just comePresumably Charlotte’s letter that arrived 23 Aug. with TC’s letter; see JWC to TC, [23 Aug.].

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 23 [24] Aug. MS: NLS 616.654. Hitherto unpbd. Dated wrongly by TC; this letter is in reply to JWC to TC, [23 Aug.].
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Dear, Dear,—Yr Letters are become a balm to me; a cheerful morning-light in these dark times, so gloomy and troublous for a year back. Oh continue to grow better for me, to send news that you are still on the improving hand! Slowly; I will be content with any rate of progress; some, visibly some, in such a blessed novelty.

I am agn as hurried as ever: the whole day long, every available minute from breakfast-time to 1 a.m and bed, I toil and moil among these Proofs (and get wellish on, agn, the Neubergisms quite vanquished and left):—I must tell you the essential if nothing more. Charlotte was here, as her Letter intimates (what amazing spelling, worse than Betty’s,Betty Braid, JWC’s old nurse. and witht any fun in it),—but she did not see me, and I always forgot when writing to you since. This day I sent to ask for poor old Southam: “No hope, the Dr desperate” (his poor Wife too, sitting up every night, has bad ailments):—and now as to yr dear little Plan abt Charlotte?

Well, Goody, thrice—well,—if you like. But as to me I cannot pretend to have knowledge either of Charlotte or of Londn Servt-Girl-ism, to give any solid advice at all. You know I always liked little Charlotte beyond anything of her kind that ever was in the House; and was very sorry when she had to be packed away. Do you think the maxim, “Don’t take a servt back,” is practically inapplicable here? Possibly it may,—nay probably, when I consider
everything (for the creature has a finer head as well as dispositn, and may have learned & repented;—but I don’t know at all. One thing can be said: If you decide to try her, and do find it agn a failure, it is small loss, extremely small! I confess myself totally sick of Servt-Girl-ism as practiced here; really quite driven to a nonplus by it; and only submitting (with continual disgust & protest) because I cannot help myself at all. This Helen is an incurably careless creature, and I perceive, never will essentially mend. She is honest, cheerful, respectable; and can work well, but won’t or doesn’t. The things she neglects for me from day to day are manifold;—she has also a tendency to disobedience, to choice of work; whh wd have got her turned into the street, on the moment, twice or thrice before now, had not we been situated as we are. She is now all for civility, flattering obsequiousness of manner,—but she does my poor bit of work no better; and is the kind of “valet” I cd gladly bid adieu to at any time!— If you find Charlotte feasible in any real measure, try her agn by all manner of means. I can keep the term secret from this individl, till we are within a month of it, and then—! Oh how glad we shd be, and I shd be, of a right little servant— “But we can dow without her too!” as a deft Scotsbrig man said of the moon.
Hoity-toity! it is close on five o’clock, and Helen will have to make for Sloane Square.To post the letter; see TC-JWC, 16 [17] Aug.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [24 Aug.]. Addr: 5 Cheyne Row / Chelsea / London. PM: Thornhill, 24 Aug. 1864 . MS: NLS 608.658. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.dateline: Holm Hill / Thursday [crossed out] No! Wednesday [24 August 1864]
docBody.p:
If I don’t do it the first thing, I shall be sure to forget it entirely! I have got to ask you for an autograph! The assistant Minister of Keir, a pious, Babe-like Young man,Unidentified further; Keir, parish 2½ mi. (4 km.) SW of Thornhill. begged of Mrs Russell to get him, from me, a scrap of your hand-writing—not as an Autograph Collector; but as an intense admirer of you!— You have a curious variety of admirers here—as elsewhere Within a mile of the young minister, who swears by you, there lives a young—blackguard, who swears by you also! Young Hoggan of Waterside,George Hoggan (b. 1835), son of George M. Hoggan (b. 1808) and Phyllis, b. McMurdo (b. 1812), of Waterside House, Keir; presumably now the laird of the Waterside estate, which included Scotsbrig. who was so many years
lost in Australia, “living with Convicts”; his Mother supposed! He seems to have read no Book but Sartor in all his life! You are “the only man in the world he would go down on his knees to see”! He raves about you wherever he goes, and his emphasis is appaling; for he is like a savage, and a convict, and “a mad”Coterie speech; see 31:188JWC to TC, [23 Aug. 1856]. all in one! He was going to Scotsbrig to see Jamie; “not about business! uncle EdwardEdward Hoggan (1793–1867), George Hoggan’s great uncle, was factor of the Waterside estate; see 25:183TC to JWC, 30 Aug. 1850. manages all that! but to see the man that had the glory of being Brother to Carlyle.” And “wasn’t it a glory for himself that a Brother of Carlyle’s should be his Tenant”!

I was awake, for good, far to early this morning, and by Dr Russells advice beguiled the time in swallowing a doze of rhubarb and magnesia! But I had a charming little dream, before waking the last time. I dreamt I was going down a hillside to join some people on the road below—and I was running! and there were steps on to the road and I cleared them at a bound! I thought oh how delightful to be able to run again! and awoke—to find a bad pain in my knee! Today I am as stiff as a crutch!— The frost I suppose acting on the neuralgia about my legs.

I liked Mr Thorntons SermonSee TC to JWC, 19 Aug.—for the true and loving appreciation it showed of Lord A’s character—there was nothing else to like in it—“no Gospel” (my Aunts would say). Poor Mary Milligan (Charles McKie wife) is deadMary Milligan (1811–64), servant of JWC’s mother, m., 1841, Charles McKie (1801–47); she d. 17 Aug., the cause of death noted as “disease of the brain for years.”— It was just as I said when she wrote to me that time she was going mad again;Mary Milligan wrote in summer 1863; see 39:187JWC to MR, [16 Sept. 1863]. and again she was sent to the Asylum. They brought her home better—but the illness soon returned, and out of kindness, the DaughtersShe had 2 das., Rachael (b. 1842) and Agnes (b. ca. 1846). thought they would try keeping her themselves; but they “had mismanaged her,” the Dr said; and she died last week—a natural death fortunately.
It is terrible to look over to Templand, and think how all who were there are dead and gone! and the place itself green and bright looking as if nothing had happened!

If I don’t write tomorrow you may suppose I have made out the journey to Dumfries, and been short of time before starting— You dont mention the Kitten? I hope Mary understood the matrasses and feather beds were to be aired and beaten as well as “the blankets”?

div3.sourceNote: JWC-EF [EFO], [24 Aug.]. MS: NLS 1797.95. Quot: Hansons, NE 521, 523.
div3.head: JWC TO ELIZA FORSTER

docBody.p: If any one in the world is capable of sympathizing with you under that terrible infliction, bad nights; it surely must be me! I have experienced every degree and every description of bad night! I have been nearly driven mad with bad nights!— I don’t know if it will be any comfort to you to say it; but I have arrived at this conclusion; that the sleeplessness proceeding from incidental pain, is much less distressing than the sleeplessness proceeding from sleeplessness! and much less dangerous! So I hope to hear that the pain is gone out of your head, and, your sleep come back in the course of nature.

i go on mending. I make no great hand of sleeping yet; but I do sleep more or less every night. And I have returned to my old habit of dreaming, discontinued ever since I fell ill. (for I do not count my horrible opium visions as dreams!)

I now dream a little as well as sleep a little every night. Last night I dreamt that I was running! and that I cleared some steps of stairs at a bound! “Oh the delightful sensation, I thought; to be once more able to run!” and I awoke with the joy of the thing! to find the air frosty and my legs stiffer than usual!

Don’t be in the least hurry about my commission.To choose wallpaper for Cheyne Row; see JWC to EFEFO, [17 Aug.]. I trust in God that I shall not have to return to Chelsea this good while yet!— But I do want the Drawingroom papered as well as my bedroom and dressingroom—no oil painting of course— I should like the papers or paper of a small pattern. and nearly white—and some sort of border in the Drawingroom—

I should like Mr C not to be troubled about it, till the great affair is just ready to come off! He would worry himself thinking about having to give up the first floor for a day or twoTC wrote later on the MS in blue pencil: “kind true soul; kindest of women.”—
I do hope you feel better there. Give my kind remembrances to Mr Dickens and the rest.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 24 [25] Aug. Addr: at Holme Hill / Thornhill / Dumfriesshire. PM: London, 25 Aug. 1864. MS: NLS 616.655. Hitherto unpbd. Thurs. was 25 Aug.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: The Kitten (forgive my oblivious, for I was charmed with the questn at first) is happy: the Maid at Marina accepted it joyfully from Mary Craik; and it is now, I doubt not, slaying mice (or perhaps breeding new cats) and a victorious creature, arrived at Cathood and “a glancing future.”Cf. J. P. F. Richter, “Army-Chaplain Schmelzle’s Journey to Flaetz,” trans. Carlyle, Works 22:173.—

I hope you have got to Dumfries, this fine day, and go home unhurt with yr new dresses: Oh God be thanked! If I get no Letter tomorrow. I will wrap myself in that hope;—perhaps to be thrown out of it, too, when sad Saturday arrives. Helen has made but little way with the balustrade, only the topmost stair-carpet off (yesterday) and the extremely dirty steps swept). But indeed this morng, happening to notice how dirty my dining-room floor was, I broke (with brevity) into provocation; and all hands are really astir, washing, sweeping, upstairs down-stairs, seemingly bent to make a thorough job of it. Poor sluts, after all;Cf. “Poor fellow, after all”; coterie speech; see 13:55JWC to JOST, [9 March 1841].—they are not inattentive to me; there are many worse servts, in these times of anarchy.

I yesterday had a dinner of chicken-broth and pumpkin (vegetable-marrow) boiled;—refused my pudding; and had a long brisk ride (witht sleep as preliminary) in the cool dry evg: I finished Proofs before 10;—then found my vegetable marrow was disagreeing with me; tried my best resources, walked, took to reading a carefully written, but essentially rubbishy Book of Meredith’sPresumably George Meredith’s most recent novel, Emilia in England (1864); the Carlyles’ copy of the 1st edn. was sold at Sotheby’s, 1932, lot 93, with two letters from Meredith to JWC inserted loose in vol. 1. They had known Meredith for two years and both had read Feverel (1859); see Lionel Stevenson, “Carlyle and Meredith,” in Carlyle and his Contemporaries, ed. John Clubbe (Durham, N.C., 1976) 258–60. whh was lying abt; got to bed fairly before 2;—and did not wake finally up this morning till near the stroke of 11; a highly parboiled flaccid indivdl, full of remorse too! My Day has yet had nothing pleast in it but yr Letter that lay waiting (Let me not forget the Autograph!)— Mary’s Blanket apparatus (comon clothes-line) broke just as I stept out with my pipe (at noon), I had some ordering & helping with that &c &c: in short, my day is dies non [a nothing day] or little more: I have done next to nothing, but read at my Frh instead of writing; and annihilate more or less a good deal of litter
lying abt. Tonight I will still do some reading;—then Tomorrow, tomorrow! Oh that I were out of this;—oh that I had some wholesome root or vegetable to eat, by way of furtherance.
You surprise and amuse me by yr account of Young Hoggan: what on earth can a man like that find in Sartor Ress above all!
But I will now write my Autograph, & despatch in time. May Heaven’s blessings be on thee my poor little Woman! Be in no haste to walk; gather weight. Adieu, adieu
docBody.name: T.C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 25 [26] Aug. Addr: Dr Russell &c &c / Thornhill / Dumfriesshire. PM: London, 26 Aug. 1864. MS: NLS 616.656. Pbd: Bliss, TC 371–72. Quot: Froude, Carlyle 4:280; Wilson, Carlyle 5:551; Ashton 433, 434.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Dearest,—I will take the nothing whh has reached me today, as per bargn, to mean that you accomplished yr Dumfries trip yesterday, and will not believe it worse than “No ill news,“—unless perhaps (whh Heaven grant not) you contradict me tomorrow.

Here all is on the old footing; not a mouse (or a new mouse) stirring in my environs. The ride of yesternight was long and brisk; not one gentn on horseback did I see after passing thro’ the Park,—hardly above 3 while there;—a Town utterly at its emptiest. Fuz I am told is doing the Coleny-Hatch Asylum,Colney Hatch Lunatic Asylum, Barnet, 6 mi. (9.5 km.) N of London; Forster was an inspector for the Lunacy Commission. near 2,000 mads in it; I have seen nothing of him, heard nothing since those Letters. At home-coming there sat a Mr Morrison (Son of the Morrison’s Pills, I believe!) who did a Book you heard me talking of:James Augustus Cotter Morison (1832–88; ODNB), author; his The Life and Times of Saint Bernard, Abbot of Clairvaux A.D. 1091–1153 (1863) was dedicated to TC (see 38:96TC to JCM, 2 June 1862); he was the son of James Morison (1770–1840; ODNB), manufacturer of vegetable pills for purifying the blood, and his 2d wife, Clarinda Sharmer, b. Cotter; see also 38:96TC to JCM, 2 June 1862. An innocent, polite, intelligt kind of man;—who kept me talking till 11 o’clock (sorrow on him) instead of reading for my task of today! Whh accordingly has gone all into the melting pot in that way: ah me! But conscience forbade to go on witht reading,—many mortal pages, & boring over maps &c. That will end, altogether I hope, in a few days.

The girls are raging & scrubbing; the front dining-room windows pure; the curtains all on the rope in the Garden;—Cat, with miniature black Likeness of herself, contemplatively wandering among the skirts of them:—not a
mouse stirring as I told you Oh dear, I wish my Goody were back! But I won’t be impatt (oh no, no) so long as I hear of her getting inch by inch into her old self again. The Heavens (truly and really) are merciful & gracious to me, tho’ they load my back rather sore.

Yellow demons seem to be rifer than ever, after Bass’s triumpht Act of Parlt. Think of Parlts sitting debating, passing act after act;Michael Thomas Bass; see TC to TWTWO, 31 May. The “Street Music (Metropolis) Bill” came into law in Oct. about the beautiful melody I now hear saluting me not far off! I try to care as little abt it as I can; that seems to be the one remedy. I have even twice had my bit of sleep in spite of the yellows; clap the fore-finger of the upper hand firmly on my ear, and fall asleep all the same!—
Meredith is going at once to be married,George Meredith m. Marie Vuillamy 20 Sept. said Morrison to me. Meinet wegen [for all I care]
Dinner is up: Adieu till Tuesday,—oh for good news of thee then. Blessings on my poor little Goody.— Ever Yrs T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [26 Aug.]. Addr: 5 Cheyne Row / Chelsea / London. PM: Thornhill, 26 Aug. 1864. MS: NLS 608.659. Quot: Froude, LM 3:207.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p: All right Dear! I have been to Dumfries, and have not, I think, sustained any damage. That I did not lie awake all night after, shows how much less nervous I am; I was very near doing it; but I didn’t; and “a miss is as good as a mile.”

We left here at a quarter after ten, and had long waiting at the station. That platform business is the wor[s]t part of a railway journey, always; especially if you have “many friends”; as I had yesterday—so many gentleman attempting to seize me round the waist and lift me in! I, in terror for my ribs, imploring to be let scramble in as I could!

When we got out at Dumfries we engaged a cab by the hour and drove first to Jane’s, to report myself there, and say I should come back so soon as I had done my shopping; while Mrs Russell would pay visits to her own friends. It was a consolation to find the consulting Physician gone that morning into GallowayJohn A. Carlyle was possibly going to Auchenhay, Kirkcudbrightshire, to visit the family of his old friend Robert Arbuckle (1802–62); see 38:166JWC to TC, [27 Aug. 1862], and 27438:biographical notes.— Jane expressed herself “sensible of a great improvement on me, in all respects but my legs”! Walking at all is indeed hardly possible for me at
present; the change of weather having produced rheumatic pains and stiffness in my knees—especially in the knee of the leg that was hurt. I did the best I could for myself, in buying a good supply of woolen undergarments—not “new dresses” not a single new dress! nor anything for the outside. the mercury of my mental thermometer had not risen to Care for appearances yet! only to hope of living long enough to need new flannels. I did once turn over the idea of a new bonnet; the one I have having lasted me three years!!Possibly the same hat as JWC wore in her Thornhill photograph, summer 1862; see 38:178JWC to TC, [31 Aug. 1862], and 193JWC to TC, [4 Sept. 1862]. But I sent it to the daughter of your old admirer Shankland the Tailor,Mary Shankland (b. 1805), milliner, 44 North Drumlanrig St., Thornhill, da. of James Shankland (ca. 1781–1841), tailor, High St., Thornhill; see 13:227JWC to TC, [27 Aug. 1841], and 313TC to MAC, 3 Dec. 1841. and she took out the clures and put in a clean cap for tenpence!!

My business done; I drove back by myself to Jane’s, and lay on the sofa, and by and by she gave me a nice little dinner, and it was all very quiet and comfortable; as it wouldn’t have been, had the consulting Phisicean not “had to go” into Galloway. At half after four I drove to the Station (a stone cast off!) Jane accompanying me and Mrs Russell joined me there and we got home to tea before six. I find I forgot nothing but “Medicated cotton wool.” and perhaps they had none in Dumfries which looks a most stagnant place.
My Dear have you paid the rent lately? the last quarter was due on the 29th of June.See JWC to TC, [31 Aug.].

There is an oil picture of you large as life in the Entrance Hall at Jane’s, that is more horrible than even “The female satyrs suckling their young”!A painting by “old Manfredi” (who is unidentified further), who lived for a time in the household of Count Carlo Pepoli (1796–1881; see 8:194–95JWC to JCA, Aug. 1835; see 25:188–89JWC to TC, 1850-09-022 Sept. [1850]. It looks like a man who having died mad, had been buried for several weeks and then raised. I told Jane that I was sure if you were ever near it with a penknife in your pocket; you would cut it in shreds; but she declares it excellent. Her own portrait by the same goose is bad enough and John said his was “the worst of all”Possibly one of a set of family portraits by Maxwell of Dumfries who painted the portrait of their mother, Margaret A. Carlyle, in 1842, and who supposedly died soon after from drink; see 13: frontis.13:frontispiece (viewable in the CLO on the table of contents page for vol. 13) and 15:130TC to JCA, 17 Oct. 1842. Otherwise unidentified. but he “didn’t attach any importance to such things”!
give me Mary Craiks address if you have it— Thanks for the autograph which will perplex the Babe-ministerFor the assistant minister of Keir; see JWC to TC, [24 Aug.]. considerably I should think.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 29 Aug. Addr: Dr Russell &c &c / Thornhill / Dumfriesshire. PM: London, 29 Aug. 1864. MS: NLS 616.657. Quot: Froude, Carlyle 4:280, combined with an excerpt from TC to JWC, 30 Aug.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Dearest, I am living in hope of good news from you tomorrow;—I will not expect too good: Heaven grant I be not disappointed altogether! Jean sent me a Letter this morng (the only one I had or cd expect) whh testifies how chatty and pleasant you were, and what a change for the better. Old “despair” quite gone out of yr face: evidtly all improved,—“except the walking, whh seemed no better at all.” Never mind the walking for a while; no hurry abt it,—if you only gather weight, and keep well to windward of “despair.” Oh my poor little Jeannie, poor little soul!—

My Horse rode with me like mad on Saty night (in fact, I think they are giving him too much of beans); but for him I shd not have had so tolerable a sleep,—conveying me into the blessed silence of Sabbath. Nobody loves his Sabbath as I do! There is something quite divine to me,—in that cessatn of barrel-organs, pianos, tumults and jumblings (few of them worth much); I easily do a better day’s work than on any other of the seven; and (if left alone) have a solemn kind of sadness, a gloom of mind whh tho’ heavy to bear is not unallied with sacredness & blessedness.

Yesterday I hoped to get done with Seven-Years War (done with such an enemy, only think of it),—abt 5 p.m. however, I magnanimously left off, “wait till a new day!” And it has taken me every minute of this day, as fast as I cd go;—and there will be a good deal of Printer’s-devilling still (little else all this week perhaps): but at the week’s end, surely I shall see myself in Book 21st and last;—half the volume quite gone; and an easier half ahead! Nay it is all in type here, after a sort,—but such a “sort”! Well, well.—

Last night, at Tea-time Geraldine was waiting when I came in. She had been writing to you, she said;—nothing of Speech came from her, that was useful or entertaining. Marshall & his Distracted Welsh-Irish PhenomnProbably one of the five sons of John Marshall (1765–1845; ODNB), originally flax-spinners of Leeds; see 10:95TC to MAC, 12 June 1838, and Carlyle, Reminiscences 143–44. TC’s most recent contact was with James Garth Marshall (1820–73) in Aug. 1861; see 37:215–16TC to JGM, 19 Aug. 1861; or he might possibly be James Marshall, “a little black Ccocknosed Irishman” (22:222TC to MAC, 17 March 1853) from Ayrshire, who had been sec. to Maria Paulowna (1786–1859), grand duchess of Saxe-Weimar-Eisenach; Marshall had last been in touch with TC about the Order of the White Falcon in 1859; see 36:9JWC to EFO, [14 Nov. 1859], 13–14TC to JMA, 28 Nov. 1859, and 23JWC to MR, [9 Dec. 1859]. “Welsh-Irish Phenomenon” unidentified. (whh really is too absurd even to laugh at,—might as well be wept for, and prayed
for); Mrs Greenhow,Rose O’Neale Greenhow. Mr RawlinsonRobert Rawlinson (1810–98; ODNB), civil engineer, whose main work was in public health and sanitation; appointed by Palmerston, 1863, to organize relief for the thousands of workers unemployed and starving because of the cotton famine in Lancashire. &c &c SheGeraldine Jewsbury. went away before 10; and I still got my fractn of Proofsheets put to post.

I have been in pill (bankrupt too, whh is not a good thing. Heaven will at last send ripe potatoes!— My scissors up here seem to be irrecoverably lost,—had disappeared yesty morning; “Can’t find them Sir!” ansrs Goose Hellen ever since. “Post time”; adieu dearest. T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [29 Aug.]. Addr: 5 Cheyne Row / Chelsea / London. PM: Thornhill, 29 Aug. 1864. MS: NLS 608.660. Quot: Froude, LM 3:207–8; Bliss, JWC 315–16.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p: I wish Dear, that the religious embargoOf the collection of letters in many parts of Scotland on Sundays. had lasted a few days longer; for tomorrow or next day might perhaps find me in better spirits for writing. I have had bad nights (tho’ not wholly sleepless) and bad days too since I wrote last. “The change of weather“— Perhaps!— But what have I to expect when the real winter comes, if a change like this acts so distressingly on me? My legs are both painful and useless, my feet (both of them) swelled again; and I seem to have “got a general jandy” (as John HunterProbably John Hunter (1795?—1858) of Tynron, uncle of JWC’s cousin Janet Pott, b. Hunter (1827–1912); JWC last saw him, Sept. 1858; see 34:242–43JWC to JPR, [23 Nov. 1858]. “Jandy” is probably a version of “jandies,” Scots for jaundice; otherwise untraced. described his sensations after being thrown from a gig!)— In this state, the thought of how I am ever to make that long journey back, which I made here on the strength of desperation, troubles me night and day. And what is to become of me when I am back, with my warm milk, and my nursing and my doctoring taken away? Oh I am frightened!—frightened! A perfect coward I am become—I who was surely once brave! But I cannot—that is must not stay on here thro’ the winter. Besides the unreasonableness of inflicting such a burden on “others”; it would be too cold and damp for me here in this valley of the Nith, which mists are already overhanging.

And so, Dear, tho’ I would fain spare you this, and all troubles with me, I must go back to the subject of the papering. and you must forgive what may
strike you as weakly fanciful in my desire to have “a new colour about me”! you must consider that I was carried out of these rooms to be shoved into a sort of Hearse,See TC to JWC, 9 March. and (to my own feelings) buried out of that House for ever. And that I have not had time yet, nor got strength enough yet, to shake off the associations that make those rooms almost terrible for me! To give them somewhat of a different appearance is the most soothing thing that can be done for meTC wrote later: “Poor, forlorn darling! All this was managed to her mind—all this yet stands mournfully here, and shall stand” (TC’s note in Froude, LM 3:208).—

Mrs Forster will manage it all, if you will just give up the first floor for a few days. She knows of a man, and she has sent me some papers to choose from. I have chosen one nearly white—and shall send her word tomorrow.

Tell Mary (I wish her to do it Helen is such a breaker) to take down all the pictures in my bedroom and dressing closet and carry them up to the spare bedroom. Then they must cover over the bed, putting a sheet or something over the roof and take up the carpet, and go for the carpenterPossibly Mr. Parsons; see 38:155JWC to MCH, [21 Aug. 1862]; or Frederick Freure. “The Chelsea carpenter” (TC’s note in Froude, LM 3:284). to take and beat it—and when the room is ready he may put it down. When the bed room is prepared for the paper hanger, they must do the same in the Drawingroom. Only; the Large PictureAntoine Pesne (1683–1757), The Little Drummer; a copy of Pesne’s painting was given to JWC by Lord Ashburton and hung on the south wall of the drawing room (Carlyle’s House 106); see 35:35JWC to DD, 14 Feb. 1859, and Carlyle, Works 12:370. An engraving of the copy by Francis Holl was used as the frontis.frontispiece to vol. 1 of the first edn. of Frederick (1858). does not need to be taken down, but covered over with a sheet—they need only to paper round it. It is such a botheration to have servants that can do nothing without telling! yes, and telling how. I sent a bit of paper that I think would do well for your dressing room—tell them about that yourself—
I wrote to Charlotte—that is, I answered her letter—and I put out a feeler—more than that would have been unwise as yet
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-EF [EFO], [29 and 30 Aug.]. Addr: Palace Gate House / Kensington / London. PM: Thornhill, 30 Aug. 1864. MS: NLS 1797.97. Quot: Davies, John Forster 109–10.
div3.head: JWC TO ELIZA FORSTER

docBody.dateline: Holm Hill / Thornhill Dumfriesshire Monday [29 August 1864]
docBody.p: Such is the severe observance of the Sunday in these regions that the letters posted in the South on Saturday are detained at Carlisle till monday; and so I have your letter only today. And I couldn’t make up my mind about the paper till after post time. I have now come to the conclusion that the pattern I return will do for both the Drawing room and bed room (with closet) There is a striped white one among the patterns marked “for Drawingroom” which I like better, that is, think prettier—but one must study a certain consistency, and I fancy that one would be too fine, for a room with otherwise no pretensions to finery. I do not admire any of the borders—the one I return is the best—but rather too marked a contrast I think.

I have written to Mr C to tell him you would be down upon him with a paper-hanger! So as soon as perfectly convenient, you will perhaps be so kind as call at Cheyne Row, and explain to the maids about clearing out the first floor,—remembering always that they are to be addressed as perfect idiots; and ascertain from them and Mr C when the Man may come. And oh please get the man to be speedy—so that Mr C may not be fidgited with him too long. and Oh tell the maids, when the rooms are done they must not go rubbing against the clean paper with their dirty Crinolines!— It wont be necessary to paper behind the large Picture, which would involve its being taken down— Bid them cover it with a sheet.

I am so glad to hear of Mr Macready’s visit.William Charles Macready (1793–1873; ODNB), retired actor and theater manager, now living in Cheltenham; Forster and Macready had been friends since 1833, but Forster strongly disapproved of Macready’s second marriage, 1860, to a woman much younger than himself, Cecile Louise, b. Spencer (1827–1908), ending the friendship. By 1863 Forster regretted the rift, and Charles Dickens effected a reconciliation; see Davies, John Forster 59–60. The Carlyles were friendly with Macready and his first wife, Catherine (1806–52), from 1839; JWC visited them in Sherborne shortly before Catherine d., Sept. 1852; see 27:200JWC to TC, [3 Aug. 1852], and 209JWC to TC, 5 Aug. 1852. It seemed such a pity that old and dear friends should be parted before the time
I have been very poorly for some days—but I hope it is only an accidental worseness.

closer.salute: Thank you very much / Affectionately yours

docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

ps.p: Tuesday—
I have opened my letter to say that the paper hanger had better wash the paint (doors &c) in the rooms. The maids couldnt do it properly without my direction.
Also. I have changed the border this one will suit the yellow doors better than the purple & gold pattern
I had no wink of sleep last night but instead horrible neuralgic pains; so today I am very wretchedTC wrote later on MS: “(ah me!).”

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 30 Aug. Addr: at Holme Hill / Thornhill / Dumfriesshire. PM: London, 30 Aug. 1864. MS: NLS 616.658. Quot: Froude, Carlyle 4:280, combined with a quotation from TC to JWC, 29 Aug.; Wilson, Carlyle 5:552.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Alas, Dear, the news are not so good this morning;—we must be prepared for waverings, for disappointts! It has grown hot weather here agn (to my sorrow;—nearly banished me out of my poor workshop agn, half my things down stairs at this moment!)—I hope it will be suiting my poor Jeannie better. The new milk &c I believe to be a great thing for you: diet and the liver, I consider Dr Russell’s superr success with you to be due in a most principal degree to his insight into those two points. How I shd, for my own private share, like to be deep in milk, whey, buttermilk, porridge at this very time! But it won’t do just now!— Having a dirty headache &c &c, and my proofs quite done, I think of snatching half an hour’s walk before dinner;—and will, with all brevity, touch upon the indispensable, & run.
