First then of the Papering, the maids are both busy (dilatory Hellen at length doing my flight of stairs (had merely had it lying stript for a week past): Mary I believe has all the Pictures &c of yr bedroom shifted, and the carpet nearly up (ShakspeareGeorge Shakespeare (b. 1817), dairyman, living at 6 Queen St., Chelsea; see 35:65TC to JAC, 5 April 1859. is to do the beating as he has done that of the others hitherto,—well, they say;—and no FreureFrederick Freure. to be called in till the end): Bedroom therefore will be ready for the Paperhanger tomorrow (if he like, whh he won’t till Mrs FrI.e., Mrs. Forster. tell him, whom I cd tell if it were safe, but you had better): in “six hours” after the Paprhr’s appearance, it is computed that the Drawing room can be ready for him;—so I continue to live there (mainly indolence of change, for the cold is now gone, and the groundfloor fully a better place) till we get farther notice.

2°. I have, alas, paid no rent at all,—shame to me! Send the Address (landlady’s name, Coutts Bankers), the Sum;Presumably Mrs. Oldridge; see JWC to TC, [31 Aug.]. Coutts & Co., bankers in the Strand; see 30:261JWC’s Journal, 21 Oct. 1855. The sum for the quarter was £8 .. 15. and I will at once act.— Wretched Tax-papersPresumably annual income tax papers; see 38:204TC to JWC, 9 Sept. 1862. For the deduction of income tax from the rent, see JWC to TC, [31] Aug. are stuck for a fortnight past behind the Lookinglass;Thus in MS. always waiting “for Larkin,” who hardly comes once a month, and always when the thing is out of my head!Larkin had apparently paid the rent as TC recorded: “2 Septr 1864 / To Larkin (House Rent) £8 .. 15 .. 0” (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753). Is this all? Tell me if you know of anything else forgotten by me.— Poor little soul you are the helm-intellect of the House, you see; nobody else has the least skill in steering. My poor scissors, for example: you wd find them in perhaps five minutes; nobody else I think will in 5 months! “Nowhere to be found, sir; can’t find them!” say they,—as so many rabbits, or bluebottle flies, might!—

Yesternight in the Park, as I passed thro’, Miss Bromley came running up: really glad, I cd see, to hear the better news of you:—has been at Cromer (Norfolk sea-side) “very wearisome”; and today is off “to The Grange & Lady An for a week.” Looked much tanned by sunshine, and a good deal more crowfooted, good soul. In the evg as I lay prostrate resting, the wretched Ballantyne turned up,—and I had half-hoped our receptn of him at St Leond’s (you remember?) had disgusted his haughty heart.Thomas Ballantyne presumably visited the Carlyles at St. Leonards when he asked TC for the Testimonial; see TC: Testimonial for Thomas BallantyneTC’s Testimonial for Thomas Ballantyne, 5 June.— God bless, my own little Heart. I now run!—
docBody.name: T.C.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [30 Aug.]. Addr: 5 Cheyne Row / Chelsea / London. PM: Thornhill, 30 Aug. 1864. MS: NLS 608.661. Quot: Froude, LM 3:208, combined with an excerpt from JWC to TC, [1 Sept.].
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p: Dearest, this is bad. I got no sleep at all last night. Had no chance at sleep, for the neuralgic pains piercing me from shoulder to breast, like a sword. Today of course I am nervous and miserable; and can send you no letter, to be called a letter. Dr Russell is giving me dandelion “to act on my liver and kidneys. Oh dear! what a heap of precarious things one is made up of!

I wrote to Mrs Forster last night—happily—for I could not have done it
today— I recollected in the dead of night that I had not told you to order the chimnies in the Drawingroom and Bedroom to be swept, so soon as they had taken up the carpets These women do nothing, however necessary, of their own accord—“the voluntary principle”Coterie speech; see 32:48JWC to IC, [10 Dec. 1856]. is not their principle.
I pray that I may have a better account to give of myself tomorrow.
“Forgive all my rongs” as dear BettyBetty Braid. says.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MCA, [31 Aug.]. Copy: NLS Acc. 7864. Hitherto unpbd. Dated by the return of JWC’s worse “neuralgia pains,” also reported in JWC to TC, [30 Aug.].
div3.head: JWC TO MARY CARLYLE AUSTIN

docBody.p: I have been long in answering, which is a bad sign of me—a sign of having nothing of a comfortable nature to say; for when I have, I like nothing better than to say it. My improvement lasted so long as the fine weather lasted; but the frequent rains seem to have been much against me; at least I know of nothing else, to which my backgoing can be feasibly imputed. My nights have been more restless (they had never got to be good) my appetite weaker, and worst of all, the special ailment to which all other ailments are as nothing in comparison, and which had been wonderfully in abeyance for two or three weeks, has been tormenting me at least a part of every day. Dr Russell says that damp is the worst sort of weather for neuralgia pains; so it is to be hoped when the Heavens dry up again, I make take to improving again.

After all; if I compare my present condition of body with what it was at St Leonards; instead of, as I am too apt to do, comparing it with what it was before my illness; I have reason to be deeply thankful; and I am thankful; though poor human nature longs and prays for something more!
I have not fixed the time for going home yet; but it cannot be put off much longer. I must wait only for a blink of good weather.
Dr Russell says “the fatalest thing for me in my present state would be to catch a cold and cough on the top of all.”
I hope you have not been hurt by the fatigue of the harvest; and that the work is all successfully over. There is little grain left in the fields hereabouts; and only in the fields of sluggards.
God bless you all.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JP [JPO], 31 Aug. MS: NLS 2883.239. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JULIET POLLOCK

docBody.p: Thanks for the pleasant bit of entertainment you send me.Unidentified. I confess myself arguably astonished at the vivacity of an Octogenarian Law Dignitary still loaded with so many labours;—his fire wd be beautiful to me, even if I were not myself the object of it! Pray make my humble respects (as I think you were to do at any rate); and tell the Lord C. B.Juliet Pollock’s father-in-law, Sir Jonathan Frederick Pollock, Lord Chief Baron of the Exchequer. that he knows me much better than he is aware; that I had a very lively evg beside him four or five years ago (at Forster’s in yr Square),The Pollocks lived at 59 and the Forsters lived until late 1863 at 46 Montagu Sq. In the previous five years TC mentioned dining at Forster’s on three occasions: 31 Dec. 1859 (36:31JWC to JF, [29 Dec. 1859?]), 8 Nov. 1860 (37:41TC to JAC, 9 Nov. 1860), and 31 March 1861 (37:141JWC to IEB, [3 April 1861]); Pollock was not noted as being present at any of them.—and that, in abt 3 months hence, if the Powers be kind, I expect to terminate my writing Labours or nearly so.— —

Rondâche is undoubtedly a round shield (or buckler); such were worn by Queen Elizth’s Dandies,—“swashbucklers,” still so called;—each buckler had a spike in the centre (that is, Vr Ho’s pointeVictor Hugo (1802–85), French writer, currently living in exile in the Channel Islands; he wrote in his most recent work, William Shakespeare (Paris, 1864): “En 1596, l’année où Elisabeth publia un édit contre les longues pointes des rondaches … [Shakespeare] fit Macbeth [In 1596, the year Elizabeth issued an edict against the long points of the bucklers … Shakespeare wrote Macbeth]” (31). The edict proscribing the carrying of certain weapons was passed in 1562: “Her Majesty’s pleasure is, that no man shall … wear any Sword, Rapier, or any weapon in their stead passing the length of one yard and half … neither any buckler, with a sharp point, or with any point above two inches length, upon pain of forfeiting the Sword or Dagger passing the said length, and the buckler made otherwise than is prescribed” (Articles for the Due Execution of the Statutes of Apparel; printed by R. Jugge and J. Cawood [1562]). It is now thought that Macbeth was written in 1605–6. Elizabeth I (1533–1603; ODNB), queen of England and Ireland.): yr Dandy had his buckler flung over his left shoulder, spike outwards, as he walked the streets,—and if no opportunity occurred there, he was sure to make one on getting to Smithfield;Smithfield market in the City of London was for several centuries a favorite place for public gatherings, for jousts, and for tournaments. where you wd sometimes see 30 of them at it all together; making a noise like coppersmiths, and little or nothing more than a noise. So I read, long years ago, not in Hollingshed,Raphael Holinshed (ca. 1525–80?), Chronicles of England, Scotland, and Ireland (1577); this was the source for many of Shakespeare’s plays, including Macbeth. but in some Brother of his (Survey of London,William Maitland (ca. 1693–1757), The History and Survey of London, 2 vols. (1756): “This Field [Smithfield], as it had antiently been … a Place of honourable Exercises of Justs and Tournaments, so loose Serving-Men would commonly meet here, and make Uproars and Quarrels; insomuch that it was many Years called Ruffians-Hall, being the usual Rendezvous of Ruffians and Quarrellers, during the Time that Swords and Bucklers were used: When every Serving-Man carried a Buckler at his Back, which hung by the Hilt or Pommel of his Sword, hanging before him” (2:989). I believe).
The news from my Wife, thank Heaven, have been considerably better since you last heard.
With many kind regards to F. P.Her husband, William Frederick Pollock. & you,

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 31 Aug. Addr: Dr Russell &c &c / Thornhill / Dumfriesshire. PM: London, 31 Aug. 1864. MS: NLS 616.659. Quot: Froude, Carlyle 4:280–81; Hansons, NE 522.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Alas, my Dear, this is bad news agn,—and unwelcome salutatn, but sent from Heaven, like the rain that was falling when I got it (in Cheyne Walk, by favr of Bullock). You take it easy: thank you for such spirited procedure:—I wish it had not been there to take! I am very dreary, abt it and other misgoings and traverses, in my solitude here. Send me better news, as you promise, poor soul; oh do, for tomorrow!—

I did not bethink me till this morng that I might at least go and tell Mrs Forster that the “rooms were ready here, if she and you were ready“: I will do that this afternoon. Yr bedroom ventThe chimney. does not need sweeping (was swept since you left it); drawing-room, since this morning, is getting rapidly dismantled, discarpeted, and I think will be ready also (sweep-work and all) before tomorrow Noon. My bedroom, not to increase the flurry, I think I will keep untouched: all is clean, cool, quiet there;—a bedroom whh I count among my earthly invaluables,—due to my poor Goody who has none near like it herself. Oh my Dear, my poor Dear, when I think of that carrying out into what you call “the Hearse,“—this poor “Papering” now, ever since I first heard of it, is the waeest and forlornest looking thing; like to make me cry outright! Indeed I often feel, if I cd sit down and greet for a whole day, it wd be an infinite relief to me. But one’s eyes grow dry;—what a quantity of greeting, too, one used to do in the beginning of life!— No wonder, you have a shudder at yr rooms, my poor Dear; but they are the one Nest we have for the prest;—after a three or four months (Book once done), I care not abt leaving (in fact, I shd infinitely prefer a more silent, quiesct natural kind of country for growing old and ending in): but for the prest there is no remedy. Stand up to the thing, like a brave one, since you must! I see you do;—and oh, and oh my poor wee
Woman, if in me there is help shall I not give it you!— In regard to the Journey hither, when that comes,—my—myRepeated at turn of page. Sister Jean I have no doubt wd be glad to accompany you, and to do her very best? But you yrself will contrive and adjust. Oh that I had you here agn, able to sit at the chimney nook opposite, and live beside me agn on any supportable terms!—

I am but low-spirited you see,—(want of potatoes, I am ashamed to say, is the source of everything);—and I will give up; tho’ there is no getting out (at present) under such rain. By mistake, Quiller’sCharles Rowett Quiller (b. 1829), pharmacist, 15 Sloane Sq.; see 39:90JWC to GWE, [17 March 1863]. man sent me, sevl weeks ago, a Box of Pills for Mrs (think of my reflexions on that Label!),—I had them put by: and this day, have decided to take one of them (for luck; John’s kind having totally refused service). Book 21° is not quite worthless; but lies in such mad disorder: the very acme of confusn! Geraldine & Rawlinson threaten to come tonight (since I began this). Adieu my own little Jeannie;—“forgive my rongs,” you too.

ps.p: Chelsea, 31 Augt 1864

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [31] Aug. Addr: 5 Cheyne Row / Chelsea / London. PM: Thornhill, 31 Aug. 1864. MS: NLS 608.662A. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p: A little better today, Dear; but very nervous, and discouraged! I had got to be too hopeful! More hopeful than there was solid grounds for. Yesterday “the Despair” was in my heart again as well as in my face. Perhaps it is a good sign that one night of pain and total wakefulness should have taken such serious effect on me. It must have been worse when such nights left no feeling of fatigue—worse because unnatural. There was no return of the neuralgia (“spasms in the Diaphragm” (?) Dr R said) last night. And tho’ I was out of bed fourteen times during the night, I got good mouthfuls of sleep between whiles. But I do not feel refreshed by my sleep—but shaky, and low, and terrified for the return of the pain. That had been quite in abeyance for a fortnight or so, and therefrom came my new hope and bright spirits. Oh anything but that! Last evening again I had to take myself to bed at seven with the intolerable irritation.

I am provoked at Marys stupidity in employing Shakespear about the carpets. I was obliged to take the job out of his hands years ago. He had no
proper apparatus for beating, and no clean ground to beat them in, and no conscience about getting the dust out. The carpets came back torn, dirty and dirtied. The little CarpenterMr. Parsons or Frederick Freure. does them capitally; so if the Drawingroom carpet, and my bedroom one (also Brussels) is still to do, pray let him have them.

The rent is paid into Coutt’s Bank, “For the Trustees of Alfred Oldridge—from Thomas Carlyle” The amount eight pounds fifteen shillings, when paid in full. But each half year an income tax has to be deducted—varying—I think when I had to do with it last, it was thirteen and sixpence—Larkin would know what sum was last paid—as a receipt would be given for it— I always got a receipt to keep me in mind.
I can not think of anything else particularly needing to be said just now—and I am too dull for spinning yarns

ps.p: Did I mention to be sure and have the SweepsUnidentified; possibly one of the four chimney sweeps in Chelsea listed in the 1864 London post office directory: John Burrows, George Clayton, James Pritchard, and John Scott. when the carpets are up—And to cover the bed hangings from the soot. and the Books

div1.p: Airlie, Henrietta Blanche, b. Stanley (1829–1921; see 26:30226:biographical notes), 5th countess; m., 1851, David Graham Drummond Ogilvy, Lord Airlie (1826–81; see 26:28926:biographical notes), 5th earl; for their children, see 37:26137:biographical notes. They lived at Cortachy Castle, Forfarshire (now Angus).

Aitken, Jean (“Craw”) Carlyle (1810–88), TC’s sister; m., 1833, James Aitken (1809–87) from Troqueer, housepainter of English St., Dumfries; they moved from Assembly St., Dumfries, to their new house, The Hill, Lochmaben Rd., Dumfries, 1863. They had two sons who d. in infancy (1834–36 and 1855–56), both named Alexander; their surviving sons were James or Jamie (1836–71), who worked in a mercantile house in London from 1858 and lived in a suburb in S London; Thomas (1841–69), who had been at an inst. for the deaf in Glasgow (see 29:186TC to JAC, 4 Nov. 1854), but was apparently now living at home; and John (1843–1911). Their das. were Anne (1839–1919), Margaret (1845–1932), and Mary (1848–95), who m., 1879, her cousin Alexander Carlyle.
Anderton, Sarah; see Dilberoglue.

Anstruther, Mary Frances, b. Stewart-Mackenzie (1819–1913), sister of Lady Louisa Ashburton, m., 1838, Philip Anstruther (1802–63). For their 11 children, see 38:273–7438:biographical notes. The family lived at 17 Norfolk St., Park Lane, London.

Ashburton, William Bingham Baring (1799–23 March 1864; ODNB; see 11:40TC to MAC, 8 March 1839, and later vols.), 2d baron; politician and partner in Baring Bros., bankers. He m., first, 1823, Harriet, b. Montagu (1805–57; ODNB; see 11:40TC to MAC, 8 March 1839, and 26:ix—xv26:introduction); they met the Carlyles 1839 and became close friends. Ashburton m., second, 1858, Louisa Caroline, b. Stewart-Mackenzie (1827–1903), da. of Mary Elizabeth Frederica, b. Mackenzie (1783–1862; ODNB), chief of Clan Mackenzie, and James Alexander Stewart (1784–1843); on their marriage (1817) the name Mackenzie was added to that of Stewart. JWC expected not to like her, but was swiftly won over. The
Ashburtons had one da., Mary Florence (1860–1902). They lived at Bath House, Piccadilly, London, and The Grange, Alresford, Hampshire; they also had a farm at Addiscombe, near Croydon. In 1861 Lord Ashburton bought Melchet Court, a country house 6 mi. (9.5 km.) W of Romsey, Hampshire, on the border between Hampshire and Wiltshire, for Lady Louisa; see 38:8JWC to LLA, [11 Nov. 1861]. His brother Francis Baring (1800–68; see 36:27636:biographical notes) became 3d Lord Ashburton. Where necessary for clarity, we refer in notes to Lord Ashburton’s first and second wives as Lady Harriet Ashburton and Lady Louisa Ashburton respectively, although these are not the correct forms.

Austin, Mary Carlyle (1808–88), TC’s sister, m., 1831, James Austin (1805–78), farmer of The Gill, 6 mi. (9.5 km.) SW of Ecclefechan. They had eight das.: Margaret (1831–74), who m., 1859, Thomas Stewart (1832–69), farmer at Hollybush, they had a da., Mary (b. ca. 1861) and a son, William (b. 1863); Grace (b. 1833), who m., 1856, William Yeoward (b. ca. 1824), of Toronto, Canada; Jessie (b. 1836), who m., 1859, George Grierson (b. 1835); Jane (b. 1840); Mary Anne (b. 1842); Catherine (b. 1844), who m., 1866, her cousin James Carlyle; Isabella (b. ca. 1846); and Mary Carlyle (b. 1851); and one surviving son, James (b. 1848).

Ballantyne, Thomas (1806–71; ODNB; see 11:32TC to TB, 23 Feb. 1839, and 30:xviii30:introduction), author and journalist; associated with several publications including the Manchester Guardian, the Leader, the Illustrated London News, the Statesman, and the St. James’s Chronicle; he anthologized TC and other writers.
Baring, Louisa (1804–88; see 38:27438:biographical notes), Lord Ashburton’s elder sister.

Barnes, Dr. Alfred Brooke (ca. 1802–67), physician, living at 182 King’s Rd., Chelsea; m. Susannah (ca. 1804—ca. 1855); their children were Rev. Brooke Cremer (b. 1833), Dr. Herbert Sedgwick (ca. 1835–65), and Isabella (see Simmonds); their eldest child, Laura Susannah (b. 1829), was now dead.
Barnet; see Blakiston.

Blakiston, Bessy, b. Barnet (ca. 1810–91), m., 1862, Peyton Blakiston (1801–78), M.D.; they lived at St. Leonards-on-Sea, Sussex. Blakiston’s first wife, m., 1825, was Frances, b. Powell (d. 1858); their sons were John Richard (1829–1917), Peyton (1831–65), Douglas Yeoman (1832–1914), and Matthew Folliott (1835–1906).

Blunt, Abel Gerald Wilson (1827–1902), m., 1851, Frances Mary, b. Forssteen (1820–99); they had seven children, including Reginald (1857–1944) and Elaine Mary (b. 1862). Gerald Blunt was appointed rector of St. Luke’s, Chelsea in 1860. His sister was Julia Sophia (1823–95), and his elder brother was Henry George Scawen Blunt (1821–99), m., 1846, Charlotte, b. Daniell (1818–86).

Braid, Betty, b. Pringle (1795–1875), Grace Welsh’s Haddington servant, close
to JWC (see 21:82JWC to SS, [29 Oct. 1846], and 24:221JWC to TC, 25 [5 Sept. 1849]); b. in Prestonkirk, E. Lothian; m. Alexander (1792–1874), stonemason and shopkeeper. They had one surviving son, George Pringle (1827–65), who suffered ill health. Three other sons d. in infancy: Alexander (b. 1826), James (b. 1829), and James (b. 1831). Previously living at 15 Adam St. (see 17:127TC to JWC, 12 Sept. 1843), they moved in 1858 to Upper Stenhouse, Liberton, S Edinburgh.

Bromley, Caroline Davenport (1820–91), da. of Rev. Walter Davenport Bromley (1787–1862) of Wootton Hall, Staffordshire, and his first wife, m., 1818, Caroline Barbara, b. Gooch (1791–1827). A friend of Lady Louisa Ashburton, she became a close friend of JWC. The Carlyles called her “Lark,” “Die Lerche,” or “Flight of Skylarks.” Her London home was at 32 Grosvenor St. Her brother was William Davenport Bromley (1821–84).

Browning, Robert (1812–89; ODNB), poet, TC’s friend since the mid-1830s (see 30:74TC to JAC, 26 Sept. 1855, and 133TC to RB, 4 Dec. 1855). His wife, m. 1846, was Elizabeth Barrett, b. Moulton Barrett (1806–61), poet. Robert Wiedeman Barrett (“Pen”) (1849–1912) was their only child.
Buccleuch, duke of; see Scott.

Bullock, John (1815–90), from King’s Lynn, Norfolk, letter carrier, who had succeeded John Piper as the Carlyles’ postman; see 33:64TC to JWC, 1 Sept. 1857. His son was John Joseph Bullock (b. 1846), listed in the 1861 census as an errand boy and in the 1871 census as a letter sorter.

Butler, Charles (1802–97; see 28:314TC to JCA, 18 Nov. 1853), U.S. lawyer, financier, land speculator, entrepreneur, and philanthropist; welcome in Britain for his part in handling the threat by some U.S. states in the 1840s to default on their bonds; met TC Nov. 1853 and looked after his Illinois bonds and other American investments. He m., 1825, Eliza, b. Ogden (1803–78); they had five children: Abraham Ogden Butler (1832–56), two other sons who d. in infancy, and two das., Emily (b. 1840) and Anna (d. 1877).

Carlyle, Alexander (Alick) (1797–1876), TC’s brother; emigrated with his family to Canada, 1843; settled at the Bield, 4½ mi. (7 km.) W of Brantford, Ontario. He m., 1830, Janet, b. Clow (1809–91), they had six surviving sons: Thomas (1833–1921), John (1839–1924), Alexander (see below), James (1846–1924), William (1849–1935), and Robert (1851–1932); and three surviving das.: Jane Welsh (1831–84), who m., 1852, Robert Sims; Janet (1836–1916); and Margaret (1847–1935); see 1:166TC to AC, 23 Feb 1819. An unidentified son (1832–33), Margaret (1835–36), James (b. 1840), and Euphemia (1853–54) all d. in infancy; see 32:4TC to AC, 3 Oct. 1856.

Carlyle, Alexander (1843–1931; see 16:153TC to AC, 4 May 1843), Alexander and Janet’s son; m., 1879, his cousin Mary Aitken; lived with TC from 1879 and ed. various collections of the Carlyles’ letters and other writings of TC.

Carlyle, James (Jamie) (1805–90), TC’s brother, farmer at Scotsbrig; m., 1834,
Isabella, b. Calvert (ca. 1813–1859). Their children were James (Jr., the younger) (1835–71), who had been working in Glasgow as a clerk but was now back home; m., 1866, his cousin Catherine Austin; John (1836–1901); Thomas (1839–41); and Janet (Jessie or Jenny) (1843–74).

Carlyle, John (ca. 1792–1872), TC’s half-brother; emigrated to the U.S. in 1837, then moved to Canada (see 12:228TC to AC, 15 Aug. 1840); he lived on a small farm at Mount Pleasant, nr. Brantford, Ontario. He m., 1817, Margaret (Peggy), b. Benn (1798–1867), they had six children: Janet (1818–89), m., 1844, John Randall Ellis (1811–1911), carpenter; Mary (1821–50); John (1825–26); John (1827–97), m. Mary Catherine, b. Smith; James (1830–1900) qualified as a doctor but worked for most of his life as a teacher; and William (1833–1911), a teacher and later a school inspector, m., 1860, Emily b. Youmans (1835–1912); their da. Florence Emily Carlyle (24 Sept. 1864–1923), became a prominent Canadian artist. William visited TC in London, Aug. 1864.

Carlyle, John Aitken (Jack, “The Doctor”) (1801–79; ODNB), TC’s brother, physician, and translator. He m., 1852, Phoebe Elizabeth Hough Watt, b. Fowler (1810–54), wealthy widow of Fitzjames Watt (1809–48), from Leek in Staffordshire, with four sons; she d. in childbirth; the child was stillborn. John A. Carlyle assumed responsibility for his stepsons: Thomas Fowler (1838–62), went to sea in 1856 (see 32:29TC to IC, 12 Nov. 1856), went to Australia, July 1861, and d. on his return; Henry (b. 1839), at sea from 1854 (see 29:121TC to JCA, 30 June 1854), m., 1863, Jane Wilson, b. Hunter (1837–1908), da. of John A. Carlyle’s friend John Hunter (1801–69; see 8:161JWC to SS, [30 June 1835]) and Helen, b. Vary (1804–85); Arthur (b. 1840), at school in Edinburgh from 1856, joined the civil service 1862; and William (b. 1842), at the Royal Military Academy, Woolwich, from 1858.
Carlyle, Margaret Aitken (1771–1853), TC’s mother; she had lived with James and Isabella Carlyle at Scotsbrig. TC’s father was James Carlyle (1758–1832); they m. 1795.
Chapman, Edward (1804–80; ODNB), senior partner in Chapman & Hall, TC’s publisher since 1842 (see 14:37TC to JF, [5 Feb. 1841]); he m., 1841, Mary, b. Whiting (b. ca. 1820).
Chapman, Frederic (1823–95; ODNB), Edward Chapman’s cousin and junior partner in Chapman & Hall; he m., 1861, Clara, b. Woodin (d. 1866); they had one son, Frederic.

Chorley, John Rutter (1806–67; ODNB; see 19:135JWC to TC, [7 Aug. 1845]), poet and scholar of Spanish literature, reviewer for the Athenaeum; highly regarded by TC. He helped supervise the building of the soundproof room in the attic of 5 Cheyne Row in 1853 (see 28:245TC to JCA, 11 Aug. 1853, and Carlyle, Reminiscences 154) and assisted in proofreading Frederick (see 34:146TC to HL, 18 Aug 1858).

Chrystal, Jeannie, b. Welsh (Babbie) (1818–95), JWC’s cousin; m., 1853,
Andrew Chrystal (ca. 1811–83; see 24:186TC to JWC, 10 Aug. 1849), wine merchant with Ronald & Co., 27 St. Vincent’s Pl., Glasgow; they lived at 14 Queen’s Cres., Glasgow, with their da., Mary (1857–1937). Jeannie’s earlier correspondence with JWC ended after her marriage.

Conway, Moncure Daniel (1832–1907; ODNB), American Unitarian minister, abolitionist, and author; m., 1858, Ellen, b. Dana (d. 1897); they had two sons, Eustace (b. 1858) and Emerson (1861–4 Aug. 1864). Friend of Emerson, who introduced him to TC. He came to Britain 1863; was pastor at South Place Chapel, 11 South Pl., Finsbury, London, 1864–84; they lived at 16 Lansdowne Ter. until Aug. 1864.
Cook, Mrs. (b. ca. 1785), Chelsea laundry woman; by 1865 she was in a workhouse; see 39:82JWC to EFO, [5 March 1863], and Carlyle, Reminiscences 186.

Craik, George Lillie (1798–1866; ODNB; see 8:207JWC to SS, [20 Sept. 1835]), author, prof. of English lit. and history, Queen’s Coll., Belfast, 1849–66; friend of the Carlyles since 1835; m., 1826, Jeannette, b. Dempster (d. 1856; see 10:159JWC to TC, [30 Aug. 1838]). They had one son, George Lillie (b. ca. 1825), and three das.: Mary (1827–1909), Isabella (1829–42; see 15:221JWC to JW, [8 Dec. 1842]), and Georgiana (1831–95), novelist. Mary came to nurse JWC in St. Leonards early May until mid-July.

Dickens, Charles (1812–70; ODNB), novelist; friend of the Carlyles since the early 1840s; m., 1836, Catherine Thomson, b. Hogarth (1816–79); separated from her since 1858; see 33:233TC to RWE, 2 June 1858.

Dilberoglue, Stauros (1818–78), Greek businessman, philanthropist, and art collector. His naturalization papers (1861) named Smyrna, Turkey, as his birthplace; however, the 1871 census gave the island Chios (then in Turkey, now Khios, Greece) as his birthplace. TC wrote “Greek; of Chios” under Dilberoglue’s photograph; see 197. He moved (presumably as a child) with his family to Corfu, where they were naturalized Ionian. Stauros lived in England from the mid-1830s; he was a partner in Cavafy & Co., which traded from 31 Threadneedle St., London. He m., 1859, Sarah Anderton, b. Coxon (ca. 1827–69; see 28:21–22JWC to KS, [28 Jan. 1853]), actress (Anderton was her stage name). They lived at 13 Barnsbury Park, Islington. His sister, Calliope (b. 1835), m., 1858, John George Honiere (b. 1814), general merchant.

Dods, William (1795–1873, see 33:79JWC to GEJ, [11 Sept. 1857]), Haddington bank agent; childhood admirer of JWC. He m., first, Harriet, b. Shirreff (ca. 1804–53), with whom he had seven sons and two das.; see 37:26537:biographical notes. He m., second, 1854, Jane, b. Wilkie (ca. 1809–85). His photograph, 39:63JWC to MR, [17 Feb. 1863], is incorrectly captioned. His brother was Thomas Dods (1800–1878; see 33:88JWC to WDO, [19 Sept. 1857]).

Downes, John (1827–15 May 1864), writer; originally intending to be a minister in the Free Church of Scotland, he abandoned theology for philosophy, writing later, “Carlyle tore my nature to pieces; Thackeray built it up again” (William Knight, Some Nineteenth Century Scotsmen
[Edinburgh, 1903] 118). He m., 1859, Elizabeth, b. McNeil (b. ca. 1829) and they had two das., Annabelle (b. 1860) and Margaret (b. 1863).

Emerson, Ralph Waldo (1803–82; see 6:425TC to JAC, 27 Aug. 1833), philosopher, essayist, poet, and transcendentalist. He first met TC in Aug. 1833; in spite of their differences they had close ties; he introduced many Americans to TC and played a leading part in arranging the publication of TC’s works in the U.S.

Erskine, Thomas (1788–1870; ODNB; see 10:18TC to JAC, 1 Feb. 1838), theologian and retired advocate, living at Linlathen, Dundee; known to the Carlyles since the mid-1830s. He had two widowed sisters who lived with him: Christian (1789–1866), who m., 1817, Charles Stirling; and David (1791–1867), who m., 1821, Capt. James Paterson.
Farie, Robert (1813–82; see 21:96TC to JAC, 20 Nov. 1846), translator of German works, old friend of the Carlyles.

Forster, John (“Fuz”) (1812–76; ODNB; see 6:118TC to GE, 15 Feb. 1832, and 11:7TC to JF, 17 Jan. 1839), historian, journalist, and biographer; ed. of the Examiner 1847–55; sec. to the Lunacy Commission 1855–61, and a commissioner from Feb. 1861; friend of the Carlyles since the late 1830s and TC’s literary adviser. He m., 1856, Eliza Ann, b. Crosbie (ca. 1819–94), widow of the publisher Henry Colburn (ca. 1784–1855; ODNB); they previously lived at 46 Montagu Sq.; from late 1863 they lived at Palace Gate House, Kensington.
Freure, Frederick (b. 1835), Chelsea carpenter, m. Ann (b. ca. 1830).

Froude, James Anthony (1818–94; ODNB), journalist and historian, ed. of Fraser’s Magazine 1860–74; he m., first, 1849, Charlotte Maria, b. Grenfell (1812–60); they had two das., Georgina Margaret (1850–1935) and Rose Mary (b. 1852), and a son, Pascall Grenfell (1854–79). He m., second, 1861, Henrietta Elizabeth Warre (1824–74); they had a son, Ashley Anthony (1863–1949), and a da., May (b. 1867). They lived at 6 Clifton Pl., Hyde Park. Henrietta’s father, John Ashley Warre (1787–1860), had m., as his third wife, Charlotte Froude’s sister Caroline (1809–86).

Greenhow, Rose, b. O’Neale (1817–64), m., 1835, Dr. Robert Greenhow (1800–54), Virginian physician and lawyer. She became a Confederate spy, was imprisoned, and then released and deported, 31 May 1862, to Richmond, Virginia, where she was welcomed as a heroine and appointed as a Confederate emissary by President Jefferson Davis. In 1863–64 she toured France and England and was received by Napoleon III. In London she published My Imprisonment and the First Year of Abolition Rule at Washington (1863), in which she defended slavery.

Hanning, Janet Carlyle (1813–97), TC’s sister; m., 1836, Robert Hanning (1796–1878), who had emigrated to Canada in mysterious disgrace in 1841; she joined him in Hamilton, Ontario, Aug. 1851, with their two das.,
Margaret (b. 1838) and Mary (b. 1840). In Canada they had two more das., Catherine (b. ca. 1852) and Jane.
Helen, Hellen, or Ellen, Cheyne Row servant, hired early March, possibly by Margaret Welsh, dismissed Nov. 1864.

Hiddleston, Margaret (ca. 1800–65), maid to JWC’s mother at Templand; see 14:160TC to JWC, 21 April 1842. Her das. were Margaret (1831–1904), m., 1855, Joseph McCaig (1829–76), cabinet maker, living in Thornhill; and Jessie (1835–1904), recorded in the 1861 census as with the family of Andrew Bennet, Closeburn Manse, Dumfriesshire, but now living in Edinburgh; she became the Carlyles’ maid, 1865–66, then m., 1866, Robert Broadfoot (ca. 1833–90), butler.

Houghton, Richard Monckton Milnes (1809–85; ODNB; see 9:8TC to JAC, 14 July 1836, and 12:9–10TC to RWE, 6 Jan. 1840), 1st baron, author, and politician; lived at 16 Upper Brook St., London, and Fryston Hall, Yorkshire; the Carlyles’ friend since the late 1830s despite political differences; Milnes supported religious and civil liberties and championed progressive causes such as education for the working class and prison reform. He m., 1851, Annabella, b. Hungerford Crewe (1814–74); they had two das. and a son; see 37:27037:biographical notes.
Irving, Edward (1792–1834; ODNB; see 1:92TC to RM, 12 Feb 1817, later vols., and Carlyle, Reminiscences), the Carlyles’ great friend; religious leader and preacher.

Jewsbury, Geraldine Endsor (1812–80; ODNB; see 12:103–4TC to GEJ, 12 April 1840), novelist, reviewer, and misc. writer; a friend of the Carlyles, particularly of JWC, since 1841. She lived at 41 Markham Sq., London. She met Walter Mantell (see below) late 1856 and fell in love with him; he did not reciprocate, but they remained close and exchanged over 500 letters in the course of their friendship.

Larkin, Henry (1820–99), collector or cashier for the Chelsea Steamboat Co.; partner in an engineering business. His Extra Physics and the Mystery of Creation (1878) included an appendix (written in 1858) giving an analysis of Sartor Resartus; also author of Carlyle and the Open Secret of His Life (1886). For TC’s early contacts with him, see 25:322TC to HL, 29 Dec. 1850, and 27:78TC to HL, 29 March 1852. He worked on TC’s indexes and maps from 1856; see 34:57JWC to TC, [19 July 1858]. He m., 1862, Louisa, b. Wagstaff (b. 1837), and they lived at 6 Cheyne Row. They had a son, Alfred Edward (b. 1863), and a da., Nora, b. 22 March 1864, but d. within 12 hours.

Lincoln, Abraham (1809–65), lawyer and politician; 16th president of the U.S. 1861–5. He m., 1842, Mary, b. Todd (1818–82), and they had four sons, only one of whom survived into adulthood. Lincoln was shot by an assassin 14 April 1865 and died the following day.
Mackenzie; see Stewart-Mackenzie.

Mantell, Walter Baldock Durant (1820–95), politician and naturalist; b. in
England, he settled in New Zealand in 1840. He was politically active in trying to obtain rights for the Maori; see 33:276–7733:biographical notes and 37:27037:biographical notes. See also Jewsbury.

Mary (b. ca. 1838), servant at Cheyne Row Dec. 1862–Nov. 1864. She gave birth to an illegitimate child in the small room next to the dining room in 5 Cheyne Row, 29 July; the Carlyles were unaware of this until Nov. 1864 (see JWC to MR, [12 Nov.], Vol. 41).

Mazzini, Giuseppe (1805–72; see 11:225TC to JSM, 6 Dec. 1839, and 28:xiii—xiv28:introduction), Italian revolutionary; friend of the Carlyles since the late 1830s. He was usually based in London, but continued to encourage active Italian resistance to Austrian domination. His photograph, 39:64, is incorrectly captioned.

Meredith, George (1828–1909; ODNB), novelist and poet; acquainted with the Carlyles for two years. His first wife, Mary Ellen, b. Nicolls (1821–61) had an affair with the painter Henry Wallis (1830–96) in 1857. He m. his second wife, Marie Vuillamy (1840–85), 20 Sept. 1864.
Milnes, Richard Monckton; see Houghton.

Neuberg, Joseph (1806–67; see 11:231TC to JN, 21 Dec. 1839), a Jewish German businessman who had worked in Nottingham; naturalized British 1845, and retired from business 1849–56; m., 1841, Marian (d. 1848; see 23:77JWC to JN, 22 July 1848). He was introduced to TC, whom he had long admired, by Emerson, 1848; helped TC as an unpaid sec., translated his work, and twice accompanied him on visits to Germany (1852 and 1858). From 1856–63 Neuberg lived at Oakley Villas, 25 (renumbered 140) Adelaide Rd., with his widowed sister, Rosetta (or Rosette) (ca. 1816–98)—who had m., ca. 1851, Adolph Frankau (1820–56; see 32:32TC to JAC, 19 Nov. 1856)—and her two children, Frederick Joseph (b. 1854) and Gertrude Rosette Adolphine (b. ca. 1856). In 1863 he moved to Roslyn Park, Hampstead. After Frankau’s death, Neuberg managed Frankau’s company, which imported meerschaum pipes and fancy goods, at 25 Clements Lane, Lombard St., London.

Otthenin, Jean, b. Johnston (1807–70 according to French genealogy website, but she must have been born earlier as TC had left the school in Ecclefechan by 1806), known to TC as a child; her mother, Margaret Carlyle (d. 1830), fled with her from a brutal husband, James Johnston (d. 1809), to France. Jean m., 1832, Nicolas-Julien Otthenin (1785–1845), a French cavalry officer, who d. in a carriage accident; see 20:18–19TC to JWC, 8 Oct. 1845. Now living at 33 Northumberland St., Edinburgh, with her das. Margaret (the elder), who was ill, and Irma (1838–97).

Palmerston, Henry John Temple (1784–1865; ODNB), 3d Viscount Palmerston, politician; m., 1839, Emily, b. Lamb (1787–1869), widow of 5th Earl Cowper (1778–1837). Whig prime minister 1855–57 and 1859–65.
Paterson; see Erskine.

Plattnauer, Richard Eduard (b. 1814), son of Nathan Plattnauer and Jeanette Breit; originally named Salomon, he was christened, age 24, at Sankt Nikolai, Brandenburg, Prussia, 17 Nov. 1838; political refugee from Prussia; see 22:10JWC to HW, [5 July 1847]. Friend of the Carlyles since the mid-1840s; see 18:194JWC to JW, [29 Aug. 1844]; he suffered periods of insanity.

Pollock, William Frederick (1815–88; ODNB), lawyer and author, m., 1844, Juliet, b. Creed (1818–99). His father was Sir Jonathan Frederick Pollock (1783–1870; ODNB), 1st baronet, judge, lord chief baron of the exchequer 1844–66; m., first, 1813, Frances, b. Rivers (ca. 1787–1827); m., second, 1834, Sarah Anne, b. Langslow (1815–95); see 29:33TC to JAC, 17 Feb. 1854.

Quain, Richard (1816–98; ODNB), physician, specializing in heart diseases, and with many wealthy and influential patients; he lived at 67 Harley St. He m., 1854, Isabella Agnes, b. Wray (1828–91); they had four das. He treated the Ashburtons and JWC.

Robson, Charles (b. 1805), TC’s printer since 1837, of Robson, Levey & Franklyn, printers, 23 Gt. New St., Fetter Lane, which went bankrupt early 1864. In partnership with one or both sons John (b. ca. 1837) and Christopher (b. 1843), he then formed Robson & Son, Great Northern Printing Works, St. Pancras Rd.
Royston, William Haylett (1822–71), m. 1847, Isabella, b. Harris; they had a son, William Haylett (b. 1863), and a da. (b. 31 Aug. 1864); they lived at 1 Cheyne Row.

Ruskin, John (1819–1900; ODNB), author, artist, and social reformer; m., 1848, Euphemia Chalmers, b. Gray (1828–97); marriage annulled 1854 (she then m., 1855, John Everett Millais [1829–96; ODNB], artist). Ruskin lived in the family home at 163 Denmark Hill, S London, with his father, John James Ruskin (1785–3 March 1864), wine merchant, and his mother, Margaret, b. Cock (1781–1871). He was J. M. W. Turner’s foremost admirer and was strongly influenced by TC.

Russell, Elizabeth Ann, b. Rawdon (1793–1874), widow of Lord George William Russell (1790–1846; ODNB), soldier and diplomat; she had two sons, Arthur John Edward (1825–92), M.P. for Tavistock 1857–85, with whom she lived at 2 Audley Sq., and Odo Leopold William (1829–84; ODNB), diplomat. She was always known as Lady William Russell; see Carlyle, Reminiscences 187.

Russell, Mary, b. Dobbie (1802–75; see 6:145TC to AC, [7 April 1832]), close friend of JWC and her mother. She m., 1829, Dr. James Russell (ca. 1796–1878); they had moved to Holmhill, nr. Thornhill, by Oct. 1859. Her father was Rev. Edward Dobbie (1773–1857; see 14:65TC to JWC, 9 March 1842).

Scott, Walter Francis Montagu-Douglas- (1806–84; ODNB), 5th duke of Buccleuch and 7th duke of Queensberry, magnate and politician; m., 1829,
Charlotte Anne, b. Thynne (1811–95; ODNB); they had three das. and four sons. They lived in Drumlanrig Castle, Dumfriesshire.
Silvester, John (b. ca. 1799), livery stable owner, Upper Church St., Chelsea. His wife was Phoebe (ca. 1800–1865); they had a son John (b. ca. 1829) and a grandson William (b. ca. 1857).

Simmonds, Isabella Emily, b. Barnes (b. 1837, d. by 1899), became close to JWC from their first meetings in 1859; see also 35:188JWC to JGCO, [2 Sept. 1859]. She m., 1862, John Simmonds (b. 1829, still alive in 1899), barrister; they lived at 82a Oakley St., Chelsea. Their first child was Ethel Jane (1863–65).

Sinclair, Sir George (1790–1868; ODNB; see 24:18–19TC to SGS, 10 April 1849), politician; living in Thurso Castle, Caithness. He m., 1816, Lady Catherine Camilla, b. Manners (1792–1863). They had a son and three das. (see 36:28636:biographical notes); the youngest, Olivia Sophia (1823–94), became a travel writer. Sir George’s sister Catherine (ca. 1801–64) was also an author. His father was Sir John Sinclair of Ulbster (1754–1835; ODNB), politician and agricultural improver.

Southam, Charlotte, b. Watson (1842–1905), the Carlyles’ maid until June 1861; see 37:27337:biographical notes. Now housemaid at the Kent home of George Charles Pratt (1799–1866), 2d marquis of Camden; see 39:103JWC to CSO, 29 March 1863. She continued to visit and correspond with both Carlyles. She m., 1866, Adolphus James Mills (b. 1842), a carpenter; they had five sons: Adolphus Berby (b. 1869), Thomas (b. 1871), Alfred George (b. 1875), Ernest (b. 1876), and Edward (b. 1880). Orphaned in childhood, she had been adopted by her uncle and aunt, Thomas (1806–3 Sept. 1864), a waterman, and Elizabeth (b. ca. 1805) Southam, whose surname she took; Elizabeth and Thomas are often referred to as Charlotte’s mother and father; they lived in Lawrence St., near Cheyne Row.

Stanley, Henrietta Maria, b. Dillon (1807–95; ODNB), m., 1826, Edward John (1802–69; ODNB; see 12:59TC to JAC, 27 Feb. 1840), Whig politician, who succeeded as 2d Baron Stanley of Alderley, 1850; living at Alderley Park, Cheshire; their London home was at 40 Dover St. Both were friends of the Carlyles. Lord Stanley was nicknamed Lord Ben after Sir Benjamin Backbite, a character in Richard Brinsley Sheridan’s School for Scandal (ca. 1780) (see 35:26435:biographical notes). They had nine surviving children: Henry Edward John (1827–1903; ODNB); Alice Margaret (1828–1910), m., 1853, Augustus Henry Lane Fox-Pitt-Rivers; Henrietta Blanche (see Airlie); Maude Alethea (1833–1915; ODNB); John (“Johny”) Constantine (1837–78); Edward Lyulph (1839–1925; ODNB); Katherine (Kate) Louisa (1842–74; ODNB), m., 8 Nov. 1864, John Russell (1842–76: ODNB), Viscount Amberley, politician and writer; son of John Russell (1792–1878; ODNB), 1st Earl Russell, and Frances Anna Maria, b. Kynynmound (1815–98); Algernon Charles (1843–1928); and Rosalind Francis (1845–1921: ODNB), m., 4 Oct. 1864, George James Howard (1843–1911; ODNB),
artist and politician, only son of the Hon. Charles Wentworth George Howard (1814–74) and Mary Priscilla Harriet, b. Parke (1822–43).

Sterling, Sir Anthony Coningham (1805–71; ODNB; see 9:103TC to JAC, 2 Dec. 1836, and later vols.), soldier; m., 1829, Charlotte, b. Baird (d. 1863), who suffered attacks of insanity and was jealous of JWC (see 18:266–67JWC to HW, [12 Nov. 1844], and 19:9JWC to HW, [9 Jan. 1845]); they lived at 3 South Pl., Knightsbridge. His brother John (1806–44; ODNB), writer, had been a particular friend of TC; see CL vols. 8–18 and Carlyle’s Life of Sterling (1851); for John Sterling’s children, including Julia Maria Sterling (1836–1910), see 35:264–6535:biographical notes.
Stewart-Mackenzie, Maria Louisa, b. Marriott (b. ca. 1826), m., 1850, George Augustus Stewart-Mackenzie (1824–52), brother of Lady Louisa Ashburton; always referred to as “Mrs. George.”
Stirling; see Erskine.
Sylvester; see Silvester.

Thackeray, William Makepeace (1811–63; ODNB; see 9:271JWC to TC, [3 Aug. 1837], 288, and later vols.), novelist; friend of the Carlyles since the 1830s. He m., 1836, Isabella, b. Shawe (1816–93), who was mentally ill from 1840. His das. were Anne Isabella (1837–1919; ODNB) and Harriet Marian (1840–75; ODNB); they lived at 36 Onslow Sq., London.

Trevelyan, Sir Walter Calverley (1797–1879; ODNB), naturalist; m., 1835, Lady Paulina, b. Jermyn (1816–66; ODNB), art patron; they lived at Wallington Hall in Northumberland. Lady Trevelyan was a great friend of Lady Louisa Ashburton.
Trollope, Anthony (1815–82; ODNB), novelist and post office surveyor; see 37:183TC to JAC, 9 [8] July 1861.

Twisleton, Hon. Edward Turner Boyd (1809–74; ODNB), close and respected friend of the Carlyles (see 28:184TC to JWC, 5 July 1853); he m., 1852, Ellen, b. Dwight (1828–62), from Boston, Mass., JWC’s close friend and confidante; she wrote, 1855, an account of JWC’s early married life at Craigenputtoch (see 30:267–74Ellen Twisleton’s Account of Craigenputtoch). He lived at 3 Rutland Gate.

Venables, George Stovin (1810–88; ODNB), lawyer and journalist; contributor to the Saturday Review from its founding, 1855, and to the Times, 1857–88; friend of Tennyson and of Thackeray, who claimed he was the model for Warrington in Pendennis (1848–50).

Venturi, Emilie (ca. 1819–93; ODNB), da. of William Henry Ashurst (ca. 1791–1855; ODNB; portrait painter), supporter of Italian independence and campaigner for women’s rights; unhappily married to Sydney Hawkes, whom she divorced 1861; see 30:215JWC’s Journal, 21 Oct. 1855, and 23527 March 1856. She m., 1861, Carlo Venturi (ca. 1830–66). A strong supporter of Mazzini and the Young Italy movement, she published various English editions of his writings and Joseph Mazzini: A Memoir (1875).

Ward, Charles Augustus (1828–1914), vintner, author, antiquarian, and book
collector; see 29:123–4TC to CAW, 6 July 1854. He lived at 1 Chapel St., Mayfair. His mother was Eliza, b. Wade (1796–25 Aug. 1864) and his father Charles Ward (b. ca. 1791). He often wrote under the pseudonym Feltham Burghley; see 36:262–64TC to CAW, 24 Sept. 1860.

Welsh, Alexander (Alick) (b. 1816), son of JWC’s maternal uncle John; m., ca. 1849, Sophy, b. Martin (b. ca. 1824). Their children were John (Jackie) (ca. 1853–64), Isabella Helen (b. 1856; see 31:201JWC to TC, [29 Aug. 1856]), Margaret (b. 1858), and Jean (b. 1860).

Welsh, Ann (1799–1877), Elizabeth (1792–1877), and Grace (1801–67), JWC’s paternal aunts (see 14:67TC to JWC, 11 March 1842, and 16:219JWC to JW, [26 June 1843]), living at Craigen Villa, Morningside, Edinburgh.
Welsh, Grace, b. Welsh (1782–1842), JWC’s mother; m., 1800, John Welsh (1776–1819; see 1:202–3JBW to EWE, 5 Oct 1819), JWC’s father, doctor in Haddington.
Welsh, Jeannie (ca. 1798–1828), JWC’s maternal aunt; for her death, see 4:358TC to JAC, 16 April 1828, and Carlyle, Reminiscences 127–29.

Welsh, John (d. 1853; see 28:286–87TC to HW, [12 Oct. 1853]), JWC’s maternal uncle, retired brass and copper founder, who had lived at 20 Maryland St., Liverpool; m., 1808, Mary, b. Colliver (d. 1838; see 10:200TC to AC, 15 Oct. 1838); their children were Helen (ca. 1813–53), Walter, Alexander, Jeannie (see Chrystal), John (1820–60), Margaret, and Mary.

Welsh, John Amelia (“Jackie”) (ca. 1812–64), illegitimate da. of JWC’s paternal uncle William (1790–1819; see 14:90TC to JWC, 25 March 1842) and Elizabeth Scott (b. 1782). Jackie lived in Haddington with her mother and her aunt Jane Scott (1787–1863).

Welsh, Margaret, b. Kissock (1803–88; see 13:44JWC to MW, [Feb. 1841], and 20:128JWC to MW, [Feb.–March 1846]), widow of JWC’s paternal uncle George (1793–1835), living at 19 St. Johns Grove, Richmond, nr. London. Her son was John Welsh (1824–59; ODNB; see 15:37JWC to MW, [20 Aug. 1842]), F.R.S., meteorologist, whom JWC described as “worth all my cousins tied up in one bundle!” (35:58).
Welsh, Margaret (Maggie) (b. 1821), da. of JWC’s maternal uncle John; lived in Auchtertool with her brother Walter; came to nurse JWC, Dec. 1863 until early May 1864.
Welsh, Mary (1823–79), da. of JWC’s maternal uncle John; lived in Auchtertool with her brother Walter.

Welsh, Rev. Walter (1815–79; see 16:12JWC to JW, [8 Jan. 1843]), son of JWC’s maternal uncle John; minister at Auchtertool, Fife, since 1842. Two of his sisters, Margaret (Maggie) and Mary, lived with him.

Willis, Robert (1799–1878; ODNB), physician, writer, and translator; see 20:224TC to JWC, [8 July 1846]. He lived at Rose Cottage, Church Rd., Barnes, Surrey, and four of his das. are listed as living there in the 1861 census: Eleanor (b. ca. 1832), Anna (b. ca. 1833), Frances (b. ca. 1838) and Mary (b. ca. 1841). His wife was Eleanor (1804–63).

Wilson, Thomas (b. 1811; see 26:30426:biographical notes and 34:28434:biographical notes), moved to Weimar about 1854 and conducted schools there for the Archduke of Saxe-Gotha-Eisenach; his Catholicity Spiritual and Intellectual (1850) was dedicated to TC. He and his German wife, m. 1861, (not further identified) made frequent visits to London; in 1861 they were living in Paragon, Blackheath (see 37:170TC to JAC, 2 June 1861); more recently they were at 17 Addison Terrace (probably lodging with Miss Brown). They returned to Weimar spring 1864.

Woolner, Thomas (1825–92; ODNB; see 26:37TC to TWO, [21 Feb. 1851], and 29:176–77TC to LA, 20 Oct. 1854), sculptor and poet; he lived at 29 Welbeck St., London. He m., 6 September 1864, Alice Gertrude, b. Waugh (b. 1845), da. of George and Mary Waugh.
